The gameplay has become increasingly more of an arcade style and the series is in danger of losing all resemblance of a true simulation sports experience. The online team play, which features 12 users playing 6 vs 6 at locked positions for their respective team, has turned into a tilted affair that very much favors offensive players, or more specifically, forwards. This leaves true defenseman and goalies that have long been dedicated to their craft wondering why they bother to play this game. Perhaps EA should just through in the towel and make this a strictly 3 vs 3 game. They could also re-invent the big head feature while their at it. Great job ruining the online team game by cowing to the complaints of non-skilled forwards who cry incessantly about how difficult it is to score. This game needs new design leadership before the next revision is released.

I bought the Logitech Harmony 950 remote. It has been everything I expected. Easy touchscreen operation and setup. I am very pleased with its operation. It works with all of my components in my TV room including Samsung TV, Directv PVR, 7.1 Pioneer Stereo system, Samsung DVD player, Lutron lights and even motorized curtains. I am replacing another Logitech remote which I've had for several years. I would highly recommend this remote for all.

Mystery Dungeon Red/Blue Rescue Team were my favorite games to play when I was younger (besides XD: Gale of Darkness). I've never laughed and cried at a Pokmon game before MD came out in '06. im not going to bullshxt you here. this game is gorgeous. and im not just saying that because i played it in the seventh grade with my friend sara. im saying this because it is the truth. the art style has been updated and the classic dungeon crawler with a pokmon tint is HERE and it is here to stay. well, at least until animal crossing comes out. i mean, come on, so they not have a release schedule buffer? animal crossing is right around the corner guys, i cant finish this before it comes out. and you already know: when animal crossing comes out, everything else goes to the cosmos. im talking divine separation from my ability to concentrate on anything else that isnt animal crossing. alright bottom line this game is good. its pretty. old school dungeon crawling rpg game for the switch. it works for kids. it works for me. my dog ill eventually grow up and play this game too. if the regular pokmon games were too hard for you then this will bemuse you as well, just in a different way. 5/5 stars. would take a test to become a mudkip only to get totodile like an idiot and then retake the test to get my desired outcome again.

It's not often a game gets released these days that doesn't in at least some way copy previous formulas, but the Gravity Rush series absolutely qualifies as an original. The original was an underappreciated classic on the PS Vita (available on PS4, but difficult to find and lacking the touch screen features of the Vita), and the sequel is just as fun a trip. The mechanics of the game revolve around your character being able to alter the direction of gravity in a fully 3-D environment. The effects are temporary, but can be improved upon as you level up. This has effects in both platforming and combat as you collect power-ups and fight creatures alike. I will warn those that suffer from motion sickness that this game can be VERY disorienting, and I've had to limit myself to brief spurts of it as a result. Still, absolutely give it a shot; I think you'll find it as unique a game as there is available today.
Really rich story and gameplay. One of my favorite games on the PS4 so far after bloodborne.

Tekken 7 truly is a hallmark, a fighting game crafted with obvious affection. It strikes a fine balance between accessibility to series newcomers and retaining much of its technical traditions. The soundtrack is an electronic treat, and while the story can at times seem a bit cliche, the fact that it never takes itself too seriously lets it bring in a tremendous amount of flexible character customization. Its dedication to the details helps push it into the position of one of my favorite fighting games.

There seems to be TONS of content here, and the characters are very very very diverse, but at the moment I'm all but betrothed to 'Dragon Ball Fighterz', and in comparison this is lacking a little bit of 'umph', and it lacks the kind of fluidic cinema-like action that the DOA series -- despite it's ridiculousness and exploitativeness -- actually has a really great handle on. Tekken has always felt 'slower' and seems like it's more technical, but it also has wacky characters like a half-cheetah and a panda bear and a samurai-ninja robot. There's tons and tons of cosmetic add-ons and so far they all seem like they're actually earnable -- unlike the DOA moneypit or the Street Fighter faux variety -- but again, that stuff's just all about more kookiness. ... and I don't really get why those things are seen as like a revenue stream. This takes that microtransaction approach, but without the microtransaction option of buying your way out of earning all the in-game currency needed to get all the items. It's kinda neat, but it's also this thing that I don't really understand in general. As a very very casual game-player, I get the rewarding nature of unlocking things, but it also means that there's a required investment. It means that by buying the thing, you don't get the whole thing. If I wanna hang out with friends and dress up a pandabear like a super soldier and fight robot ninja in a wedding gown ... I'd have to pre-invest days or weeks of effort, just to have a silly and memorable game night experience. If you buy legos, you don't have to build an airplane to unlock the ability to make a spaceship ... so I just don't get it. Buying more characters and getting more customizations with those more characters, that makes sense to me, that's like buying more lego sets, that's like buying new boardgames. But buying hats and getting no new moves or characters or anything ... what are you buying? Playing the game for hours or days is basically spending money. It's effort, it's time that could be spent doing other things. I dunno, I feel like you'd wanna make something fun, put everything into it, unlocked, and if you want to make achievements or goals or fancy titles or make it so that complicated moves or combos or special attacks get unlocked, you're trading effort and skill for earned skills, it's an actual progression. If this had everything it has, all unlocked, this would be so fun and wacky and it'd be great for a game night. It'd be fun and memorable to try everything out, and it'd make me wanna keep investing in other things the team / company puts out. It's an inherently multiplayer experience, so I just don't get this contrived limitation. Am I really supposed to invest 72 full hours as a panda bear punching ninja demons just so I can dress up as a panda bear in a wedding dress and continue to go back and continue punching the same ninja demons i was just punching for the last 72 hours? How many days or weeks of my life is it going to take to carve out 72 hours? And what about the other 20 characters? Do I get all their stuff too, or do I have to do this for each character? If everyone has the same cowboy hat, how come I have to pay the fake 'game money' to unlock the same cowboy hat for every character? What's up with that???
I've played tekken for over 20 years. Still feels like I'm playing the original. You're not a fighting game fan if you dont play tekken
This game is really fun to play and learn. The only downside, if you want the whole experience. You have to buy all 3 season passes, which is 20 bucks a piece.

I'm not always into fighting games, as there's usually a skill gap between me and all of my friends (Better than some where they don't have fun, and infinitely worse than others were I proceed to have 0 fun). Because of this, I usually look for fighting games that have a plethora of single player content as well as robust online. Tekken 7 delivers on this front between the story mode, extra post story fights, an arcade mode, and a few different online game modes.

I had hoped this would be something like the games of old, but there is so much about it that is very disappointing. There is no clip showing what unfolds when you beat the game (old school like) with a given character. There are only 5 lvls to the versus mode and to play online you have to have PS plus. There really isn't much replay value...and a lot of the game's main characters were left out of the game. Then there is the rip off found in every next-gen game....DLC. I remember the times when you bought a game and you got the whole game not just 50% of it and had to dish out more money for the other half by way of DLCs....Gamers out there....YOU MAKE THIS PRACTICE OK BY SUPPORTING IT (read buying the DLCs). Anyway, I don't have PS plus, having that may add some value to this game, but I wouldn't recommend it and I used to be a hardcore fan since Tekken 2...the graphics have come a long way...the gameplay not so much.

It's easy to pick up a controller & battle. Whenever friends come over the trash talking starts and the battles begin. You will have hours of fun playing this game, it definitely brings back a lot of good memories of memories from playing this game in the past, but the graphics now are amazing. The only downside of this game is the VR mode. You can play the whole campaign but the graphics playing in VR are terrible, so just stick to the PS4 mode, & you will enjoy this game.

I won't go into detail on Tekken 7 as it is a Tekken game. Like it or hate it is subjective. The only thing I want to point out is the new Rage Art system. IT'S JUNK! This new feature has no game-play elements what-so-ever. It's only for show. You can't fake it to trick your opponent, nor can you cancel out of it. You only use it near death in hopes that it can save you, which sounds OK on paper but the execution is anything but. Tekken 7 would be better without it.

Tekken 7 is probably the greatest fighting game of this generation of consoles. It has great characters, The game play is better than ever. The story mode is really good as well. One complaint is that the story mode was too short for my liking, especially since we have waited for such a long time. The customization mode is really good except sometimes i feel like I want more. The online at the moment is beyond terrible as I have been searching for a game for hours and couldn't even get one. But the pros really get the better out of the cons
Good fighting mechanism, nothing great in terms of storyline. A good casual game to play a 1v1 with your friend.

I love that I can have a nice collection of classic Sega genesis games for Nintendo Switch, a console I can play on the go or at home on my TV. However, the emulation on this collection is horrible. There is very bad latency between button presses on the controller and action on screen. We are talking about Sega games here, they are usually fast paced and require accurate timing to when you press the button, but on the Switch it's nearly impossible to play most of these games because of the delayed action of button presses. Press jump in sonic, takes half a second for games to detect you pressed the button. Did many tests, it's not a connection between the Switch and TV being delayed, it happens in handheld mode as well. Test various controllers from Joy-Con, pro controllers both 1st and 3rd party, and Gamecube controllers. The delay is present in all of them. Maybe it is my Switch, tested it in other Switch consoles, nope, not a problem with my Switch, same issue on other systems. Giving a two start because it's a great collection of amazing games, otherwise I would 1 start it. Also Best Buy please credit my 25 points for this review. I never receive points, I've written 10+ reviews over the past year, still yet to see my reward point balance change once from writing these.

This is the third Genesis compilation in as many console generations, so it's a real shame to see extras and controller guides that were included in previous versions removed and replaced with an unnecessary interactive menu screen. Old men like me remember when Phantasy Star II was packaged with a comprehensive hint book, so omitting any kind of game or controller guide seems simply lazy. Good luck divining the technique system in PSIII without online help! Thankfully, button functions are made clear in the options menu for most games, and the better games in this collection don't require consulting a manual. The deletion of unlockables, like original arcade games, is just plain baffling. The previous edition contained an unlockables Space Harrier arcade game, which is far, far superior to the Genesis Space Harrier II. Given that Sega supposedly now owns the rights to the Technosoft developed games, the exclusion of Herzog Zwei and any of the Thunderforce titles is another disappointment. But, all faults aside, you definitely get $30 worth of Sega classics on this collection, so it's definitely a must-buy for Switch owners. Just let future anthology developers know that Noone wants to ever see the Genesis versions of Galaxy Force II or Super Thunder Blade again.

Before you scroll past this ignoring it because the title sounded absurd to you since there are many, very good games on here like Sonic, Gunstar Heroes and so on, let me start out by saying as of version 1.0.2 there's a sizeable controller lag, joycons attached or not, pro controller, it doesn't matter. There's a good half second delay from press to action. It felt less noticeable in Shinobi 3 but it was very harsh in Sonic 2. Just to drive this in, I'm not nitpicking this isn't the controller delay you might see someone complain about from using a wireless controller, the lag is genuinely a 1/2 second from press to action. Making the RPGs the only viable games to play here. Because it's not gonna help in the platformers or the Columns. I have the PC version as well and I don't recall anything like this. So much for getting these games on the go right? :\ Arg It's annoying to have to write this review because, this should be such an easy thing. There's been so many ports of these games over the years from the PS2, PSP, Wii, PS3/XB360 etc but the Switch version at the very least? The lag ruins it. The collection has been out a while too and I'm not sure this is getting fixed. Other negatives are, the emulation isn't 100% if you're a snob for that kinda thing. Some sounds are just off sounding. Hitting a sign post in Sonic 1/2 is weird sounding, as is the 1up in Shinobi 3. It's missing Sonic 3 & Knuckles as well, a very, very notable omission given how it's in many other ports. As for the games, I mean there's a lot of great games here. Sonic 1 & 2 are great, as are the Streets of Rage titles (even lets you play the japanese version of 3!), Phantasy Star 4, Shining Force 2 and so on. Just agh, the controller lag seriously ruins this port. As I said it's been out a while so I don't think they're gonna patch this out.

This is huge collection of games on a small cartridge. I have not played every game on the collection, but most of what i have played has been fun. It is great for those who never had the chance to play any genesis games while growing up.

It was awesome to have the option the bring the nostalgia of Sega to Nintendo switch and introducing retro games to my kids. The intro to the video game represents a total 90s experience which was awesome feature. Graphics are about what you would get from the original Sega but still fun to indulge in the classics.

This collection has every single sega genesis game I love. All 3 Streets of Rage games, Gunstar Heroes, Alien Soldier, Beyond Oasis, Landstalker, Comix Zone, and plenty more. With Streets of Rage 4 being released soon this is your last chance to have a physical copy of every single Streets of Rage game on one platform, plus I cannot stress how lucky it is to have Alien Soldier on a physical format.

There are some excellent classics in this collection that return me to my childhood. I'm surprised by how hard some of these games areI guess I used to be much better at them back when I was a kid growing up with them. I would have given 5 stars if there were some of the other Genesis games I really miss, but this is a really good collection.
If you liked Sega games this is a just have to bring back Retro gaming from days past on Sega consoles. For Sega gamers of past.

Bought this for the Whole family. We all take turns playing this game. It brings back old great memories for all my family. I am so happy I purchased this game and at a great price too thank you Best Buy!!

First off, the selection of games in this collection is excellent. There are always a few titles that get snubbed in compilations like this, but what's here is great and serves as a solid representation of the Genesis library. If that's all you're after, you're set. Buy it and enjoy it. On the other hand, if you're looking for more than just old games running on an emulator, then there's not a lot here for you. Other similar compilations, such as Capcom's Mega Man Legacy Collections or SNK's Anniversary Collection, include extra material or play options that help present their games in a fuller context. These extras are pretty sparse in this release. Some of these games have alternate arcade versions that aren't included here and there aren't any concept art/promo material galleries or anything along those lines. Other than save states, there aren't any extra gameplay options, either. You can tweak the presentation, and there's a rudimentary achievement/challenge system, but that's it. If it sounds like I'm being harsh, it's only because these collections of games can be incredible when a little extra effort is put into them. Don't get me wrong, the selection of games here is huge and awesome and I'd still recommend it to most people. It's just a little disappointing that we're missing out on some of the other content that we've come to expect from these types of re-releases.

$30 for 50 retro games is a steal. They're not all mega hits from the past, but all my Segafavorites from childhood are here and a good number of games I've never play as well. I'm having a blast playing with my kids. All the games I've played play spectacularly and look great. Sega added some nice touches, like the menu presentation looking like your expect a kid's room in the 90s to look, complete with actual slotting in the cartridges to a Sega Genesis to start each game. Theyve also included options to emulate the visuals (and issues) of a CRT TV for those that want to go full on retro. This is one heck of a package and well worth the price of entry.

Guys!!! Remember SEGA's sorry attempt at making a retro classic console? Remember what a big flop and disappointment it was? Well THIS is redemption. All your favorite SEGA titles on the switch!!! Sure its not going to have everybody's favorite game, but the collection is pretty stellar. GET IT!!!!!

Sega Genesis Classics is a great compilation of games but excludes some absolute classics like Ecco the Dolphin. It is really awesome to play these games on the go and I recommend this to any Sega fan

I absolutely love this collection! The only negative is that there are no extras (prior Genesis compilations contained developer interviews, arcade titles, etc.). I haven't noticed any input lag in the games.
I have this on my ps4 also and love the games on it! Now I have it for my switch and on the go!

the best way to experience old school sega genesis on the switch. has some old favs and some i've never heard of. the interface/menu is a throwback to maybe how your room looked when you owned this system. good pickup for fans of retro video games.

This is a great collection if you grew up playing these games; otherwise, there are plenty of other remasters, remakes, and collections that would be better to suited than this. (Sonic Mania, Street Fighter 30th anniversary, Monster Boy/Wonder boy, etc.)

I bought this for a handful of the games on the list because it was cheaper than getting the mini Sega Genesis and it nice being able to play the old school games from when I was a kid, on the go on the Switch. Unfortunately, they picked a lot of crappy games to put onto this list, but at least it has the core ones like Golden Axe, Sonic, Streets of Rage and Toejam and Earl.

I ended up giving this away after I had a hard time getting the games to load and play. I don't think converting the old games to this format worked very well. All the games have a weird frame around the screen that I found distracting, and I learned it did not contain the same version of Sonic 2 that I originally had on Game Gear or on Wii. I learned there were 2 versions of that game made, which was the main reason I bought this, and it didn't have the one I grew up playing. I wish it stated what format it had included, and it would have saved me time and money. I also didn't find the main menu user friendly. I ended up just fighting it far too much and the pixelation hurt my eyes. The Wii and original versions of these games were not all at this resolution. I would give it a break if it was an issue with converting it to a modern system, but Wii is fairly modern, and the games don't look this bad on that platform. I got this as a replacement for the original Wii going offline, but it was not a good replacement.

The Sega Genesis Classics feels right at home on the Nintendo Switch. Pixels and sounds are reproduced faithfully here with added graphic filters, quick save and a rewind feature. Being able to play classics like Shadow Dancer and Streets of Rage on the is awesome. I do however wish that Castlevania Bloodlines and Contra Hard Corp were in this compilation

While I wish there were a few more particular games in this collection it has a great selection especially for the price. I like the options for adding scan lines and borders. Plus it's nice to have a virtual 90s room to remind me what things were like back then down to the time of day being reflected in game. All around a nice package of classic games that has been out for a while, but nice to have on the Switch.
Only ever heard of 2 games on here. The rest were forgotten for a reason
I purchase this for myself. Very disappointed, I thought there would be more of the old school Nintendo games on it.. only Sonic was really on it. I expected Contra and some others.

First off the graphics are phenomenal. Im still in disbelief that we havent moved forward in fighting games though. I thought Soul Caliber was the next step but every other creator goes back to the 2 dimensional fighting. I mean grabbing a piece of the scenery is cool and all but where is the sense of freedom, of movement. I mean this is fighting after all and we still cant side step a punch. Makes no sense to me. We have all the abilities to make games open world but we are still using a street fighter/mortal kombat platform nearly 30yrs later. I know the popular tournaments are in this style but could a developer break the chains and send us into another dimension, into the future? Soul Caliber is so much more balanced, you put these graphics, this legendary background, and these moves into a true 3D arena and watch the minds of every player in the world be blown away. Truth...

I have bought almost every Need for Speed game over the years dating back to High Stakes on PS1 and this entry was good but a little disappointing to be honest. I will start off with the good things. It gorgeous, as expected. Need for Speed games always look really pretty especially since they switched to the Frostbite engine. The world is also quite sizable. It definitely feels like the largest to date. There is also a rather large selection of cars even excluding the DLC cars which is good for those who don't want to spend the extra cash. The derelict cars are a pretty cool idea, although I wish there were more. The engine sounds are pretty good once the cars are upgraded. Pretty realistic and they are recognizable. The idea of cosmetic Super Builds once a car reaches a certain level is a great idea, really making the car look the part. They also have way more custom parts for super cars than previous games which is cool if you want to make it feel like your own. General handling, especially for race and drift cars is excellent and fun with a great sense of speed. Live tuning is also a great idea. NOS is also not as important to gameplay as other NFS games which I think is a good thing but it's still there if you need that little extra bit to get past a competitor on the last stretch. Now for the things I don't care for. The music selection sucks. Even if rap/hip-hop is your genre of choice there are far too few songs. If I had to guess I would say there are only 1.5-2 hours of music that play during regular driving. This gets old quick, especially if you sit down and play for 3-4 hours. That means you heard every song twice in one sitting. In previous games it let you turn individual songs on and off which would have helped. I really wish more games let you feed in your own music either from Spotify or locally. I could play it over the top of the game but it's really hard to balance the sound effects and music that way and that means the music plays during cut scenes. Anyway, moving on from music, the other biggest complaint I have with the game is how much upgrading costs. You can easily dump $100k into a car between every event in order to stay ahead of the curve but you only get about $25k from any given event which means you are always strapped for cash. This gets worse the further you get in the game, the exact opposite of how it should be. By the last story event you should be able to buy whatever car and upgrade you want without having to budget everything. You upgrade with speed cards at shops which are random so some times they don't even carry the part you need. I get the random perk and level from cards you win but shops should have a more consistent stock. Especially if I'm spending that much money. While this game has a pretty good selection of events, race, drag, drift, off road, and runner, some of the events, especially near the end of the game, require you to do stupid things with a car that it wasn't built for. Taking a drag car on a twisty highway or a runner car for long sections of off road. This leads to real frustration when the car refuses to behave because it wasn't built for it. And you can't cheat the system by using another class of car on those select events because you can only enter cars in their respective class events. Being able to live tune is really cool and useful except they don't let you do while you are participating in an event which kind of defeats the purpose. If you tweaked your car incorrectly before the event you have to quit the event, tune it, and then restart the event. Super annoying. The story is okay but the characters are very one dimensional and unnatural even resorting to catch phrases. I also wish there were more cinematic events in the game. The highway car heist that was played at E3 2017 was the best event in the game. I was hoping for a whole game of ridiculous Fast and Furious type heists and action, but alas, it was not so. It's much more normal than that. I think that could have really made it stand out in the genre. NFS The Run is still one of my favorite NFS games just because of how well they were able to blend racing with cinematic events. It really made you feel like a hero. My final thoughts. I know my list of complaints is longer than the pros but that doesn't mean it's bad game by any means. It's very enjoyable to play and besides having the penny-pinch constantly the general experience is pretty positive with the other problems only popping up once in a while (except music, but that can be turned off). This one feels kinda like a less balanced Most Wanted (2012) but a bigger world. So if you like Need for Speed games definitely give this one a go.
excellent game , good graphics, good levels and not get bored

This game had so much potential. A big open world with interesting areas to explore and lots of great cars and events, but the gameplay is clunky and the vehicles feel too heavy. The game is essentially the same concept as games like The Crew and Forza Horizon but isn't on the level of those games at all. I think it's time for EA to return Need for Speed to its roots.

A racing game based around grinding. Recommended level, 380. Your level 260. Towards the end of the game (didn't beat, at beginning of the fifth chapter I'm guessing) your cars have to be near max (399), requiring you to grind the previous races like you would run in circles in a 90s era RPG. Story is very much nonsense. You can't buy one car, and change the specs to fit the 5 different types of racing in this game. You'll have to buy a new car for each type of race - of course - requiring you to grind for money or cards. You don't really buy or get parts, you get what are called cards - that are essentially the parts to upgrade your car. Drag racing sucks. NOS is useless as the car makes noise, the camera pulls back and shakes a bit - but your car goes no where. Did you miss that checkpoint - might as well restart the race. The game gives you some loot boxes called 'shipments'. Some cool one-time use cosmetic items, along with what they're calling tokens and chunks of in game currency. The tokens are used like you would on a slot machine. One roll/pull = 3 tokens. I think I had earned about 100 from the basic shipments, but went through them very quickly trying to complete a set of cards (parts) for my car at the end. You can also trade in the parts you've won for tokens (1:1), but you'll more than likely just sell them for cash. After beating one of the last few racers, I was then faced with having to grind again for another car, and I wasn't going to pay for the real money loot boxes. That's when I gave up. In the end, the way the game is setup is just garbage. Everything negative people are saying about this game is true. Ignore as there are racing games out now that are much better. PASS.

Need for Speed Payback is a fun open world racer and you could do much worse than playing it, but its attempts at goading the player into using micro-transactions, uneven difficulty and attempts to crib open world design elements from Forza Horizon keep the game from being truly great. You play as three protagonists, Tyler, Mac and Jess as they race Fortune Valley a Las Vegas stand-in as they complete various racing, drifting, dirt, drag and getaway events to take down 'The House' a cartel that has been fixing street races and screwed over Tyler. Blah blah, the story is knock-off Fast & Furious schlocky tripe, but nobody plays racing games for the plot anyway. The game can look very good at times and the open world is fun to drive around in, mostly because of the open world activities you can do in it. Smashing billboards, breaking speed records, drifting, finding derelict cars and challenging roaming racers are all fun to do, and I know that because I had fun doing them in Forza Horizon. Still, for people who don't have access to an XBox One or a decent PC, this game can be a good replacement for Forza in its best moments. It's just too bad that the highs are counterbalanced by a vehicle upgrade system that, maybe true to the game's Las Vegas aesthetic feels less like upgrading a car and more like pulling a lever on a slot machine. To the game's credit, since it has been released the game has made its upgrade system kinder and gentler, putting less pressure on the player to give in and purchase micro-transactions. However simply having to engage with a randomized upgrade system that was designed to frustrate you into paying more left a bad taste in my mouth, regardless of them walking it back. Also, this game has some of the more ridiculously blatant rubber banding I've seen in a racing game in a long time. You will absolutely feel it when you eat wall and get sent to the back of the pack and the cars ahead of you slow down to give you a chance, just as you will when you're ahead and the cars always manage to stay close enough to pass you if you make one single mistake, no matter how high you've leveled your car. This ties back into the micro-transactions; the game seems to purposefully try to frustrate you so you will go to the store and pull the level on the slot machine and hope you get something useful. Forget about being the same level as an event being enough to beat it; I found that you need to be at least 15 to 20 levels higher before your chances of winning went from being a coin toss to likely. All in all, it's an okay game, but people with access to Forza Horizon 3 should just get that instead.

Its not the worst entry, however its obvious that the game was built to please the publisher and satisfy their vision of the series instead of the players. When you first see the open world it appears to be filled with a lot of activities to do. However, the deceptive nature of this becomes apparent as you progress. Pretty much all the story sections are quite dull due to bad writing and the game has too much grinding. The free roaming areas lack random diversion like police roaming around to avoid or a running into a random pack of cars to take out. In the end, the remaining side activities like challenge races while a little enjoyable are not sufficient to keep you coming back. Having to go through unfun bits in hopes for some fun is simply not acceptable. Also, a lot of the cool customization options which used be given as rewards can now simply be purchased by anyone through microtransactions which makes you feel less like you're unique or skilled and that's also not a good thing.
Great visuals bogged down by weak car chases and races that's less than exciting or thrilling. Still worth a look however if you are big into car game.

If you were interested in this game because of its E3 gameplay, then dont buy it. That gameplay was a lie. It depicted the game as being a Fast N Furious like game, and that isnt true. Its story is very bad and only features a handful of those FNF style missions. And even those arent good. The graphics and gameplay feel as if theyre modern, yet everything else feels like the game hasnt changed since Undercover. It directly borrows things from NFS 2015 without any changes or improvements. Its 'diverse' open world is very empty, but filled with pointless collectibles. Its new card based upgrade system is terrible and ruins parts of the game. Collecting cars is no longer easy because each car needs to be upgraded with a new set of cards. And upgrading is now dependent on luck and grinding. Its just a bad idea. If youre looking for just an arcade racing game, then youll be fine with a Payback. Though I recommend getting it on sale. If youre expecting a much improved NFS game with a well done story and set of characters, then do not get this. A lot of people didnt like NFS 2015. This game does has some improvements and good changes, but it still feels like a step back.

The game started off promising with a lot of fast paced racing, but it quickly dissolved into a routing of driving from one race to another race just like in Grand Theft Auto 5 years ago. The other issue is that the AI is designed to force you to have perfectly clean run to win the boss challenge which requires running the same track over and over and over and over (get the pattern). So, I got bored and stopped playing.

It has fun arcade racing mechanics and looks nice. Yet it somehow fails to be the core game that I look for in a NFS game. For me, that is being able to customize a car to be fast and to look as cool (ridiculous) as possible. While this game does have some very fun cars, the derelicts somehow are not the customizable powerhouses I would've expected. Since you have to unlock new cars to buy through racing, you're never incentivized to switch cars because you have to then grind out new cards to upgrade every car. Nothing carries over except the currency which gets used up pretty quickly when buying new cards. Somehow the game comes up short and the grind, which I don't want in a racing game, gets boring quickly.

It seem as though people are giving this game a low star rating because of the micro and hate that you have to drive so far to get to a race event. Not a problem because on my way there I'm breaking speed trap records ( which gives you earnings). Crashing through Billboards etc. I can care less about the voice as one mentioned did not like the voice of characters and complaints about how to upgrade your vehicle but the vehicle that I have now is way better than more than half of what the dealerships had to offer from manually upgrading it.. you do not have to accept all upgrades because sometimes when you upgrade something you might lose something from overall performance like if you upgrade your brakes, you will lose horsepower ( not a lot) but you will be informed before you accept by looking at your side bar attributes. This is the first time I have ever played a Civ game but I have always been interested in the series. I tell you this because I do not have any knowledge as to what has been improved or what new additions have been added to the game. This review is specifically for those that are looking for a strategy game to play. This game plays from a top down view although you are allowed to zoom in very closely. I'd compare this game similar to a board game but I want to be careful with that description as its really not like that. You start off with a choosing which leader you want to play as and must claim land to which to build your civilization. Every turn you make decisions as to what you can research to expand your knowledge of new tech or policies. Your cities must be expanded through addition of various buildings that grant benefits such as increasing science. You select what characters to create much in the same manner as rts games and must wait a set amount off turns before you can use them. You can move them around the map to either scout, claim land, or battle cities or other infantry. The game is a very long game though as you start off in BC and go well into the 2000s. It has lots of complexities, which I believe adds many exciting things to do within the game. I'm sorry if I'm confusing or not providing lots of detail but trying to explain how this game works is best left to a video. If you are looking for a game that has lots of replay ability and lets you build a civilization from nothing and see how far you can take them, then I recommend this game.

I've been playing Civilization since the first installment. I even have Civilization VI for the PC. I bought this version with some concern about how well the game would transfer to console button controls. My hope however was having the game on the Switch would make it much more convenient and comfortable way to play. My hopes were pleasantly confirmed. Although it takes a bit of getting used to it is clear a lot of thought was put into the button mapping and control scheme of the game. Less than half way through my first game everything was second nature for me. I even used buttons in handheld mode over the touch screen. Playing portability on the switch is super convenient. Playing docked with split joy-cons on a large screen is very relaxing and comfortable. I'd play Civilization this way over using my computer every time. It should be noted this version of Civ 6 does only supports local wireless (2 Switches, 2 games, same place) multiplayer. I've never been interested in multiplayer for this game, so that doesn't bother me.

Bought this for the switch because I love to play this game and is perfect game to play on long road trips or when needing to kill some time. However, if you are familiar with the Civ game series, the developers changed the gameplay just a enough that it gets confusing. It is not a show stopper though, if you happen to get stumped on something in the game, just reference what you need to know on You Tube. I promise you that you will find your answer on there. Overall, I am happy that I made this purchase

I have been playing Sid Miers Civilazation since it was first released in the early nineties. I absolutely love this series. I was very skeptical at first when I saw it had been ported to a console, particularly Nintendo since they are mostly kid like games. But, I was also somewhat excited. I have transitioned from pc gaming to consoles for many reasons and was excited by the possibility of playing Civ on a 55inch tv. But would it be good or flaky? Well, its not good, but amazing!!!!! Very easy controls, very simple to navigate, beautiful graphics (especially in 4K HD), and the depth of play is definitely there. All the reports, statistics, information, choices, everything is there and fairly easy to find. I can now sit and relax on my couch or gaming chair in the living room and play my belov d Civ series game. Im a very happy camper. By the way, it is well worth buying the Nintendo Switch just for this game alone.
Should be required for all Nintendo users! Me likey
Its a little bitcg if a learning curve but once learned good game.
Exactly what hed hoped for. Hours of enjoyment and fun!!!

The game is good if you like turn based strategy games. I had played a few of the simpler Civilizations games and enjoyed them. Even with some previous experience and a tutorial, I still feel somewhat lost when playing especially when navigating menus. Its definitely Civilization so if you like their other games, youll like this one. If you like quick paced action, you may want to skip this one.

Interface is clunky. Very little in way of walkthrough. If you are fan of civ series this game will fit the bill. I believe game works better on p.c. due to interface. Graphics decent . Gameplay decent . Can't go wrong for $20. Wouldn't pay $49,99 or more .

The controls are good and you can do everything on the switch without too many clicks, but it is just a little bit faster and more intuitive on pc. Great game though and again, so nice to have portably!

My biggest issue with this port is that it's missing out on all of the expansions that the PC version has, at least last time I played. That said I can't really deny the charm of Civ 6. Having it on a mobile device is nice. And eats up a lot more of your time as you take just one more turn.
A great strategy game for any fan of turn-based strategy games.

If youve never played Civilization now is the time. Aspyr did an excellent job of porting the must have strategy game for everyones darling the Nintendo Switch. I only docked it one star because its sometimes difficult to see in handheld mode. Other that if youre a fan of excellent strategy games this is a must buy!

Civ 6 is a great game, but you have to invest a ton of hours in it do understand it - you can't just click 'new game' and go in blind. I had to go through multiple built-in tutorial sections to understand how the game played, and often have to check guides to remember how certain functions work.

This is not a pick up and play game. If you haven't played any civ before, which I haven't, you gotta do some major research to figure out how to get started. I'll update the review if it gets any better. Most people love this game. I think it's ridiculously complicated.
Plays almost exactly like the PC versions. It's a great update to a classic game. If you'd never played the CIV series, do yourself a favor and buy it. You won't regret it.

It keeps intact all of the good elements of the original civilization game.

This is my first Civilization game and I've been loving every minute of it! I now understand why the game has such a devoted fan base. There's a lot of depth in Civ 6 that can be overwhelming at first but stick with it because once you get into a flow, and begin to understand how everything works, you'll be fascinated by the Civilization you've created. My only warning would be that this game can be very addicting! I've lost track of time and found myself playing the game for over 6 hours in a single session! Happy playing everyone!

If youve ever played the Sid Meyers games then youll definitely want to add this one to your collection. Has the usual great aspects of the game as in the computer but now can be enjoyed anywhere you go. Playing can take up to hours and youll not want to stop.
Not me kind of game. Had to go through a long Tutorial

I've never played a Civilization game before, but this one looked cool and I like the portability of it. However, there is a steep learning curve, and I haven't fully been able to enjoy it since I'm having a hard time learning to play. I should come with a basic book (even downloadable) explaining what the icons are, actions, etc...
I purchased as a Christmas gift for my son. I'm sure it won't disappoint.
Ok ok the tv impossible on the handheld. Options arent visible and screen just isnt quite enough.
Bought this as I thought it was going to have online and didnt.
Game plays like the mobile port. Never played the PC version but I would not recommend the Switch one at all.

I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this port vs the PS4 version...Ubisoft did a good job carefully considering the compromises to get Black Flag running well on the Switch. Granted this is a first-gen PS4 game (ported from PS3/360) vs a late-game Switch title, so it really shouldn't be too much of a surprise. There is some detail pop-in at short draw distances, and the PS4 version runs at a noticeably higher frame rate (on the Pro), they're really only noticeable if you compare them side-by-side. The character models and textures look about the same, and all the spoken dialogue and shanties are present as well. My only disappointment is that Rogue isn't included on the Switch cart and it has to be downloaded...I really wish this practice would stop.
Im very excited to reply Assassins Creed black flag and take it on the go got to be a dream come true I'm very happy with my purchase =)

Of all the Assassin's Creed versions (including the newest ones that are populated by microtransaction - boo!), this has to be the best. The action is interesting and intense; the settings amazing, and the music is great. This is a game to get lost in. Get it; rediscover the joy of being a pirate. Highly Recommended.

Love this game! And its definitely got everything from the previous versions. I wanted to give it 5 stars because Im having waaaaay too much fun pirating on-the-go. But annoyingly the controls are a little clunky at times but this could just be a technical issue on switch. Either way, if youre like me and enjoy more serious titles on the Switch. Its a must!.

If you want a review of the game there are many out there already, as ACIV and Rogue are well established as 2 of the best entries of the entire series. This review pertains to the quality of the port itself, which is impressive. The frame rate is rocksolid and the resolution is sharp. Full 720p handheld, dynamic 900p-1080p docked. Bonus download included- HQ pictures, videos, manga, Blackbeards journal... this game is chock-full of content. If every game ported to Switch was this good we wouldnt have any problems. And as much as I do love playing The Witcher 3 portably, AC Rebel Collection really reminds you how much a sharp resolution and stable framerate can positively impact your experience. 5 stars.

I started out the Assassins Creed series with the 3rd remastered and I hated it. I wasn't sure if i should spend even more money on this series but i decided ide buy this one and I LOVE IT!!! Totally worth the purchase!

Assassins Creed Black Flag has been considered one of the best games of the decade. Its a fantastic pirate simulator with great mechanics and so, so much to do. While Rogue isnt as good or good at all, frankly, Black Flag is definitely worth the price.

The only thing keeping me from giving this collection five stars is that Rogue is downloadable content which the box doesnt state and the graphics looks on a Switch Lite like gen. Other both are solid games especially the highly overlooked Rogue.

Call center needs additional training. Dewan, who took my call, after on hold for 25 min, gave me my answer but when I told him I wanted to take your survey he hung up on me. Not happy with my experience.
Rouge is not on the cartridge, its a download and it doesnt even display that on the box.
My son really loves this game. He plays it alot and his little brothers enjoy it also!
It pretty much follows the anime series from the middle of the Forth Great Ninja War. The cut scene and the QTE are what I love the best, it's like you are watching the anime again.
My son and my daughter love this game they spend time together with this videogame.

-Welcome back to the world of Naruto. -The story line for the road to Baruto is not extremely long however it does add some well needed character. Though does not add enough charters as it seems. I've either not met certain goals to unlock them or the do not exist in the in game that I am aware of as of yet. -In game play is very typical of the other Narout storm games and found it most enjoyable to return to. -It does seem hard to find other similar games that allow for this style of 3d vector style of fighting and/or have the fluid movements that have been worked out in there games. -I look forward to future expansion on the series. -I would recommend the game anyone who is a fan of Naruto, enjoy fluid movement to the fighting games, and overall anyone else in general. -I hope you found this useful and if there are future questions I will try to answer them.

Its like somewhere someone said what if we just made games, tv shows, and movies where we make the villains the main characters ! And no one stopped them to say villains shouldnt be redeemed if you want to sell the world on heroes being the better person

LEGO DC SUPER-VILLAINS is a great game, I have some fun playing It. You can select your favorite super villain and do super villains` things on free world mode. The story mode is good, it shows some of DC`s favorite heroes and villains. The tutorial is great and the game has some tips to Make it easy for a player who is not familiar with LEGO games.

Similar to other LEGO games, the DC Villain game plays through stages and you unlock characters as you go through. But the game offers the opportunity for you to create your own villain who gains powers along the way. Good concept but you dont have the ability to choose what powers are available just customize based on options. Fun play but finished quickly

If you've played a Lego game before, nothing about this game will surprise too much, it's pretty straightforward like most other lego games that have been made. This one did keep my interest longer than some of the other ones since the story isn't an exact rehash of a movie like how Lego Incredibles or Lego Avengers was. If you've enjoyed other Lego games and want a fun new take on it, this is still a lot of fun to play through.

My son and I have spent countless hours playing video games together (much to my wifes dismay). We love the LEGO games weve played so far and this is our next challenge to conquer. Hours of couch time are calling!
Having a lot of fun playing through this one with my 5 year old son, who is educating me on all things DC.

I purchased the Switch Digital Download version of The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. I prefer to have all of my games downloaded onto a microSD card rather than needing to purchase the game cartridge and needing to carry that around with this portable system/home console hybrid. I could have bought the digital download via Nintendo's eShop, but this way I receive rewards points by purchasing it trough Best Buy. The process is simple: after you purchase the digital version, Best Buy e-mails you with a 16-digit code, which is what you input into the Switch eShop under the 'Enter Code' option. The game downloads immediately once you have successfully entered the code. It is a 13+ GB download, so depending on your internet connection, it will take awhile, but the game is worth it! I've only had the game for a day, but I can say this game is a must have, especially for Zelda fans! It is a well crafted game, the mechanics work well, and now you can take an HD Zelda title on the go! The world is huge, so I know it will take me quite a while to explore everything!

The game is incredible! I was nervous to purchase the electronic version of the game outside of Nintendo but I was pleasantly surprised by the ease to purchase through best buy! The email with the game code for download had easy to follow instructions. I will definitely purchase games electronically again through Best Buy!

As a child I played all the zelda but Ocarina of Time literally changed my video game expectations. I bought a switch and Breath of the Wild in Hope's that at the age of 30, I could feel that way again....And I did....TIMES 10! This game is simply amazing. Brought me back to when I was 8 or 9.

Bounght this when i got my Switch at the urging of my friends. I haven't played a Zelda game since the good old N64 versions. It's my favorite title for the platform so far, with good hits of nostalgia thrown in with the new.

I have only played it for about 5-10% of its size. In my very limited gaming experience, my favorite type of game used to be combat racing. Zelda (Breath of the Wild) may have changed that for me. I love the technical side of it. The sound makes me feel like I am there, in nature. The only part that I don't like about it (and it's not Zelda in particular, but these types of games) is the complexity of things that you acquire, the large number items that you can have in your inventory and use to cook, for example. I repeat that my video-gaming experience is limited, but this title has redefined my expectations of what is possible in terms of beauty, art, direction, and technics, especially on such modest hardware as the switch. I purchased the game and tried it because of hearing people about the experience of it being special, and it did deliver; now Zelda holds a special place in my heart too!
If you are looking for a beautiful open world style game this ones for you whether you are a Zelda fan or not.

First game my son bought after receiving his switch. Like all Mario games this is so fun!!! Lots of new things going on in this game that none of the others have. But super Mario is a no trainer for single player games. Very addicting!
Hours of fun playing. Zelda is one of the best games

So I accidentally purchased the digital copy of this game, which from what I have researched, happens to Best Buy online customers a lot. Depending on where you add to your cart, there is not much to tell you if you are loading the digital or physical copy. Even the image of the game for digital purchase if of the physical copy of the game. I thought that Best Buy would be reasonable and provide an exchange for a physical copy, given that I had not redeemed the digital copy. I was wrong. In fact, the online customer service agent told me that I had to do this at a store (why?), only to be told by them it could not be done. I am very disappointed, since this was to be a gift. Suffice it to say, I will never shop at Best Buy again.

You can not return or sell this! Even if it has not been activated. This is the same price as the game you can buy in store and you can sell it when done or return it if it was not opened. We bought the bundle and did not know it was a software download bundle.

Divinity Original Sin 2 has upped the game for turn-based 'Western' role playing games to a point that it's hard to imagine it getting any better, in regards to game systems, controls, and handling, barring some major controller change to the next generation. Surely, the next gen PS5 will offer more in the way of graphics, loading times, or other technical increases, but as for porting over a game that relies on using a good chunk of a keyboard on PC to a console controller, this may be the very best we'll have, and it's great. As great as it is, the 'handling' would be nothing more than a wishlist item for a completely different game if the game itself wasn't any good, but Larian Studios continues with its amazing pedigree. You'll have a group of 4 heroes chosen among 8 characters, all with their own fully fleshed story, or, if you choose, you can create your own. (The heroes they offer are excellent, and I'd recommend beginning with one of them. They introduce you into the gigantic array of systems easier. Even these pre-made heroes are customizable almost entirely from the ground up, so you'll be able to change a fighter hero to your preferred class right from the outset!) Their stories and their characterizations are done so well, you'll want to see them all play out! Choice is perhaps the biggest thing here in DOS2. Every step of the way, you're truly in control. From choosing your class to interacting with other characters, whether they be major or minor characters, you truly 'run the show'. And it's much more than surface level- you won't just have a character class, spells, and attributes to choose from, but talents and backgrounds that help shape your story and how the world and its inhabitants engage with you. (Highly recommend 'Pet Pal,' which allows you to speak with animals, which are fully voiced!) Choices will also shape the world, as decisions are permanent. Accidentally hit an onlooker during a battle, and they'll attack. Steal from or kill an NPC, and they or villagers may seek revenge, shun you, or close off quests you may have otherwise received from them. Beyond choice, DOS2 offers an 'innovative common sense' method of play. In a day and age where every game seems to take pride in hiding behind obtuse systems, DOS2's will almost seem easy to overlook in battle, even in the non-hurried gameplay of taking turns. Cast a rain spell, causing enemies to be standing in a puddle, then zap them all with one lightning bolt. Knock over a barrel of oil, then set it ablaze to force enemies to bunch up at a chokepoint. (Or, in a personal example, launching a water arrow at a teammate who had been set on fire to put him out!) What else makes DOS2 stand out among RPGs? You can play online to adventure with up to 3 other players. (Even in single player, you can split your adventurers and tackle 2 quests at the same time, if you choose, as you're also able to take direct control over anybody on your team). You can even play couch co-op with a friend or family member. Even more intriguing is the 'Game Master' mode, where up to 5 players play together, with one controlling the game's narrative as the GM. DOS2 is, with very little wiggle room for debate, among the very top of the list of RPGs available for a console. You can argue for some of the Eastern style RPGs with some moxy, but among the Western style, it IS the best. But, be warned, if Final Fantasy or Persona is what you're looking for, DOS2 is not it. It's still completely recommended, being the masterpiece that it is, but it is a different playstyle. It's Dungeons & Dragons in a digital form that's advanced further than the old Icewind Dales and the like from 15 years ago. It's a more complicated, more micro-managed game and takes lots of patience and a frequent willingness to save the game, especially early, as you learn the game. (Pretty sound advice to save often here, no matter your experience). It's a time-consumer, so set plenty of time aside when you pop this in. If you're looking for one of the greatest RPGs ever made, your next addiction that will eat up over 100 hours to play through, then leave you heading back in with a new party to experience it from different eyes, DOS2 simply cannot be passed up!

This felt way too similar to actually playing the magic card game. Just a weird gameplay for someone who isn't used to it. I started to play it but was so taken aback by it that I didn't play it for a bit but the pandemic had other plans for me! I eventually became used to the gameplay. Not sure if I'd play another game but it would nice if this were more of an open world environment rather than just being restricted to the area you're playing in.

I grew up with the Baldur's Gate / Icewind Dale / Planescape games on PC. To me, those were the peak of digital RPGs and nothing else has come as close to their greatness as the Divinity series. This game is truly designed for lovers of pen & paper D&D games. If you played the first one, you've probably already bought this one. If not, you can easily jump in here, or pick up the first game on the cheap and double your fun.

I played this game shortly after completing the first title in the series. I quickly discovered that enough had changed between the two games for me to need some guidance. This is a game the will reward you with hundreds of hours of entertainment or have you rage quitting in your first hour if youre not prepared. This isnt a pickup and play kind of game but well worth the effort needed to master or at least achieve competency in.

I bought this game looking to scratch an itch for a good turn based, action RPG. This game definitely delivered. It take elements from traditional DnD to greatly influence the story. I love this game. I'm over 40 hours in and I'm already itching to start it over once I finish it. The story is gripping, you grow to care about your companions. You may get emotional with this game, just as I have. Great Game. I absolutely love it.

Isometric-view, computer RPGs have had a bit of a new lease on life in the last few years with games like Divinity Original Sin, Pillars of Eternity, Torment, and Wasteland. Now we have the updated version of Divinity Original Sin 2 on consoles and it exceeds all my expectations. If you enjoy story-driven RPGs with fleshed out characters and choices that actually make a difference in your story look no further than this.

Only a few hours in but I can say the gameplay is much more polished then its predecessor. Menus, inventory and such are much more streamlined and organized. Visuals are tenfold better with HDR and 4K support. I spent nearly 45 minutes creating a character with the endless amount of skills and combinations you can use. Battle takes alot to get used to, as it did in the first game. I'm never a fan of putting a game to 'easy' as I always enjoy the challenge. But much like the first game, this game is guilty of punishing you early. I enjoy exploring in RPGs, and pushing the boundaries. But unfortunately this game makes you pay for it early on. If you steal and get caught, or go somewhere you're not supposed to, chances are you will be thrust into a battle against multiple enemies 10x's as strong. But battles that are storyline related you will fair pretty well against. It may sound ridiculous listing this as a gripe, but i dont enjoy having to quit and restart multiple times simply because I ticked off one NPC and the entire tavern turned against me.

If you're a fan of the first game, then you'll love this one as well. Awesome story, lengthy campaign with lots to do and the controls have translated to console gaming better than you'd think. The music is great, character creation is deep, and the combat/magic systems are robust and well thought out. One of the best games of the year, no doubt.

What can I say about this game? It is amazing on every level. It brings out creativity and focus. It is challenging and entertaining. The interwoven stories and choices make replayabililty huge, which honestly isn't a big thing for me. For me I usually find myself bored several hours in and wonder to the next. Not here, this holds my attention and keeps me pondering after I quit playing.

so I grabbed this looking to fill the hole after completely beating diablo 3 and wanting a game similar. after some research this game came up and at the price point it was hard to say no. I've only played for a couple hours. I wouldn't say I didn't enjoy it, it's just not what I thought I was getting. it has the feel or better yet look of diablo with its isometric view. The one thing I was a little bummed about was the fact that it's a turn style based combat system. it's not horrible I was just looking for the type of system found in diablo. I feel I need to put more time into the game I'm sure once I get a better feel for it I will undoubtedly really enjoy this game.
Super lame unless youre into moving boxes out of the way to find stuff before just killing things

If you like the old style roll playing game from the commodore 64 days, then you will love this game. This game uses none of the graphics and processing available on today's platforms. Sadly I found it a waste of money.
Every 3DS owner must have this game for their collection.This is one of the best versions of this game. Turn on the 3D and lose yourself in this gem.

This game is basically Star Wars meets Big Top Pee Wee. Except there's no Hot Dog tree in this game. They really missed an opportunity there. I have a great idea for a game... Hot Dog Farm 2. Why skip Hot Dog Tree 1!? Sequels are ALWAYS better. This game is ALMOST perfect. Come on guys... watch some Peewee sequels and LEARN SOMETHING. Perfect game.

This particular game has been out of print for some time, so was very excited when it was announced that it'd be a 19.99 Nintendo Selects title. I played and loved the original Star Fox 64 back in the day on the N64 and am surprised it took me this long to play the remake. Very faithful to the original content with improvements in all the places you'd want improvements. Definitely worth the $20!
Best way to experience once again this game from my childhood!
Game has terrible bugs and glitches. Hopefully an update will fix the issues.

I have bought all of the wwe 2k games and this one is the worst! The graphics look like a ps2 game and the glitches in this weak pathetic garbage is so bad I had to return my copy. It makes me disappointed that 2k would ship a game out in this condition. If you are a fan of all the other wwe 2k games then don't buy this trash because you will be sadly disappointed!

The game as everyone knows is extremely glitchy. I wanted to return it but of course Best Buy essentially told me no when I reached out via twitter. I understand that it isnt their problem because they didnt make the game but as a retailer for the game something should be done. With that said the second patch came in today and I don notice improvement so Ill try to be optimistic as more patches come. It isnt AWFUL, but there are issues.
This game is broken very glitchy and just dont play good graphic look like it was a ps2 game and it just not worth the price i paid Also some key features are not even featured yet
Very different from last year this game show need be harder on game
This game is awesome. I will recommend this to a friend
Let everyone know about the game to buy it at best buy

This is the first rune factory game that I have ever played and, so far, I have really enjoyed it. The farming mechanics are simple to understand as are the quests and relationship building mechanics. The battle system is fairly basic with just one attack button and a few spells, but it is still fun to play. The only downside is that the details of some of the mechanics are hidden behind certain conversations with characters that do not always trigger before you have to use a mechanic, so sometimes I found myself having to google the mechanics to understand the game.

Rune Factory 4 is my personal favorite Harvest Moon / Story of Seasons type game. I had it on 3DS, and was happy to have the chance to get this Switch version. It has more exploration and combat than other games of this type, and its possible to get more done in the early game than in something like Stardew Valley. For me, it makes the game more fun. Being a 3DS game first, this port might not look amazing vs recently developed Switch games, but it does benefit from a higher resolution, stable performance, and a few minor extras. I like the NPCs in this game a lot. They seem to have a lot more things they can say vs other games of this type, and sometimes their own little story elements. I think they add more personality to the game vs similar games. They can also help you fight if you want, with their each villager behaving differently. Like one may fight with a sword, where another might try to help by throwing food at you if you get hurt.

Love it to death so far. The only complaint I have is the visuals. They don't translate very well to the Switch, but it's still charming. The gameplay is fun, and everything you do gives you levels so no matter what you do during a day you feel like you're making progress.

I got this for my son and he loves it. My wife also plays it and loves it, too. They say there is a lot of depth to the game. There are a variety of ways to play the game, so it makes replaying it enjoyable. There is good depth of character development, too.
Similar to Harvest Moon and Stardew Valley. My fianc has been a fan of this series for a long time.

Rune Factory 4 makes a great transition to the Switch with high definition art and smooth gameplay with minimal load times. The extra voice lines, cutscenes, and other added features may not be enough for a repeat purchase from the 3DS game for some, but I highly recommend this gem!

I played this game when it was out years ago. I never finished it because of other games at the time, but I always wondered what the ending was like (third act etc). Well, I picked this up again to find out, and I started at the same time as animal crossing. Big mistake. This game has taken over my life. I do not want to fire up animal crossing at all. This game is chill, and so much deeper. I am probably 30 or so hours in. Still loving it. This one is worth picking up.

I was excited about this game. A farming sim with relationships and RPG dungeon fighting... yes, please! I am enjoying the game but I'm super disappointed with the music and sounds. They are terrible. You sound like you are at a carnival 24/7 in this game with a pinball machine in the background and it gets really annoying. It wouldn't be so bad if you can turn down the music... but you can't. I finally decided to turn OFF the music and it is MUCH better. This is more like a port of a 3DS game than a remaster. If they had updated the music then this would be a solid 5 stars for me because everything else is fantastic. It has a very nice reward system throughout the game and you really feel like you are progressing even though there is a lot of grinding... and that is a good thing.
THIS IS A PORT OF A 3DS GAME FOR THE SWITCH WITH MORE ADDES CONTENT NOT ON THE 3DS, IT'S AN OLD GAME, BUT IT HAS IT'S CHARM

Astro Bot is an absolute Master Class study of fun and creative level design in a VR space. I'm not sure it's possible to play this game with out smiling. It's hands down must play and must own! Astro Bot is an awesome game that continually wowed and surprised me. With each level I played, I thought I had discovered my new favorite level. It just keept getting better all the way to its fun and creative conclusion. There are many good games now that make PSVR worth the investment, but this game by itself makes it worth the purchase. It's a true system seller and more than worthy of all the good reviews it's gotten. For those of you old enough to remember the feelings of pure fun and joy you had the first time you played Mario 64 in the 90's, be prepared to have those feelings. If you are on the fence, but interested in VR, now is the time. This is a game for people that love games and will convert all that try it into believers of 3rd person platformers in VR!

Wonderful game, that is well crafted and whimsical. I was grinning ear to ear each step of the way. While a shorter game 4-6hrs main play through it well worth the asking price. You will easily double that playtime if you do the additional challenge levels and content. Lots to do. It's a game that must be experienced, since describing it or watching previews on flat screens doesn't do it justice. Most VR games are like that, but this one especially so. After God of War, and Spiderman I would easily put this among them for game of the year contender. It does so much with the medium. It's rare for me when a game gets better each level you progress. Just when you think they could not possibly top themselves... they do. There is a demo now, so try before you buy if you must. Stay away from spoilers too if possible. This is a game that is will best serve you if you go in blind and let it unfold.

This is by far the best PSVR game in my opinion. The experience playing Astro Bot, the first time I played it, reminded me of the first time I played Mario 64 (first truly great 3D game)... it was a quantum leap ahead of the other current generation games, and made me feel like I was playing something ground-breakingly new. Astro Bot uses VR to the fullest potential I've yet seen. Phenomenal platformer! So much fun to play!

This game has it all, except gore (which sometimes is good for gaming). Anyway, great family friendly game that will impress anyone as an introduction to VR. Not only as a technical showcase, but also because it is a straight up fun game.

This is the best V R game that exist today. Everything is perfectly done. I love how the touch pad is integrated in the game. My only convert is that the game should be longer. With at least a few more Words. Apart from that this is the best.
One of the best games you can get for PSVR, the other being Resident Evil 7
This game is one of the best reasons to own PSVR. Buy it. You won't be disappointed.
perhaps the most immersive game on the psvr, breathtaking

Astrobot is the mario of PSVR, if you don't own a copy do yourself a favor and buy it. Its is a good value in terms of length as well (shorter than most full length titles but superseding what most VR games offer by far). A+
I bought PSVR when it was released. This game is amazing and fun for PSVR.
It's a really fun game. Would be nice if more than one play can play it.
kids are enjoying this kid friendly game. I can hear them laughing at the characters
As a new vr user, I am really impressed at this game. Its replay value is worth it too.

I haven't had this much fun with a platform game since Sonic Adventure came out for the Dreamcast. The game-play, graphics, music, the VR usage, the ideas they put into it and the boss battles are just simply amazing!! The worlds are just awesome!! Sony's 'Team Asobi' is a developer company to be reckened with, can't wait for their next game.

I was enthralled, and thoroughly entertained by this game from start, to finish. I haven't had this blown away by a platformer since playing Super Mario 64 for the first time in the 90s. This takes 3D platforming to a new level using modern VR tech, with you as the camera, and headbasher of obstacles, coupled with a stellar level of polish. The visuals are superb amongts PSVR titles, controls are flawless, and there is a large variety in levels. Difficulty curve is well balanced, providing an entertaining, and occasionally challenging experience. It took me around 6 hours to get through the campaign while hunting down as many collectibles as I could along the way. Many more hours were spent finding the remainder. If you've got a PSVR, or are on the fence about buying one, this is a must have, milestone of a title. I sincerely hope we will see sequels in the future.

This is hands down the best VR game and perhaps one of the best platformers I've ever played. Nothing feels forced and there is PLENTY of content between the main story mode, bonus area with unlockables and even challenge modes for EACH LEVEL (including harder bosses!). Graphics are amazing, controls are perfect, and the characters are super cute! Check it out, it's a great (discount priced!) VR game!

I'm typically not a fan of 3rd person platform games in VR, but Astro Bot is a fantastic addition to the PSVR library. The visuals are as good as any I've ever seen, the game play is upbeat and fun, and the game is just very, very well made.
Haven't had a lot of time with it, but it seems like it will be a lot of fun
This game is like Moss but not quite as good. Fun

The game looks great and from what I played it was fun. I had to stop though due to motion sickness. You can control the robot but not the camera. The camera advances for you as you move through the level and not knowing when it was going to move was jarring. If you don't suffer from motion sickness than I'd recommend it.
Very fun. Son and I had a blast playing. Looks so cool in vr.

This is an ok game. Bought it thinking that it was going to be like a 3d version spin off of a Mario style game. It is, but yet isn't, as it has a lot to do and to explore. Be warned if you get motion sickness easily, this one may not be able to played for to long.
This game is good for byoung and old. Challenges for all level of play.
Ok game cannot complain. Keeps then kiddos busy atleast.
We bought this for our son so that he had an additional VR game than the one he got for Christmas. We have all really enjoyed playing !!
This game is the Mario game for the PSVR. If you own a PSVR better get this game.

I like this game. Its fun, but I dont love it. I grew up playing the older Pokmon games.
