Celeste is a great game. The graphics are awesome the gameplay feels fluid and the story is great. I immediately fell in love with this game because of how fun it was and beat it it about 11 days time. This game is now one of my favorites and I look forward to playing it a second time. The only thing I personally think was bad was that in order to access the final stage you need to collect four hearts which you get by completing b-sides and I had no clue the hearts existed until the end of the game and while a small hiccup I still must remove a star for it.

Mega Man 11 is a great addition to the main-line Mega Man series. So much of the gamefrom the graphics, to the controls, to the enemies, to the level designfeels reminiscent of classic Mega Man, but informed by advances in game design in the decades since then. Mega Man still has his basic run, jump, and shoot gameplay, and the levels do a lot to test what you can do with that move set. You don't have to use the Robot Master powers you unlock, or the new Double Gear system, but most of the Robot Master powers are actually useful throughout other levels, and where I initially thought the Gears would be a fallback, like a temporary easy mode, the levels actually feel designed with their use in mind. Certain parts of classic games do feel a little bit outdated in 2018, such as needing to replay much or all of a level if you die (depending on your difficulty setting), or the lives system, but the ability to buy lives in the in-game shop (with in-game bolts, no real money) make it somewhat a non-issue. And if you are the sort of gamer who is so inclined, it can be fun to keep trying parts of levels until you are able to make it through without taking damage; if you are not, you can also buy extra E-tanks in the shop. MM11 definitely plays it safer than you could argue it needed to, but with such a long wait since MM10, and the missteps with Mighty No. 9, I will take the smaller game since the team at Capcom clearly put in the effort to get things right, and I look forward to them building on this in MM12.

It's been quite some years since we've seen a Mega Man title done with love. This right here is a return to form Without losing any of the elements the series is known for. Kudos to Capcom for not following the trend of changing up a classic, well established series for the sake of catering to potential newcomers but instead alienating the loyalist fanbase.

My son, who is 6, and I take turns playing this game. It is only a 1 person game but when one of us dies, the other person gets to play until they die. It's not a super hard game but not super easy either. Simple and fun. We love it.
This game is just way too hard to be any fun to play.

The Blue Bomber has long been a nolstalgic figure for me. Mega Man 11 feels exactly like those classic titles that I played on Nintendo tight, precise jump controls, a slide to get you out of trouble and around obstacles and a simple basic weapon the Mega Buster which can be fired rapidly or charged for extra damage. Anyone who has ever played a Mega Man game will feel right at home, and anyone who hasnt will quickly. The Mega Man games have always been challenging and this is no different, but the new setting available for newcomers makes it enjoyable. Mega Man 11 has a reliable base that has been the foundation for so many classic titles. Fans of the series are going to be spoiled like I was with the new challenges. We may live in a new golden age of hardcore platformers, but Capcoms blue hero has shown all these newcomers that class never fades. Not only a game that sits alongside the best Mega Man games, but one of the best platform games released in recent memory. Thank you Capcom.
Game is very fun but can be hard to the point of frustrating. Id suggest trying casual.
He's back, and blue'r than ever! Bought it in switch for the nostalgia. Tight and tough gameplay so just keep at it!

The greatest and most underrated video game character of all time is back in a remastered version of the greatest game ever. I give this game a 10 out of 10. Ive only given that rating to the PS4 Spider-Man, Super Mario Galaxy 2, and of course the original GameCube version of Luigis Mansion. This also has a good amount of extra content too. Considering its on a handheld console.

This was one of my absolute favorite games as a kid, so when I heard Nintendo was releasing this I bought a DS. Great decision. It's just like the original and some added content for co-op! The c-stick controls took me a minute to figure out, it's motion controlled instead of an actual button, but the up down left right triggers also work but not as smoothly. Great game over all!

I have wanted to play this game for years! When I heard it was coming to the 3DS I just had to get it! I have 100%ed the game and I must say that I had so much fun with it. However, the camera and controls were not only difficult to use, but also insanely frustrating at times. The camera would kill me a lot and depth perception was a big problem as well. Only a few complaints, but overall the game was solid and super fun!

This is a great remake, the controls are a bit clumsy and it seems a bit easier. But I don't think that's a bad thing. The original game was never very challenging, so I don't think that's the point. Treasure sticking around on the ground longer definitely helps you collect everything and be a little less strategic when picking things up. Which I always thought was just an annoyance. The motion controls do help with aiming kinda similar to Breath of the Wild when Link uses his bow. Because of the placement of the second analog on the New 3DS I find my fingers attempting some strange stretches, but it is very doable. Over all a great game and worth buying if you liked it the first time through or you missed out on the GameCube version.

I played the Luigi's Mansion on the GameCube once upon a Time and I thought was one awesome game to bust some ghost! Especially when your doing it with your loveable character Luigi himself. Instead of Mario saving the day, you have Luigi saving Mario in this epic spooky story. Save Mario by finding out who Marionapped him and why did Luigi win a Mansion! Have fun ghost chasers!

I absolutely adore the Gamecube version of this game and was so looking forward to this one. Overall, I think it certainly does a good job of transitioning it all, sans the controls, which for me personally can be difficult at times to navigate. The game was designed to take advantage of the Gamecube's unique controller, and the 3DS version just doesn't feel comfy in terms of movement at times. Otherwise, though, a nice port of a time-tested Nintendo game.

I never got to enjoy this game on the Game Cube, so when t was released for the 3DS I jumped on this one. Controls well on the New 3DS and finally got to enjoy this entry before Luigis Mansion 3 is released next month. Definitely recommend picking this one up while the 3DS is still available.
Much better than Dark Moon, Classic port of the original for the GameCube

Luigi's Mansion is a classic. While the game didn't receive much fanfare when it originally launched on the Gamecube since everyone wanted a new Mario at launch, it has garnered a lot of love since then & people have come to appreciate what this game offers.

Luigis Mansion proves that theres still life in the 3DS, even as the Switch seems positioned to become its replacement. This version is so much more than a look at a title from that past. Were getting to play a lost piece of Nintendos history; a game that was originally designed for 3D, but was never fully realised due to the limitations of the technology at the time. After nearly two decades, we're playing Luigi's Mansion as it was originally intended, and it is as fun now as it was when the GameCube launched. If youve never played it before, you should definitely pick up this version. If you already have, the added functionality in the 3DS port provides more than enough reason to pick up the Poltergust one more time, although if you're one of those people who found the 2001 original disappointingly shallow (yes, such people actually exist), then this update is unlikely to change your mind, even with the welcome introduction of 3D support. Review summary from: linklink
Not scary at all, just loads of fun. Really great for mystery lovers.
Ever since Nintendo announced Luigi's Mansion for the 3DS, I was so exited, I am gonna save $40 to buy this game on my New 3DS XL.

Back in the day when GameCube was Nintendo's hot new console. Luigi's Mansion was the game that made me run out and buy the console. The idea that Luigi was starring in his own game without hia big brother Mario and as a inside joke/nod to Ghostbusters (one of the greatest movies of the 80's) blew my mind. I loved that game so much and when Nintendo announced they were bringing it back I had to get it. I was slightly disappointed they decided to release it on the 3ds over the switch there new hot selling console. But I'm just glad it's back with new features and upgrades. The fact this game can fit on the 3ds is a testament to just how powerful that little handheld is. If you never played it before you will love it. And if you have then you don't need me to tell you why it deserves to be on your 3ds so get out there and bust some ghosts Luigi style.

Nintendo is trying very hard to keep the 3ds alive and make as many sales on it as possible including this title. I had this on the game cube and enjoyed it. But it would have been better to port this to the switch instead, especially with the recent announcement of luigis mansion 3. With that being said, it's nice to have this title again for on the go, but an emulation of the original game looks and feels better
I played this game as a kid, now my daughter can play it and enjoy it like I did.
This game is very fun and the only reason I gave it three stars was it should have been ported to the Nintendo switch not the Nintendo 3ds

Overall a very good port from originally a 360/PS3 game. If this is your first tales game, it's a good start as it's known as one of the best in the series alongside Tales of Symphonia on the GameCube. Incredible graphics for on the go and a likeable cast which is the most important part in any Tales of game. Standard Tales battle system which makes for a good action RPG. The only downside in this game on the switch is some frame rate drops when on the world map. Battles and towns are very smooth and for a game you can take with you anywhere, it's impressive to say the least. Dock mode eliminates most of the drops so if you're planning on staying home to play, you won't have to worry about any of that. One thing for people that have played this in the past, Bandai has added some new voiced lines for the English dub. It is a bit awkward as they never got Troy Baker to come back and voice these additions so they found someone that sounds similar. It's supposed to be bit awkward according to others but I personally haven't noticed it as of yet or I just haven't reached a point where it's apparent. Whether you are new to Tales or replaying, this port is awesome and hopefully it shows the interest of JRPGs from the Nintendo Switch crowd.

Tales of Vesperia is one of my favorite games, almost strictly for its game play and art style. The story and music are a bit lackluster, but the 9 different characters this game offers, each with a unique play style, more than make up for them. If you want a really fun (single player or co-op) action JRPG, this is it. However, this port is not as good as it should be, despite what others may tell you. The most glaring problem is that, despite Namco claiming the Switch version would run 30 fps outside of battle and 60 fps inside of battle, outside of battle instead runs at an unlocked frame rate. This means that in towns, dungeons, and on the world map, the fps will constantly rise and drop, making for a very jittery experience. Also, consistent 60 fps in battle is not a thing. It is certainly smoother than field areas, but if Rita (the spell caster in the game) casts even a mildly flashy spell, expect drops. Also, if you do what is called an Encounter Link (which is running into 2 enemies on the field at once, making for around 6-10 enemies in the actual battle), expect constant frame drops to around 50 fps. People all over claim the battles are a constant 60 fps, and unfortunately that is just not true. The PS3 version ran far better in this regard. And while that was at a lower resolution than this port (PS3: 1280x576 vs Switch Handheld: 1280x720), it is mind boggling that a constant 60 fps cannot be maintained in battle. The unique issue with this Switch port is the washed out color palette. For some reason, the colors are nowhere near as vibrant as they should be. The PS4 version shares some of the same frame rate issues, though they are not as severe, but it certainly does not have washed out colors. For a game that thrives on its art style, this is a huge disappointment. I really can't recommend this port. It feels like a poorly optimized rush job by Namco. As my base PS4 also has mind boggling frame drops, I really could only recommend trying out the PS4 Pro, Xbox One X, or PC versions, though I haven't played those ones so I can't vouch for their performance.

I enjoyed what I've played of this game so far. The problem is, my girlfriend did not. I've been desperately looking for something we can both play together, and this caught my eye for it's ability to have multiplayer. The problem is, it falls flat on it's face with absolutely no explanation on how it works. Granted we figured it out in a few minutes of online searching, but still, it should be more apparent. During battles, the camera follows just the primary character. If other characters fall out of frame... oh well. Even if it wasn't multiplayer, the camera should pan out and pan to include all players and NPCs in frame. She couldn't see her character, or what she was doing, meanwhile I was getting ganged up on, and eventually died, along with our interest in playing this in multiplayer mode. That being said, as a single player game, it holds quite a bit of my interest. It plays something similar to Ni No Kuni and Lightning Returns (FF13-3), leaning much close to Ni No Kuni minus the familiars(think pokemon) stuff. The story seems fun, and the battle system is relatively straight forward. For the price I paid I would highly recommend it for someone looking for a color RPG. I haven't run into the voice acting issue others have mentioned, but I can be pretty obvious to that stuff, as it matters little to me for games I'm not super vested in.
This is one of my favorite Tales of games of all times. I am happy to see a remaster of it.

i love jrpgs a lot so i figured i would try the tales series for the first time. this is most dialogue i have every experienced in a game ever and it really ruins the pace of playing the game. the battles also feel repetitive and simple, but with a huge difficulty spike when playing against bosses. i loved the art style, tons of costumes, and character design though
It just doesn't hold up to other games that are out now. I rather spend my time saying better games.
The characters are really entertaining and the gameplay is fun. Only issue is that sometimes the game gets a bit too story heavy for my liking.
Very good game, story just keeps going and going you will fall in love with characters after 8 hours in to it lol

this is an action rpg out of japan, so you know what to expect from the combat. the seller is the story, which is one of the best tales of games to come out and has aged wonderfully from its first release on the xbox 360. the only odd thing is the little cutouts talking to eachother, but there are LOTS of voiced lines, more than they could animate and these are optional during exploration that shine more light onto the characters

Tales of Vesperia is my first JRPG game. I had been interested in this game for a while now, but decided to buy it when I found out about its action combat. I prefer this type of combat to turn based combat because I find it to be more satisfying and engrossing than waiting for your opponent to attach before you can. Pulling off a long combo feels great! I recommend everyone try this game!!
Amazing game for the switch! If you enjoy RPGs back on the ps1 and 2 days you would definitely enjoy this especially on the go.

I'm most likely to actually play through and finish this game due to the portability of the Switch, but like most larger multiplatform games, performance is the worst on this system. Still, this is a great, worthwhile JRPG no matter where you play it.

The tales of series is a lengthy one, and this is one of their most popular and well-loved entries and for good reason. This game is huge and has all the things you would want in a JRPG, a good story, compelling characters and a good fighting mechanic. While sometimes it gets grindy, it is fun and just feels right at home on the nintendo Switch. So if you are looking for a JRPG game to sink lots of time into, THIS is the game for you.

This has and will always be my favorite tales game. So much so that I actually have played the japanese version of the game. I cannot even begin to express how wonderful it is to finally be able to play this game in English. The story is engaging, the characters are well developed, and the gameplay is fun. It is also fantastic to have this portable! One thing to note, there are two voice actors for every character if you choose English as a language. It's not enough to take you out of the story, but if you're a longtime fan of the game it may seem a bit jarring at first.

The game and story is fantastic. The problem is they didnt update the graphics as well as they probably could have. Still a fun game, though compared to the newer versions of the tales series the battle style seems delayed and slow.

I didnt get a chance to play Vesperia when it released 10 years ago, so Im very glad that Vesperia Definitive Edition is available for all consoles, & that I & many others can now experience it! Its considered by most Tales of fans to be one of the best entries in the series, and at about 20 hours in a of playing, Id agree so far! While it shows its age in some aspects (camera mainly, but some graphical parts), its a solid game that overall has held up nicely over the years. It works fine in handheld version too, and havent noticed any dips in the 60 FPS for combat, & 30 FPS while not in combat. The load times are quick between battles & new locations, few seconds at most. The battle system is solid, & allows for players to make it as simple or complex as wanted. The voice work (both ENG & JP) is great with strong performances. So far the characters are all very likeable & seem to have depth to them. The protagonist,Yuri Lowell is neat from the start intrigued me. Tales of Vesperia DE is a great game that any JRPG fan should check out!
Aside from minor frame rate dips, the Switch version is well worth picking up for gamers who like to grind on the go!
This game is a remake of a 10 year old game, and it shows in some of its mechanics and graphics, but it still plays well and looks great for a dated game. Plus, portability helps.

Even though the Switch version of this game might not be the most graphical impressive. It still makes up for it in its portability aspects. If you aren't bothered by a few frame rate drops here and there then I would recommend this version to just about every tales fan.
This game looks amazing and is almost fully voiced acted. The only down side is the combat does feel a bit dated at times, but you do get used to it.
This one has started slow, but Im very intrigued.

I have played many games in the Tales series and I was excited to try this one out after hearing that it's considered 'one of the best,' but my experience with it so far has been a mixed bag. I find the story and some of the characters just interesting enough to be compelled to keep playing, but the battle system is frustrating enough at times to make me consider selling it. The battle system is not as convoluted as some of the later entries in the series, but some battles, particularly boss battles can be infuriating. This game is not a button masher so you can't expect to just waltz into battle and bash everything into oblivion. It does take some strategy and quick reflexes to dodge/block enemy attacks as well as good timing to chain combos together. However, despite knowing this, there are still things that make me want to pull my hair out: 1. Your attacks miss semi-frequently even when you're using the control stick to aim your attacks. 2. Despite my efforts to roam around and strategically avoid enemy attacks, it feels like the character I'm controlling has a target on his head and most of the enemies seem to gang up on me and disrupt my attacks/combos. Blocking doesn't seem to do much when you're surrounded by multiple enemies because they will just tag-team your butt as soon as you stop blocking. 3. There are huge spikes in the difficulty level with many bosses. The only way I've been able to get past many of them is by setting the game to 'easy' mode. 4. Some of the characters are really slow in battle. They move slow, their attacks are slow and they are slow to get up when knocked down. 5. Skills. You earn lots of skills and you have to equip your skills using your skill points in order to use them. The problem I have is that you earn very few skill points (at least early on) and there are many skills I'm not using because they require a lot of skill points, thus limiting my options to use other skills. It seems like this could have been balanced better. I wouldn't recommend this game unless you're a die-hard fan of the Tales games, you like a challenge, or you can get paste the things that have frustrated me.

This game is good but could have been better if they didnt be lazy and ported over the cell phone version because in tv mode you use only a single joycon as a mouse on your tv screen, but portable mode is where it shines but like I said before its because it was a lazy port from a cell phone version but all in all still a fun game but only in portable mode

I had played this game briefly on the Nintendo DS, and played it fully through when it was released on IOS on my iPad. This is a direct port of the IOS release, and looks and sounds great. The story is still compelling years later, and the constructs between character interaction, combat structure, and RPG mechanics all work great. What doesnt work great are the controls. There are two methods of control, one which uses a point cursor and motion controls to draw the designated shapes to trigger attacks when docked, and one that uses your finger on the screen to do the same when in handheld mode. The latter is the same experience as I had on the IPAD, but feels slightly more cramped on the switch screen. I had been really looking forward to a proper console experience on the tv, but found the point controls both overly sensitive and less effective, which hinders combat and therefore the rewards you obtain. I would love o see them patch in a new control scheme, but think it is unlikely. I would strongly suggest that this is a fantastic game to play but worth renting or borrowing to see if the controls resonate before making the purchase.

This is basically the mobile version of TWEWY with remixed music and 2-3 hours of extra content. It plays very well in handheld mode but is extremely difficult to play in docked mode due to the lack of traditional controls.
I played this game on the DS like 10 years ago and loved it. Today on my Switch it's no different!
The game is fantastic, but the port is only OK. The controls aren't as great as the DS version but it's still a blast to play.
Love the game. Would recommend a stylus type instrument on the switch tablet for more accurate play. The joy on controls are interesting but not great

This is a port of the Mobile game that is a port of the DS game. I use touch screen to play as I'm not a fan of motion controls. I'm fan of the look and game play, but the dialogue is a bit winded. If you are a fan of JRPG but like to try a new game play element this Is a great game.
This is a must own switch game. Fantastic story, gameplay and art style/music. Please buy this game so we can get a sequel!
The transition from mobile to switch is very good. I would have liked to see some more updates to the UI but otherwise it is very good.
... then I'm okay with that. Gorgeous art style, and great soundtrack. Just wish they would have included some standard controls. Oh well.
I hope you have a good day and I hope you have a good day and I hope you have a good day and I hope you have a good night.

I've heard that this game was all the rage when it was first released for the DS. I played it for a few hours and was not impressed. However, I had just logged 60+ hours playing Octopath Traveler which is an excellent RPG!

The World Ends With You is an RPG originally released on the Nintendo DS. Square Enix decided to release this many years later on the Nintendo Switch. The game is an RPG which takes place in Japan. It's a cult hit, and some of the characters from this game later appeared in other Square Enix games (Kingdom Hearts for instance.) The star of the show is this game's soundtrack, one of the best you'll hear in gaming. Only complaint I had is that this game doesn't allow a 'pro controller' to be used while playing on a TV (the Switch version has been retrofitted to allow the 'touch controls.') Still with all this said, the game is well worth playing.
Great game and the controls are simple to learn. Funtime playing

The World ends With You is Squaresoft at their finest. Nicely updated sprites, the old incredible music that includes a remixed version to keep things fresh, a co-op mode that is great to play with a friend, and an entirely new chapter at the end of the game. If you like JRPGs, TWEWY is a unique experience you should not miss out on.
I couldn't get into the DS version because of the dual screens, so I was excited to play this version. I'd highly recommend this game, just not the motion controls.

This was one of those titles that Ive enjoyed on the Nintendo DS. Quite the surprise that Square-Enix and Nintendo would bring this game over to the Switch. Hopefully people get to enjoy this game the 2nd time around.
This is a fantastic RPG. Own of my all time Favorites. Is this a Good Port... Not really. But it is still a must own game for the Nintendo switch. If you like RPG's check this one out.
This was a game I played a lot on the original DS. I did not expect it to be ported to the Switch but I am glad it was. The motion controls added to the game is a nice bonus.
the original game on the ds was amazing. this is a remastered version of the ported phone game. its not the same but still good. way overpriced at $50

This game was originally released on the Nintendo DS and was one of the best games to come out near the end of that platforms life. Since then the game has been ported over to iOS and android. This game has a great story. The lead character is trapped in a game that he must win or face deletion. The characters are well developed. Collecting and leveling up all the pins(weapons) in the game can become a rewarding obsession. This edition is the definitive version. It adds a brand new character. The graphics have been updated from the ds version and look great on a big screen tv.

2K did an absolutely and completely poor job both developing and putting this game out. The core gameplay and graphics are ridiculously inferior to any big name game out out this year. 2K has lost my trust with product quality. Completely regret buying it and should have kept WWE2K19.
Great graphics, and a wonderful video game!!!!!!!!
Pre-ordered this for my son. The graphics are great, and he loves it.

EA must be spread pretty thin when it comes to this franchise. While the gameplay itself is enjoyable, the customizability does not get the support it deserves and also the endless frustration with EAs attempts to milk those micro transactions out of you!!! If I am paying full price for a game, give me all of the content!!! This game will also lock up and glitch out at inconvenient times, this was both on an older and newer game console.

Here we have another awesome port for the Switch. This version does have slightly upgraded visuals (not as good as PS4/Xbox but thats to be expected). It also comes with the Artorias of The Abyss DLC. For Dark Souls veterans this is a welcome port as you can play Dark Souls anywhere. For new players this is a great way to get introduced to the Souls series as it is the complete package for Dark Souls. Gameplay wise Blighttown has ZERO frame rate issues whatsoever. The games plays wonderfully on the Switch at a very steady 30fps even in Blighttown. Also the graphics and visuals were much better than anticipated. Online also works well. Servers appear to be pretty stable, and I have noticed little to no lag when playing online with others or when invaded. Overall its a great port for the Switch & I highly recommend it to Dark Souls veterans as well as newer players who want to try it for the first time.

So Im completely new to Dark Souls, but its my boyfriends favorite game, so I was reluctantly talked into playing it. Its tough. Mind numbingly tough at times, but simultaneously one of the deepest and most interesting games Ive ever played. It takes time to learn everything, but once you do, its one of the best games you will ever play.

Do you like Dark Souls? Would you like to be able to play Dark Souls anywhere, anytime? Then you will like Dark Souls on Switch. It's an incredible game on a hybrid console. It runs much more smoothly than the original release back on 360/PS3. The visuals look great too, though not quite as good as the remastered PS4/Xbox One versions. My only gripe is the poor sound compression. The audio isn't as great as it should be in certain instances.
decent game, not as hard as everyone makes it out to be. I didn't expect to grind in this game, its not a lot, but more than expected.
Seeing how the switch doesn't have access to the patches like the PC does, this is the best option for playing Dark Souls on the go
Not bad, not great. Not awful. Its right there in the middle.

Don't be afraid to get help from a guide! Despite what the 'git gud' meme and hardcore Souls community say, if this is your first experience with Dark Souls don't be afraid to look up some things online. You don't want to spoil the whole game so don't go watch an entire Let's Play or read a walkthrough, but the game really explains very little to you. Use a guide to learn a few mechanics and find a few items, then trust that the game has given you all you need to beat that 'unfair' boss. With practice and patience, anything is beatable. Only misses out on 5 stars because of a higher barrier to entry and, mostly, because of the poor audio quality on Switch. You learn to live with it, but the sound should be better. Fantastic game and I'm glad it finally made it to the Switch!

I have never played any of the Dark Souls games (except Bloodborne) but I knew what to expect going in. This game is made to be challenging for action/adventure/RPG game fans. Between the beautifully grotesque atmosphere and fantastic tight controls, this game is worth playing. It is hard, and you will die. But if you like a challenge, get this.

Dark Souls is an amazing game and having it on the go is even better. It runs smooth and delivers a great experience. Nothing has changed content wise, so don't except anything to be different this time around. If you love Dark Souls before, you'll be happy visiting this old friend.

Its been 5 months since Dark Souls Remastered was released to current gen consoles, not that Ive been counting. Im relieved to say the switch version was not a long waited disappointment. Visually its an improvement from the x360 version. Its not in 4K running at 60fps, but unless youre looking at a side-by-side, the differences doesnt really take you out of it. Sound quality has been compressed but not enough to dampen my experience. The controls feel fluid and responsive. I have big hands, so Ive been using the pro controller. Using the joy-cons still works just as well. I dont think motion controls have been added. I think the portability aspect is perfect for this game. If you need to grind for souls with the tv on in the background. Or have one more go at the boss before work. Playing undocked still looks just as good, if not better, docked. For newcomers, Dark Souls is a game about patience, risk and reward. And I think the portability aspect will make you wanna come back and try...and try...and try again.
Highly recommended...cant wait to finish it one of the best in the series and sooo much fun on the switch
Ok game haven't fully played through yet but seems ok.

I wanted to check this game out since Ive heard slot about it. I knew it was supposed to be hard but didnt think it would be that bad. Its a very challenging game but if you enjoy open world youll like this.

Been waiting for this game since January, and it finally showed up on Switch. Definitely a must have for Switch owners who have never played the game, despite its flaws, like only being 30 FPS as compared to the other versions on PS4, XBOX One and PC.
This port is great for mobility but does not work as well as any of the other ports, also the audio is highly compressed.

I also purchased Dark Souls Remastered for the PS4 and it looks and runs much better. But, if you want to play Dark Souls while on a plane, train or automobile, this is what you need to get. Still Dark Souls.

First the bad, there's frame rate drops, especially in blight town if you played it before you know how annoying this was. The good, is that if you wanted to play dark souls on a airplane or trip then this is perfect. Haven't had the chance to play online yet since you need Nintendo Online for that but it's not deal breaker.

Good game, but the audio quality on this port is terrible and compressed, much worse than on the other consoles. You also can't swap the A and B buttons, and B is confirm and A is cancel (unlike the majority of games). Both of this problems could be fixed with a patch so I'll update my review if they fix it.
A fun classic brought to the switch. Id your a fan you most likely have already purchased this game, but you can for the switch!
This game is so tough I didnt really enjoy. Only for pro gamers?

I bought this game because of all the reviews (and of course because it is on the Switch). It took forever to release on the Switch, but from what everyone is saying it is worth the wait. I have just started to play the game though, and maybe I just can't get into it, but it is HARD. Good if you like a challenge I guess.
A lot of bugs, ran into game load issues, and it just doesn't play as well. Look out if you are a huge fan cause this isn't the game you want to play then.
Dames game just with an amiibo not worth 40. Just wait for a sale.

I own all 3 Dark Souls games and so far the same thing always happens with me personally: 1. Create Character 2. Manage to Beat First 2 Bosses 3. Get Lost/Stuck and Stop Playing So far that cycle has continued with DS Remastered. It isn't so much difficult as extremely obtuse and vague, and is perfectly content letting you miss important details (I started as a Pyromancer, couldn't figure out how I could get the spell to work the first 5 hours I played, then found out I left/didn't pick up the necessary component in the tutorial area). If you're not a hardcore fan of this series, you need a game guide to progress. That said, I do enjoy the time I spend with Dark Souls. The scenery is gorgeous, and I love the lore and ambience. I'm don't prioritize framerate, so it plays perfectly fine to me on the Switch, with the added benefit of being portable.

Looks a bit dated despite being a remaster which I took a star off for. I had lag and frame problems playing this docked which led me to become suspicious. If you have a smart TV, be sure to research the settings and adjust them for better performance. For me(Samsung) I had to put it on game mode.
If this is your first time playing dark souls, beware. This game is extremely difficult and very frustrating but if you're into that, then this is the game for you.
Purchased this for my Husband for Christmas, when he opened the game case low and behold......there was no game inside. Doubt BestBuy would believe us, so i'm out 40 bucks.

This game is a wonderful casual experience of a video game that I highly recommend for anyone looking into getting to play video games for the first time. They will have a great time picking up the easy to navigate control system and will find going through levels to be a breeze while still being very entertaining. Would recommend for any age group! 4/5 not enough skeletons
GREAT GAME TO ADD TO MY COLLECTION OF SEALED GAMES
Dark Souls...hard as can be to play, and yes, YOU DIE!!!! This game was always hard to play,but always fun to play.
This game is very difficult to play. The controls are to hard to figure out and storyline is very hard to understand.
Bought for my nephew! He liked it since he likes this kind of movies/books.
Game is good....hard to play but that was expected by the programmers that made the series.

Gears 5 is an improvement to an already great game Gears of war 4. The world is semi-open, great graphics, deep story, etc. Its in my opinion worth a buy. (My review is for the single player campaign only).

I have played every Gears game made. I am a huge fan of Gears 3 and of Judgement. Gears 3 had a great story in Campaign mode and they both had excellent offline split screen verses modes that I spent hours playing daily to the point of needing to stop as I feared I got carpal tunnel. This game like 4 has no offline slit screen cooperative version. I find the graphics really not that impressive and the need to have a wide view of the action makes everything small. The play is repetitive to previous games. I have had it since it came out and am probably not half way through the campaign. Sad. They lost me.
Long time Gears fan and 5 delivers the satisfying Gears gameplay with new features and level design. Great co op experience and an overall good title from MS finally.

I can still remember the first time I played the first gears of war back on the xbox 360. Oh the memories! Here we are now with Gears 5 and so far so good. Great pacing, loads of action and a great story. Highly recommend it. A must own!
Great game! Ive been playing gears since day one, I played every one leading up until gears 5! Storyline picks up right from gears 4! Awesome storyline! awesome game!
Spending Pandemic2020 playing Gears has been a highlight. I can't understand why the reviews were so negative when the graphics are good, gameplay is fun, and it's a good story line.

This is an excellent entry into the Gears saga. Wonderful 4K HDR visuals bring to life the story. This will also play on the yet to be released Xbox Series X and will load even faster and look even better. Cant wait to see this when the console is released end of year. Highly recommend
This the best campaign in gears history! Love the open world mechanics. The story is engaging and long. Multiplayer is still top notch!!
Gears continues to be better than COD in my opinion. They don't pump them out like an assembly line and they make a great game! Very pleased again!
best game ever there is and this one doesnt fail for sure
I like the gears 4 was a good game but I didnt that was as good as the original trilogy, but this gears 5 was a really good upgrade to gears 4, and you can find gears 5 to 25 dollars which is a steal
Ive always been a fan of the series, doesnt dissapoint.

Ive been a big fan of the gears of war franchise. From the Xbox 360 to now the Xbox one Ive always loved their story modes with No other than Marcus fenix! Gears 5 along with gears 4 has been a little different with new playable characters. This time we have options to play with Kate Diaz or del. Multiplayer is great.

For those of you who have been playing since the beginning you will not be disappointed in this latest endeavor the graphics characters and plot twist will make you happy you picked it up beautiful open world and some aspects to explore just make sure that you pick up everything you need to pick up because the the enemy is in abundance LOL

The game has a campaign, multiplayer, horse mode, and the new escape mode which also has a map editor. The story is exciting and visually impressive. The game also gives background to the previous game so you can get right into the story if you're new to gears.

I bought this game and was not disappointed. I really enjoy the story telling and game play of the Gears series. If you have played any of the other games in this series this is a must have. Campaign felt a bit short but otherwise I loved the game.
I've been a fan of Gear of War since the 1st one & it gets better & better. Everything from the storyline, characters, weapons & the graphics... I recommend getting this game!

I pre-ordered this game and was so excited to play but I've been so busy that I haven't been able to start the campaign (crazy considering that it's my favorite part of the Gears games). That being said, it has great online multiplayer modes and great graphics on my 4k monitor. I can't wait to try the campaign! Try it out!

I've been an avid Gears gamer & fan for over 10 years, and I cannot wait to divulge into this glorious game that's finally arrived. The packaging is beautiful, especially since the game is included Boost, which turned out to be a pleasant surprise I wasn't expecting. By the way, I had no issues with redeeming the code to unlock the extra content that is included with this purchase!
Gears 5 is action pack fun, it now offers 60 gps on the campaign and online. Great graphics and story, must buy game.
I have played this game every free hour I get during the week and multiple hours over the weekend. Amazing!
Graphics are awesome. All Gears is the best on XbX
This is one of my favorites Xbox games 1,2,3,4,5 I got all of them there is no other game like gears of war!!!
Chapter 5 is insane. Same cog gameplay and more advanced enemies. Play on the xbox one x for true 4k heaven!!
If youre a big fan of campaign.mode then youll love this.
For an old gamer, this is reminiscent of the first Gears played on my original XBOX, only the story line is better, and the graphics are great, which compliments this franchise!
Is my Favorite franchise on xbox games system. Worth owning system for.
Very worth it. So much content compared to other games
Gears is back and better than ever get your moneys worth and grab this game
Its more gears and if you love the first 4 games there is no reason not to pick this one up

GOW franchise has always put out great games. This one is just OK. Horde features and characters were changed months after games release making players very unhappy. Horde experience is often glitchy - npcs freezing and getting kicked out of game after 40+ levels. You will get a great game playing experience, but previous Gears were better.

Gears of War 1 was the game that got me from a die hard Sony fan to the Xbox player that I am today. The franchise has always been top notch, even if there are different levels of quality from game to game. Although Gears 5 has good mechanics like previous entries, its bogged down by a travel system that just doesn't fit the franchise.
Story is cool. Multiplayer still the same. Got bored really fast even though Im a gears fan.
Adds some thing I like a lot, some not so much. Amazing graphics and controls. If you like the series you should like this one.
Excellent game, I recommend it 100%. Excellent story and excellent multiplayer.

This is the glitchiest game Ive ever played. Ive been playing the campaign with my friend across the country as its become a tradition of ours in this series and Ive never experienced so many glitches than I have in this game. For example, when you start upgrading Jack it tells you to go to the Jack menu, so I did but I got stuck in it and the only way to get out of it was to restart to the last checkpoint (as many other people have reported the same problem). When we finally beat the Matriarch, it put me in a loading screen and my friend in a cut scene. He wanted me to see the cut scene, so he reloaded the last checkpoint and it made us replay the Matriarch boss battle! There are also many times where the game will freeze for a second, especially after rolling whilst in combat and when it unfreezes, I get killed. We were playing again the other day and I was driving the skiff and kept getting stuck without being able to drive or get off of it. The only solution was to reload the checkpoint and even then sometimes he had to reload it three times for it to allow me to do anything. I have attached a screenshot of this. All of these glitches are completely unacceptable. As someone who has loved and played this franchise since the get-go I am truly disappointed how they would release this game with so many glitches. Its a shame too because it is visually beautiful and I love the new additions and storyline as well but they were obviously money hungry and didnt care about fixing the bugs before launch. Man was Turok 2 a huge improvement over the original Turok. I enjoyed the sequel on the n64 and this remastered port improves the game. Again, the game doesn't wow you, but if you remember the old game on the 64, you will be amazed at how it looks without all the fog. The draw distances have been improved tremendously. Also, getting lost when you first started was frustrating, but they have added helpful and optional waypoints if you need them. The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars is because they completely removed multiplayer from the switch version. The Xbox One port has it, but sadly there is no physical copy for that available. Still I loved Turok 2 on the n64 so this took me back and with improvements making this worth playing. Thanks to Best Buy and LRG from bringing a physical copy to retail.

I was excited for this sequel since playing the first. However, there are some flaws. There is no option to play 2 vs 2 privately. I don't like the switching character feature on solo play, should have just given you the option to play as one character with a slightly different kitchen layout for solo play. You cannot use another mii account when playing 2 or more. Gameplay has some bugs like items getting stuck or characters disappearing completely. The campaign story is very short, the first game had more stages. You could finish the main game in a weekend. Hopefully the upcoming dlc will fix these issues or add more features. If not, I'm afraid the replayability of this game will be non-existent even with online play.

Great sequel to its predecessor. Overcooked 2 added new features that improve upon Overcooked. First, players are now able to toss raw ingredients to one another over a significant distance, hastening the ever need to stay ahead of the orders. You can also play with other individuals via internet connection, though I honestly have not used this feature this far. I did however, play this game with my 11 year old niece and she loved it. Also, the overall chaotic nature of the game is entertaining to watch, even if not actively playing. Overcooked 2 is a game that brings together all ages and skill-ranges of individuals. This game is easy enough that one can pick up the controller and quickly learn and enjoy its gameplay, while gradually adapting to the progressive difficulty of new levels.
The co op is so hilarious, I cannot believe it. Do not play this solo, it's not fun that way. Play as a family. You will laugh until you pee your pants.

What a great game. No matter what age you are you can have so much fun with Overcooked 2. It gets very challenging as you go further into the game, and you get to test how fast your team work skills are. Great buy

The first overcooked was a pleasant surprise. It's production values were a bit low, but it was a quality game and quite simply one of the best co-op experiences available. The second game is better in just about every way. The production values are much higher and the new mechanics are fun. The only issue is the game was a bit easier, however they recently added more goals to really push the player to work harder, so i guess you could say that's been fixed. All in all if you're looking for a great co-op game or you loved Overcooked 1, Overcooked 2 is definitely for you.

Because it seems like Ubi changed Breakpoint so much more between their previous titles (inc. what some refer to as a cookie-cut Wildlands, but 'worse'), I'm going to provide an outline of the gameplay and mechanics, rather than a comparison of previous Ubi / Clancy titles. Suffice it to say, I'm a vet Ubi / Clancy player (& Clancy book reader), so I already like the stories, but this review isn't about the story (no spoilers, lol), only the gameplay and mechanics, which will be unbiased, so you can come to your own conclusions about it. I also played the beta, but this isn't a comparative of the beta, nor what they should have added / took away from the final release... only about the current PS4 version of the game (which I believe is 1.02, if I remember correctly). FOREWARD To those who either regret purchasing games like this, or have nothing but complaints about games... (1) There's a reason (beyond final bug testing) many game makers provide an open beta; start making use of this option to form an opinion before you buy the release; and (2) Even with a few bugs ironed out of a beta, new games seldom come out wrinkle-free... if your opinion is based solely on these new-launch wrinkles (every time), then you might as well stop playing games. GAMEPLAY & MECHANICS - A LOT of Gameplay Details I've heard a lot complaints about this game dropping your allies (something that the Ubi / Clancy games aren't know for), but the irony is that I think most people who are complaining about this have never read a single Clancy book. Some of his books involve groups (Rainbow Six) while others do not (Jack Ryan); and Jack has allies that come and go. Breakpoint has struck me as a game which is following the path of 'The Empire Strikes Back', where we're finally seeing the dark side of this world... all alone... heavily out-numbered and out-gunned. Without giving anything (else) away, from what I've seen of the beta and official story, this looks to be a very promising story; if you don't like stories in games and are only playing for the 'hack and slash' or PvP aspect, I don't think this is the title for you. In addition to the immersive story, there is also a gear and character level system (which meshes together to determine your 'combat rank'). Between the loot / gear drops, crafting system (which for an FPS, is quite immersive), collection system, optional non-guided system (e.g. you can disable all mission / objective hints and find things on your own), open world (which isn't as 'open' or wide-spread as Wildlands; making traveling and missions much better), and a classic-feeling (but re-designed) driving / vehicle system, this new title seems to be more overwhelming (in detail and options) that people give it credit for. From a new generation gamer perspective, I can understand the criticism, but as both a VERY old-school gamer and one who has a little experience coding and producing audio, Breakpoint has (so far) proven to be a well thought-out and immersive experience; speaking purely from the perspective of enjoying the gameplay and mechanics (since I haven't had enough time to form a review of the story); and to elaborate on that perspective, it seems like Ubi has taken slices (e.g. mechanics) from Blacklist, GRAW, Far Cry, Wildlands, and systems now specific to Breakpoint to make this game. - Realistic Movements Meaning that when your character stops, it isn't a sudden / instant motion like older games or PvP type action games, rather there is some character swaying and what some might describe as 'clumsy', but is in fact much more realistic (if your only interest is PvP or instant controller / character response, you'd be better off with a different game; how about Fortnite, Modern Warfare, or Black Ops?). These realistic movements extend to being hurt (via limping) and sliding / rolling down the sides of mountains (if you try to run too quickly or run out of stamina). Since the animations are made to simulate an actual movement / action experience, they can seem clumsy, slow, or 'clunky' to some... but I've found that they merely take a little getting used to, and enjoy the experience of how a person would actually reacted in the field. Is it perfect? No. A few of the movements could be ironed out a bit, but beyond that, the movement is everything I'd expect it to be. Thinking back as far as Far Cry 2, Blacklist, and GRAW, (many titles which I still own and have played again to compare to Breakpoint) Ubi seemed to incorporate more focus on 'realistic' movement than other games; where the first title that came to mind in typing this is Blacklist. As time has gone on, it seems like this is a strong focus point for Ubi game titles, so it shouldn't be surprising to see such 'clunky' (lol) movements in Breakpoint. - Detailed TacMap & Menu System If I had a complaint, it'd be that navigating the menu is a bit slow, but given all of the detail provided in the menu, it is understandable why it is so slow (I suppose Ubi could re-code or re-design this a bit in the future to make it a bit snappier though). That being said, there is a LOT of detail in the menu. Among the many menu features, you have an instant drop in / out system, a very nice / detailed map (which is smaller than Wildlands, but as detailed, or more-so, than Far Cry 5), a detailed inventory / gear-level system (VERY much like The Division, if not 'cut' from it), a fairly diverse class / skill tree system (again, like The Division, Destiny, or any other MMO-structured game), an objective board (which takes a bit to get used to navigating), an in-game store (which is like Wildlands and other games, that provides both a rewards / crate system and a non-intrusive microtransaction type system; giving players the option to 'buy' their game progress), and a LOT of in-game settings (on par with the settings one might find for a PC). ***Menu System Hint*** The whole menu is navigated via your left control stick (like a mouse cursor), and I've found that it is MUCH easier (and snappier) to hit the Options button (as opposed to the touchpad) and use the control stick to navigate the menu, instead of using the trigger buttons to switch tabs. - Detailed Graphics More detail to the character (despite complaints over initial character design / customization), the environment (inc. weather effects and lighting), and item textures. The one, odd feature I find is the transitional lighting between indoors and out. While I get the effect they're going for, the result of the lighting 'balance' (we'll call it) is just 'off'. You'll have to play or watch some YT reviews to see what I mean. - Realistic AI Contrary to common complaint, the AI isn't 'dumber', but (I feel) more realistic. Using a simple example, let's say you and I were playing a game of paintball and I took a shot at you from a distance. Now, if I hit you, (without dealing a 'critical shot'), you should be able to get a rough idea of where I shot from by both the sound and where I hit you. If you have nearby allies, they might even see movement or 'gun smoke / flash' (in a realistic scenario) in the direction I shot from. This means that you and your buddies will either carefully head towards the last area you saw me, or take cover from that direction and fire back. If you decide to track me, depending on your RL skills, you may be able to track me from my last location or can guess where I might have relocated to and try there. Regardless of your strategy, you'll have one... and so do the AI (depending on their skill / level).; it's not that their strategy is 'dumb' (at least, not in every instance, lol; and certainly not if you're playing on anything harder than the normal difficulty). In several instances, I've seen the AI react in different ways, depending on how I chose to approach them. Drones and machinery, on the other hand, are a beast. Not only are their movements harder to predict (if not impossible) over human AI, (inc. an erratic-ness about them), but they each have a strength and weakness, each of which you must (or should) figure out for yourself. - Realistic Damage and Combat I've seen a LOT of complaints regarding how a Lv10 character can kill a Lv100+ AI with a single head-shot, but if discovered, that Lv100 becomes a bullet-sponge. Again, let's use a RL example. If you're a lightly-geared soldier going up against something of a 'Juggernaut' caliber (e.g. a VERY heavily armored enemy soldier), you should be able to kill that soldier with a single shot to the head (or, like in Breakpoint, one shot to damage the helmet and one shot to kill), regardless of how much more powerful that soldier is than you; a head-shot is a head-shot. On the other hand, if you tried to bring that soldier down with rounds to his armor, you might be there for a minute... and if that soldier is more skilled than you, it might be only a matter of seconds before you're brought down (lol); regardless of your own gear or tactics. When attempting to hide from hostiles, the enviro-camo is nice, being able to throw dirt, mud, or snow over yourself, and adds a nice 'guerrilla' type tactic to the battlefield. - PvP Gameplay This doesn't strike me as a game designed with PvP in mind, although that type of gameplay IS available. It reminds me of The Division, in that the game mechanics were NOT designed with the snappy control that a PvP'er might be more used to (or prefer), but it does have a tiered reward PvP system like so many PvP games out there have right now. Between the controls, animation, and story, this game should provide a solid experience for any solo or co-op players out there... but for those looking to play this game solely for the PvP experience, I think you might be disappointed... especially if comparing Breakpoint to other popular titles out there. - Requires a Connection to Ubisoft's Servers I've heard that there have been issues with connecting to the Ubi servers; and that it's required to play th

I purchased the $60 version for the ps4 after playing the open beta a week ago. The amount of bugs in the game is so disappointing. There were fewer bugs in the beta. The three main issues I had: player movement, enemy AI and cutscenes in the first HOUR of gameplay. When you move the left stick up your player's cuts in and out of walking and jogging, same in a crouch. Sometimes when you aim in crouch you stand up for no reason. When you log out and load in, on the ps4, it takes almost 2 minutes for your weapons to load and enemy NPC's to load in. In one cutscene by the lake with the guy and the daughter I had enemy NPCs surround me in the cutscene and then after it ended I was Kia. You guys have the audacity to charge $120 for one of the versions and still do microtransactions for things THAT CAN IMPROVE YOUR WEAPONS there not just cosmetic microtransactions. This game has so much potential but I didn't pay $60 to do your bug testing for you. I'll be posting this review everywhere else because people need to no you put out such an unpolished game. These issue I had didn't even happen in the beta, so I don't know how your game got worse on launch.

Majora's Mask is one of the most unique games in the Zelda series and is definitely worth playing for any fan of the series. This version makes a few gameplay changes compared to the original N64 edition, but the basics are all faithfully restored.

One thing that becomes an issue over time is the longevity of the great gaming titles. Luckily backwards compatibility is there to save games in the short term. Nintendo thoughtfully re-released Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask on the 3DS and retained all of the great aspects from the original titles.

Available games in this compilation: Pac-Man (1980) Galaga (1981) Dig Dug (1982) The Tower of Druaga (1984) Sky Kid (1986) Rolling Thunder (1987) Galaga '88 (1988) Splatterhouse (1988) Tank Force (1991) Rolling Thunder 2 (1991) Pac-Man VS. (2003) Pac-Man Championship 2 (2018) This is a very good compilation with Pac Man VS. and Championship 2 having 2 player modes in addition to some classics like Pac-Man and Galaga. If you are a fan of these old school arcade classic games or if you enjoy the new modern style of Pac-Man Championship you will love this collection on Switch. Having these titles portable is something I could not have imaged back in the day.

The reason I purchased this is the Pac-man games, mainly the original Pac-man game, Pac-man was may favorite game back in the 80;s I was able to get to the 6th key which was my best game, after playing the original game on the Switch it's an excellent copy of the arcade version, all the patterns work exactly like they did back in the day, even the hiding place is there. Now Pac-Man Championship version I wasn't sure about at first cause I never played it in the arcade version, but it takes Pac-man to a whole new level, more like Pac-Man on steroids! I fell in love with it after a while it's a the best Pac-Man game I've played and that's from someone that grew up loving the original Pac-Man. For the other games Dig-Dug, Splatter House, Rolling Thunder I & II, Tower of Druaga, Tank Force, Sky Kid, Pac-Man vs. and let us not forget the two Galaga games is just as I remember it for me arcade, I mean the sound and the graphics are the same from the arcade. I did not care for Sky Kid even back in the arcade from the late 80's and during the 90's, I think the one I like the best is Rolling Thunder II you can tell from the artwork from the game that the old pinball machines had an influence on Rolling Thunder II this one held my attention more that the others. Splatter House is my second favorite but a little more difficult than I remember but that's okay I going to really get into this one more, I had this one on my old Sega Genesis and I was so much better cause it gave you unlimited lives. But Let us not forget Pac-Man Championship Edition is clearly the best game in the bunch, this whole bundle of games I really like cause it brings me back to the days that you could go to the arcade and just spend one quarter per game, so I had a great time with a few dollars and could spend a hour just getting away from everything.

I recently purchased NAMCO Museum for my father who is an old-school, retro gamer. As he travels a lot for business, he only has free time to play games while in the air or on the train, so he has been a portable gamer for some time. Every generation of console I buy him NAMCO Museum and I was delighted that it was finally released for the Switch. Now my Dad can play Ms. Pac-Man and Galaga everywhere!
I really like this game. I mean it's Pac-Man along with other classics. HIGHLY recommended.

I've never owned a copy of Namco Museum and felt like it would be a good choice to pick up this version. Considering how dated these games are, I find them enjoyable in short bursts. It's awesome to get the chance to play these games. PacMan Championship is a nice addition as well but I found myself liking the 1st more.

Pac Man is a nice extra, but for me the best game in this collection is Splatter House. It is the first time we have seen this arcade game in a console release done properly. It has a beautiful border and scanlines. There is a good variety of games also.
Good compilation. Mainly bought for Splatter House but will enjoy the rest.

Awesome collection and all the games are Arcade Roms. Theses arent the typical nes rims that I always seem to see. A great collection. Splatterhouse Arcad version alone is worth the price of admission.

This collects the Namco Museum collection with Pac-Man Championship Edition 2+ and is a pretty great assortment of old classic games. You have your obvious stuff like Pac-Man, Dig Dug, and Galaga, along with Splatterhouse, Sky Kid, Rolling Thunder 1 & 2, The Tower of Druaga, and a few others. It's a bit odd to see games like Mappy, Xevious, and the Pole Positions missing, but the assortment here is still good and I imagine Bandai Namco has plans for those in either another compilation or as DLC. Regardless, this is highly recommended for old school gaming fans, especially on Switch. It's like having a little arcade available on the go.

In every version of Namco Museum that I own, the single constant is that PAC-MAN and Ms. PAC-MAN are always present. This is the first time when Ms. PAC-MAN is absent and its absurd.

I know its supposed to be a remake of an older game but for the price you pay for everything the game/setup couldve been a lot better. Even though Pac-Man is a classic they shouldnt of used the same classic graphics from the early 1980s. It looks exactly like it did 40yrs ago when you were playing it in an arcade. For the price you pay for a Nintendo switch they could of put some more effort into their product.

If you want the classics and don't own them anymore this isn't a bad collection. However, if you already own them and you are buying this game for Pacman CE 2 like I did... You might want to look up a video before you do. All the charm of the first CE is gone. It isn't easy to tell were you need to go and the maze isn't split with changing sides. You bounce off ghosts until they for a single ghost that can harm you. The bomb no longer gets rid of them and only transports you to the center of the maze. Forget power pellets... You just wait until you get to a maze that will allow you to eat the ghosts and pacman eats the chain the moment you catch just the lead ghost in the chain. There are annoying jump points and some mazes are so riddled with them that it is more annoying than fun. Namco needs to go back the the first CE to see what made it fun. I'm rather disappointed in this purchase, but I guess it could be worse.

i love the older rpgs on the pc. i was excited to play bg/bg2 when they announced the console release (especially since i've heard bg2 is one of the best rpgs ever) as i haven't played them in the past. i'm still playing bg1 and haven't gone to bg2 yet. however my thoughts on this so far is that the game is great- especially if you are familiar with the elements of desktop rpgs (d&d, etc). but i can't deny that the game would be better on a pc with the use of a mouse and keyboard rather than the console controller. this isn't the fault of the game- it's just what it is. i would definitely recommend picking this game up as you will likely enjoy it (again, if you are a fan of rpgs).

I returned this game before opening. I had a 2 Baldur's Gate games for the PS2, both of which had 2 player options. I hoped that this one would also, but it does not. It does have online play, but that is not what I was looking for. Too bad, I really enjoyed the PS2 versions. To get both names for 1 reasonable price is a good deal if you want 1 player or to play online. If 2 player is not important to you, I'd give it a try.

This is more about the marketing and not the game itself. I returned this game unopened and untested when I saw it was single player only. Nothing from Skybound games ever seemed to disclose that it wasn't a co op or online eligible game. Myself and apparently a lot of others from what I've seen, were also unsatisfied. This is not the same game that was a co op game on PS2. It's a port of a PC game.

JRPGs aren't known for their 'western' visual/audio entertainment budget, so if you're going into this expecting ground-breaking graphics and a whole mind-blowing JRPG experience, you'll be disappointed. However, if you're into JRPGs and you already know what to expect, this will fit the bill like a glove. So you might wonder, then, why I've stated this is the most complete JRPG ever. It's quite simple, really: there are virtually no JRPGs that provide an endgame that encourages you to reach the maximum level. Many JRPGs have a sort of 'plateau' at which point you've become so powerful, you can do whatever you have to. Grinding to lvl 99 or whatnot is just for fun. Not with DQXI it isn't. My advice to you? When the credits roll, go right back in. You're not even close to done.

After a handful of spinoff titles and a Japanese-only release for the tenth game, Dragon Quest XI marks the return of the iconic JRPG series after several years since it's ninth installment on the Nintendo DS. You are the Luminary, a hero of prophecy. However, there are those who do no see your presence as beneficial to the world, and thus begins a perilous adventure to fulfill your destiny against mounting odds. Along the way, you'll assemble a party consisting of a reformed thief named Erik, twin sisters Veronica and Serena, and many more. Combat in DQ11 will be somewhat familiar to returning fans, it's still turned-based, but now with the option to freely run around the battleground as you pummel slimes and other beasts. A revamped skill system allows you to customize your party to your liking, favoring preferred skills/weapons over others in order to obtain powers and abilities ahead of others. Much like the eighth installment way back on the PlayStation 2, the game features full voice-acting, giving the game a kind of medieval fair-like vibe. If you're a fan of the series, you will not be disappointed with this entry.

My expectations were very high for this game, since Dragon Quest VIII is one of my all-time favorites for the PS-2. It was a beautiful, easy-to-play but challenging game. Dragon Quest XI is all that and more! I'm no young fan boy; I'm 66 and have played video games since 1973. Few games draw me in as much as this one does. The atmosphere, the characters, the often silly-looking monsters, many side quests, the easy leveling-up and skill grid, I only stopped playing after 4 hours because I just had to eat. If it's anything like DQ-8, I'll be spending a lot of days wearing out my controller!

I last played a Dragon Quest game on PS2 with Dragon Quest VIII (one of my favorite games on PS2) and this was just as great, if not better. If you enjoy traditional style RPG's with a great story and fun gameplay, you'll want to play DQ11. I put in about 100 hours finishing the story and then going back to complete all sidequests and enjoyed every minute of it. The game can be a bit too easy at times, but you do have the option to handicap your experience, by choosing various options (tougher enemies, not being able to purchase equipment, etc.) when starting a new play though

It's been so long since we got a AAA turn based JRPG stateside on a home console. I've truly missed this style of gameplay. The grind if you want, blast through if you want style is definitely my jam. The graphics are great and will hold up years down the road. The music is good, if a bit repetitive. Might be a nitpick but I'd love the option to stream other music especially during long grind sessions. The Fun Size Forge mini game is great and way more intuitive than I expected. 30 hours in, the story is pretty much the same as all JRPGs which is both a blessing and a curse. They don't go too crazy, needlessly complicating it, however most of the plot twists have been fairly predictable. The one exception is pretty early on which I'll not give any spoilers to. Overall, it is great to see Square Enix on their A-Game again.
One of the best purchases I've made for the PS4, if you are in to jrpgs, you will likely love this game. Good graphics, gameplay, and a lengthy story. A must have!

This is a very high quality JRPG, and has just about everything I would want, but its hard for me to get through this game because of my own bias and I knew this when I started it but I just wanted to give this series a try. I don't like full on mid-evil fantasy settings, so I normally avoid every game that uses this setting but I really wanted more JRPGs to play so I picked it up because it looks so good. Everything from scenery, animations, sound, gameplay, difficulty, contents is excellent, but if there is one thing I don't like besides my own bias its the music.

I've been a Dragon Quest, or Dragon Warrior as it was known back then, fan since the first game back on the NES. And while it was never super huge here in the US as it is in Japan, it's still got a cult following. DQ5 was the best the series has been...until now. DQ11 is simply fantastic and a must have JRPG for any fan of the genre. I'll likely pick this up on the Switch as well once it comes out.

Currently in my mind based on recent relevant game releases by SquareEnix Dragon Quest has surpassed the Final Fantasy Series. It has stayed with its foundation and is developed from it's strengths. Balanced story and great dynamic animation and you'll enjoy it for hours on end. Being that I'm a big fan of the Final Fantasy series, 15 was decent but seemed unfinished compared to Dragon Quest XI.

I used to play JRPGs almost exclusively. I'm not sure, at some point either they started to change, my tastes started to change, or both. I just found myself not enjoying them as much as I used to. Not only did I stick to Dragon Quest XI to the end, I put over 100 hours on it completing post game content. I will have to say, the story was so riddled with tropes that it almost became a parody of itself, but the overall design of the game was great and combat was enjoyable (if not a little too easy). If you remember the golden era of JRPGs (SNES and Playstation era), you'll find a lot to like here. Recommended.
This is a great and charming JRPG , a very whimsical and charming world.

I was skeptical about this game at first because jrpgs in recent years haven't been as great. Dragon quest XI is a very traditional style jrpg that does everything right. It's an excellent throwback to the golden years of the genre with a top notch turn based battle system. My only complaint would be the sometimes cringy voice acting, but it's easy to overlook when everything else is of such high quality. Much better game than FFXV as well.
only playedabout half way through. Pretty easy on normal mode on so far. Heard there is a difficulty spike later on.

DQXI is very much a traditional JRPG, so if you're not a fan of older-style, turn-based RPGs like Final Fantasy VII or Xenosaga, this game is not for you. For the rest of you, this game has tons of charm, humor, and a nice cast of memorable and likable characters.

I've always wanted to get into the Dragon Quest series, but never found myself diving into the games--that is, until the 11th installment of Dragon Quest came out. I'm immediately thrown into a new yet familiar looking world thanks to artist Akira Toriyama--famed illustrator of the Dragon Ball series. There's quite of lot of places to see and new characters to meet. Gameplay-wise, it's a very traditional turn based JRPG. Random encounters are a thing of the past! While in the overworld, I can run, ride, and helm my way around an area all without getting into a monster battle. However, when I do find myself in encounters, it's all familiar territory--some battles even providing a good challenge. The dialogue can be a bit cheesy and the accents seem to tire after a while, but it's charming. Can't wait to play more!

This is my favorite of all the Dragon Quest games! Players of the series will argue, perhaps, as Eight, One and Seven were all incredible entries. This game though... just flows. It never misses a beat. Seamless cutting between action and story, scenes of drama and fights that blend perfectly. Characters to hate and fall in love with. It's all here. Oh. Gameplay. All of it is perfect. No kinks. Graphically amazing. Swapping characters and equipment mid battle is a breeze. This is the most accessible Dragon Quest yet. A must play.

I can't believe I have not been loving this series for years now. This game requires exploration and mental mapping to a degree that no other series really approaches nowadays. This game (and series) is also a testament to aesthetics. The enemies are silly looking and have names based on puns and silly word combinations. Despite this, when the game wants to get serious, you buy into it fully because it stays within the boundaries of it's reality. the same goofy eyed behemoths can be made to look menacing or threatening by just changing the context around them. The total length of this long game is also staggering compared to what is acceptable nowadays. Love it!

Well known for being an awesome series of great JRPG's and artwork of Akira Toriyama, this one is the exception, so far so good, it has vivid colors, great scenarios and lovely characters, its a must have for any RPG lover.

So stunning graphically that for the first time I can recall my ps4 actually had to stop and load for a few seconds while I was walking into one of the bigger towns. The monsters and even most bosses can be put down without much effort, so even though I know there are mechanics the game provides to make my team more powerful I honestly have no reason to take advantage of them. I have not yet completed the game but the story so far is kinda weak and generic compared to something like the golden age of Final Fantasy. The characters have somewhat interesting personalities but so far there has not been a lot of character development. I can only hope this changes further into the game but to have come this far without it makes the game less attention holding. All that being said if you are looking for the babies first RPG experience (new to RPGs) or just miss that classic line up beat em up game play, you could definatly enjoy this.
This game is an amazing turn based JRPG experience! The story is great, the music is good, and the graphics are stunning!
If you're a fan of JRPGs from the 90s you'll probably like this game.
I love it! Classic RPG, no frills, huge world, standard battle system, polished to a sheen. Love it!
This game is perfect for people looking for an old school turn based rpg. Lovable cast and the story is going good so far.
Very good game tht uses old shool turn based fighting. Cant stop playing.

I've always liked Dragon Quest games and have been playing them a long time, 8 has been my favorite of the series. This one is right there, however I've never really liked the voice acting in them ans this one is no exception. Not quite sure the direction they were given but it hasn't ever been that great. Maybe it's just me. Other than that I haven't had more than 10 hours and it's pretty addicting outside of my minor annoyance. The world is beautiful the combat is traditional with some flare and it's fun if you like JRPGs. There seems to be a lot to do. If you never played a Dragon Quest game this would be a good one to start with. I know they are releasing 8 as well so look out for that too.
Back to the basics, this is all I love about old school rpgs but with a fresh coat of paint. If you like old school rpgs, this is a no brainer
