While I'm a From Software newbie, having been intimidated by their previous efforts, the aesthetic and the setting really pulled me into this one. Also, I've always had a bit of FOMO with From Soft games, wanting to be in the conversation, but too fearful to try. Sekiro is a masterpiece. Is it incredibly difficult? Yes. One boss took me a literal two weeks to defeat. TWO. WEEKS! But the highs that come from finally getting that last deathblow on an incredibly tough enemy is where the addiction comes from. I finally see what all the fuss is about with From Software games - and immediately purchased Bloodborne as a follow up. If you're curious, give this a shot. Learn the system and try it. Maybe it won't completely click -- but stick with it until you beat a difficult boss. If it still doesn't click then? Maybe it just ain't for you. Me? I've just spent another week bashing my head against the Guardian Ape - and all I'm thinking about is strategy on how to take it down.

NOTE: Soulsborne vet here - 100% all prior installments - 60+ hours with this game. An excellent experience, but in my opinion cutting past the hype of a new release --- it's a very clear step back from Bloodborne and Dark Souls III. Fans are going to buy this regardless of what I say, and I encourage them to, so rather than focusing on the game's obvious strengths - let's look at it's weaknesses to temper some expectations. Sekiro breaks every rule of Soulsborne mechanically. It's control scheme and necessary play style force the gamer to lose their prior muscle memory of any of those games or they will be punished. This provides as close to a fresh experience as possible for even Souls veterans, and while the new mechanics have some definite advantages over prior ones, whether you like it better or not will come down to your own subjective judgment. For me, these new mechanics encourage too much button-spamming (get ready to break your L1s and R1s people) - something that Dark Souls and Bloodborne (I thought) were right to punish. The special attacks in this game (stabs, sweeps, grabs) are also terribly annoying because you need to react to them in specific ways, but a kanji (identical in all three cases) often obscures them, making it much harder than necessary to react. Some mini-bosses also require specific consumable items to damage, which is genuine artificial difficulty - for real this time. Much of the design philosophy in this game aligns with the black sheep of FromSoft's recent work --- Dark Souls II. There are multiple 'lifegem'-like items and a lack of truly interconnected world (fast travel is once again open from the start and most paths terminate in dead ends rather than the intricate world design of loops and shortcuts in Dark Souls 1 or Bloodborne). One 'shortcut' in this game is legitimately more insulting that the Iron Keep volcano on top of Earthen Peak's windmill (the revolving wall from the top of Ashina Castle to Dilapidated Temple). Where at least DSII could pull some impossible space lore to justify this, there is no such argument to be made in defense of Sekiro. The music is an unfortunately same-sounding disappointment after previous installments. The addition of area music is a frustrating mistake as most will likely come to find it repetitive every time the standard 'combat theme' goes off the thousandth time for a three second fight. Boss themes are made less memorable occasions by the addition of area music, and are often more chaotic this go around than actually having any thematic grace. Lastly, the main hub area has no unique theme unlike Majula or Firelink Shrine - a major departure that cheapens its significance. Lastly, the central new feature of this game - the resurrection mechanic - rarely feels like you can employ it to any sort of tactical advantage, as enemy AI often stays around your body even after you die and is still often alerted to you getting back up at ridiculous ranges. It boils down to an extra half a health bar, nothing more. The stealth mechanics and new focus on platforming are incredible add-ons in their own rights, but unfortunately provide a multitude of ways to now cheese most of the game, taking much of the skill out of actual combat and replacing it with something that, while interesting, is ultimately just less satisfying because of how easier it is to earn this way. Also, it goes without saying that the lack of character customization, multiplayer, and genuinely different stat 'builds' greatly reduces replayability. In fact, after the first playthrough, almost every pickup in the game becomes practically worthless as without more than one weapon to upgrade, all upgrade materials have literally no purpose after you max it out, which is shockingly easy this time - no Pure Bladestones here! DISCLAIMER: Despite only mentioning my issues above, I still highly recommend this game. It's by far a GOTY contender and a worthy experience for any FromSoft fan. I simply have to say that for a project with Miyazaki's direct involvement, I expected more. It definitely feels like Activision got their hands on this one.

I love Demons Souls. I love Bloodborne. I enjoyed the Dark Souls series. Sekiro is Bloodborne level of genius. This may look like Nioh, but this is not Nioh. I will say both are equally frustrating, but Sekiro does not suffer from infinite stunlocks that hampered Niohs combat. Sekiro may not feature the varied combat of Nioh, but the simplification of stances has made for less complex, but equally satisfying combat system that'seasier to master. The world created here is unique and beautiful. The bosses and enemy placements make sense and pacing flows incredibly well. Had to get use to combat based on posture and parrying, but once I got it this frustrating experience became one of my favorite games of all time. This was an annoying game in the beginning, but just like every fromsoft game, once you learn the mechanics you start experiencing the unique rewar of achievement these games provide.

I like what I've seen and played so far, but holy cow this game is challenging. I think I died more in the first five hours than I have in any other soulsbourne game. There's some enemies early on who test your sanity. There's some elements of dark souls, but it plays completely different. It's more of a stealth game first, otherwise you'll mobbed and killed quickly. When you do have a straight up fight it's all about precision parrying, timing up your enemy, blocking, using the awesome prostetic arm, and going for those beautiful executions. Can't wait to keep playing, and FromSoftware has done it again.

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is not a SoulsBorne game in terms of mechanics. It is unforgiving which is the commonality between the FromSoftware games. And your patience will be pushed to the edge with Sekiro but it is so WORTH it. Upon defeating a boss, you will sit back and relish their defeat. And then soon after you will anxiously move forward to see what awaits in the new area that has opened up as a result of the defeat of said boss. What I really liked about Sekiro is that it allows the player room to breathe compared to past games like Bloodborne or a Dark Souls game. If you're feeling pressed by an enemy, you can flip backward, dodge sideways or sometimes grapple to temporary safety. That said, Sekiro rewards you for being aggressive and having quick reflexes. Basically, you have to unlearn what you were taught from Dark Souls and Bloodborne. Your muscle memory will adjust and in no time, you will be aggressively slaying enemies that had destroyed you an hour before. The visuals of Sekiro are breathtaking. Not since Bloodborne have I been this impressed with the landscape in a FromSoftware game. If you're like me, you're going to explore every nook and cliffside that lead to secret areas. And there are PLENTY of secrets. And yes, Sekiro isn't an RPG like other FromSoftware games but you are encouraged to upgrade your side abilities which there are a lot to choose from. So, sharpen your blade, take a deep breath and prepare for an emotionally taxing adventure that will be worth the rage.

If you love these type of games then this one is a no brainer. But be aware that you'll need to forget most of what you learn in other games of the genre. Here is all about staying in front of the enemy and blocking/parrying on time in order to break their posture and do some damage. Of course this also means that you are standing in front of Front Software enemies so if you don't get good at it then expect to have a hard time. The world is amazing, with twists and turns and hidden passages and secrets. Front game worlds are among the best and this is among their best. Just be aware that it is a haaaaaard game. Get it.
The game is, and isn't like FromSoftware's previous ventures. It's fun, and as always difficulty is rough, but the payoff is huge!
Combat and gameplay better then dark souls and blood borne. Has the Tenchu stealth assassin feel tmes 10

For an old school Tenchu fan like me, this is the game I was waiting for. For veteran SoulsBorn fans, it might take time to learn the new combat system, but once you master it, you will feel like a god. You can pause, you can swim, you can jump, and while you have more freedom of exploration and movement than ever, the combat's steep learning curve can really punish you early in the game.- The progression is cruel, but fair and extremely satisfying. It is admittedly a hard game, but if you stick with it, you will love it
This game is a mixer of the the a classic game called Tenchu and from the current games of today Dark souls games in the best way, set in the federal era, love it.

Should have named it Sekiro: Shadows twice way more than twice. Super hard game. Sometimes it better to stop playing the games for few days and fight the bosses another day. Once you beat a boss you have this sense of accomplishment. Very challenging.

If you're into challenging games and feel like modern AAA releases are too 'hand-holdy' then Sekiro is a great alternative that will keep you entertained to no end. Once you manage to beat a boss, you feel a sense of accomplishment that no other game can equal.

Pros: - exhilarating combat - movement feels wonderful - (mostly) great boss fights - beautiful aesthetic - brilliant sound design - just the right level of challenge Cons: - story is a bit disappointing - less replayability compared to other From games - No multiplayer (if that matters to you) - feels a little light in terms of content Overall, Sekiro is probably my favorite Fromsoft game. One thing to note is that Sekiro DOES NOT play like a traditional soulsborne game. So if you go into Sekiro expecting souls, you might be disappointed.

The combat system of this game is phenomenal. You really have to learn how to use it in order to be great at this game. Once you do figure it out it is very exhilarating! The bosses are OK with a few stand out ones. Be aware there are a lot of repeat bosses but they do make them interesting.
You can tell this is from the makers of Demon Souls/ Dark Souls franchise. You will die alot. This game relies more on the timing than anything.

I've been a big fan of From Software games since the later King's Field games, and have loved all of them up until now. Sekiro is no exception. It is decidedly more fast-paced than the Souls games, and focuses on fast, smart, aggressive combat tactics not entirely unlike Bloodborne. The feeling of playing a shinobi with a grappling hook is perfectly realized -- by the time you reach the end of the game, you'll have honed the playstyle to a razor's edge and feel in tune with the game's eponymous protagonist.

If you're a fan of the Dark Souls/Bloodborne games, you won't be disappointed with Sekiro. It shares many similarities with the previous From Software games but has enough changes and additions to feel fresh and different. The world design is absolutely top notch, with the grappling hook ability adding a sense of verticality and depth not seen in previous Souls games. I would say the game's difficulty has been grossly exaggerated. It's definitely challenging and can take some time getting used to the complexities of the combat system but it never reaches stages of ridiculously, controller smashing hard. The bosses are all well designed, feeling tough but fair. In fact, I'd say the most challenging encounters are the few optional bosses. So if you're just looking to clear the story, it shouldn't be too much of an obstacle, with a little practice of course.

If you mastered the SoulsBourne games and are expecting to hop right in to From Software's newest game and start wrecking, you have another thing coming. I'm a SoulsBourne veteran. Hundreds of hours in all the games. The games are almost easy now and yet Sekiro destroys me. Absolutely wrecks me so thoroughly that it almost makes me regret buying the game. I spent nearly two hours on the first MINI BOSS. Not an actual boss, but a freaking mini boss. The game play is wildly different than From Software's other titles. I don't remember ever being this frustrated with any of the SoulsBourne games. With those games, beating a boss always produced an intense feeling of accomplishment and satisfaction. So far in Sekiro, beating the big bois just leaves you feeling exhausted and relieved that the suffering is over. Hardly any satisfaction or accomplishment. Very little of that SoulsBourne high that drives you forward through the punishment, craving more. When you die, you lose XP similar to the SoulsBourne games except you can't get it back. Once it's gone, it is gone for good. And if you die enough times, all the NPC's in the game suffer from a disease that then prevents many of them from talking to you and giving you side quests. It is not easy to cure this disease. Not sure if I'll have it in me to finish this game. At least the story is interesting and on the off chance you beat a boss with perfectly timed deflects, counters, and dodges, it looks pretty cool. Expect to stumble through the fights though. Now excuse me as I go relive last night's Sekiro session while crying in a corner.

Sekiro is a game that is chock full of enemies ready to cut you down. Luckily for you, and unlike the Soul series you don't have a stamina bar, so you can block with near impunity! Master the art of the parry and you shall win the day. It also looks fantastic which is a definite plus and the stealth is made all the sweeter by the fact that you sneak up and take down enemies as a ninja who wears ORANGE, dattebayo! If you haven't picked this already and don't mind the challenge (death is your constant companion in this game) it is worth the price.

From the creators of other difficult/rewarding games like Darksouls and Bloodborne comes SEKIRO.....a story of redemption as you try to save your young master. Great gameplay DIFFICULT YES but not an impossible game.....FORGET WHAT YOU KNOW/HOW YOU PLAY DARKSOULS this game is a quicker pace not as fast as Bloodborne but it takes its sword fighting gameplay up a notch no more avoiding all hits with a dodge roll. Absolutely love this game the art style looks amazing the game environment and graphics really shine and come to life.

Being made by FromSoftware, the comparisons to Dark Souls and Bloodborne were obvious. Though Sekiro does draw a lot of inspiration from those titles, it's an amazing game in its own right. This game is all about parrying and countering. Many enemies require you to break their posture before you can defeat them and mastering that is key. The world isn't as open as the Souls games but it's filled with many twisting paths and shortcuts like them. Being a FromSoftware game, it's challenging so if you're looking to breeze through a game, this ain't it. Sekiro is an amazing title for any fans of ninja based games but it's definitely not for the weak at heart.

As a souls veteran this game is not anything like the soulsborne series the combat is fluid and tight. This is a game that will challenge you to your limit and deserves multiple playthroughs. This game teaches you to learn from your mistakes and encourages you to go through so many routes be it stealth full on combat or different styles of combat and I highly recommend it to not only veterans of the soulsborne series but to newcomers as well. This game is not easy so be ready to test your own patience and skill.

The game is hard. Not really a surprise for a game from From Software, but the design goes beyond that. To begin the story flows and twist like a great mystery novel and has the player wondering. The gameplay has a steep learning curve, but once learn the combat becomes fulfilling and enjoyable. While there are few tools and fewer weapons to pull from, the open way of deciding how to play does not. Going from stealth to open combat easily. Planning how to fight or when to retreat and regroup. The is enjoyable because of its difficulty giving a sense of accomplishment when a tough part is beaten. While many of the bosses are a pain and tedious to fight. The slow and steady grinding of the fight challenges to the patience of the player. Many parts are confusing and the use of similar areas can feel repetitive. Personal I miss the ability to both aid and be aided by other players. This is a great if stressful game.

From Software is famous (or infamous, depending on your viewpoint) for putting out tough-as-nails games. I thoroughly enjoyed Dark Souls and was extremely excited to test my skills against From's new style of action-RPG. Needless to say, anyone who's used to the Souls series' turtling/armadillo approach to combat will go through an adjustment period to start facing attacks head on, as Sekiro is adamant with punishing passive playstyles. In spite of the obvious difficulty, this game shines with visceral combat and highly memorable boss encounters. There's a huge sense of progression seeing your use of healing items decrease as you learn a boss' patterns. Even aside from the amazing combat, exploration is rewarding, with tons of items to find off the beaten path. Give this one a shot - games that provide this level of fair challenge and mechanical polish are very few and far between.
GREAT GAME TO PLAY. YOU'LL LIKE THIS ONE IF YOU PLAYED THE FIRST ONE.

This is a From Software game, so you expect to see and experience the things that make their games so great. Great exploration, but this time its more vertical because of the hookshot mechanic. Interesting combat system, which you need to learn if you want to succeed. Sweet graphics. Cool story. Amazing boss fights. This is a game that gives you all the tools you need to succeed. When you die, its because you screwed up and only youre to blame.

The premise of this game is you are honor bound to obey your master in life and death. This game is produced by From Software, meaning you will die, many times, sometimes unfairly and other times because you pressed the wrong button at the wrong time. Of the SoulsBorne category, I would rate this game as the hardest and perhaps the steepest learning curve. When fighting opponents the newest mechanic from From Software is posture breaking, essentially you are attacking and parrying to weaken the stamina of the opponents allowing you to perform a death blow. The music is quite peaceful with a slightly haunting quality. The graphics are done quite well, I would say stunning. I truly felt I was in a war-torn landscape from feudal Japan. Occasionally enemies will not fully load until they are attacking you, which happened a few times to me but it is rare and you can learn where they come from. A new mechanic was also introduced that allows your character to respawn during a fight after death but you cannot do so multiple times in quick succession.

Beautiful and challenging game from Miyazaki. Ive played all the souls games plus Bloodborne and Nioh. From my experience this game is more challenging than all of those. Why? This game doesnt allow for over leveling, and theres no summoning others. Also, the combat requires precision timing and an ability to analyze the animation of moves in order to react appropriately. Beautiful graphics and level design. The skill trees and weapon upgrades are well thought out.

I am a huge Fromsoft fan. That being said I was actually concerned with this game not living up to my personal expectations. It had been years since their last release, Dark Souls 3. This game has not only met my expectations, but has blown them out of the water. The combat is smooth. The story is great. The enemy types are creative and awesome. I love this game. Another grand slam from Fromsoftware!
After much anticipation Sekiro is finally here! And does not disappoint! Amazing graphic and beautiful environments. The game is challenging and fun!
What can I say, it's hard...very hard. I know I'm a scrub with these types of games, but the atmosphere and era is amazing. Good luck!
Great visuals. Punishingly difficult. Somewhat inaccessible to gamers new to the genre, but not impossibly so.

Most games are too easy, they are designed for 12 year olds to be able to complete them with very little difficulty. Not so with Fromsoft games. They are hard. And this one is probably the hardest they've ever made. Good stuff

Although I am still only in the early stages of the game, Sekiro is already becoming an amazing spiritual successor to the legend that is Dark Souls. Veterans of that series will quickly realize that although Sekiro is Dark Souls and Bloodborne's successor, the same formula of playstyle in those games cannot be applied to Sekiro. The AI can be brutally cunning and does not allow for many mistakes. The toughness of the game may turn casual players off, but the satisfaction of overcoming Sekiro's punishing and yet visually stunning world is tremendous.
If you liked dark souls and ninjas this is the game to get, you will be immersed for hours and hours of fun!
Yeah another hit and another master beast. From software
I was hoping for more... But it's a pretty fun game. The graphics could be better.

In my view Sekiro is a decent but not great game. While far from being awful, this game does not deserve the high scores that it has received as result of the unexpected zeitgeist From Software has enjoyed for the past decade. While some aspects are fun and well presented, its shortcomings ultimately stem from From Software's attempt to combine two types of games into one, while doing neither of them very well, or at least not nearly as well as those that are top of class in each category. Sekiro is a ninja/samurai action game and it's a stealth game. While the combat is okay, it is, in my view, completely outclassed by Nioh which not only has the parrying mechanic of Sekiro, but multiple weapon types, 3 stances per weapon and dozens of moves per weapon. Sekiro tries to nail the dance of sword fighting, but Nioh executes that dance much more effectively with greater variety and a much smoother frame rate. The limited attack options in Sekiro basically come down to a game of blocking, parrying, jumping and attacking with a simple fixed combo. The challenge of the game is in learning each enemy's attack patterns and selecting the correct sequence of parries, jumps and attacks to break their posture and deliver a deathblow. When first presented this feels very challenging, but as soon as it is memorized it goes from challenging to trivialized as you learn to fight in the game's intended metronomic fashion, simply keeping the beat until you can deliver a 'shinobi deathblow' (fancy name for quicktime event) rather than engaging in dynamic combat. Because the AI is very simple, enemies rarely mix up attacks like they do in Nioh. This combat system is further marginalized by the inconsistency of quicktime shinobi deathblow. Sometimes a red dot appears when you sneak up on an enemy without them noticing, other times you can repeat the exact same scenario with no dot. The jankiness of this mechanic is demonstrated most often in the context of dropping onto an unsuspecting enemy and baiting enemies around corners-- situations in which triggering the quicktime shinobi deathblow seems at times truly random. I'm not sure if this is because the game wants you positioned in a very specific way and fails to account for what is displayed onscreen, or if the variable framerate is to blame. In an event, it creates a sort of randomizing effect to the game where sometimes I found myself missing kills I felt I had earned, and at others getting kills I felt I did not. This aspect significantly erodes notion that one can 'get gud' (or not be good) at the game. As a stealth game, Sekiro does much worse compared to the best in class, namely, Metal Gear Solid. The stealth options and AI in Sekiro are behind the original Metal Gear from 1998, and the game is so far behind the stealth mechanics of MGSV that it's not even comparable. At times enemies will spot you when you are completely out of sight and at others they will fail to notice you when you are right in front of them. Unlike Metal Gear, enemies make no changes in their behavior based on your actions. A quick assault and retreat does not result in reinforcements being called in, nor do enemies change their combat tactics or armor choices to defend against over-used attacks. This is a shame because stealth is such a vital component of any ninja/shinobi based game. It seems like a missed opportunity since From Software jettisoned the RPG elements of its previous games in order to focus on the shinobi archetype, which was them hamstrung by lackluster stealth mechanics. From Software has made a fair game, but in order to be great you can't just make a new IP that is decent or perhaps better in some regards than your previous games, you must make a game that competes with what others have done in the space you are trying to occupy. Sekiro falls short of this, but it's still a decently enjoyable game to play for a short stint. I will say that some aspects are well done and more enjoyable than From Software's previous titles. The speed of the game makes it more engaging and as always, the art direction is excellent. From Software's games are always presented with a certain serious mood and artistic design that makes them beautiful to look at and the color palette of feudal Japan is their best yet. The music and voice acting, particularly the work of Noshir Dalal, are spot on. Unfortunately, actually playing the game is not nearly as captivating as looking at it.
Sekiro is extremely challenging and recommended for veteran players of past from software games

Be prepared for potential frustration. Even as a Soulsborne veteran. While the core combat mechanics are simple enough, technical issues really hold this game back. Between mechanical enemy tracking, ridiculous hitboxes, questionable AI, and sometimes unresponsive controls, deaths frequently feel cheap. That said, if you're patient (or in my case, a stubborn masochist) the game is still worth a try. The majority of my issues with the game can be (hopefully) addressed in future updates.
The game graphics and play are amazing. I give it a 3 cause its way to hard of a game. If you like dark souls this game is for you. Just not for me.
Good game and graphics, non stop action. But very challenging.
This game is very hard. Theres no difficulty setting. Its so difficult that you forget whats happening in the story as you try to beat one mini boss for 3 hours!

I went into this game never playing a From Software title but the setting and gameplay i saw looked fantastic. Unfortunately this title is just much too hard for anyone not familiar or willing to put the hours and countless deaths into this game. It's just my personal experience, but this game is more frustrating than it is fun.
Yay samurai fighting for our life with dark souls like combat

I really wanted to like this game, but I don't. I played for a couple weeks, dredging through hours of game play hoping that I'd come to love it, but it just never happened for me. I know it's not a souls game, but I really disliked being stuck into a single play style without real room for adaptation and creative play: I found it to be very repetitive and frankly more than a little boring. I also have a kiddo, so the over the top bloodshed was a bit much for me. At least in souls or Bloodborne you are fighting monsters and things that don't really look like normal humans so when there is blood it's far less impacting. It's just a side note, certainly didn't keep me from playing, but it bugged me a bit. The arm prosthetic were all quite underwhelming. I really expected the abilities they gave you to be more useful, but they really do little good aside from tactical necessity, which just makes them another button to push instead of a fun extra weapon or tool. In the end I sold my copy and deleted the game. Really wanted to like it, but it's just not exciting to me at all.

Look, I knew going in that the latest offering from FROM SOFTWARE was going to be hard, but this is just ridiculous! (Btw, I have played & finished Bloodborne & Dark Souls). I still haven't been able to get past the first miniboss. If you're looking for an exercise in frustration & don't mind risking throwing your controller through your TV screen, go all in. Just don't say I didn't tell you so!

Great game if you love minecraft but need a little bit of a story to go with it. Portal Knights has you moving from several different biomes fighting bosses, plundering dungeons and all the RPG elements in between. You craft items for your character and can choose from three classic hero types: mage, fighter and archer. On top of all of that it is a sandbox game. You mine different resources and build things just like minecraft. Good game for kids.
One of the best things in this game is Couch Co-op play! Play it 1 player or get a friend and hand them the 2nd Joycon and get playing 2-player!
Bought for my son and he loves it, seems like a quality game that can go either young or old. Good buy.
My grandson loves this game after playing minecraft the past few years. Similarities, but different. He still plays minecraft as it has more be can do where this is an adventure. Highly recommended.

I know the Switch isn't the most powerful system out there but I feeeeeeeeeeel like maybe it could run this better. I have it PS4 as well, I picked up this version so I could play on the go and I'm not entirely thrilled with it. It still works but the draw distance isn't great and the loading is forever. If you love Portal Knights and want to play on the go, give it a whirl!
This is a great game and is immersive like Minecraft. Ive spent hours and days playing this game

Highly recommended. I am not usually into these types of games. I never got into Minecraft for sample. This is an exceptiono to that, it is an excellent game and high in value in relation to cost. I think anyone who wants 30 to 40 hours of multiplayer action will enjoy this very much.

So much fun! You wont be able to contain yourself! Also If you havent already sign up for the Best But Gamers Club and do yourself a favor of saving 20% off any new or pre ordered game! Even if you just buy a few games a year it will pay for itselve in no time!

My daughter really enjoys playing this game. She likes the experience of designing your own avatar and world. It gives you the opportunity to craft and go into multiple places to save your planet. It also allows you to use some strategy as well in crafting and attacking. You can also build whatever you want with what you have. The game lets you be creative.
Portal Knights is an RPG Lite game that plays similar to Minecraft but has WAY more you can do. For the price, it is absolutely worth it!

My 7 year old recently got a Nintendo Switch and decided to get this game instead of Minecraft (which he loved). After playing with Portal Knights, he claimed that he liked it much better than minecraft. To top it off, we got this game during a sale so paid half price for it.
Fun game to play with other half...love the art style
Its a good game. Looks like Minecraft with RPG elements in it. Must play this game. Really fun.
We haven't played it yet but it looks like good family fun!

This game is decent. It does a lot of things well, like environment variety and movement, but does things poorly, too, such as enemy variety and confusing controls/menus. Worth the $17 I paid for it with GCU, but wouldn't pay much more than that.
this game is okay I got as something the wife and I could play but the switch controls are a little janky

Pretty fun minecraft like game with more rpg like elements. The worlds are huge with a lot of planets to explore. To me minecraft is boring but this one is a little more fun somehow. Cool toony artwork style but the game seems kind of generic. The enemies seem generic too but it seems like you can build vast worlds so it makes up for it. The price is what makes it a good deal, I wouldn't pay $60 for it but $30 is not bad. There are islands floating in space and you can build huge land bridges to connect them all. It has a lot of potential but it requires a lot of time
This game kinda reminds of Mine Craft in a way but it's fun so grab it while it is on sale.
This is really a more RPG oriented version of Dragon Quest Builders. If you liked DQB but felt it was missing character leveling and a simple class system then this is the game for you. A lot of fun.
This is like Minecraft meets a dungeon crawler and its pretty fun.
minecraft style game, but you dont have to build stuff if you dont want to
This game is very much an open world sandbox type of experience. My problem with it was the lack of structure. I much prefer Dragon Quest Builder's, where you have more well defined quests.

Portal Knights on Switch is a poor port of the original game that fails to play consistently in handheld mode and docked. This doesnt impact the game play overall, though the action itself isnt very inspired. The core combat mechanics are too basic, and the building and crafting has been done better in other games like Dragon Quest Builders or Minecraft.
It's an ok game that is all one can say about this game.
I'm very happy with this Best buy purchase. I love shopping at Best buy.
This game is just a Minecraft ripoff it's a joke. Hate this game.
I like to shop at Best Buy for CDs movies and other appliances

Picked this game up for my kids cause they love minecraft. So far, it's pretty good, it has 2 player co-op/split screen, which is good if you only have one switch and one cartridge. You can build, mine, craft items and armour, fight monsters, and level up your stats.
great game very fun to play and many hours of enjoyable fucn
Great game for a 7 year old boy, he is having a blast playing with his friends!
This is a great game that is a lot of fun. Worth buying to play.
This one is a good addition to the collection, it's not as big and deeply crafted as some AAA titles, but it delivers in what it promises.
Portal Knights is like a mini MMO and Minecraft hybrid. You can play with people online, do quests, level up, and build structures. A very cool game indeed!

Portal Knights is an indie-RPG which has been released on Steam and PS4 previously. It's now available on the Nintendo Switch. Game is enjoyable and is highly-regarded. Given the low price of the game, plus the portability of the Switch, if you like RPGs give Portal Knights a spin.
its like Minecraft but a little bit different. I like the RPG element. Good game.

It was a cute game and pretty much minecraft but more adventurous? There are endless things to customize. One thing to mention is that the sound can get a bit loud when multiple things are going on at once but maybe they came out with a patch for that.
3 characters to choose from 3 different endings not for everyone
Very blah sandbox game. You can breeze through levels minutes after visiting them. Maybe that's intentional in a sandbox game but I don't care for it. Call me old school.
Great game. Fantasy life meets minecraft. This game is great for all ages. I'm 20 years old but my little brother would enjoy this game as well.
This game is very fun, but you have to spend some time getting used to it. It is a little confusing at first, but really worth it!
That was the main reason i bought was beacuse it was two players, its fun over all
This is such a fun game I have played it for hours, graphics are nice, questline to do, can buy your own island and build a house. Overall great game

It's a decent game. It has a mix of minecraft and dragon quest. The graphics are good, game controls are good as well. My only problem is with the lay out of the worlds throughout the game. Sometimes is a pain in the butt to get around. I recomend to try out the demo in the nintendo E-shop before making a final purchase.

A very fun game you will get hours of entertainment. This is one of the few games I own that I always go back to on a regular basis. If you're a fan of Minecraft or Dragon Quest builders you will enjoy this one.
Havent played this before.. started it the other night.. sucked me in. Not bad for the sale price
This is like Minecraft and World of Warcraft in one. Build up a character and slay the dragons. The kids will love collecting loot and building treasure rooms for it.

Portal Knights takes the crafting elements of Minecraft and build an actual game around it. The overall look of the game is fantastic. Some design choices were a bit frustrating, even if necessary: in particular forcing combat in the third person view. But these minor nitpicks do nothing to tarnish an otherwise fantastic title.
Okay if you like those building ports but I was not impressed. Stick to Minecraft
this game it is not bad ,it is OK to play same time
As usual, this game runs terrible on the Switch. Framerate makes it unplayable, even if you turn down all the graphic settings. It's a 10x better experience on other consoles.
really cool game for kids! my daughter love it!she love the characters!
This is a really exciting and fun action packed game, highly recommended,
I bought it because it was cheap and its an ok game.
This game is great for kids has local wifi play up to 3 players.

Portal Knights is a neat merger of Diablo-like RPG mechanics with Minecraft's blocky world + building mechanics. I didn't find anything particularly new here, but it would be a fun game for younglings who are Minecraft fans and looking for their next game.
This is a very cute game for kids. My kids love this game.
fun game for small children. Character graphic is cute enough. Map is limited with a portal to move to a different map, so you cannot really do much creative things like minecraft.
Fun coop experience with your significant other. Me and the little lady love it.

If you're already a fan of games like Minecraft, you will most likely appreciate this game even more. There's an actual plot, and it even has local multiplayer, which adds value to the game even more. Overall, good game, and highly recommend for those interested in a fairly open world type game, and if you're a Minecraft fan, definitely consider this.
A fun game, especially for the sale prices it's going for now. Worth a play!
This game is cute. Reminds me of some of my IPad games.

I saw this game on sale in store on Thanksgivings and wasnt sure that my eight years old boy would like it or not but I bought it anyway. It turned out he likes it a lot because it delivers hours of fun without too much of violence like some adults or other teen games. I would recommend this game for kids under 10 years old and of course, parents and older siblings can join in for fun too.

Similar to Minecraft but with more then enough originality to stand out as a fun co-op experience. The controls/menus are all easy to pick up and the core game play is fun. The art style and music should have been much better for a game that wants you to sink so many hours into it. All in all a fun couch co-op game that makes a good alternative to Minecraft.
Its a good game, somewhere between Minecraft & Dragon Quest Builders. The kids love it.

at a budget price this game is a really great adventure title for the switch, you can choose between 3 different characters play through multiple levels. The graphics are chibi cutsie style but the gameplay is solid and entertaining.
New game for nintendo switch its a good game for kits
The game is grate and fun for every age ... higly reccomended
Similar in style to Mine Craft. My 8 year old was able to play it and had a great time with the game play.

If you enjoy Minecraft and Dragon Quest Builders then you will find this to be fun. Like the two mentioned this is another block builder game with some rpg elements thrown in. The only issue I have is with the random biome generator. Minecraft and Dragon Quest Builders both create wonderful worlds to roam around in. Portal Knights can be a little chaotic and doesn't feel like more than random blocks placed together. You collect materials from breaking blocks and fighting monsters. You also gain exp from every activity in the game. What this does do better than minecraft is when you create your work stations they look like functional objects with more detailed geometry.
Good game with a weird concept some are going to be surprised and bewildered by.
The game has a nice look to it. It is vibrant and has charm. Thats the end of the good things. Its gameplay becomes stale too quickly and often times feels unpolished.
My son really enjoys playing this game. It's great
Not very into it yet, but so far good, and looks like it will get better
Very much like minecraft but for people like me who need goals and story.
Pretty fun games, pretty much like minecraft but with my rpg elements! Like that it has split screen for couch co-op!
This is basically mine craft with RPG elements, got this game on the cheap.
When I ran in to problems I quit playing. I will have to revisit this game once I'm done playing my other's.
It is like minecraft but you do no need to build everything from scratch, you can just loot around!
This game is multiplayer and it's a blast. Managed to get it on super sale snd in very pleased with my purchase.
Ive played this game for about half an hour and so far and has been a good game.
OMG, found this little hidden treasure in the value bin. My kid is in love with this game.
I got this because it seemed similar to dragon quest builders and I feel like it it but also as more building like Minecrafts
Get this one on sale. Would defiantly recommend using the Gamers Club discount with the Best Buy Visa.
It's a cool building game, I wish there were more classes for characters but what they got now is good.
I bought this for my son, and he really loves it! It has worked fine with no issues at all.

Amazing game for the price! Nothing to lose when buying this! So much fun and on the go? Yes! Only downfall is that the golden throne add-ons are only for PS4 and Xbox! But its either minor extras or portability and I chose portability! Playing on split screen with my husband is AMAZING AND SO MUCH FUN! Highly recommend for those that like building with RPG elements as well!
Very similar to the My Sims games for the Wii. Break things to collect items and build new items in your forge workshop.

After logging more that 200 hours in PC Skyrim, I thought there was no reason to revisit it again. I was wrong! It took me a few hours to adapt to using the move controllers, and to adjust screen brightness and controls properly, but once done in in love with Skyrim all over again. Hundreds of hours await you, and while the resolution is far lower than what I played with on pc, the game is so immersive, you'll find totaled just gawking around while in caves, or just taking in the night sky. You could easily just buy a psvr and Skyrim and justify its purchase. My wife also gets motion sickness, but she can play Skyrim for hours without problems. If you are considering getting it, Just Do It!

I've owned and finished Skyrim on my XBox 360, played it again when the 'Special Edition' came out on my XBox One, and now playing through it again with my PSVR. Despite having played this game to death, it's such an INCREDIBLE experience to play it in VR and to be ACTUALLY INSIDE THE GAMEWORLD! After starting it in VR and playing for 7 hours straight, I lost track of how many times I said 'Wow! That's awesome!' as I revisited familiar locations in the Game World. The immersion level is awesome and though many may complain about the somewhat 'fuzzy' graphic quality, the feeling of immersion and feeling like you're actually walking around in Tamriel is absolutely breathtaking. I'm actually quite happy with the overall graphic quality (I'm playing on a PS4 Pro) and kudos to Bethesda for giving players so many VR 'comfort' options so that those more prone to motion sickness can set the options to make it more comfortable. I personally have no issues with 'VR Sickness' since I've been playing with my PSVR for almost a year now, so I've disabled all the extra VR limitation settings to give myself the full experience! This is a DEFINITE MUST BUY for any current PSVR owner and also a great way for people still thinking about getting a PSVR to finally pick up a headset and experience the wonder of VR.

There are not many titles that can boast being open world and VR. This is the same game most of us know and love, but the VR aspect adds a new dimension. Personally, I find the game to be more of a technical feat than the preferred method of play. There are certainly episodes, events, and highlights that take advantage of the VR technology, but once the novelty has worn off, I do not anticipate any but the most diehard of the VR or TES fans/enthusiasts will have a lasting appeal for the countless hours it takes to play through Skyrim. Between Doom VR and Skyrim VR, on the basis they were released the same date, I would venture to say Doom is the better VR iteration, because it is a different game, designed around VR rather than a different perspective of the same game. I'm not disappointed with the purchase overall, but for my style of play, shorter sessions in a game packed with as much content as Skyrim tends to make the VR presentation less appealing.

I'll start off with I own Skyrim for ps3, ps4 and pc so that should tell you how much I liked this game. Playing in VR is INSANE! They had to scale down the graphics a little so it's not graphically as good as the remaster but you will forget all about that with in minutes of playing really. You can use move controllers or a dual shock but I would recommend the dual shock. This is not a watered down version it is the full fledged game!
This game is the full skyrim experience in vr. Its cool to explore the world in vr, but the motion controls for this game feel very weird and gimmicky

Skyrim is my only VR game that I return to after the novelty has worn off. This is the same, entire fantastic game, playable in VR, with move controllers. The graphics take a huge hit, and some balance issues come about because you can perform actions much faster than you can with a controller, but this is an incredible way to replay an incredible game. The feelings of standing by a waterfall in a cave, drawing your bow while sneaking up to a goblin, or getting to a mountain top under the stairs are incredible in VR. Especially recommended if you are used to VR and don't get motion sick. There are great movement options for people who do get sick, but they are not afraid to let you turn them all off and walk around like normal if you want, which I appreciate.
This on of the best games I ever play definitely should make 2 game

I am new to the vr experience but have played Skyrim in the past. It's definitely a fun way to play. Using the motion controllers you basically teleort which takes away from the vr experience. However, using the controller to smoothly walk kind of causes a little motion sickness. Still would recommend

I've played skyrim on ps3, ps4, pc and switch but his is an entirely new experience. The controls with the moves are a must! DS4 felt cheap but the moves make the game an unforgettable experience. The new pro patch fixes all blurriness of the previous version and you will spend hours getting lost within this world. Magic is powerful and exciting as you feel like emperor palpatine firing lightning at everything in sight. Don't buy into Reddit and negative reviews this is a must own PSVR game!

I personally love the ability to explore areas that the developers never intended you to get to but this could be a turn off to others. If you are looking for the immersion but don't want the movement bugs, the use of a standard controller works fine.

X is a series that I really enjoy, X1,2,4 are games I come back to often every year as they're fun to blast through. The collection here? It's a mixed bag. For one you don't get all the games- you have to download the rest which is immensely irritating. You buy games to not take up space on your tiny SD card, not some half and half nonsense. This is further annoying since the PS4/XB1 versions of the game come with another disc for the other half- AS DOES THE SWITCH VERSION in Japan, where it's sold together OR separate. No such options here. The second half of the collection is the larger of the two as well, setting at a hefty 6.6GB vs the first part at 2.9. As for the actual collection you do get a lot of stuff, merch pics, the ability to play the Japanese versions of games*** the anime from the PSP title (but not the actual PSP remake) and the XChallenge. (Japanese versions of the game do not have the original Japanese intros, infact Megaman X6's English intro which had japanese is entirely replaced. All commercials that had japanese have been removed as well). Nevermind changes to X4 where they have removed a 'potentially offensive scene' and darkened certain scenes to help not set off epileptic fits- something that isn't done to much more aggressive flashing in any point later in the game, cutscenes or otherwise. Sound emulation is off on the PS1 titles, it doesn't make it sound bad, but different. Sound effects seem to be much better mixed, where you can hear the enemies making noise where in the OG you couldn't. The issue is, the SNES titles (X1-3) do not save your game like the PS2 collection where it had a new screen to display your powerups and what not- it just remembers your password. So if you get the hadoken fill up etanks etc? Doesn't save that stuff. This is something they had on the PS2 collection but couldn't manage now, something the PS2 version also did was remove/lessen slow down in games- this one does not. The X-Challenge is pretty okay? You can't pick your fights, they're all preselected boss-rushes. You fight 3 sets of 2 enemies with a set number of lives and get to pick from 3 powers, and as X only, no Zero. Some fights are fine, others are INSANELY hard on the normal difficulty and Easy is TOO easy. The first half of this collection is pretty gold, X1 is great, X2 is also really good, X3 is ...alright, X4 is great. The second half is where the series got a bit funky....and bad. X5 is okay, X6 is the worst (with great music), X7 is runner up for worst, X8 is alright... I hope that explains the mixed bag part of the title. There's great games here, but the execution is lacking and half the collection is arguable in it's value should be on the cartridge, there's really no excuse for it not to be given the games that have easily fit. (their reason is so they can sell them on the store separately and they need different SKUs & physical versions to match, it's a poor excuse) Should you get it? I got it because I want portable Megaman X and while the games can be got on PSP/PSV you don't get the SNES titles, just the PS1 games. So, options are limited. Should you? That's up to you, hope this review was helpful.

All these 1 star reviews complaining they won't get the 2nd collection physically should remember that the original legacy collections were digital only for most platforms and grow up. These collections are proof that Capcom wants to bring the series back and if you love MegaMan X then you should absolutely purchase this.

Crippling input latency on X1/X2/X3 make this collection unplayable on any console/PC. Capcom has not fixed or even acknowledged this major issue. If you were looking forward to playing the SNES games, avoid this and get an SNES Classic which comes with X1 and can be easily modified to add the sequels.
I've always been a big Mega Man X fan, so to finally get every mainline game in the series on a portable is fantastic.
Great port of all the megaman games, I only wish that they were all on one cartridge and I didnt have to download the second half. otherwise a fantastic game with tons of nostalgia

This is a great collection of MegaMan X games. It plays very well in tablet mode; I haven't played connected to the TV yet, so I can't comment on how that works. I have heard mention of some minor input lag with this version, but I didn't notice any playing with it. One standout addition was the Novice Hunter mode, which is essentially an easy mode for the games. I found it helpful to play on this mode for about half an hour or so when I first started to get used to playing these games again, since I hadn't touched them for so long. It could also be fun if you have young children, so that they can play the same games you do without having a rough time with it. For adults, I would definitely recommend playing with a pro controller. I played in handheld for a bit, but the button layout was causing my hands to cramp up due to the small form factor of the joycons, so I ended up using the kickstand and playing with a pro controller instead. Finally, my major caveat: the cartridge in the box only includes X collection 1 (1-4). Collection 2 (5-8) is included as a download code. I have heard the PS4 version includes both games on a single blu-ray, and almost bought the collection on that platform because of it. I finally decided that off-TV play was more important than having a physical version of both, but it is worth noting that you don't actually get the whole collection in this box.
Could not get out of initial story movie, had to go switch out the game for a new one

As happy as I am to have the entire X series available on my Switch, the collection falls short of excellence for a few reasons. The second half of the collection being limited to a download code instead of a cartridge is infuriating. We have multiple Switch systems in our family, so we like to be able to share our game cards. When a game is only available as a download, that is option goes away. My other big issue is the lack of features that I consider pretty basic when emulating classic games at this point. There's no save state feature for instant file saves, instead relying on the original games' built in save menus. All in all, I'm glad I have the games, but I'm far from satisfied with this release.
X1 and X4 are incredible; X2 and X5 are great; X3 and X8 are good; and X6 and X7 are bad. All things considered, a solid collection.

Why give a game 1out of 5 stars? Presentation! Nintendo just did it with the Wii, and previously the DSi. I have a massive collection dating back 40 years. All games I can still fire up and play. 40 years from now , I will be stuck with a gamecard and case that only contains the first half of this collection if I were to buy this. Capcom is greedy.

I have always liked Far Cry games and have been playing them since 2 on the PS3. But out of all of them, I would say that New Dawn is something special. It takes almost everything that made 5 great and improves upon it. The only aspects that are weaker in New Dawn compared to 5 is the story and size/scope (but that's necessarily a bad thing). First off, the weapon creation system, while not mind blowing, is a nice throwback to 2 where your weapons would malfunction without the frustration. In the beginning of New Dawn when you pick up a random weapon off of a dead guy it doesn't work that well. It's slower to reload and shoot because your character is fighting dirty mechanisms and rusted parts. As you get better gear it works much better (although it's usually not much prettier). This is a really nice system that adds to the experience. I also liked the addition of the damage numbers showing when you hit your target. This might annoy some but I really like it. Character models, visuals, environments, and sounds are all improved compared to 5. I know it's got to be running on the same engine so I have no idea how they made it look better, but they did. Also the HDR color on this game is fantastic. The bright magenta flowers that are everywhere really pop on my 65 inch TV. HDR makes the sunsets and sunrises in this game quite beautiful too. Speaking of visuals, the setting of New Dawn is very interesting. It's obviously post-apocalyptic with strong Mad Max vibes with the driving, Highwaymen, gas wars, bullet farms and hodgepodge style weapons. It also has moments that it reminded me of The Last of Us and Dying Light (although there are no human zombies in this game) while exploring the overgrown buildings for resources and using the new running/jumping mechanics respectively. These are all media that I love so I will say I enjoyed the mashed-up feel. YMMV, of course. Like I said in the beginning of my review, the only weak point compared to 5 is the story. 5's story was frustrating at points but it really sucked me in and made me feel like I was living it. New Dawn's, however, relies a little too heavily on the supernatural. But, I will say I like the conclusion better than 5's. And the shorter story made it so I got through the game without getting burned out, which I liked. Not every game needs to be a triple-digit-hour slog. This is especially fine since the asking price of the game is considerably lower than most AAA games. It's also a pretty easy and fun Platinum if you are a trophy hunter. To summarize, if you like Far Cry games, you should give this one a go. I doubt you will be disappointed. And, as a surprise to no one, if you don't like Far Cry games you won't like this one. New Dawn is unmistakably a Far Cry game but somehow manages to feel nostalgic and fresh at the same time, and that's an achievement worth celebrating.

The story and setting, the diverse weapons, the challenges, the ways to earn perk points, the rooster of support characters, the vehicles, the expeditions, the outposts (and recapturing) all topped off with an ability to double jump. This spinoff was more fun than the main title.

Not quite a sequel, not quite DLC, Far Cry New Dawn is some sort of unholy amalgam of the two that perfectly represents this age in gaming: a video game that manages to rip you off with its small size and disappoint you with its small amount of content, all while pretending to be a new entry in a storied franchise. Don't believe it. The game has maybe 40% of the content of FC5, without any of that game's surprisingly great story or characters. In this one you are simply tasked with taking down two post-apocalypse baddies and... that's it. No intrigue, no cool new gameplay elements. Just go over there, shoot, and come home. This would have been a fine addition to a $20 season pass. Instead, I'd just give it a pass, period.

The long and short of it... if you liked Far Cry 5, you'll like New Dawn. It's a continuation of the story and a tweaking of several gameplay features. It builds more of a crafting system too, which is a fun addition. The only reason I don't give this 5 stars is because it was something fairly easy and simple for Ubisoft to make and is a cash grab. It feels lazy of them to do, but is still fun. Feels a little contradictory to say that, but hey. Just my opinion. Happy looting!

This game delivers the sequel Far Cry 5 deserved. It shows an entirely new face of Hope County, but if you did not play Far Cry 5 before this game it explains enough of the back story that you would not need to play Far Cry 5 before playing this sequel. It is a fantastic game to play!

I'll say that after playing through the original game, I didn't expect the route the developers took with the sequel. Without giving away spoilers, this game left me a bit disappointed. I really can't say why without spoiling the story so I'll just leave it at that. Gameplay is entertaining and much like the FC5 so if you liked that, you'll be satisfied with this. The NPC's are amusing and will have you laughing with their off-the-wall one liners and snarky comments. The problem lies with the length of the game and the amount of content available. The main missions are short and could have been fleshed out. Then again, this game is only 40 dollars so I should have expected a shorter campaign.
I was hesitant on this title but figured better than Primal and cheaper on day 1. Very interesting take on sequal to 5

This is a cash grab, since they don't have much content they have made this rpg style of leveling up where it will take you latterly all the ammo you have to kill a squirrel. The game looks the same which I like but other than that, Its Trash

Save your money and rent it a few days. seems like you can get a lot done in a short amount of time. its good, just like the last few but doesn't seem like a different game. 'expansion pack' priced like a new game
This should have been released as a DLC for Far Cry 5 for about $10. It not only continues the story but uses a lot of recycled content.

I have played it for a few hours and if you liked 5 it's good, but honestly it is not great. This is the first Soulcalibur I have purchased since the Dreamcast and as a sequel to the first, it would be amazing. As the 6th in a series by the same developer that makes the Tekken series, it is an attempt to port the evolution of one series onto the graphics of another. It has inherited the customization of Tekken, but also the excessively slow fighting style. Every move has to be perfectly timed in a nearly robotic manner or the player comes to a complete stop that requires a gap before accepting input. The AI is designed to have an expert response to these gaps and will retaliate with an array of attacks that ends in your death. This is not a game of skill, but a game of repetition. You will find that many players in ranked and unranked matches have become so accustomed to this style that even their attacks follow a very obvious and redundant pattern. For those of us that come from Dead or Alive and the fast-paced fighting games, it is not hard to adjust for the 'lag' and easily overcome these mechanized opponents. In terms of quality, the game is a visual masterpiece with technical mediocrity. It's a fun distraction until Dead or Alive 6.

SoulCalibur has always been a great fighting game that's fun for casual and competitive play. It's pretty much the only 3D weapon fighting game that's still in existence. If you played any of the games in the franchise, you know what you'll expect in terms of gameplay. The newest gameplay mechanic introduced is the reversal edge system. It basically works like a guard impact (effective against throws and low attacks even), but the character immediately follows up with an attack afterwards that launch a rock-paper-scissors mini game. Vertical beats horizontal, horizontal beats kick, and kick beats vertical. The problem is that this mechanic slows the game down to a guessing game. It's a good way to build meter for critical edges and soul charges though. Critical edges are basically like super with an easy input. Soul charges are powered states that give attacks special attributes depending on the character, it also open up a new moves that can be used. They're okay though I prefer no meter for my 3D fighting games. Single player content wise, the game is beefy at least with Libra of Souls and Soul Chronicles. The first is similar to weapons master mode in past SoulCalibur game(with more of a RPG twist where you can weapons and level up) where you create a character and fight in various battles with varying conditions. It's very text heavy so expect to do a lot of reading. The mode starts off easy, but cheap A.I. becomes prevalent at higher level where they read your input. The story isn't anything to write home about though it does flesh out more of the lore. Soul Chronicles is your traditional story mode for each character that features static character portraits and voiced lines between bouts. It's not bad for what it is I guess. There's an Arcade mode though you just fight through seven or eight characters. All the story content are pushed into Soul Chronicles. There's also always the Create A Soul mode where you can create your own character with fighting styles used by existing characters in the game. Online is what you expect with casual matches and ranked matches. The latter can take awhile with matchmaking some times. The game overall has a budgeted feel. Graphics are okay, but could be better compared to past games and other fighting games currently out. There isn't even a intro video. I'm not a fan of how Tira was cut off and sold as DLC even though she's in the main game already. Overall, SCVI is worth it if you're into fighting games and it's not a bad choice for fans of the franchise or newcomers. It's a simple game to get into, but has good depth if you want to play on a more hardcore, competitive level.

This installment of Soulcalibur is A LOT of fun! I think the developers learned from their mistakes with Soulcalibur V and improved on what worked with the previous entries. As a longtime fan of the Soul series, I can say that this fighter is approachable for both new and veteran players. Add the new features like Reversal Edge and Critical Edge, and there's a lot to learn without feeling overwhelmed. This fighter rewards the player for combos and skill whereas other fighters are all about the 'rock, paper, scissors' formula of mastering a match. The visuals and sounds are stunning as always as you'd expect from a Soulcalibur game. I do wish that there were more fighting stages and added to the 'mood' as we had seen in past games but it's not a deal breaker. The online is solid and I have found that there is hardly any lag when taking on opponents. Of course, you can always have friends/partners play against you with a second controller. If you're looking to tackle the single-player challenges then you won't be disappointed. There's A LOT to do without getting bored. And that's not including the campaign. I do wish that this game encompassed everything but alas, there's a season pass offered that will eventually offer four additional characters and armor (for custom creation characters). At the end of the day, you're getting a fun and gorgeous fighter with Soulcalibur VI.
Soul Calibur is back baby, great graphics and online works smooth so far

Xenoverse 1 was horrible in my estimation but the second was done far, far better. Better fighting mechanics, better story, better camera...imagine what we wanted in Budokai 2 with the fighting, 3 with the exploration (flight) and the legacy of Goku games for GBA.

Having never played Xenoverse 1, I was a bit worried the learning curve would be too big to overcome, or I would just be downright lost(you can even import your existing character from Xeno1), but I'm so pleasantly surprised that's not the case! Xenoverse 2 delves into DBZ territory and transitions all the way through Super. I was also worried, as an offline player, the gameplay would be limited, but again, I was wrong! As far as I can tell, I'm still getting to navigate through the main story line and there is no shortage of things to do. The game takes place in Conton City, where you get to be your own new character as a time patroller! Following orders and instruction from the Supreme Kai of Time and Elder Kai, you get to right the wrongs of the discrepancies of some of the greatest events and battles throughout Dragon Ball history. You get to fight along side some of the best, and can even chose your instructor(don't expect Vegeta to take too kindly to you at first!). The whole premise of the game is just really cool and there's always somewhere to go, or someone to see... Whether it's battles, side missions, training, collecting supplies, or even just helping out your fellow Z fighters. Now, here's where the 4 stars come into play... The game play in battle can get a bit repetitive. Sure you can train to learn these awesome 20 button combos, when you're fighting Frieza AND Cooler at the same time those long, multi-button combinations kind of go out the window and you just stick to your few tried and true. The navigation of the actual game can be a bit confusing at times and you truly just have to 'figure it out' because there's little to no instruction when it comes to that. But honestly, if you're a fan, you have come to love and accept that the Dragon Ball universe has it's own logic and is just plain confusing at times. The background music in your main map, Conton City, is Dreadful to the ear!! Lol. Go to settings and change it... Immediately!! So, even though the gameplay at times can get a little repetitive and stagnet which may leave you turning it off that particular day, after you've slept on it, you find yourself wanting to come back for more the next day! That's a good thing! Solid game with awesome graphics. Voices of the characters are spot on as well!

So awesome to have no eyebrows and huge hair as SS 3. Golden Frieza. Pure Form Kid Buu. Namekian giants! It's just awesome. I would play a Saiyan though since SS 3 doesn't require stamina or anything so you can stay as SS 3 the entire fight vs Kid Buu for instance drains stamina and you eventually get kicked out of it. My only complaint is that the story should be co-op! It would make it way more fun since Parallel Quests are okay, but they can get pretty stale since a lot of them have bad rewards. I enjoyed the story though. You can really identify with your character and you feel a part of the universe as a Time Patroller.

Dragon Ball fans will all enjoy the story line of the game play and those who enjoy fighting style games will take even more enjoyment with the fluid combat. The online features in my opinion were very poor. There is no online co-op for story related missions but there are 100 quests and 17 expert missions you can do with teams of 3 and 6 respectively... Honestly I think it's best to do all of these solo with AI generated teammates which disappointed me veRyan bad at first and I think most of the community would agree. As for online versus matches, that's not my thing... but I would bet it is very very good for those who enjoy player versus player.

After the fiasco of launch day, No Man's Sky has been patched to the point of being an amazing game. Love the VR!

I have heard all kinds of things about No Man's Sky, from its procedurally generated worlds to its impressive planetary scale. However, I avoided buying it in 2016 due to some of the backlash I heard about it not being complete or offering what was promised. Cue in No Man's Sky Beyond, a re-released version of the game with all the updates installed with it on the disc! And boy are there a lot of things added. For starters, there's base building, which is something I really enjoy after playing games like Fallout 4 and Minecraft. You can create a base on any location on any planet you wish, and it feels good to build your own space colony of sorts. Another addition is multiplayer, though I haven't used that yet since I don't have the subscription to play online yet. And furthermore, there are more story elements and quests to run and even a third-person view which was not present in the original version. These additions make the game feel like an experience you can call your own, and I love it. On the downside, there are still a few goofy things like weird-looking alien lifeforms as a result of the procedurally generated creatures system. And while the game technically has a story, it can still feel aimless as you might just get lost in what you want to do (though honestly that's more of a good thing since there are a lot of things to do). You can explore the planetary surface, build your base colony, pilot starships, engage in space battles with said starships, trade with aliens or just simply wander the impressive open world (open-planet?) environments in the game. The feeling of hopping in your spaceship and blasting off the planet's surface into outer space without any load times at all is still something to behold, even more so when you look back at the planet you were just on and see how massive it is. Or even the opposite when you enter the planet's atmosphere and the landscape slowly materializes as you make contact with the surface. It's an interstellar wonder to just experience these elements in this game, and I am happy it was re-released with all the additional content and updates on the disc. This is easily going to be one of my most played games ever.

I watched and read many reviews about playgrounds 2 and just about every one focused on the micro transactions and how it's a cash grab. I get what the stink is about but just playing the game itself if fun and nice to pick and play. Sure I want all the great players and I can buy the whole roster if I want. I can also grind it out and try to unlock them too which is what I plan to do. Yes it is tedious at a point but also what makes me want to come back and play more. If I unlock all the players then I'll just be bored and won't play at all. I got the game for less than 20 bucks and it was a good investment in my eyes.

I have never been a huge sport game fan though I did really like the arcade style games like NBA Jam and NFL Blitz which are faster paced and less about picking plays and simulation. NBA Playgrounds 2 is not exactly like NBA Jam, but it does have a similar spirit in that it's a fast paced arcade style game. The gameplay is alot of fun. And that is really important. Games are quick and alot of fun and other diversions like 3 point contest is addicting. Local co-op is also a blast to play. This would be an easy 5 stars if it were not for the unlocking and progression system. You have to unlock pretty much every player on the roster. Most games give you at least a small amount of characters to start with. And this game kinda does that. The way you unlock players is through buying in game 'packs' of cards. Those cards are your player unlocks and they vary in cost using in-game currency. You could of course also use real world money via micro transactions. This wouldn't be so bad if the game gave you at least two players from each team. But no, the game gives you a small set of starter packs that give you a few players to start with, around 10. So obviously you wont get enough to be able to play as all teams at first. Because the game is two on two, you need at least two players unlocked to play as that team. So if you are a Lakers fan for example, unless you get at least two Lakers players in the starter packs, you really wont be able to use the Lakers. So you have to grind to earn baller bucks and buy packs in the hopes of getting lakers players. Or you can buy specific lakers players for a huge amount of Baller bucks. This is where the game makes you feel like they want you to spend actual money instead. I got lucky and unlocked Scotty Pippen and another bulls player to start so I have been using the Bulls and I have been earning currency pretty steadily but I have still not unlocked all teams with a minimum of two players each. The game will give you at least enough to start with maybe one or two teams but it might not be the teams you want. And that's what really bogs this experience down. NBA jam had a full roster ready to go. You already are paying for the game. This model makes this game feel like a free to play game or freemium game. It's too bad too because the gameplay is really great.

the upgrades from the first game: 1. jordan and kobe are the biggest additions 2. you can get special clothes and costumes 3. there is a season mode that feels like an actual nba season. the old game just had random exhibition matches in different countries. 4. playing and leveling up actually mean something, in the first game when you leveled up you only got special animations. however in this game leveling up increases your stats. thats great. addicting trying to get your fav players to top stats. 5. 3 point contest is added. 6. online is integrated very nicely. much better options than last game. tons of ways to play online. 7. more cool music instead of the 1 song on the other game. 8. the UI in general is just tons better. much more polish. the old game seemed low budget in this regard. ok... now the bad things: 1. missing key players. james worthy/reggie miller/allen iverson/charles barkley/vlade divac/karl malone/tim duncan/ben wallace/steve kerr/wilt chamberlan 2. also a little nitpick but i wish some of the players where available on different teams. kevin garnett is only in the minnisota roster but i want him on the celtics. there are various other players that i also want on other teams. the first game had more than this game. overall a huge upgrade to the last game. tons of fun.

I have so much fun with Tetris 99! It's a Battle Royale mode meets Tetris gameplay with much more involved! Now while the main game does require you to be online, this packaged version also comes with the DLC that allows offline play, which is a big plus for those looking to brush up on their skills when they don't have an internet connection. You start out playing regular Tetris and, as you destroy rows, you can send them to enemies (98 other players who are also randomly paired against you online) but they can also send theirs to you as well. As the field narrows down, it gets faster and tougher! I believe the best I did was 7th place...haven't seen first yet! There is also a two player mode and you can also play and earn themed levels! This also comes with a 12 month Nintendo Switch online subscriptions. That's a $20 value with the game (including DLC) costing $10. This would be the exact same price as if you just got the online, downloaded the free Tetris 99 through the eShop and then purchase the DLC for $10. HOWEVER, if you are able to do like I did and get this cheaper using rewards certificates, you'll save money. Hope you enjoy Tetris 99, see you on the battlefield!

I like the idea of the game but many glitches including freezing plague the game. In this game you are trying to get into your neighbors basement to see what horror lies beneath.
