I was skeptical when I first saw footage of the game. It seemed too bleak and simple, what is there to do? Then MS started slowly showing new content and footage and it became more appealing. I pre-ordered the game and have tried the Closed Beta and I don't remember the time before this one where I said 'This game is sick.' to a multiplayer game while nervously chuckling to people I was playing with. The nervousness came from the thrill of the game. You go on missions which are only limited to looting chests in beta, and get to know/bond with your teammates. Sometime after going out to sea you may run into other pirates and when you and 2 other ships have all come to the same island from opposite sides and you all got chests on your ships, things get intense and your team's bond and teamwork is tested like I haven't felt before or in a long time in a game. I was lucky enough to log in and join a team with a guy who helped with learning the game and we voyaged out for 2.5 hours together while cycling through new members on our team. So remember that this game can take at least an hour to get used to but ultimately its easy to pick up. One time we were all looking at the map and a newcomer got so drunk and threw up all over us so we put him in the Brig, which is a little cage on the ship's bottom level serving as a timeout. Another time we saw another ship and we had no treasure so we risked attacking them only with 3 teammates. After some back and forth battle moments, we sunk their ship and they happened to have 3 chests of booty which we stole and brought back to town. A cool part of the game is that gear is simply cosmetics and there are no levels or super powerful weapons you get from playing a long time. The good thing about that is everybody can play together regardless of rank, nobody gets left out and if you don't play as much as your friends, that doesn't mean you two will have to stop playing together because they are too far ahead. It's a fun game and the experiences it offers are fresh, exciting and imaginative. Excited for Day One and where the game will go from here.

Although the game isnt out as of yet, I was privileged to be selected for Alpha testing for the game. I cant say much except for the fact that even in an alpha stage, the game is down right amazing! I love the direction the game is going. I would pre order this game in a heartbeat because this is one of the few games I know for a fact will be good at release.
Great game to play with the boys, sailing the seas, hunting pirates and seeking treasures!

Let me start off by saying the graphics are absolutely stellar. While sailing the ship around you can easily spend several hours experiencing the wind, rain and wave affects. Stunning. The game takes forever to load on X Box One X. Really, start it up and then go get your favorite beverage because when you return the game will still be loading. The developers included splash the words to a cute pirate song to try and distract you while it's loading. It may work once but after that it's simply annoying. The game play itself is SLOW. Seriously, the missions involve starting at an island, sailing to another island and digging treasure or grabbing farm animals and then taking back to the original island. They take forever. In addition, there is a high probability someone will come along and kill you. Usually, someone or group of someones are just running killing everybody and taking the loot. Which means you have to start all over. If you happen to die you go to what I assume is Davey Jones locker. Where you WAIT again (forever) for the game to respawn you somewhere else. I really wanted to like the game. I was hoping for a fancy Age of Booty game. But alas 'tis not to be.

I had been excitedly following the development of Sea of Thieves for close to a year, and after trying out the Open Beta in the beginning of March I was completely blown away by the game's charm, beauty, and over the top fun to be had! No online co-op game has ever been this enjoyable for me, and it is a wonderful way to spend quality time with my son and nephew who live half a continent away. Well done, Rare!

This game gives you a sandbox environment to have some great pirating adventures if you give it a chance, but it is not for gamers who need a very structured gaming environment all the time. The best description I have read and can provide is SoT is like being given a toy pirate as a kid, and you played with this toy pirate by creating by acting adventures either alone or with friends. You loved playing with this toy pirate, and only wished there was some way to make the adventures more real. That's what SoT CAN be if you let it. It provides an interactive play field where multiple 'kids' get to play out this pirate fantasy in the same place with others doing the same thing simultaneously. For those who have realized this potential, SoT can be amazing. However, if you are someone who needs to have your game completely defined for you, telling you what to do all the time and have little interest in this type of sand box adventuring, this game will probably not make you happy. Word of warning even if you think you are ready to make SoT your personal adventure gaming environment... currently there are a very limited actual pre-created adventures provided in the game, and most of these basically require you to do similar things. You will be required to complete an egregious quantity of repetitive fetch quests that has ever been required in ANY video game to gain the sweet bounty needed to make your pirate the envy of the seas. If Rare does not keep adding some form of content to the game it will risk losing its fanbase quickly. Read reviews and forums before you buy the the game to make sure you understand what it is and what it isn't before you put your coin on the table to purchase the game. If you go in with a full understanding of what you will find in SoT, you mught just have some of the best gaming adventures you have ever had.

This game feels like a beta indie game. There's almost no content currently and I wish I hadn't bought it. For one, if you purchase the version from the XBox/Microsoft store you get two copies. One for PC and one for XBox, but not with the XBox physical disc purchase. There are already PC players using cheats like infinite health or aimbot. And to my knowledge there's no anti-cheat device in place. The only fun aspect of this game is multiplayer, and that's only fun if you find someone who's fun to play with. Honestly this game should be no more than $30, for the content it has to offer currently. There's no upgrading anything in the game. The only thing to unlock are vanity skins. After collecting treasure and dropping it off for a few hours, we headed to a Fort. We beat that brought the treasure back again and now all that's left is to defeat the Kraken. So currently the entire game can be played in about five hours. You should wait until more content is released before purchasing this game, and if you do, buy the digital version so you get a PC copy for free.

Your adventure on the high sea awaits. Sword Fighting... Check. Treasure hunting...Check Ships rolling over the waves... Check Danger from other pirates, monsters and storms wanting to take your life and your treasure.... Check, check and triple check. Sea of Thieves is very cool. This game successfully puts together a play set of muskets, swords, ships and pirate outfits that allow you to lose yourself in the game and become a pirate. It's set in an open world you share with everyone else playing the game. All of you going after various treasures or skeleton crews at the same time. Also you can at any time choose to go and fight any of the other human players in the game. This can at times be terrifying when you realize that you can't not play with other humans. At any moment the player in that ship that you see on the horizon might decide to see if you have any treasure on your ship and come after you. And there isn't anything to stop them. Except your own musket, sword and skill you gain while sailing the seas. This has led to multiple situations in my own game where I've had to fight off another player or two to keep them from getting a treasure chest I had just dug up. The best advice I can give you is to realize that while the pirate you are having to fight might have a super cool hat, peg leg, and a hook with tattoos and a sweet looking sword, he/she actually isn't any more powerful than you are. All of the 'upgrades' you can buy for your ship or pirate are only cosmetic. This means that the one guaranteed advantage one ship has over another is the number of crew. Your crew can consist of up to 4 pirates working together. It supports a closed crew where just friends can be on the same ship or you can join a crew of random pirates. I've enjoyed playing with my kids. So we take the smaller ship and there is usually just the two of us. If you choose to do the random assignment the community has generally been great. Lots of people have been very helpful and talkative while sailing. I can't say that I've made any life long friends yet but I don't encourage people trying to do that on the internet. Ultimately this always online structure and being thrust into a world and forced to interact with other humans will be the appeal or repelling force for this game. Much like playing dress up and imaging to be a pirate growing up, you are only going to get out of this game as much as you put into. There is almost zero narrative to be found in this game. As the point of this game is to do pirate stuff. So if a compelling story is what you come to games for I would certainly encourage you to pass this game. The journey is the point. Hopefully this helps anyone on the fence about this game, and if you think you'll be getting the game.... Well I'll see you on the high seas. Best of luck and remember to put the kegs of black powder in the crows nest. That way if it explodes it won't damage your ship.
It isn't that the game is bad. You HAVE to have a team of 4. You will die if you okay by yourself or just with one other person. It's not fun that way.

This is a Pirate game meant for playing in groups... not as solo. I played the first few days on my own, using a sloop and trying to figure things out by myself. I tend to like PvE and not PvP so much. Unfortunately, this is an open world and after spending about an hour collecting things - another sloop came up on me and took my stuff. After a few times having this happen and literally dying at what I thought would be a safe Outpost port - I decided to play in a full Galleon mode. This was a much better overall experience. Again, it's about who gets paired with you - so you can get some folks that really shouldn't be in the group and are there to troll. There are mechanisms to get rid of them. Make sure you have your mic on as well. And for Pete's sake - don't let you 8 year old play. For PvE - Gameplay is buggy and glitchy and a bit repetitive. You jump around a lot trying to get around on the ship. You get used to it but it doesn't make it any less annoying. I hope it gets better with patch releases. The water dynamics and weather dynamics are awesome. The AI is pretty good as well.

For a $60 game this is an embarrassment. After one hour of gameplay I promise that you will have seen all this game has to offer and it never gets better. You aren't working toward anything, the money you earn can only be spent on cosmetics for your ship or character, so you never get stronger, faster or anything like that. Makes you wonder why you are even playing this game when you aren't working towards a goal. The game plays like so: 1. Get on a ship. 2. Follow map to island. 3. Dig up treasure/fight skeletons. 4. Return to outpost trade in gold to buy a shirt that does nothing. Yup that's the game. $60, have fun. Stay AWAY!

Sea of Thieves in its current state is nothing more than a skeleton of a great game. Massive potential currently ruined by lack of content and variety. There are only 3 mission types at this time, all of which are truly just fetch quests. You either go on a treasure hunt, find and capture animals (chickens, pigs, and/or snakes), or you hunt a bounty. There is currently only one NPC enemy type - Skeletons. There are a few types of skeletons, but otherwise you are just fighting skeletons over and over again. PVP is great, until you realize sinking an enemy ship puts you at a disadvantage when they respawn 3 minutes away with full supplies. There is not vertical progression. All progression is cosmetic based and currently there are only 3-4 clothing designs that have 3-4 recolored skins each. This game is beautiful, and sailing and goofing around with friends is fun, but after 3-4 hours you have seen what there is to offer. I do not recommend buying this in its current state.

Everybody has their go-to game they play when they are just looking to zone out for a while. Diablo 3 is that game for me. Kill lots of baddies. Get lots of randomized loot. Wash, rinse, repeat.

It's still the same Diablo gameplay you've come to know and love, however there's more differentiation ability, and more need to focus in areas. Previously, you could gain almost all skills for a specific character class, and get fully powered up, now you have to choose a gameplay style and sculpt your skill set to best assist that type of play. Yes, it can be a little frustrating at times, but all it takes is a pause to rearrange your skills and try something different, if what you're doing isn't working. Long story short, if you used to enjoy Diablo or Diablo 2, give it a try, you won't be sorry.

Just Cause 4 is arguably the most fun 3rd person shooter just out of the sheer absurdness and chaotic nature of the game itself. Just go around and destroy everything in the most creative ways you can think of. Your tether now has tons of mods that you can add on so there are even more ways to destroy things in this game. There's really no story, just go out in the world and wreck havoc. The game is naturally repetitive. 'Go here and kill everybody and destroy everything, go here and kill everybody and destroy everything, go here and do it again x100'. It's fun at first as I've said, but it does get old fast. There's very little other gameplay aspects to this game. The wingsuit challenges are back (and are easier now, thank god. JC3's wingsuit challenges were infuriatingly hard), speed challenges and then there's these tomb challenges (obvious nod to Square Enix's other series, Tomb Raider) where you have these short little puzzle challenges to figure out. Nothing crazy but they're good for a quick change of pace. The controls are really good and feel really fluid. You can seamlessly switch from the grappling to the parachute to the wingsuit and back again and it makes traversing the world fun. The gun play and tether system is also really nice and easy to control. I feel like the vehicle mechanics have been improved. The cars are easier to handle. I know that was a big complaint with the last Just Cause. Apparently, this game was built on a whole new engine and it almost doesn't feel like it except when you look at the graphics. The graphics are pretty terrible. Most of the time, the game is so chaotic that you're not even paying attention to the graphics and they make no difference to the core gameplay itself. However, if you just stop and pan around with the camera while you're standing still. Oh my, this game is a blurry, pixelated mess. But like I said, you only really notice it when you're standing still and this game is not Red Dead Redemption 2 and you're not standing still very often. You'll most notice it during cutscenes which are just bad in general (it is Just Cause after all, it's not supposed to have a good story or engrossing cutscenes) but the cutscenes look like in early PS3 and that is no exaggeration. I mention graphics last because I'm not one to have graphics hold so much weight. It's totally aesthetic and does not effect the gameplay itself. I'm sure they'll patch it over time to make it look better. JC3 looked great but I remember it having some serious frame rate drops to the point where the game becomes a slide show. I don't know if they ever fixed that but something like that does hamper the gameplay experience. Luckily, JC4 doesn't have that but they severely downgraded the graphics to compensate in this new engine. It improves in some areas over JC3 while downgrading in other areas. I like all the modifications they added to the tethering system and the improved physics to allow to allow more craziness and creative destruction which is always good. I also like the huge and varied map. I don't like that the gameplay is still pretty stagnant and repetitive and the graphics could definitely be better.

whether you've played any JUST CA USE games before doesn't really matter, this game is hands down F.U.N.!! I really loved JC3, and #4 took all that and threw a creative edge to playing as Rico......... one tough Mofo!! Bottom line, ....... get dis game, it's fully worth it!!
This game is a positive choice of more fun. It so different than the Fortnite and other games my child has. It's so funny hearing the screams and pleading of Noooooooo.

The graphics on this are not as good as the last game. Even more lacking if you have a PS4 Pro with a 4K TV with HDR. The story line is a very weak. Basically can blow up everything and they have added a lot of extra features to do this. Still a fun game. Could have been a bit better.If you enjoyed the last one then you will probably like this. A really solid, fun title if you're looking for a faster-paced, less strategy orientated Monster Hunter that's more geared towards action than the more methodical approach of MH (Monster Hunter). It's also much easier to approach game than MH for newcomers; every control and system is explained to you in a way that's easy to understand, making this a great game to get into if you're on the fence about the depth of these games. To go over all of the positive aspects of the game, I, of course, have to first mention the combat. The combat is, bar none, some of the greatest in any video game I've played in recent memory. The music can be hit or miss, but the majority of the time, I found myself either enjoying the score or forgetting it was there entirely as I focused on combat, but it was never intrusive or too much. The game also has an insane amount of customization allowed for your character with the number of weapons you can choose from, as well as a decent cosmetic customization system. The Aragami design, the monsters in this game, is also very good, and I'd go as far to say even better than recent MH titles. While this game does have stellar combat and a few other great mechanics, I do want to touch on the flaws as well. The story isn't anything to write home about and the dialogue really isn't up to par with most modern games, but the characters are memorable and charming. Another small issue is the mission design; Every mission you go into is very straightforward, with a path akin to a corridor, a room, another corridor, another room, and copy and paste this formula for almost every map in the game, meaning exploration is out of the picture entirely for this title. All of the maps in the game are also reused multiple times, taking away from the immersion in the game, but considering most people won't be too terribly into the story and its continuity, it's an easy flaw to look past. The visuals are also nothing spectacular. Take any JRPG from the last few years and you'll see that God Eater 3 looks almost identical to other games that came out years before it. The landscapes and design of some areas are interesting and cool to look at, but overall, it's just a small step below of what we should be expecting at this point, even for a switch title, but that also doesn't necessarily mean the visuals are bad either. I personally think it's a complete non-issue, I never really care about graphics in video games, but for the select few, I think it's worth mentioning that it isn't anything grand.
this is an excellent remaster! high quality graphics quick smooth fluid gameplay!. it is so much fun lan the monsters and leveling up!! the weapons get crazy!!! you will love it!!

The online lobby is pretty dead, though, but the game does fill in empty spots (up to 8 players) with A.I. bots. I've put WAY more time into GH3 than I anticipated and always look forward to jumping back in.

This is another in a great line of Dark Souls releases. If you're familiar with the franchise, it edges Dark Souls II - generally speaking - just barely and lags slightly behind Bloodborne. If you're new to the series, be advised; you may want to think twice about this purchase. This is a very difficult game where you will die a lot. An extremely frustrating amount of times, in fact. And if video games are prone to giving you fits of rage, then avoid this game and series at all costs. On the other hand, there's something very rewarding in this franchise with defeating a boss that other games fail to capture. It's incredibly addicting. As such, this is one of my all-favorite franchises. Highly recommended.

Wow. I'm new to the Dark Souls series and it's worth it to note that no previous experience in the series is required to enjoy this game. This is the best single player RPG experience I've had since FF7, Zelda, Diablo - I haven't played games in years. I understand why this series has such a strong cult-like following now. As new player that's unfamiliar with the series, you really have to push through the initial learning curve to really start appreciating the game for what it is. What do I mean by that? It's a game that doesn't leave good first impressions in my opinion - my first impression of this game was that it was lack luster. The graphics I thought looked like crap compared to other games like battlefield one, Until dawn, and so on. I thought the controls were stupid - I can't jump, the enemy aiming initially felt bad and confusing. I couldn't even customize the button actions to make it all better and had to adapt to what the game forced me to use and that led to an intial frustrating experience as I struggled to dodge, block, hit enemies and even just general movement across the starting area lead to death from falls off cliffs and unexpected enemies. And the game gives you no breaks, you can't even pause in the game which is what I'm used to. If I want to take a break I just press the pause button, but not in this game you have to be in a safe zone if you want to rest or just plain quit the game ( and there is a special menu option for you to quit , you can't just hit the PS4 button and close the app ). So yes, the game doesn't leave a good first impression, but if you can push past that and give it a few hours, defeat the first boss, learn the controls and start getting better weapons and understand the upgrade system, you start to be able to appreciate what this game has to offer and I think it's a rare thing to have quality RPG games like this. It is genuinely addictive. Gameplay: It's hard to explain the game play without experiencing it yourself. Watch a few game review videos if you want an idea, but the gist of it is that it's not a button mashing game. It's a third person RPG that requires enemy targeting and some level of strategy. Every enemy can be a challenge and has the ability to kill you if you are carelessly swinging. You need to know their attack patterns and know when to attack and if you're really into it, what to use for attacking that works most effectively. It's casual enough that you can just jump right in but not so casual that you can just hack and slash your way through the entire game ( if you're new ). Besides that, the game offers a pretty unique way to level up, but the stat adjustments are typical of the genre but with a twist here since the game has unique attributes associated with each stat. There are no skill branches, just attributes, weapons, armor, weapon/armor upgrades, spell purchases, but it's varied enough that you can have near unlimited choices to make the character you want. And the game can be as hard or as difficult as you want it to be depending on the time you spend upgrading/leveling. Game progression: The game progression itself is rather linear with forks in the quest line that you can choose to do and affect outcomes at different parts of the game with NPCs and game endings, but it's done so well that you never mind that it's linear since there is enough freedom that it makes the player feel they have control of what they want to do next. There are enough things players can do and side areas to explore if they so please. Basically it has an open world feel in terms of side quests vs main storyline but the map areas are pretty closed with hidden and optional areas but the level designs are so well done ( the best I've ever seen ) that I rather prefer that than exploring a boring barren open world. Boss battles: If you're looking for epic boss fights then this is the right game for you. The fights can be brutal but impressive and no two bosses behave the same way or have the same attacks. They are enjoyable and I hesitate a little every time I see the door that could lead to the next boss fight because I just don't know what to expect. Game replay value: I am only going through this game my first time and I'm hooked. The game does have a lot of replay value , different endings, new game difficulty after your first run, and different faction enlistments , different character attributes /customizations / weapons armor you may want to try, and quest lines that could have been missed the first time around, npcs you may want to kill etc. the game is brilliantly designed so it never really gets old even if you revisit an old level. It will offer hundreds of hours gameplay if you choose no doubt. Even just one play through will probably require at least weeks or months to complete if played casually about a few hours a day. The game levels / areas are deceptively huge. They feel large and natural and will take time to explore if you don't have maps or a game guide.

This is a great edition to a great. Dark souls 3 is a challenging, action RPG that is packed with tough enemies, incredible boss fights and memorable locations. The Fire Fades includes not only the base game but also the the docs Ashes of Ariandel and The Ringed City, both of which add new locations, weapons, enemies and well designed tough bosses. All in all, the fire fades edition is an amazing send off to a spectacular franchise. If you are a dark souls fan and you have not played dark souls 3, definitely recommend you pick this up. You'll love it.
I've been playing this game nonstop since I got it. Highly recommended to anyone who likes Bloodborne, Nioh....

Now a couple years old, Dark Souls III remains a beautiful, deep, and challenging RPG experience. As a veteran of DS 1 & 2, as well as Bloodborne, all of which are From Software titles in the same tradition, it's been fun to revisit this masterpiece a couple years after the original release and to finally play the DLC included on this disc. Buyer beware that this game takes no prisoners-- you will be tested to the utmost within the first 10 minutes of game play. But if you progress beyond what will be an obvious hurdle, your efforts will be rewarded and you can settle in a bit with the game and its lore before the next monstrosity presents itself. Good luck hunters!

This entry to Souls series is up there with the best of them. The transition in terms of gameplay from Souls to Bloodborne was jarring, however, going from BB to DS3 was smoother than I had expected. The gameplay, at its heart, is what you would expect from a Souls game, but the pacing in combat takes a few queues from Bloodborne with its faster than normal DS combat and seemingly quick transition from strike to strike. The world design is leaps better than DS2 with a feeling that a world was created and not a bunch of individual levels tied together in a mishmash. The world is not as interconnected as DS1 with areas looping around on each other, but that hasn't bothered me much as it reminds, in a sense, of Demon's Souls. Overall, a fantastic game and one any fan of the series should get.

So this is a mixed review for sure, Spyro 1 played great and Saved everytime without issue. It also has a Manual Save Option that allows you to save when you want. The 2nd and 3rd Games rely solely on Auto Save and it DOES NOT WORK! I played to 27% in Spyro 2, when I shut off my Xbox to play another game it said it had SAVED. When I reinserted the Disc and tried to continue my Saved Game the save amount had dropped from 27% to 9%, HOURS of effort were not SAVED, I had to start over again. The same thing happened with Spyro 3 and the Auto Save feature. Activision has not addressed this (and they were recently sold to Bungie) so who knows when it will be resolved if ever. I paid full price and can only use 1/3 of the game. It's a waste of time and Money. Poor Product, I do not recommend this game at all due to faulty Auto Save. It is a waste of your time and money.

I consider myself to be well-versed in platformer/Metroidvania games. The Metroidvania is my favorite genre of game and is the genre I play the most often. The pixel art and animations are very pretty and fluid. The music and atmosphere are also wonderful. The story is interesting. From my understanding, this game takes place before the others in the series. I am heavily considering playing the other games in the series to pick up the story. I think this game is good, but some aspects rub me the wrong way. I think this game is a tad too difficult. There's a fine line between a fun challenge and an aggravating one; Momodora RutM crosses that line for me. Here are a few reasons I think this game is frustratingly difficult: 1) Enemies, especially bosses, can completely drain health in three or four hits, whereas it takes many more to take them down. When fighting bosses, I felt like I couldn't make even one mistake, because one mistake can easily take out half of my health in less than a second. I'd often reset the save if I made any mistakes during boss fights because I knew there was no way I could recover from it. The combat is woefully unbalanced. 2) Saving points are rather scarce, which can make dying in some situations very annoying. 3) The controls are not as responsive or 'tight' as other Metroidvanias I have played. There have been many times where my character does something else other than what I wanted to do. I've never had this problem with other Metroidvanias on the Switch (e.g. Axiom Verge, Hollow Knight, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, etc.). 4) I cannot find any option in the menus to lower the difficulty. As far as I can tell, you choose your difficulty at the very beginning and that's it. Maybe there is a way to lower the difficulty. but I can't find it. I don't want to sound like I hate this gameI don't. I still think it's worth picking up if you like Metroidvanias. Just don't expect a game as grand and refined as say, Hollow Knight.
This game is awesome, the graphics are perfect and the music is a masterpiece

This game has absolutely beautiful art, and plays amazingly on the Switch. As many of you know already, Limited Run does small batch game releases, so If you missed this one please Consider picking it up here! This one is an excellent choice for the platformer fan!
Haven't had a chance to play this yet. But might have to leave it wrapped.

I grew up as a SEGA Fanboy. I had everything from Game Gear all the way through Dreamcast. I thought for sure SEGA would win the console wars. Sadly, I was wrong. SEGA then decided to release some of their old titles in multiple collections throughout the years. This all started with the classics on Genesis. It seems that since then almost every SEGA system has had a SEGA Collection. Even PC got a few. When I found out that the PS4 was getting a SEGA Collection, it was a hard decision for me. I already purchased the PS3 collection and got most of the trophies. Did I really want to sink money into a PS4 collection? Here's how SEGA gets you. They release these collections with different combinations of games. You are always missing a game or two that are epic, but not represented in the latest collection. What's more is that this is essentially a PS4 port of Steam's SEGA Collection with a few games in and a few games out. So on to the product. You start in a game room. All the Genesis games are on a shelf in alphabetical order. You choose the game and watch an animation of it slid into the Genesis. It's charming at first, but after playing the @tGames Sega Systems, I miss just clicking on an option and launching the game. In addition to the library of games, there are challenges for most games. For Virtua Fighter, you have to win a match while starting with only 30% health and 1 round lost. Unless you've played the game religiously, there's very little chance of completing this challenge. There are also trophies for a chunk of the games. Some are as simple as collecting a number of potions in Golden Ax to reaching a certain chapter in Shining Force. What bothers me about the trophies is that some seem too daunting to be worth the effort. DO I really want to play through Shining Force until I reach that chapter? What if it's not my style of game? New to SEGA Collections is the Fast Forward and Rewind options. You can use the shoulder buttons to rewind a game to a previous point to undo a mistake. You can also increase the game speed to skip through cutscenes, text, or other portions of the game you would like to shorten. The game library is the 'largest yet'. While true, the question is whether you'll find something you like. The core games are split as follows: RPG's, Strategy, Beat'em Ups, and Platformers. If you like more than 1 of those genres, you'll find something worth your time. There are also several Genesis ports of arcade titles. Altered Beast is represented as a Genesis game in this collection (while you could unlock the arcade version in the PS3 edition). Then there are games (like Flicky) that are fun for a moment, but obviously products of their time. Overall, I enjoy this collection. The ability to play online makes it great for those rainy days (or if you just want to relive your childhood online with a friend). With over 50 games, I would recommend this.

The biggest positive I can give this collection is that you can play many of the titles online with friends if you want to, but this collection to me falls short of the PS3/Xbox 360 collection. For starters Sonic the Hedgehog 3 and Sonic & Knuckles are missing this go around. Also most of the Sega Collections previously also gave you arcade versions of some of the games or even Sega Master System like Phantasy Star. The other problem is it is missing the game manuals. I actually liked having that in the previous releases more than say mirror mode and I have finished almost all of the challenges already. Only like two are super ridiculous and the rest fairly easy. The second Golden Axe Challenge gave me a really hard time while the first and third one I completed in one go. Even beating the first box in Streets of Rage with max health is not that difficult. Now if you do not own any of the prvious collections, then this collection will likely be a big bonus. For me though it is a light version of so many of my previous collections at this point.

This compilation has a greater number of classic Genesis games than previous console compilations, but a few things might give you pause: * The main menu is clunky and slow, and completely unnecessary. Set in a pre-rendered early-90's teenager's game room, you'll have to slowly navigate from the TV to the Genesis, or to the window, or to the stereo, or finally to the bookshelves where the games reside. * Once you get to the games on the shelf, you can only see the box spines. Who wants to just look at the box spines? Give us the front cover box art! * And there lights affixed to the shelves, which means any of the box spines not directly under a light are almost completely black and illegible. Seriously? * As for the emulation, it's pretty good. The audio sounds off in places, but it is notoriously hard to properly emulate Genesis sound. The only major gripe with the emulation is with the fast-forward and rewind functionality, which is accompanied with an ugly 80's/90's VCR vertical hold filter - that you cannot turn off! If you can look past these shortcomings, I would recommend this collection.
If you like the Sega Genesis and you own the PS4, you need to buy this game!

If I was just reviewing the games lineup and the emulation Id probably rate this game 5 stars. Yes, there are a few notable ommissions but no compilation is ever perfect. What I cant forgive is the complete lack of in-game instruction manuals. No way should I have to look up games online and then adapt the control schemes to my PS4 controller buttons.
Good deal on a nice selection of Sega Genesis games for your PS4, and some nice additions over the PS3 edition. No Sonic 3, no Sonic & Knuckles, which is a little disappointing.

This was a great pickup. It feels like you are back in the 90s playing your favorite Sega games. When you go to the opening menu it's set up as a bedroom and you play the games on a 90s tv. You can change background settings, make a game a favorite, and rewind part of the game if you die or miss something important. You are not just picking and playing a game but it gives you that feeling of being a kid again.

Frankly I found this collection to be unplayable. There are constant audio glitches and stuttering as well as really bad input lag. I'm playing on a PS4 Pro, so I don't know how it runs on other consoles, but this is just terrible. I feel cheated.
Very nostalgic but the games are terrible except for the 2 Shining Force games

This is the best we could hope for with a Sega Genesis collection on PS4. The online multiplayer is a great feature but I experienced latency on a 60 mbps cable connection. I still highly recommend this for anyone who enjoys these classics or wants to explore them with the classic mindset for the first time.

From Sonic to Streets of Rage, you get a lot of bang for your buck. Including a 3D interactive game room instead of a generic menu with the list of titles was a great design choice. Online gameplay is also present for those interested. A few game-changing features are also implemented like a rewind/fast-forward button and being able to customize the TV screen HUD. Only gripe involves the rewind feature being too slow and imprecise to undo significant changes in use.
I want impressed with this game...maybe my Hope's were too high...but I thought this game was to be way cooler!!
My girlfriend loves this game. She play it all the time
I love that Ubisoft didn't just port an existing version of Monopoly onto Switch. It looks great and I am enjoying it with my friends in both tabletop and docked modes!
I love playing Monopoly but I dont have anyone to play the game with at home. The game allows me to play at home alone.

This is a very fully featured Monopoly game for the Switch. The game features the classic boards in addition to some graphically snazzy boards (including one featuring Ubisofts' Rabbids characters). The controls work great and the game uses all of the Switch's control options. Up to six players can play together on the same screen (either with individual controllers or by sharing the same controller). A great party game for families and friends. The only complaint I have is that some of the new style maps have considerable frame skipping when playing in docked mode. Portable mode appears to run much better.
This game is nice for monopoly lovers. Game play is a little slow but overall fun.
Many hours spent playing on the switch. Cool graphics. I like that you can choose what kind of game you want to play.
We play this with the kids .. they love it .. Fun family game , easy to play on the switch.
I purchased this for my granddaughter and she loves it!!

This is a fun rendition of Monopoly and makes for a speedier game vs the board game due to the automation. There are variations of the game to play for quicker sessions that dont take the massive commitment of playing a traditional game. The game kind of stalls out after playing awhile though due to lack of achievements and just turns into playing the game rather than having tasks to attempt to complete. If you love playing monopoly though it wont let you down.

This game is more for older kids to adults.We enjoyed this game. Love that they have live boards to chose from as well. Our 4 &6 year olds were able to play except for when trading, auctioning or mortgaging bc they didnt understand what it was. Other than they they liked it as well.

Overall, this game is amazingly addictive! Especially if you're already a fan of the original board game! With all the different ways to play, this game will definitely keep you playing for awhile! However, I wish there were more themed boards to play on... when you play the live boards, you only get a choice of three. A haunted theme, a city theme, and an amusement park theme. You can also play the game on the classic board as well! Another issue I've come across is the game crashing... it often does this when the auto-save feature isn't working (which is currently the only way to even save the game). Whenever the next player's turn arrives, there should be an icon in the upper right hand corner that indicates the game is saving... but sometimes this icon fails to appear during gameplay. If it does, the game is certainly bound to crash at some point during the game (unless you're lucky enough to get through it quicker). That's my only major issue with the game as a whole. Otherwise, it's a fun and addictive game to play! Especially with friends and/or family!

A lot of people complained about the long loading times. I haven't had that issue. However games take very long to play. Waiting for the AI to move is like watching grass grow. And there's no way to skip past their turns or speed them up. 'Quick' games can easily take upwards of 2 hours and will drain your battery in handheld mode.

I LOVE Monopoly. I collect both physical and video games. I have played many versions of Monopoly and this Nintendo Switch version sucks. It is very boring and a little difficult to play. I love Monopoly. But this game is lacking. Even on the easiest setting the computer trades with itself to get monopoly.

Complete garbage. Not only do you have to deal with a huge day one patch, but the game takes an hour to start. 30 minutes to start up and 30 minutes to load the board. The fact this got tested and approved is a huge joke. This is the cartridge version.

I was excited to get home to play the game only to be greeted with a huge update, no problem. After the update the game is unplayable... literally. Its been sitting at a loading screen with houses and hotels for around 15 minutes now and thats after one reset. Ill update my review if I ever get to play the game.

I know I'm not a fan of Monopoly but still bought this. It was painfully slow sitting through a game of this, which is much worse on a digital platform than the actual boardgame. More for people who truly enjoy Monopoly.

Monopoly is a true classic on any platform. While you could certainly pay a lot less and pick up the boardgame version, you'd miss out on all the cute little themes and animations this version has to offer. There's everything from a Nintendo themed board to a Haunted House themed board that changes as you play. Worth picking this up for $20 or so bucks.
Such a sick game. Sick nasty bro. Sick. Sick. Sick nasty.

Another edition to the Mortal Kombat line, this edition gives you all the DLC of the regular edition except in one nice bundle.

I bought this game so my son and I could play a fighting game (and because Street Fighter isn't on the XBox One) and it's a good time. I started off button mashing and having some pretty good results, but as he actually practiced it didn't take long for him to catch up to my mashing abilities. The graphics are nice (as you'd expect from this generation of consoles and games) and the action is as high speed or as stealthy as you are a fighter. A lot of the fighters are familiar from the multitude of Mortal Kombats before it so I didn't come in unaware, but they have new moves, new sequences, and background interactions that give it some depth. Like all fighting games, it gets a little repetitive after awhile, but it's still a good game that's easy to get into and takes some time to master. Her'es a little hint that my son failed to share with me until later into the game: you can see all the combo moves and finishing moves by pressing the menu button at any time.
MKXL IS AWESOME!!!!. Not as good as the last generation game but sitll entertaining none the less.
Took it back to the store and got the ps4 version.

If you like JRPGs and anime in general, youll definitely like this. The combat system is unique as music is a part of it. Its basically about Japanese idol culture where you the protagonist are a singer for an idol group. Weird supernatural things happen and now you and your idol friends have to fight the forces of evil. All with powers given through music. Its a typical turn based JRPG that works fairly well.
Good jrpg ported on to the switch. It runs good on for me so far. I heard it been censored in the west. I hope it doesn't bother me but if it's true that kinda sucks.

Minus 1 star for censorship. Should have had all the content. It wasn't even obscene. Nintendo has allowed way worse. Otherwise, it is Persona 5 lite clone for switch owners. There's basically no Fire Emblem involved outside of a few character designs.

Picture it. You take the last three iterations of the Persona series, sprinkling in a little bit of that Fire Emblem character goodness, add a dash of MegaTen, and you've got Tokyo Mirage Sessions. Not quite as good as the sum of its parts, but an excellent romp and one of the best JRPGs in years. Gameplay has you working your way through labyrinthine dungeons, much like in the last few Persona games, with your team of magically inclined teenagers. Fights are turn-based and fluid, allowing you to get repeated advantages against enemy weaknesses, making for fun and flowing good times in battle. Atlus ingenuity plus Nintendo slickness. Story is predictable but fun, pitting your cast of heroes, all of whom are actors or models or singers, etc, against evil demons that want to steal our artistic inspiration. Silly but very enjoyable. Not quite the next Persona or Megami Tensei, but an excellent game in its own right that completely stands up solo. Very recommended.
Finally get this game from the wiiu on switch and its better than ever. If you like Persona and Fire Emblem give it a go.

Game is very similar to persona. The main relation to FE is in this game versions of personas. The main characters is Chrom. Also some sounds like leveling up. Only downside is game language is only in japanese, so unless you know some Japanese, you won't know all that is said during battles. Very weeby, so you have been warned.
Not my cup of tea for jrpg. The battle system is off putting and sometimes cheap.

This is a master-class RPG in every sense of the term. Great characters, fantastic music, unique and complex dungeons, and some of the best combat in any game I've ever played. After playing the Wii U version several years go, I was immensely excited to see this ported to the Switch, and having now tried this version for myself, it more than lives up to my expectations with its new content and optimized performance. If you are even remotely considering this, do yourself a favor and buy it.

Having sunk 20 hrs into it, can say that despite the really fun way the battle system works (chaining your party member attacks together into larger combos based off of Fire Emblem style enemy weapon/elemental weaknesses) I can unfortunately see why it didnt sell well when first released on WiiU in 2015. Lots of the game just has straight up bad design choices in it that feel like padding made to stretch out sections of the game. While that's HARDLY a new concept in an RPG experience, it's quite awful here. At the very bottom of this review I'll post my take on what a typically awful side quest feels like. How are the dungeons? They're pretty linear, with little offshoots. They would be 'fine' if not for how confusing (some) get, but only because everythiiiiing looks the same in the dungeon, that by the you reach the section of most dungeons you dont know where anything is (like oh yeah I have to backtrack and flip that switch on the mannequin, or jump off that ONE ledge...but it all ends up blurring together). Also, the amount of backtracking the game asks you (not talking Metroidvania-like or anything), just to find a glowing sparkle on the ground OR to just continue a conversation (in a sidequest) is embarrassing for a game of this supposed caliber. However the battle system is a total joy. The boss battles are difficult but not cheap and defeating them is bliss. Not a terrible game but just feels c-list in effort and c-list budget. Good music though. *Here's an example of a typical awful sidequest: 'meet me here.' You meet them there. They tell you the absolute most generic cliched little story about them possible. 'Ok. lets do this.' They disappear, you take 2 steps, get a text. They say 'meet me here (or worse yet, guess where i am).' You teleport to the general area and walk to them, of course waiting to cross a road along the way. Then they talk to you, via an in-engine cutscene. 'Ok.' They disappear again. You walk 2 steps, get another text, 'meet me where we just were before this.' Open map, teleport, walk over to them. HOLD DOWN X TO SKIP ANYTHING THEY'RE SAYING, GUESS YOUR RESPONSE TO THE DIALOG. 'ok, meet me at an area we were at 2 steps ago.' Then you'll have the final cutscene BUT make sure you go to Tiki IMMEDIATELY afterward, before doing anything else.' Games makes sure you have to also walk thru the SAME office again for the 100th before going into the Tiki room, instead of just immediately taking you there. Apply this pattern to everyone NOT in the main battles.

Shadow of the Colossus was the exemplar of how video games could be treated as art back in 2005. Between the music, visuals, gameplay, and minimalistic yet stunningly deep narrative SotC proved that games were more than mere entertainment. They could make you think and feel; they could move the audience through an interactive media in a way that people had not previously engaged with art. These sentiments are still true today, 13 years after the original was released. Shadow of the Colossus in 2018 is not just an update or HD remaster. This is a ground up re-make that retains the full spirit and experience of the original while giving a modern audience the kind of fluid controls and sharp visuals that we have become used to. This is how re-makes should be handled. This game has been crafted by people who understood what made the original so memorable, and who obviously worked extremely hard to retain that magic. Absolute recommendation. 10/10
One of the best games on PS4 I have ever played. Ever!

It seems nostalgia is dominating reviews on this. This game is not great. It is good, I guess, but I couldn't play it more than 15 mins. The controls are awful and clunky. The camera angle is all over the place. Riding the horse is awkward with camera angle and controls. I seriously hated this game. It looks pretty on the PS4 Pro. I will give it that and the only reason it got 2 stars, but I turned it off after 15 mins and traded it in. Really confused why the reviews were so good.

Never played this game for PS2 so it was a must have for me hearing all the positive reviews surrounding it. Was not disappointed. Great game which I'm assuming only got better once they remastered this from the ground up.
This how all remakes should look. Rebuilt from ground up. Looks gorgeous.
Bought this on sale as a gift for young girl. She really like it and was very happy and uses it all the time.

This game is fantastic, I played the original in PS1 and now went through it again in the PS4. Besides the gameplay being incredibly enjoyable I would like to express that you would be hard-pressed trying to find a similar game. Basically, you roam an open field land where you must destroy these living giants. However, you usually have to climb on them but the process will have you on the edge of your seat all the way through.

This game is the exact remake of the original, but with a graphical overhaul and performance upgrades --Here are a list of changes to the game: 1. Graphics. Unlike the PS3 Remaster, this version does not only have graphical up scaling, but also new renders and slight remodels of the environment, characters and colossi. A night-and-day difference; the major change you'll notice in this version as you can now see detailed in the rock formations, strains of grass and individual hairs in the Collossi. The Dynamic lighting effects in this game are amazing and is the best I've seen in any game thus far. There's also reactive foliage and water physics to get you more engrossed into the world 2. Constant Frame Rate. Unlike the choppy inconsistent frame rate of original, this game has smooth frame rate throughout. If you have a PS4 Pro you can play at 60FPS at 1080p (performance mode) or 30FPS at 4K (cinematic mode) Standard PS4 runs at constant 30FPS at 1080p 3. Controls. The core gameplay is the same, but there are some quality of life changes added to make the control more modern (you can also opt for orginial controls for the purists out there). PS4 Touchpad brings up a map Jump is now the X button instead of Triangle Dodge/Roll is the Circle button instead of R1 + Triangle 4. Game now saves automatically. Praying altar no longer serves as manual save terminal in-game and only heals Wander when activated. 5. Photo mode You can pause and take pictures at any time and add filters similar to other first party exclusives like Uncharted and Horizon Zero Dawn 6. Gallery Collection of digital pictures filled with comparison shots and concept art 7. New Game+. This time around you can select different difficulty settings instead of sticking the one you beat the game with. There's also Mirror Mode and Time Trails. 8. Trophy Support You can now earn PSN trophies (when comparing to PS2). Compared to the PS3 version; there's 7 more additional trophies you can collect bringing the total to 38 vs 31. PSN considers them different games so if you own the PS3 version you can stack trophies --What Stayed the Same: -Story. You go to this alter and try to resurrect a fallen princess. You are told in order to do so, you have to defeat 16 Collossi roaming around the land. Then off you go and try to slay 16 of them in a series of boss battles; each of them different in size and ways to take them down. Story isn't that deep at face value, but through gameplay, you'll get a deep moral understanding/emotion investment of the world especally when you reach closer and closer to the end game. -There are some returning issues with the game like how your horse does what it wants at random times and camera issues when in narrow corridors. For those who only play modern games the character controls may feel a bit stiff and clunky at first, but you'll get used to it if you keep at it as there is a learning curve to the character's movement. -Sound is spectacular as always. The colossi roars are more distinct this time around (either that or I have a better headset this time around). Still no English voice acting, just random gibberish coming from characters Overall, best way to experience the Shadow of The Colossus if you haven't played it before, and an excellent revisit with enhanced visuals for those who did.

Shadow of The Colossus is often considered a 'MUST PLAY' for anyone who considers themselves a fan of video games, and is similarly cited as one of the shining examples of games as art. While the aesthetic design, musical score, and just overall presentation of this game is absolutely stellar; the game shows its Playstation 2 era roots with somewhat clunky controls and decidedly oldschool design choices. For any potential buyers who don't know what this game is, I would stress that it is much more of a puzzle game than an action game. Each colossus feels like a puzzle you solve rather than a beast you fight like in a typical action game. The quality is there in this game, I just didn't particularly enjoy it, and I would encourage any potential buyers to research what they're getting into before purchasing.

Ive wanted to play Shadow of the colossus ever since it was released on the PS2 and never got around to it. I figured with the HD remake it was the perfect time to play it. Im halfway through the game and im pretty disappointed, its a boring, repetitive game. I knew what I was getting into and thought a game comprised of only boss fights sounded great. Yeah, not so much. All the bosses are very similar and theres not much else to do in the game.

Game is pretty and the music is beautiful, but the controls made me want to throw my controller at the screen. Everything is needlessly complicated or not nearly optimized. Gameplay is boring as well and repetitive. This is one of the most overrated games I've ever played. Don't believe the hype and make the same mistake I did.

So you're basically just riding around on a horse all the time doing pretty much nothing... there are 16 bosses in the game.. and that is the only actual game play. Like there is seriously NOTHING ELSE in this game. If you weren't riding around on a horse doing nothing you could beat this game in maybe 2 hours of actual game play. I can't believe I paid for this.
The game is good but do not expect much from it. The graphics are beautiful and impressive. But the mechanism of the game remains the same or worse than before. very very frustrating

The graphics are amazing, such was the draw to the game in first place. The reason it is not great is the controlled movements in game play are not as responsive as i would like. Another kind of annoying feature is the game makes you look at what it wants when looking around. You can of course look at your surroundings by taking control of the view but as soon as you hand comes off the button, it reverts back to what it wants you to see. The actual movemnts when on horseback look amazing however controlling it leaves something to be desired.

It probably depends on whether or not you have played the original Shadow of the Colossus. I have never played the original and I was not impressed with the overall gameplay (just killing giant colossus creatures over and over). However, the gameplay structure is great and the graphics are awesome...it just wasn't really my style of game.

In Shadow of the Colossus you play as the wanderer seeking to bring his love interest back to life. In order to do so you must defeat 16 different Colossus. What sets this game apart is the sheer size of the Colossus themselves. They tower over your character and defeating them consists of climbing onto the monster, locating and attacking their weak spot until they're defeated. There isn't anything else to do in the game besides this. The pacing of the game can drag as the world, although beautiful, is void of any characters.

I have never played the original game on the PS2 or the remastered on the PS3 but, over the years I have always heard of this game and/or seen it mentioned in the media and content that I consume on a daily basis. I have always heard of how this game and of how it influenced the production and artistic direction of a lot of future games,movies, and media and how much impact this game had in inspiring future projects. Now after getting my hands on the remake and after playing it, I see why this game was ever praised to begin with. If I could compare this game to other media like movies or music, this would be one of the many epics of the gaming world, just like LOTR is to movies or Bach is to music, this game is a classic. I don't want to make it sound like I am on the bandwagon hype just because this game got re-released (which truthfully, I was) and I just wanted to be part of the crowd. You might be thinking (as I also did at a time) that this game was just over-rated and that this game only served to please a niche genre to a niche group of people that just couldn't let this game go, but considering the fact that this game got released on the world's most purchased console, up against other great games of its time, this game had its moment and it should of just faded into one of many games that came out long ago and in the end should of be forgotten, yet this one managed to stand the test of time and still manages to be an epic game in today's standards, this game deserves all the praise it has gotten then, and all its getting now.

I have to agree with the other not so great reviews. This game just is not that much fun. You do the same thing over and over and struggle doing it because the controls are so wonky. I gave it a 3 star because fighting the colossi can be enjoyable, if only for a few minutes, and the graphics and landscape are really well done. I finished the game only because I paid $40 for it.

This game, this beautiful masterpiece, has and always will be my all time favorite game. From the soundtrack, to the ambient noises as you travel, to the most epic soundtrack ever, this games always makes me cry and get so many goosebumps cause of it's sheer awe. It never fails to amaze me and I always have so much fun playing the game. I've spent countless, COUNTLESS, hours playing this game ever since I was 12 and I still play it to this day religiously. February 6th, bring it on baby.

I don't usually write reviews, but this game is so bad that I felt inspired to write one. I hope to save some people a few bucks. I know there are alot of good reviews out there on this game. I am baffled by that. I have to believe that those people did not play the whole game. I believe they must have only played the first couple of monsters. Because up to that point, the game was somewhat acceptable. And the nice visuals might have overwhelmed them. But if they continued playing they would find that this game violates almost every rule of good gaming - and some that I didn't even know could be violated. It does have a couple redeeming qualities: It looks good; and it has some cool monsters. But that is where it ends. The game play is awful, the navigation is awful, the controls are awful, the repetitiveness is awful, the map is awful, the story is awful, and the ending is awful. The game kept taking me to new heights of aggravation. If the controls and navigation had been good, then the game would have taken about 5 hours to beat. So it feels like they intentionally made the controls and navigation bad so that it would take longer to finish the game. That is a bad mistake. I would rather have had fun for five hours, than aggravated for 20 hours. I could write a book about all the flaws in this game, but to save time, let me just focus on one issue as an example: The Navigation. The game gives you three tools to help with that: A sword (which points to your destination), a horse (to travel on), and a map. All three of them suck. The sword points you in a general direction, but once you get close, or get in the mountains, or the woods, it fails. It usually leads you to a location where you have a few choices (like go left around the mountain, go right around the mountain, or go down a path thru the mountain). There is nothing telling you which path to take, and usually taking what looks like the logical path does not get you there. And in fact takes you a long way that often ends in a dead end, where there is no way to go but back out the way you came so you can try another option. Its like getting thru a maze without an overhead view of the maze - because the map is worthless. I have never seen such a worthless map. And on top of that, navigating back out thru the woods or thru the mountain on your horse is painful because the controls while riding the horse are so terrible. I often found myself quitting the game and restarting from the staring location, just so I wouldn't have to navigate back out and circle back around on the horse. I could go on and on about other flaws in the game. But I hope this gives you a sufficient taste. I post this bad review because it is getting so many good reviews, and I hate so see game developers encouraged to keep producing bad games. So if you are considering this game, please be sure to read other review out here. I'm not the only one trying to warn you. Good luck, and enjoy your (other) gaming!

The Switch port of Final Fantasy XII The Zodiac Age is in decent shape. In handheld mode, the image is definitely blurrier than any other release, including the base Xbox One version. I have posted a comparison between the Switch Handheld version and the PC version (in 1080p), but keep in mind that it will always look crisper on the actual Switch screen than it will on a screenshot. The frame rate is limited to 30fps (which is true for all other versions except for PC/Xbox One X) but it seems to be stable. The Switch/Xbox One ports come with some new features that the PS4/PC versions do not have. They are: -Licencse Reset, which allows you to switch jobs at will (acquired less than an hour into the story) -Additional Gambit sets. Gambits allow you to manipulate party AI, and this new set feature allows you to create up to 3 different sets of Gambits and switch between them at will. -An improved New Game+ that lets you start at level 90 and carry over weapons, magic and gil With these new features, along with the portability of the Switch, it is hard not to recommend this as the definitive version. The blurriness is definitely notable to me, as I have played the PC version as well, but in this case the good heavily outweighs the bad. P.S. Oh, and the title screen appears to have some input lag not found in the PC version. If this is a bad first impression, worry not. I tested everything past the title screen

I'm so happy I got this!! I never got to finish this the first time around for a couple of reasons... The main one being because even though at the time I enjoyed the look and style of this entry... I wasn't the biggest fan of the newer battle/exploration mechanics because I hadn't really played any MMORPG games yet that FFXII is similar to. I also had NO IDEA what length/size of an adventure I was getting myself into! ...But now I can chip away at this gorgeously crafted game anytime anywhere and it didn't take me long to fly by where I stopped the first time. It's great to hear a fully fleshed out orchestral soundtrack paired with improved visuals but the best thing about this version is the new (and very customizable) job system. I will probably get daggers thrown at me for this (and trust me, this has taken a lot of thought on my end as I am very much a single-digit FF fan) but this might be my new favorite in the series!

Final Fantasy XII is my favorite Final Fantasy game, mainly because of the art style and world-building. Final Fantasy XII is a super long game, and one that I never thought would be brought to Switch, but now there are four mainline (more if you count X-2 and XV Pocket Edition) Final Fantasy games on Switch. The port of XII was done by Virtuos, who did an awesome job with both the port of XII to the Switch as well as X/X-2 HD Remaster to the Switch. The performance is really good, and it looks better than I thought it would.
Did not have time to enjoy it yet. Have played FF7 and thinking about returning it.
I am old school rpg kinda guy and this was not I had expected.

When the original Burnout Paradise came out in 2008, I bought it and had a blast playing it. After 10 years, it finally arrives to the PS4 and Xbox One. Is it worth buying for New and Veteran players? Yes*, but there are some caveats that I need to address. I'll start with the Positives first. With this remastered, it comes with all the DLCs and Updates on the disc. So, you will get the additional cars, online modes, and even an additional Island to play and race with. Secondly, the controls are very tight and the physics for all the vehicles handle great and different. The game runs natively 1080P 60FPS on both the PS4 and Xbone and also 4k 60FPS if you have the performance versions of these consoles. However, I will now address the cons for this game. While the graphic does look slightly cleaner and polished, it's not much of a bigger difference from the PS3 to PS4. Also, some of the gameplay aspects has not aged that well. For example, if you are not familiar with the map yet, you will be constantly pausing the game and look at the map to make sure you are heading to the right direction. Next, like many modern racing games you can set a waypoint or have some form of fast travel to reduce the monotony. However, in this game you have to manually drive to all the locations, and without putting a custom waypoint, it goes back to my 1st issue. Lastly, if you wanted to change to a new car you have to drive back to the Junkyard each time and then wait for the vehicle to load and then select it. These issues are annoying at worst to a minor inconvenience at best. Overall, despite some of these issues the game is still fun and if you are a new racer or a returning veteran that likes to take a turn on Memory Lane, then pick up this game. The game has a lot of things to do and you can easily spend hundreds of hours playing this game.

I assuming most players have already play the game on the old version but I will write my review for those who might be first timers on the game. first of all the game is super fun, it is just amazing I could say with all my honesty that is probably not the best racing game on ps4 but is for sure the most fun to play its the best on just racing and free roaming and do whatever you want in the city, only action, without story missions or cops or any career and that staff. The way that the cars moving in this game with all the speed and almost unlimited nitro and real trashing up the car scenes, it can blow your mind away. It has some fictional but still very awesome cars and the races and challenges can be just incredible. as for the remaster , I hadnt finish the game on ps3 but I have played a few times and I can say that game is very improved , for the graphics , for the sound effects , for the mechanics . It does not look like a brand new game but it is still much better that the old version. I give it 8 ,1 point for the graphics which are okay but not the best and 1 point because I play it for 4 days I have almost reach the end of the game , so its kind of short to me . In general is a MUST have game for anyone who just love racing games.

This game is the perfect way to take out road rage in a safe and acceptable form. I do wish they would have brought back the destructive mode that was featured in the PS2 release, 'Burnout: Revenge' where you accumulate points by causing the most damage to the vehicles in the surrounding area in one launch. Other than that missing feature, this game has already provided me with hours upon hours of entertainment. Even my girlfriend has fun just driving around and exploring the map!
I loved this game on the PS2. This was a first day purchase for me. I cant wait to replay this game on PS4.

Burnout Paradise released back in 2008 on PS3 & X360 and it was a game I thoroughly enjoyed. Stunts, crashes, takedowns and much more was on offer in this beautiful racer. A tight and very responsive racer, this game also introduced a huge open world to drive around in both offline and most importantly online with your friends. A little off putting at first because the developers didn't give you a waypoint. They gave you a compass and on the minimap a destination. It was your responsibility to find the quickest route. But this design decision was a solid one. It necessitated learning the map and shortcuts. Now EA has finally released a remaster of this title and on PS4 Pro and a 4K/HDR capable tv this is a sight to behold. Unfortunately the game doesn't support HDR but it's a looker nonetheless.
This was not what I expected at all. Worst game ever!
Save your money and get something else, this game was a waste and nothing compared to other racing games.
Not very good did not enjoy not happy with this game
What a waste of money. Never never never again. It used to be good
very hard game to get into with friends it is a bit easier lots to learn but you get no tutorial or any tips at all internet is needed to learn the basics

I just started playing this game yesterday and so far there ar eno tutorials on how to use the crafting system or where to go for points of interest. I'm playing single player mode and hopefully the game will progress with more tutorials and points of interest.

This game is an open world survival game where you are dropped off on a mysterious planet with ... wait for it ... dinosaurs. You had me ad dinosaurs. It can be hard to figure out what the controls do at first, and it can be kind of punishing. When you die, you lose all your stuff unless you can go to where you died real fast and pick them back up or you stashed them somewhere. But it is totally fun to see all the dinosaurs running around. You can even tame them! If you like complicated games where you can sink hours of fun into them, this is the game for you. It is definitely not a casual title.

Been playing this game since early access; comparing to when I first started this game to about 5 months ago, the game has come a long way despite some bugs and glitches that had taken so long to fix up; the only hiccup I've run across from time-to-time was some spawn issues with my base due to it being so large; pvp can be a nightmare sometimes, but overall, I love the graphics, adjustable difficulty, things to do throughout each map (total of 5 right now, with favorite being either Ragnarok, Scorched Earth, or Center); and with all the creatures to tame, fight, and equipment and resources to go through, it can be tedious but fun at the same time; I've had a great experience with this game and honestly couldn't recommend it more to a friend :)

My son asked me to purchase this game for him so that he could play with his friend. I don't know if it was a good thing or a mistake because I haven't seen him since I bought it and its all he talks about. Ive watched him play a handful of times and it looks like a decent game compared to the other gruesome, explicit games on the market today. Overall I would say this was a homerun purchase.

Ark is an absolute incredible game... for those who have the patience to play. There is no goal or missions, you just play to play. You collect materials, learn to build different items, collect more materials, level up, collect more materials, and die... a lot. Once you get a hang of it though and level up a bit it becomes a beautiful, fully immersive experience.
this game is very enjoyable to play with friends and online

I bought this for my son for Christmas, and Best Buy had it on sale for 30.00 plus my gamers unlocked membership which was great. I was waiting for the price to finally come down, when it did I snatched it up. A BEST BUY CSR left me know that on the 22nd of December the DLC content would be on sale, as this CSR was an ARK owner/fan. Instead of the full 80.00 dollar cost for the FULL DLC - SEASON PASS content price I got the FULL SEASON PASS DLC on the PS Store for only 30.00. Each DLC that is released is said to have over 300 additional hours of play. Not all has been released yet but they're a couple available. Scorched earth is our favorite as my son and I are Dragon lovers. I collected pewter dragons, anything dragon when I was young and into my teenage years. Now my son has my collection plus we have started his own collection. Scorched earth is full of ALL KINDS OF DRAGONS, and you can tame them, ride them, etc. I will say scorched earth isn't very easy, even if on easy. This game reminds me of Minecraft but a more realistic life like version with better options. It isn't easy to survive, but I recommend looking up survival startup guides on youtube, this will help a lot. Also if you play Co-Op it's very hard to see the writing when your trying to read, see what you have in your inventory, or when crafting.

Did not know what to expect from all the bad reviews but I am enjoying the game. Runs well on the PS4 Pro, Have had no freezes or crashes in the 15-20 hours I have played so far. Graphics are good on High detail setting, yes there are some wacky animations here and there such as fish swimming nose down underwater but its few and far between so far and framerate is stable. Got it on sale for 29.99 so did not pay full price so based on that its worth it.
My son was begging me for this game So I got it for him and it delivered as much fun as he hoped for. Hes even got his siblings and all his friends hooked on this game also.

Disclaimer: I have only played offline single player at the moment This game for sure has a much more steep learning curve when compared to games like Minecraft, but it is worth the initial frustration as the environment is truly breathtaking. Some little annoyances such as inventory management with stored items being a little cumbersome, but after a while it ends up just being a little hiccup in an otherwise finely tuned game. Patience is required, but if you are looking for an immersive experience to take you away from reality for a good amount of time, Ark is a great option.

This was a trying game in the start, but once you understand how to get resources and build things it becomes a fun challenge. As long as you are able to create a shelter and stay focused on your level of hunger and water consumption it should be a very enjoyable game.
