The cover clearly shows a woman riding a dinosaur while holding a gun. But one third of the time, ranged weapons don't reload due to a glitch that's been in the game for years and never fixed, thus you get killed. Another third of the time, you'll be searching google for instructions on how to get the game's functions and menus to work. and the other third, you'll be killed from behind by a dinosaur you're pretty sure wasn't there a second ago, then respawn killed shortly after. In short, the game is buggy and unbalanced, and not in a way that makes it any fun. Consider No Man's Sky instead.

First person survival with dinosaurs. Expect to gather and craft your way to bigger dinosaurs and more crafting items all in a pretty setting with decent but not excellent control mechanics. The story is one of self discovery. Don't expect much in the way of interaction from the game. Who should play this game? Someone who want little more than exploration and survival challenge.
Very disappointed in this game. Base building/resource gathering with dinosaurs sounded like a blast but I found it to lack any explanation, tutorial, anything. Got off to an immediately poor start.

Sadly, this game isn't a tripple A title, they don't even supply the scorched earth map with this, to me its not worth 60 bucks. Have this on xbox and pc, got both for around 20 bucks each. official servers are horrible, pvp: iv seen large tribes pretty much force smaller groups to 'pay for protection', pve: tribes fight to board up as much land as they can out of pure greed. Sadly, private or single player for the most fun. Once you start taming rexs and spinos theres really no challenge or much left to do in it without mods, the game just becomes farmesvill or harvestmoon. If you join tribes becareful of their rule sets as they can claim your dinos/gear/mats/land/buildings when you join, if you leave your SOL. If you see it on sale for like 30 bucks I'd say go for it. Deff recommend steam pc version though, with mods on private servers you can have over 4K hours logged easy.

In Beta game was a blast except for the updates 3 times a day.... now that its released they down for about 1 update a day. Here is the problem now..... If you want to play and have tech support you cant play on a'legacy' server so that forces everyone to play on a official. Well at launch and for the next month or so the servers were all full. So you can even get in, now only weekends are full so dont plan on playing then. The big kicker now is they limit the number of tamed dinos a server can have.... the personal tame limit is like 600 when the server tame limit is like 4000. what does this mean? well it means that like 5-6 people on a 70 person server can cap it out and they did. I have around 10 dinos.... i went to tame more and it wont let me because other people have 400+ so now everyone on server (ragnarok 71) is stuck doing nothing. and tons of people tryin to transfer so the last few new servers are capping. so unless you can play on a private server with friends i wouldnt play this if they paid me.

This is the old Hot Shots Golf series on PS2, PS3 many loved it is the same studios Clapz handz and Sony Japan. We finally get an arcade golf with DEEP campaign solo and online modes...After what-3,4 years...some may be tirned off by the very Japanese aspct of the game which I mean by that the games here are not straight ports from Japan like this one so for little kids much of the english translation is awkward and the game definetly has a silly anime approach that if you dont follow that genre it comes off as odd and stupid. So understand it is a straight port but nothing is chaged from the Hot Shots of old-this is GREAT ARCADE pick up and play Golf BUT has Vasttly DEEP solo campaign if you want to get a year out of your 20 dollar. YOu cant beat it. I have always felt Hot Shots golf was the must underrated Playstation series leading up to this ridiculous 4 year wait for another next Gen game finally. Will probably be the last entry we ever get here in the Us if they even make another period. Buy it bc when the next one comes out it will be on Playstation 6 and you may be dead by then anyway. Best sports series by far for quick OR hours of ginding if you like simple yet infuriating later in the game difficulty playing CPU challnges head to head. Rewarding to beat the characters in stroke play like the Hot Shots of old to unlock the different Golfer Bosses. Why this is not a YEARLY game when it is so easy to rinse, repeat the engine, models it is a easy cheap production but one of the best sports games of all-time as a series for kids and 80 year olds (I am not 80 but an 80 could play this due to the fantastic simple one button arcade style if you wish so). It is 20 dollars buy it now and thank me later. Im positive we won't get another entry.

Picked this up yesterday, so I've only played a few hours, but I'm really enjoying it. The character creator gives you a lot of freedom, and you can change your name or how you look at any time, so there's no pressure to create the 'perfect' character off the bat (unlike so many other games). The actual gameplay is easy to pick up, but super fun. There are a lot of small RPG elements to keep things interesting (clubs level up, you can buy items, there's an overworld for you to explore), and the game itself is brimming with charm. So glad I bought this game. Highly recommended if you enjoy games like Mario Golf.

This game is TERRIBLE if you are looking for a true golf game ala Tiger Woods. To begin with, it took 20 minutes to get through the beginning cinematics with no ability to skip, fast forward, etc... Once through that, the assumption was on to regular golf...wrong. Its this speed golf system that they use with early 2000s Japanese graphics, emojis, etc... After playing less then one round this game was placed back in its case and every attempt will be made to return it or sell it to somebody looking for a non-golfers golf game. My recommendation is to stay far away from it if you have any experience golfing, are looking to replace Tiger Woods or Rory McIlroy or are looking for any semblance of a true golf experience. Terrible...should just be called an arcade game, not a golf game.

Battlezone has a great co-op campaign story but it s not innovative. That s where i take a star out because it does amazing things but there is a little issue. The maps look practically the same. It would have been better if the devs were projecting 3 or 4 different maps at least in variation but no the map look just the same. This game use procedural technology which means that the replay ability is amazing although be aware of the most frustrating rules that the devs implemented for gamers that just started. 1. if all your team mate and no chance to be revived anymore then you failed your entire campaign. This is where it s frustrating because if you just started the game for the first time, it will be difficult. Also the mechanics of the game aren't well explained. For example they do not mention that if you stay close to your friends it will heal you automatically and regain your energy. A lot of players i play online with weren't aware for this regeneration. You are also dependent on other players which means that someone can screw your campaign for you to start all over again. 2. you do not keep your upgrades and you have to restart to accumulate your point to get them back. Verdict 4 stars for the game as it is a good game to start with although not goo enough for a 59 price tag

This re-release/re-master of the 360 Kinket exclusive is Impressive all around Never played the 360 version now I'm a little curious if the kinket gimmick hinders what this is meant to be If you are a hardcore FPS gamer this might not be for you If you are a open minded child of the 80's and you played some of the best 16bit Disney games on the Sega Genesis You'll find a lot to dig about this title It's also a must if you have kids (I would think kids would dig this) It's a open world adventure game in the Disney theme park Is it fun???? For what it's meant to be without a doubt I started it up and played in 3hrs straight It has that magic Disney had during the late 80's early 90's It does get repetitive at a point but, let's be honest what game doesn't Being able to ride various rides kind of sucks and feels cheap But, playing various shorts, segments from Classic Disney animation/feature films is another high point You get to fall down the rabbit whole in Alice in Wonderland and play various moments in the film! Simply awesome but, too short The items you are given along the way expands the game play from taking selfie with Disney Characters, Fishing out items with a fishing poll, a Magic wand that brings items to life and a Buzz Light Year laser gun to name a few The Story is paper thin but, it's just mindless exploring and fun You are some kid running around alone in a theme park making manhole covers explode and bringing light posts to life where is this kids parents or the park security for that matter If you are old enough to vote or do other adults thing (Just turn off your brain and enjoy the ride) Graphics A+ super slick and polished This game should have been bundled with the XBox OneX for two big reasons it would be a solid tech demo and to draw a family audience into investing in a somewhat expensive gaming console Once in a great while the game does lag a bit mostly when you are doing multiple things around a crowd of people Audio is also top notch the DTS sounds good (almost all the characters sound right except Baloo from the Jungle Book/Tale Spin) This game is super impressive with sounds coming from all around you the detail is super impressive for a game like this Controls are easy to pick up and play (The only negatives with the controls is switching between various items from Camera phone to magic wand, etc. feels a bit clunky and off it should've been just tap the (R) button and items would switch on the fly Another small negative you can not run which makes the game seem a bit slow at times, the jump while going through the them park itself has no real reason (You can't jump over gates or small areas) Overall this is to some extend a must have launch title for the One X I had more fun with this then Assassins Creed Origins Unlike AC Origins this game doesn't have massive chunks of audio drop out whenever it feels like it If you want to relive your childhood it will surprise you and do a good job 8.5/10

So I bought into this game after playing the original and not knowing anything about this entry. If you've played and enjoyed LEGO Worlds you'll likely really enjoy this game. Different from past LEGO games this entry takes a page from the sandbox genre where you explore and find items to build the world around you. This may sound similar to past games but this time your breaking down objects in the world to find unique blocks to unlock patterns to build new objects that you can freely place around the world. Once you've found the requisite number of each blocks you can advance the story and move to a new area. It's fun to play and nice to see TT Games test out some new gameplay methods. All around for this being a fun game with a $40 price tag I'm finding it pretty fun to play with my kids.

Disclaimer, I bought the digital version from PSN. I am posting here to inform of my impressions. This game may be called Anime Souls and rightfully so. There are many aspects of the Souls/Bourne genres that blend well into the game. What is Souls/Bourne, well in short, it is an action RPG adventure game where you learn enemy patterns, fight large bosses, enemies respawn when you rest/heal, using a form of currency that is also XP that is derived from killing enemies that may be lost on player death with a limited time/lives to recover lost funds/XP. Pros: Sound: The music is atmospheric and appropriate. You are energized to fight large bosses or feel impending dread during normal grinding. Character Customization: You can create and later edit your character in many ways which also appear in cut scenes. Many hairstyles, accessories, eye types, voices, the combinations are endless to build your avatar. I think I spent nearly 30 minutes building how I want my character to look only to have the option to change her later. Blood gifts/abilities: You start with 3 main classes which can be switched at any time but you also gain others. You are not stuck with predetermined roles as you can master the skills and benefits of each class and blend them. Cons: The fighting: The game is a great action game with hack/slash mechanics. There are moments when your timing is perfect yet you cannot execute an attack. Another problem I had was the backstab attack. You will do more damage as well as have immunity and a unique action sequence, but there are times when the attack will not work when it should or I had 3 in a row when the monster should have died with the first, each subsequent attack doing no damage. This is a great game. There is some fan-service, essentially overly sexualized or exaggerated body sizes and skimpy outfits, but they are not as rampant or degrading as some publications would make them seem. Honestly, Misti from Pokemon is more risque than all the characters I have encountered so far. There could be more to the game, a little more in-depth RPG mechanic or more blood codes (classes), but it is a good entry into a Souls/Bourne-style game that is not as hard. The story so far is decent and has a good premiss but the main character is lacking, not just because there is no voice acting for them but they do not act quite the same as a normal person would. There is a demo, play it if you are on the fence but I highly recommend this game.
This is up my alley of some fun!! It is more than what I expected. I have a lot of family members that agree!!

Resident evil 4 and 5 are superb 3rd person action 'horror' games with non stop tense close encounters, (Which INITALLY control clunky by modern standards.) If your not fan of having to make every round count and conserve all the healing and resource items you can, then odds are you will be disappointed with RE 4 and 5. RE4 is the full package including the alternate episodes after completing the game. As well as mercenaries. Same with RE5 (the download code in the box) seems to include all the old DLC and the better Version of the enjoyable 'mercenaries' mode. RE 5 and RE 6 have full online co-op support but require a Nintendo online membership to use. They also have offline split screen when the switch is docked but beware of the awkward cropping Capcom used to do to split the screen for local multiplayer. If you were to pay for these individually on the switch digital store I believe it totals at $90 so this multi pack (physical copy of 4 and download codes for 5 and 6) is a great deal. Also beware of the download size you will need aprox 18GB for RE5 and around 25GB for RE6.
So, this is RE4 physical copy with 5 & 6 on digital. Fine with me, but wanted to make sure this is known. Some of my favorites ever, love they are now portable!!

I expected this game to have a bunch of freezing and lag issues at certain points but it does not. I did notice a slight frame skip in the first stage of RE5 when there are numerous zombies on the screen at once, but not after that. Furthermore, being that it is Nintendo Switch online multiplayer, I expected the service to be poor quality at best like how Mario Maker 2 performs online. I didnt have any lag spikes at all during the entire RE5 campaign with my buddy (we havent played RE6 online yet). So, I am very satisfied with this port. It performs as I had hoped and beyond what I expected.

I couldn't pass up this value deal, 3 games. RE 4 is whats on the cartridge, while the code is included to download RE 5 and 6. All games work great and look great on the Switch. I would recommend this for those Resident Evil fans!
If you like the Resident Evil games, this is a no-brainer. Looks and plays amazing on my Switch Lite. Note that it is a game card of Resident Evil 4, with download codes for 5 and 6.

Im a huge Resident Evil fan so I had to buy this, but its a shame that there are 2 download codes. My concern is down the road when these games begin to be 2nd & 3rd hand, two games are missing from a title called Resident Evil Triple Pack. Also, if the eShop should ever close its servers in the future, nobody will be able to play 5 & 6.
Big fan. Love the intensity. Great buy!! Would recommend for RE fans

Give it a go if that's the case, or if you want them to be portable. If you've played them before, then I wouldn't recommend it. There are better versions of these games out there.

I played Fallout 3 and 4 already and thought I would give New Vegas a shot (even though it's a bit old at this point). With Fallout 4 Bethesda (game developer) got criticized by critics and fans a like for having a weak story and a world where most interactions/quests involved shooting generic post-apocalyptic bandits. Fallout 4 is a great game but the actual role playing/world building part is very very weak. You could make similar comments about Fallout 3. In contrast Fallout New Vegas was made by Obsidian who are known for taking other people's games and making really interesting stories. In New Vegas your actions shape how various factions in the world perceive you and treat you, so what you do actually has consequences. Many of the quests and characters are memorable and well written. To give an example the other day I played a seemingly generic quest where I had to update some radio gear on behalf of a military officer. This led to a mystery about military reports that were clearly false. This ultimately led to a conversation with a really nice old man in the organization who eventually admitted that he thought his group was involved in a military mess (think Vietnam or Iraq) that was wasting a lot of young lives. He alluded to the fact that he was falsifying reports and undermining battle planning so that leaders back home would think things are hopeless and end the war. After confronting him I tell him I will have him arrested and he accepts this. Then when you leave his office he locks the door, apologizes to everyone over the loudspeaker for losing his way, and then shoots himself. I struggle to think of an interesting story like this in Fallout 4. If you like Bethesda games like Fallout or Elder Scrolls I highly recommend Fallout New Vegas. The graphics are pretty bad (they weren't even good when it first came out) but that's not stopping me from having fun.

I originally played this game on PS3 and it was truly a nightmare. Freezes, crashes, frame-drops, and stutters getting worse and worse until the game couldn't be finished. It was terrible. Now, THIS bad-boy right here, running backwards compatible through a regular Xbox One, is the complete opposite. It plays like a dream. Load screen times are clearly reduced, few if-any frame-drops, and it hasn't frozen once. It's been widely accepted that this is the best 3D Fallout game and after finally playing through it here (along with the INCLUDED DLCs), I have to agree. The wasteland is yours. Take it! Take it all!

The story is a bit more linear and the world is less open ended but New Vegas makes up for that with more and better action. The DLC comes for free with this version of the game so that is even more stuff to do. Overall a great package that will tide me over until Fallout 4.

Most reading this have probably played Fallout 3. If you haven't, grab that one as well! Both are worth every dollar spent. I won't go into the story too much, it's on the back of the box and there isn't much too it w/o spoiling it :) It follows the basic story telling and leveling mechanics as Fallout 3. You level by executing (and I say that because nothing is Better than a vats head shot!) enemies and leveling up. As you level, you are able to put points into a variety of skills from bartering to stealth. You are able to have a maximum 2 companions at once (one human one robotic). You cannot level them up, but they do level with you and each have their own strengths and weaknesses. Onto the DLC. I enjoyed most of them, three of the four to be exact. The story with the DLCs made it feel like they could of been thrown in with the vanilla version, which is expected. I hate DLCs that entirely change the feel of a game. You want more guns and head explosions, right? Yes. I didn't care for the Sierra madre DLC in the pack. It just seemed like an entire other team created it... It was overly dark and the story wasn't as engaging in my opinion... If you enjoyed fallout 3, or enjoy a great story telling RPG (and can deal with some glitches and quest bugs), this is probably the game for you. I played thru it twice, and for a game this large you can probably fit 50 hours into 1 play through... -AgtJ

I've played this series since the beginning and when this remastered version that includes 3 previous releases came out, I passed on buying it because, well, been there done that. But when it was announced they did a FREE PSVR update patch, I finally bought it and I gotta say, this game is now one of the best offerings for VR yet! With 3 remasters in the package, Wipeout Omega Collection is an amazing value. While 2 of the 3 are from last-gen PS3, Wipeout HD & Wipeout Fury, the final entry is from the handheld series, Wipeout 2049. 2049 shows off the largest difference, thanks to the bigger difference in format, all 3 have had a ton of love involved. Everything has been upgraded; this is NOT a nostalgia cash-in for those of us who grew up with the Wipeout series from its earliest days on PSX. Beyond the visuals, the game(s) runs at 60fps, and the controls, always smooth, are even moreso now. If you've never played Wipeout, you're in for a real treat. Atop including 3 games, with numerous tracks per game, each includes a plethora of vehicles to start, along with even more to unlock. Littered around the tracks are a variety of power ups to help you or hinder opponents, along with many boost pads that keep the pace at one of the fastest (still) in any racing series. Pulling off barrel rolls (always risky, as tracks that feature jumps aren't always very high jumps- timing is crucial,) will also grant your floating rocket a quick burst of speed. But all this speed comes at a price. Vehicles all have shields; and attempting to use walls to bounce back from a loss of control will deduct from them. Opponents firing at you will also cause damage- lose your shields and your ship, you'll have to rerun the race. Picking a favorite company to race for does not stick you with their vehicles, but that said, your best bet is to find a sponsor early that has a vehicle you can handle well. As you play, you'll earn loyalty points by the sponsor which, in turn, helps you unlock more vehicles from them. Constantly switching sponsors will delay getting into newer vehicles, but you're never 'locked in'. If a particular track gives you trouble, never hesitate to swap out, as each company seems to have a 'set path' of expertise- (some may have health & shield as priorities, others as speed & handling, yet others may focus only in one area that gives a much higher bonus to just one category). If one track is giving you a hard time with turns that's costing you precious health due to many sharp winding turns, don't stop yourself from temporarily switching to a better handling/ shield combo. There's a small learning curve: it's easy to pickup and play, and if you choose to just enjoy the game, you will. Vehicles are less 'weighty,' constantly bobbing (both due to the anti-grav nature of the game,) and tracks quickly progress from easing you in to the game to challenging your reflexes. If you choose to play Wipeout as fun, no worries- easy mode, and normal, later, remains more of a fun challenge. Yet the game allows for true mastery; watching those who devote efforts into it can produce dizzying runs of speed that's more akin to a well-choreographed speed ballet. Just like the originals, split-screen is supported, as well as online racing. No skimping in that area, including a 'race box' that allows you to host multiplayer online events with varying tracks and presets. Wipeout is, without a doubt, one of the best racing series that ever hit Sony, if not in all of gaming. The slow dismissal of the series (Wipeout HD & Fury were never released physically, and hit early in PS3s lifespan,) was met with dismay by longtime fans; not due to nostalgia's sake where replaying it reminded you why it became outdated, but because it was easy to pickup, a challenge, fun even when runs went wrong, and breathtaking to behold when you had a perfect run. Two final things: They've included a fun photo mode that's becoming more and more standard now, but is still much appreciated, and lastly, if you're looking for a couch co-op game that's not something that requires tons of planning/ getting 'stuck' playing longer than you intended, Wipeout is PERFECT. It's an incredible game to sit down with friends, some pizza, and some drinks while being able to end the game once your session begins to die down. 3 games, low price, high value, and not a cash-in on memories. Whether single player or multiplayer, Wipeout Omega Collection is yet ANOTHER win in the Sony exclusives.

This was a relatively inexpensive game and my son enjoys the How to Train Your Dragon series, so I thought that this would be a good purchase. Unlike the previous How to Train Your Dragon videogame on the Wii, and as the title suggests, this does not largely feature the familiar characters of the movies. Hiccup, Toothless, Astrid and Stormfly make their occasional appearance to help you obtain items through trade, but this is not their adventure. Regardless, my son is infatuated with this game. I would note that this game is not particularly difficult; the puzzles and fight sequences/attacks are geared to a younger audience. It is not a particularly long game, but, again, it is fine for the younger set, say grades 1-4. I was initially making this a 3-star review, but because my son enjoys it, 4-stars is more appropriate as that age group is who will play this game.

Piloting your own mech is a dream come true in this shooter/sports game. I have heard some people get a bit sick playing this title, but I have had no issues and the game gives you a lot of options on how intense you want the experience. RIGS is a deep game. There is an offline line league, online battles, trials, tons of upgrades, a slew of different Mecha to pilot, and tournaments. This is the most complete game I have played at PSVR's launch. If you like shooters or sports games don't miss this gem.

You can get some multiplayer games going if you join PSN communities and go to the Rigs reddit and make some friends. However, just trying matchmaking won't work. Something that I never understood about Rigs other than you can do single player 3v3 games in leagues to hit singleplayer is that there are a lot of unlockables. There are 4 different mechs and within that there is like 6-7 special abilities like getting health after a kill is an example of one. There are also 'Trials' where you get to run through rings in a level, shoot targets, fight enemies, etc. in sort of a chain and they progressively get harder. I thought this was pretty neat. There is also a lot of customization for your pilot that you can unlock and sponsor challenges that you can do in your offline or online matches since they are separate. I can only imagine how great this game would be with multiplayer being filled with other players. However, if you go into it expecting to play against bots with some challenges and a lot of unlockables I think you will not regret this purchase. The level of polish is amazing in this game and the difficulty is there to win and demolish since initially the game is pretty confusing since there is just so much to choose from. For the $16,00 I got it for via GCU I think it was worth the price.

This game is a lot of fun for a 2nd or third game to play. After a long break from VR going back to it it was little disorienting. Still a lot of fun. Use the Comfort Settings to be able to ease your self into it.
Game is very different from typical mech and racing type. You really feel like your in the drivers seat. Can give you a headache from the fast movements at times.

It is a great game for VR. I like the mech layout and customization.... still takes a bit of time to get used to, there are different methods to control turning, etc... so find what works best for your brain. All in all, great game.
Well I thought the game was really amazing for kids and adults also I really liked the effects

Some background. I'm not a sports fan, nor do I particularly care for sports games. However, I genuinely liked this one. As a VR experience, this is one of the first 'real games' for the system. There is an authentic sports game to be experienced here. That's why I rated the game good (I really wanted to love it). My biological experience with it is another thing entirely. The game tells you to play in short sessions, to allow your body to 'adapt' to the virtual experience. After all, the body 'thinks' it's there. Not a hard thing to stay true to for me... My stomach would knot up and literally hurt after 20 minutes of gameplay, effectively ending my gameplay for the evening. After several sessions, I was able to go 30 to 45 minutes before I became too nauseated to continue playing. If I had a die-hard love for sports, or this game, I would have toughed it out. I did see improvements from the short sessions over the 2 weeks I had this game. I do not feel that it's fair to give a bad rating to a game because my biology doesn't 'sync' with it, but buyers should be cautioned - you will need time to adapt to the VR aspect.

'Detective Pikachu' is an odd 'Pokemon' title. It's a spin-off point-and-click adventure with a gruff-talking Pikachu as your protagonist. It's an interesting, but more importantly fun twist. The character of Detective Pikachu is very fun and engaging. He really makes the game come alive. I can't wait for more games like this.

I'm about halfway into this title and I'm really enjoying it. At times it feels like an interactive movie as much as a game, with pre-rendered cutscenes and voice-acted conversations taking up a lot of the play time. But especially for a kid who's new to mystery games, I'd say this would be a great choice. It's not too demanding with frequent hints from Pikachu and an optional Easy Mode, and there's no punishment for getting any sections wrong. As an adult and longtime Pokemon fan, I was really impressed with the creative direction here. The city where the game takes place is full of people and Pokemon living side-by-side, and that gets used in some really creative ways. A lot more thought went into this than the typical, main-series approach of 'Everyone you meet wants to talk about battling and nothing else'. This felt like a sort of fun spin-off of the anime world I always wanted to visit as a kid. Give it a try.

I went into buying this game with no real expectations. It seemed like an interesting addition to the Pokmon gaming franchise and it is now one of the best games I've played on my 3DS. This is a fairly simple game but extremely entertaining and fulfilling for die-hard fans of Pokmon and would also be a perfect launchpad for brand new fans of the series. The graphics are beautiful on the New Nintendo 2DS XL (this game ONLY plays in 2D anyways so it's not necessary to have a 3DS). While the game is extremely easy to advance through, it will provide a good 10-14 hours of game time start-to-finish and has fairly high replay potential due to the Pikachu amiibo adding additional content. If you are looking for a challenging game with a lot of action, this isn't the Pokmon game for you but if you are a long-time fan of the series in genera or a brand new fan altogether this is a really great addition to the 3DS gaming library.

Scooby-Doo meets Pokemon. That's Detective Pikachu. With simple cases that don't involve just a lot of guesswork by the older crowd, but is still thoroughly enjoyable by everyone, I can't think of a better description. The game is voiced quite well with some fun dialogue. No matter your take on the gruff-voiced Pikachu, the voice work on display here is solid. Nothing to knock you out of the park, but lots of wit and humor given a life. I don't want to make this a long review, so I'll actually end it off here by saying that Detective Pikachu deserves a 5-Star rating because it's, simply put, enjoyable. Much like the Kirby series, it's enjoyable, and it has a lot of heart. You can tell everyone involved enjoyed creating and localizing this title.
This is a new game of Pokemon that doesn't follow the usual formula. Great game overall
I bought this game for the memes, but I have become addicted someone help me.
amazing pokemon spinoff amd pikachi talks with a hilarious voice
Lovely game - surprisingly perfect at being enjoyable at all ages without feeling dumb for playing. Kind of unique within the Nintendo line. So far - I'd buy a sequel.

The pinnacle of human invention, Detective Pikachu bestows meaning upon my empty life. If there's any criticism to be made, the part where Detective Pikachu waterboarded Charmander in an attempt to extract info on the whereabouts of Boss Muk was arguably a bit much

The hat has true detail you wouldn't normally find in an Amiibo. sadly, there isn't much more detail you can put in a pikachu than what's already there. As for use, I'm a little disappointed. All it really does is just unlock some movie clips in the game. Not such a big deal at the end of the day. Even then, the base is so large, it doesn't even fit on the screen of a new 3DS! Still worked though, but I had my qualms when first opening it.

Detective Pikachu is a strange but ultimately entertaining installment in the long running Pokmon franchise. While the plot may seem predictable at first along with early gameplay, it quickly evolves into a challenging but rewarding experience.

For years, I've been saying Nintendo should make a 'Best Of Mario Party' game, and this didn't disappoint. Granted, I expected it to be on a home console system, not the DS family, but this thing is quite a gem. There is not a single misstep in these minigames. Whereas each Mario Party has some minigames that you groan when you're forced to play them, each minigame here is fun to play. I was nervous about who was deciding what the 'Best 10' games were from each Mario Party, but Nintendo had astounding insight as to which games should be included. I even felt there was quite a bit of thought that went into the chronology of the way the games were presented. For instance, the Slot Car Derby game is positioned in as much of a critical spot in the single-player mode of this game as it was when it appeared in Mario Party 2. Another example is Bumper Balls, which is perhaps the quintessential example of a Mario Party mini-game, and is appropriately placed in the very last stretch of the single-player mode. Even Bowser's Big Blast is described as the 'most vicious' mini-game, which is spot-on for anybody who remembers the strike of fear whenever this game would be chosen. There are two downsides to this game, the first being that there isn't any real game board to play on. There IS one basic game board where you chase stars (a la the N64 and Gamecube versions), but it's very primitive and doesn't offer much strategy. The only other downside to this game is it can't be played with friends, unless they also own a DS. This is a bummer as I am the only 30+ year-old loser I know who owns one, and I think it's illegal to walk up to minors in the park and ask if they want to play a game with me. There's a very simple remedy to both of these problems: put this game on the Switch. In fact, you could re-release the same exact game with the addition of the 'best' game board from each of the 10 Mario Parties. This way, you can have the game board style of play that became so quickly beloved and was the design for Mario Party 1-8, and you can also integrate the linear gameboard that's available in Mario Party 9 and 10, which seems to be the new direction of the franchise. I do not own a Switch. I don't plan to because I own a Wii U and there is quite a bit of overlap between those two consoles. But if Mario Party Top 100 were brought to the Switch with some of the original game boards from the earlier Mario Party series, I would get one without hesitation. Cognizant of the fact that Nintendo is not going to take my feedback and do what I'm asking, I'll just say that this game is a real treat and I recommend it to anyone who has had fun with this series in the past. I can't even imagine how fun this would be with other people.
Great mini game collection but lacks the magic of older Mario Party games. Wish this was released for the Switch instead.

I personally was hoping for more, I was expecting online play, and more board options, however after seeing my toddler play this game, it's a good game for them to explore different game play and strategy. I had fun playing with him.

Without a doubt, this is Platinum Games' best creation to date. So good it's their only game to reach #1 on the sales charts. +You can choose one of several ways to play. There's an option to focus on story, for easy gameplay, for a challenge, or slam against a wall until you get good. And all of these options are available from the start. +In-depth combat. Nail a few basics and you can get through the game. Or unlock moves and travel down the rabbit hole of creating chains of attacks that look beautiful when done correctly. +You can see how good you really are by seeing mission rankings. (only on the two hardest difficulties) +Costumes and colors to unlock by playing the game, exploring, or doing menu work. You're rewarded for trying all the things available to you. +Fantastic music. +Portable. I can't stress this enough. You can play this on the go. There really is only one bad thing I can say about this game. -You can and will be juggled by enemies if you're not careful. Especially when facing groups of enemies. This is even worse when you become stunned. Would I recommend this? With all the gusto I can muster. Nintendo gave Platinum Games a home when everyone else turned them away. And they are showing how just grateful they are. This game is sitting at a solid 8 and 9 across the board for a reason.
This game truly is the GOTY of 2019 there's no question about it, doesn't get better than this.

For those who have no idea what this game is it is best described as a Hack n' Slash/Beat em-up/Shoot em-up game that likes to at times take a break and focus on detective work similar to a game like Detroit where you gather clues and information before proceeding through a level. These detective instances can be as long as you are curious of your environment and are usually the starting point when going into a level and is followed by the combat that is the central focus of this game. If this sounds like your type of game then you are in for a treat as this game takes the style and makes it satisfying especially with it's own unique mechanic that grants you more options than just button mashing. For the most part how the game plays is extremely satisfying, especially once you begin mastering the added mechanics that make this game unique. You're given a Legion that you can control either as an auto-attack AI, fully control the movement of at the expense of controlling the camera, as an addition to your chain of attacks to deliver a strong blow, or (again once you get a hang of every utility the game offers for you) all of the above. This Legion is linked to you via a chain which you can wrap around enemies to bind them in place for a moment or use to springboard off of as you pull yourself towards your Legion along this chain. It takes a bit to familiarize yourself with controlling it, but once you do the possibilities expand and you find yourself playing a game you've never played before. Now that you got the gist of what you do in the game and how it makes for your experience, it's time to discuss the faults of the game that prevent it from being the perfect experience it could easily have been and making you aware of what you're probably not going to like. First of all as the Legion is a second weapon at your dispense, controlling 2 things at once can make a hectic fight feel even more hectic, especially when your Legion is just getting knocked around or isn't quite moving as precise as you want it to nor does it always land a blow when you use it in your string of attacks as mentioned earlier. The main reason behind the frustrating control of your Legion would be the fault of the camera and how it operates particularly during. Your camera's position is ultimately what determines how your Legion moves and given the game locks-onto enemies (who of course move and dash respectively during combat) all it takes is an enemy to move a few feet towards you and now your Legion isn't going in the direction you were pressing it to go and more importantly intending for it to go. This makes wrapping around enemies frustrating especially in hectic fights with more than 3 enemies engaged at a time; also given the chain doesn't necessarily seem to have a consistency to snap onto an enemy and stay on top of that makes attempting a seemingly crucial, centralized feature frustrating to use in a lot of instances. Continuing with the lock-on given you change targets with the same input as the camera (right analog) when you're trying to get a better view of what's around/behind you you'll accidentally be switching targets when you don't want to which will ultimately lead you into swinging or shooting as nothing as it sometimes does even when you're locked-onto the correct target. Ultimately there are going to be moments where you should be hitting something, but you aren't. As for avoiding enemy attacks and stopping enemies there's fault in that too as the game doesn't make for a nicely-tuned way of assuring your dodges are successful as most other games do. You'll be taught in the game that if you dodge an attack just before it hits, you can swing back with a fury of blows. However there'll be times where even if you perfect dodge following up with an attack will only result in you getting hit and knocked off your feet as the game will not isolate your battles amongst individual enemies so if you got 2 enemies on you and they both swing at you one slightly later than the other, dodging will only mean you moved into the other enemy's attack and trying to attack is as futile as trying to dodge both attacks at once. Your attacks barely have momentum to them too so if you deal with a faster enemy don't ever expect to land a full series of attacks as hardly anything will make them flinch and hold them back from them knocking you to the ground or flinch with 1 or multiple hit(s.) If these things get touched-up in future updates then I'd have no complaints about this game. The more technical you can be the more satisfying playing gets. They do give you a 'sparring' option in the Training Room in the HQ building and you can choose from various enemy types to practice on; use this to brush up on your skill and familiarity of the combat of the game. It's definitely a useful option that even someone like me who usually just picks up, plays, learns along the way, and avoids training modes in games even resorted to, invested in, and found great use in. As a wrap up the game despite the flaws mentioned (in detailed, horrendous length) is actually very comfortable and satisfying. From the genre it's definitely something I'd strongly recommend. While it's downfalls are frustrating it doesn't make completion feel impossible and it's unique use of the Legion makes for a feeling of a fresh new game that you've never played before. I've given a 4/5 stars as it's not perfect, but to put the frustration of the flaws in perspective in a 10-scale rating I can't put it higher than an 8/10 as 9/10 would be undermining the effect of those flaws.

After release weekend having played through quite a bit of the game I think the game has been great. The story line from this game has been better than the story line from the first game in my opinion. As always the details in this game is amazing. When you're walking around Washington DC and can see legit land marks it's a great immersion. Street names, store locations, etc all real! Add in the weapons! That's right, the weapons are real. You can find actual firearms in use around the world by military and law enforcement. Weapons react as you expect they would. Weapons and gear can be modded to give better tactical advantages as you progress. Release weekend there are still some bugs that were not detected during betas, or that just simply made it through. While annoying they're not entirely game breaking and the devs are already working on fixes. Cosmetics are where the real collector comes out in you. Everything from hats and sunglasses to little backpack ornaments. You can outfit your Agent in tons of different ways.

Since the only review at the time of posting this was a preemptive post about being excited for something that couldn't actually be reviewed at the time and because the beta managed to not expose a lot of the issues, I figured it was only fair to write an honest review. I pre-ordered the gold edition and picked it up on the 13th, which allowed for the three days of early access. The exotic shotgun you get is only good for a few levels, so it's more or less just to make you feel strong for about 30 minutes. After that, it requires you get to level 30 before you can upgrade it. That is, if you even remember it when you reach that level. The game content is just as good, if not better than the first game. Unfortunately, you may find responding to calls for help a little tricky at first because you have to respond and then locate the person on the map to accept. This is not so bad, though. It allows you to meet a lot of new players. The biggest issue is that some of the skills do not function properly and the game has a lot of random critical errors. Critical errors are the ones where the game stops and a blue screen appears. On top of seeing them rather often on certain levels, they are also extremely slow to load. After you dismiss the error, you have to load the entire game in hopes that one person in your party did not crash and you can resume progress. You usually get lucky enough that one person in four survived, but not so lucky that it won't just crash again shortly after returning. As for the skills, you probably shouldn't waste your time on sharing the revive version of the hive. It will revive you and it has a 90% success rate to automatically drop when you would otherwise need to be revived and it is available. It will not work on other players, though, which happens to be the main functionality it advertises. Throwing it will leave them sitting in a large blue region as their revive time expires and they die. The beta made it appear fairly stable, so its hard to say if a developer decided to sabotage the game for release day or if they somehow introduced the issues last minute. Either way, they have had four days or constant patching and still no improvement.

With their sense of freedom and loving grasp of the Dark Knight's comic universe, 2009s Batman: Arkham Asylum and its 2011 sequel, Batman: Arkham City, are two of the best superhero games ever made. Batman: Return to Arkham brings both games - and all their DLC - to the current generation of consoles, but an unremarkable graphical upgrade doesnt do them justice. Thats not to say its not noticeable. Textures in Return to Arkham are much sharper: Batmans suit, for example, looks much more detailed. His cape in particular stands out beautifully, pebbled, catching the light. The bigger issue is performance. For a remastered version of older games, its disappointing that neither Asylum nor City runs at 60 frames per second - theyre both targeting 30. In fact, Asylum suffers from some odd stutters when Batman runs through a corridor or turns a corner. The issues arent bad enough to interrupt combat flow, but occasional chugging is a noticeable distraction. Outside of the two campaigns, all the DLC challenge maps and additional skins are here, so you can play as 1970s Batman - or even better, animated Batman - from the get-go. But theres nothing to differentiate the extra content from what was included in the Game of the Year editions, and the lack of making-ofs or behind-the-scenes details is a missed opportunity. If youve never played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City and own a current-gen console, Return to Arkham is a fine place to start. But for those who already own both on PC or last gen, theres no real reason to pick this up beyond a rather uninspiring and technically disappointing graphical upgrade.

A collection of two of the best adventure brawlers ever created. You play as a psychotic vigilante named Batman in order to take down his most notorious enemy: Common Sense. Batman never seems to fully grasp the idea of sending The Joker to a court of law in order for him to be sent to a Max Pen where he'll spend the rest of his life in solitary confinement unable to hurt anyone else. Nope, instead he will be sent back to the Asylum he constantly breaks out off. Only this time The Joker wants to break into it so he can break out again and finally get Batman. Riveting stuff. Great remastered game with strong visuals, tight controls, and a shade of a collectathon game with the Riddler's riddles. Oh, and Batman likes to talk to himself...out loud...a lot...yeah. Get it!

If you haven't played both Batman games on last generation and want to play it for the first time, time this is the version you want to play. It comes will all the DLC, including the skins. The only thing missing are the documentary that you unlock while you progress thru the game. You will not be disappointed!

Just married the love of my life and what kind of wife would I be if I didnt get him video games from time to time? Keeps him busy and gives me something to watch. Game play is ok? I wouldnt know since OG Nintendo is all I got skill wise. He finished it in a couple days.

Both games in this collection play as well as they did when they came out, and run much smoother with stable frame rates and greatly improved loading times. Overhaul of the graphics makes environments look brilliant, and while character models are touched up some they still show their age. Batman oddly looks much uglier, particularly in the face due to details of certain facial features being more enhanced than they were on the previous gen of consoles. Aside from those few quirks, I'd say this is a remastered collection worth recommending.

Arkham Asylum is still amazing! The textures and lighting have been overhauled making for a far more aesthetically pleasing game. The framerate is a solid 30 fps throughout. Arkham City also looks amazing! I only noticed a few framerate slow downs while playing. One thing I did notice though is that it seems to play and look better on regular PS4 and not Pro. Also the FMVs look very pixelated and weird on the Pro, but look fine on reg PS4. I'm sure this has to do with native 1080p output of the game and the Pro's nature to upscale to 2160p (4K). Don't let this deter you though, this collection is definitely worth your time and money!

The original games of the series were groundbreaking in many ways, especially for game play, specifically the combat system! So if you never played the originals I recommend picking them up! However, with the remaster downgrading graphics in some instances, especially in 'Asylum,' it does not make much sense to waste your money on this one! But both games are extremely fun and entertaining, just depends what category of gamer you are in!

If you never played the games before this a great setup. If you've played before you'll be disappointed at the lack of add on for this edition. Graphics in these games is a subject of choice. Honest opinion, the remastered graphics sometime hurt their atmosphere with the high brightness. Sometimes with ridiculous timing and etc especially with Arkham Asylum.

I am a huge fan of Batman, especially the Arkham series of games. I have played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City previously on the Xbox 360 and PS3, respectively. I gave my old systems and games to my nephew when I moved, so this was the perfect opportunity to upgrade to the next-gen versions. These games are still very fun, even though I played them both to death on the last generation systems. The gameplay is still smooth, the stories are great, and the voice acting is top notch. The graphical upgrade is nice, although still not quite up to the level of polish seen in Batman Arkham Knight. The inclusion of all previously-released DLC is also nice, but the omission of the Batman Arkham Origins game is a little disappointing. That game was not as well regarded, and made by a different developer, but I still enjoyed it on PS3 and would have liked to see it included in this collection. This is a must-buy for fans of Batman and/or action games who never played Asylum and City. There really isn't anything new here for people who still own the games on last gen systems, but if you don't have access to the old games anymore and/or want a graphical upgrade, go for it.

I'm a huge fan of the original Arkham game, I played through it 3 times, I have to admit I'm still enjoying it but with this remaster there are frame rate issues. As others have said there is lag at times, something that didn't happen with the original. The graphics are nicer looking but I'm not blown away by them. If you've never played these games by all means pick it up, but I wouldn't rush out to get it just because it's a 'remaster'

I love these games but this remaster is a waste of time and money. The graphics may look better, but, to that end, they sacrificed the tone and ambiance of the game. They changed the trigger configurations for no apparent reason, which only causes problems. And there are moments where the game lags/shutters. These problems didn't exist in the original PS3 versions. A 1:1 port of these games would have been preferable to this muddled 'improvement'.

If you like the previous Batman Games, you will love this one. Graphics are good on PS4. some may like the old gen graphics. But overall looks amazing. Game runs at 30fps NOT 60FPS that is why I gave it a 4 out of 5.
Great memories. A must have for batman fans. Two thumbs up.

SDBHWM (lol) is a crazy game. You can have Goku team up with Vegeta from GT, Super Saiyan 3 Radditz, Super Saiyan 4 Bardock, Adult Gotenks, and a Saibaman. If that sentence made sense to you, that tells you what sort of fan service you're in for. This game is an arcade game from Japan. And where Japan players had to buy actual packs of cards to play, everything is in this package which is like over 1100 cards. You play by making decks of 7 cards and in some cases even equipping them with new abilities. You can even make your own cards. From there you battle and depending on who you use and how you place them on a field they battle and use super moves with their 3D models. The graphics aren't like Dragon Ball FighterZ so you aren't going to be wow'd or anything, and the sound quality for the voices are... well they are from the arcade game and they suck (Japanese arcades are loud and they can't hear them!). But there's a ton of content there for your buck. There's a amusing and cheesy story mode, as well as an arcade mode that has you play through battles based on all arcs of the Dragon Ball Super show Including the new Broly movie, and some original stoy lines as well like Cell and Kid Buu being revived with the dark dragon balls. There's also online play including ranked battles and limited time events. There's no card trading though. You get cards by unlocking tickets as you play. It's pretty generous with them and cards are one time gains. So any duplicates are transformed to a currency you can use for more tickets. Yes you do spend tickets with a Gatcha system, but there's no micro transactions and the rate of getting cards feels good. I love the game and since it's on the switch you can play it anywhere you find time for a quick match and some packs. So I definitely recommend it to any Switch owners who love Dragon Ball and wanted to see some cool things that the show never dared look into! Become a Dragon Ball Hero Today!

Okay so i really love this game, i could honestly recommend it to any dragon ball fans who want to play a dragon ball game that has a different pacing to it. Now if you're not a dragon ball fan, but a fan of weirder card games, then this game might be for you as well, just learn how to read the stats on the card and you'll be fine, you don't need to know about Super Saiyan God Super Saiyan Vegito's abilities in dragon ball lore to play this game. the story mode feels like it's going really fast, but they do a good job of explaining things like it's the first game, even though it's the fourth console/handheld release. And there's online battle and let me tell you, my first online match i fought a dude and died in one turn and all i could do was laugh because i felt like i was rolling through the story mode and then i get shown i have a lot to learn. so yeah, good video game, would recommend to dragon ball fans or card games fans.

This game is a super popular title in the east. Over here in the west Dragon Ball fans have been blessed with receiving a release for the Nintendo Switch! Before I get into this review I do want to state I am a bit bias. I love the DBZ franchise, and I am a sucker for semi grindy-heavy grind rpg's/collect-a-thons. Now if I haven't scared you away yet let me tell you what this cartridge has to offer. PROS: Hours upon hours of gameplay. A fun team building system, and rewarding gameplay. Several levels, and game modes. Nothing gets old if you like the gameplay loop. Many of your favorite faces making a return in varying combat styles, and skins. A Custom/Creation mode. Fully Voiced. CONS: Outdated Graphics (I for one do not believe it hinders the experience at all) Corny dialogue from time to time. The CI Battle system can feel a bit cheap at times in pivotal moments, and can leave you feeling like your battling a rigged game. Some unnecessary QTE's. Long story short if you are a hardcore DB fan, or just really like micromanaging your teams, and collecting stuff this game will be plenty of fun for more than one run. I do recommend getting the gamer's unlocked through best buy to buy this game for 48 vs the full tag price.

The game is so awesome. I like the procedurally generated dungeons. The artwork and the graphics are great. I am enjoying my play through. It only has local co-op which is a shame. But I highly recommend it. You can use different weapon types, spells and upgrade items. Give this game a chance.

I've played Diablo on my switch and I'll get that game again on switch but it's not a game I need to play right now, that being said, a diablo meet anime theme'd rogue dungeon game is what I need to kill a few hours. Dying is part of the progression as you keep weapons and skills meaning that you can get better and better until you finally beat a stage (first few you'll breeze right through anyway) and it's such a relief and sense of accomplishment with games like these, if you like games in the genre it's a must get, anime theme and cute Japanese voices all a plus along with a solid story.

If you've played Pinball FX or Zen Pinball, then you may have played some of these already. This is just Pinball FX but with just the Star Wars tables. There are missions you play through in a sort of campaign mode, so there is some stuff to do. It's a great game to have on the go, and it's great that there's a physical version.

This game is loaded with content. There are 19 tables to play on, and they all range from 'pretty good' to 'real, real good.' They all feature online leaderboards as well as single-player challenges. There's even a campaign mode which has you completing sets of objectives on a table before moving you along to a new one, eventually spanning all 19 tables. Any pinball game can throw a few tables together and let chase high scores on your own. Very few go out of their way to keep giving you new ways to play and new goals to achieve. Being a Star Wars fans definitely helps, but pinball fans will probably love this regardless.

The Switch version of the game has great features, like the all new career mode. The game also features tate mode. I've played a lot of the tables in the career mode plays perfect on the Switch. Great game to add to your collection if you enjoy Star Wars and Pinball Games from Zen Studios.
Couldnt pass up this game for the cost while it was on sale so hopefully it turns out to be decent either way for 20$ should be good

This isn't the first copy of NieR: Automata I've purchased, but I believe in the game's value so much I decided to gift my first copy to a friend and then buy it again. The fact that this is perhaps the only game I've ever felt comfortable buying twice is testament to its success as a video game. While it has the signature Platinum combat style (albeit one of their weaker combat models), it's outside of combat where the game absolutely shines. This game's storytelling chops are some of the best in the industry, the soundtrack is exceptional, and the characters are multifaceted without being convoluted. I do have to point out, however, that the game's side quests are largely very fetch-questy, but aren't necessarily that important beyond understanding the world's inhabitants a bit better. I would suggest researching which side quests to do in order to maximize the world-building while minimizing rote fetching. Also, when people say you have to play the game multiple times to truly experience it, they're only half right. The second playthrough repeats the first route's story through the eyes of a second character, with some major gameplay and story differences as such. The third playthrough is more like unlocking the second chapter of the story, where it takes place after the events of the first two. If you've played an Adventure-era Sonic title with their multiple stories, think of it like them. Would I recommend this version over a normal copy of NieR: Automata? Probably not. Unless it's on sale, you can stick with the normal version as the DLC is a few arenas with some mediocre rewards. Unless you thoroughly enjoy the game's combat (again, not some of Platinum's best), I'd recommend just going for the base package.

You choose a mission and go to the zone and shot up the bad guys and collect things. A lot of other games that people enjoy are repetitive. I would say try the game before jumping on the hate wagon.

Mission structure, loot drops and and load times need patching and updating. The core of the experience is rock solid but some tweaks are necessary to truly make it shine. If you're in the edge about the game, keep an eye out for news on updates and the free dlc Bioware promised to see if it's something you'll enjoy. 3/5 - good but not great. People aren't able to formulate their own opinion so they just regurgitate whatever the big hatemongers on YouTube spew. The game isn't even close to FAILURE OF THE MILLENNIA those people would have you believe, but it's probably not going to set the world on fire either in its current state.

I'm pretty sure everyone has anxiously been awaiting Anthem for a couple of years now, I know I was. Now that I have it in my hands I sort of wish EA would have cooked this one longer maybe even another year. While it looks good, Anthem is a fairly shallow game at its core. Sometimes shallow is good see my Crackdown 3 review as example but in this case, what remains isn't interesting enough to keep my attention for very long. I bought 4 games on the same day, I suspect Anthem will either be the one I play last, or yet another title that gets unceremoniously dropped in the backlog pile with Fallout 76. No, it's not as bad as Fallout 76, but it's close to as disappointing, given the expectations I have of BioWare.

Anthem has all of the potential in the world. Unfortunately, upon finishing the main story line (as of release - this game is meant to be ever-evolving with content updates), you find that the game seems to have been rushed to release without ironing out all of the details. As previously stated, Anthem is meant to be an evolving game as the developer/publisher plan to release new content over time to increase the depth of the game post-purchase. This is a great idea for a console game, in my opinion, mirroring other MMORPGs that are successful, ie: World of Warcraft, Final Fantasy XIV, etc. However, the game was also released with many, many bugs, some game-breaking. The formulas for character health and loot distribution are obviously flawed and have been addressed multiple times with patches, but are still not where they should be. Oftentimes, you find yourself having trouble with content that you just breezed through at the same difficulty. This is because a glaring issue with player statistics being loaded incorrectly for missions has persevered despite multiple attempts to rectify it. Also, there are many times where the game will outright crash causing you to lose your progress, and frustratingly, your hard-earned loot. The main draw, or plus, is the implementation of flying into travel and, most awesomely, combat. Setting it apart from its cohort, Destiny, the ability to fly in all areas of the game (even underwater!) really adds something new to the looter shooter genre. I hope the publisher/developer are able to fix many of the huge issues that accompanied the game upon release soon as this game has huge fun potential if this can occur before the game's playerbase jumps ship.

I've seen mixed reviews of this from game journalists, but as a fan of previous Bioware games like the Mass Effect and Dragon Age series, I'm having a lot of fun with this new IP from the studio. I'm traditionally a solo player and love RPGs, so I usually shy away from online multiplayer games, but Anthem has enough of the traditional Bioware flavor, while still being its own game, to keep me happy combined with fun gameplay and combat that have convinced me to fly my javelin out of my comfort zone and multiplayer missions. I really enjoy the game mechanics, especially the flying, and I've enjoyed exploring the world and talking to NPCs. I doubt any game will ever rise to the world and character-building heights of Mass Effect or Mass Effect 2, but Anthem is fun and I don't regret my purchase at all.

Anthem is a game that is very visually appealing. It is also entertaining having the ability to fly and fight like iron man... to a point. I looked forward to this game, however in my honest opinion it fell quite a bit short. More content is promised in the future, however the current content available is lacking. Anthem provides a short campaign with very little character development. The weapon progression is lackluster and the customizable gear is no where near that of other online games of its sort. Servers drop frequently even with the updates, the sound cuts out at times, and the game simply does not meet expectations. It is painful to express that Anthem is a 6.5/10 at best. It has its moments and will hopefully improve in the near future. I currently cannot recommend the game to a friend, however in the near future hopefully it can improve with updates.

Overall, Anthem is an awesome game that looks and plays very well, in my opinion. Ive read plenty of good and bad reviews on this game but wanted to see for myself. At this time, a week after launch, the game still needs some work to iron out some bugs and server connectivity issues. Honestly, Ive only had connection issues during peak play times so its understandable (to an extent). These issues will not affect the game forever and both BioWare and EA are reputable companies that make quality game experiences. Im looking forward the end game and new content. If youre on the fence about this game, I recommend getting it. Theres a lot to learn, explore, discover, loot, and master so why not get started while everyone else just waits for a bunch of good reviews to tilt the scales from mixed to positive, because thats whats going to happen anyway.
