Reader should know that I have played a very limited amount of COD 4, and have never played a WW II game. Up until now, my favorite shooting game is Gears 2. Having said that, I was very pleasantly surprised by WAW. The graphics was amazing, the campaign really puts you in the middle of the action, you will feel like you are fighting more for yourself and your country. The AI are not as sharp as the ones in COD 4, but hey, that means more kills for me. One upside it has from COD 4 is that you can play co-op in the campaign (up to 4 players), that will definitely come in handy for the veteran level. However the weapon choice isn't as fancy as its predecessor, basically there is a rifle (one bullet at a time), a machine gun (multiple bullets with one click), and flamethrower. Perhaps there will be more selections later on in the game. I haven't explored the online play too much, so I cannot really give an opinion on it. This game probably isn't worth $60, if you have that much to spend, I'll recommend Gears 2, but when you can buy it for $35, it's definitely a good deal! I would recommend this to anyone, and hope you can get it before the end of this week for the deep discount.

The multiplayer of this game is pretty cool, but if you've played COD4, you'll want to go back. The two worst things about this game by far are your AI teammates and the enemy grenade spam. I'm not kidding about either of these; it is the most annoying thing in any video game. The teammates are COMPLETELY useless. Okay, they do occasionally take out a guy, but I've had COUNTLESS times where I run up, then get shot by an enemy next to me or behind me; BUT the worst thing is that my teammate is standing RIGHT NEXT to the enemy, and doesn't do anything. Grenade spams in this game are like no other. You are prone (or crouched, doesn't matter) behind a box or trench, then one by one (or three by three,) grenades start POURING on top of you. If you're playing on veteran, you get shot if you try to run away; so you just start tappin' the right bumper as fast as you can, hoping to get every grenade out of your face. The enemies really don't care about your teammates (neither should you) and start chucking the grenades RIGHT at you (right is capitalized because they hit your face, then bounce to the ground because the enemies have such good arms) I decided to say i would reccomend this because, it still has good gameplay during multiplayer, but, i would reccomend it to them in the future, because this game is NOT worth $60. You don't feel immersed in the game; You feel like you're playing a video game (funny). If you want to hear about some bad stuff in multiplayer, there's a few topics. One of the good things is that they've fixed the spawning problems (MOST of the time) where you spawn next to an enemy a lot. But, i played an entire round with only two kills, because I couldn't find anybody. That's just boring, spending a whole round LOOKING for enemies, and not killing enemies. One of the worst aspects of CODWAW is the (multiplayer) tanks! they're so annoying! the bazooka is useless (it might be better if using the extra explosion damage perk, i dunno), because it takes about FIVE bazookas to kill one tank. Seriously. and you only spawn with two. So, in short, it might be a good game for christmas, but maybe next christmas when the price goes down. And you may think, 'how could the mess up COD that bad? it cant be THAT bad.' But it is that bad. If you don't have COD4, get it before you get this. You'll be happy you did.

This games only good thing is STory mode. THe online play is not realistic as soon as you spawn you get killed which is bad spawn placement. The Perk system is still active in this game, They need to get rid of the Perk system and this game would be much better but the run-in part of the game would be there. Too me this game and COD4 both present a Military based Halo game where u run in and shoot it up. Games are getting away from tactics and going more towards run and gunners. If you are a fan of the Story and like this kind of gameplay with a perk system to cheapen the experience and dying every 4 seconds then buy it. But if you like tactics and want to play realistic shooters go to Rainbow six:Vegas 1 until another Rainbow Six title comes out.

Hmm. Seems the same problem I had with call of duty 4 persists in COD5. The problem is that, you die instantly. Lets see, you die from 1 shot from an ordinary weapon like a rifle, long range. Another thing that's stupid about it is, theirs no more helicopter when you get 5 kills in a row, instead, you just gain the ability to release dogs, that more then half the time don't even attack anyone, they run in circles and glitch to walls. I've played every shooter released this year and COD World at War just isn't up to snuff when compared to the superior graphics and gameplay of games like FarCry 2 & Gears of War 2. COD 4 was great a year ago, but it's a year later now and with COD World at War staying with last year's technology and going with OLDER WW2 weapons, it's just not as exciting as other current shooters. It only took me 8 hours to make it through the campaign and it was a grind because it has scripted A.I. spawning in the same places doing the same thing. FarCry 2 has UNSCRIPTED A.I. which means you never know what they are going to do, for example one time I snuck up on a enemy going to the bathroom in the woods and knifed him in the back. With FarCry 2's map editor giving you unlimited maps to play on, an 80 HOUR CAMPAIGN WITH UNSCRIPTED A.I. and the best graphics on any console, I just can't recommend spending money on COD World at War when there are much better games on the market.

Im a hardcore CoD modern warfare fan and this game did not live up to CoD4's standards. They used many of the great things from modern warfare, such as weapon customization and prestige modes, but still failed to reach the same height. The online system was simply not very enjoyable. Guns lack the power to give you any satisfaction while you firing them as well as having almost no recoil. This results in a very unbalanced weapons system. Spawning was focused more on team spawns rather than safe spawns, I cannot count the times I spawned and died by crossfire. Overall, treyarch did not deliver as infinity ward did. The only aspect of the game that kept me going in the campaign was the prospect of Zombies which delivered and was ten times more fun than the campaign itself and most of the online play combined. All in all, If you are looking for a good online first person shooter buy CoD Modern Warfare or Halo3 rather than this game.

To me, this is one of the most exciting franchises to hit the Xbox 360 console. Call of Duty 2 was where it all started for me. I remember that was before I even had an Xbox and i was stuck playing on the computer. I didn't know what to expect when I began playing but I was hooked almost instantly by it's action and heart pounding intensity. The reason I'm refering to Call of Duty 2 is because this new Call of Duty: World at War will take place in World War II. I've read alot of complaints about that fact, but I cannot be more excited. Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare was in my opinion the best Call of Duty title to date, and the game engine used in that will be the same engine you see in Call of Duty: World at War. I've seen gameplay on this new thrilling title, and for the first time in any Call of Duty game there will be weapons in which you will never get bored with. Take for instance, the flamethrower! Yes, I said it, a flamethrower will be present in this amazing title. I watched a gameplay vid on this flamethrower, and I was impressed. This guy, torches a field and burns up a tree while soliders run around on fire dying, screaming, it's complete brilliance. The AI looks so intelligent it's disgusting. I couldn't take it all in immediately. They move like you and I. They hide, they ambush, they flank. I'm sure if you watch the gameplay videos you will be more impressed than my short and unsatasfying review. Please, I urge you to get this game. If you are going to spend $350,00 on a console, you might as well get the best it has to offer. Read my review on Fallout 3 as well. That is another title you won't want to miss!

Starlink, the Battle for is a new game for the Nintendo Switch, the PlayStation4 and Xbox One. With Noah having all 3, we went for the PS4 as that is the system he plays the most. This game is launching in an Real toys that play era being similar toy-enabled titles like Skylanders, Disney Infinity and even the Lego Dimensions craze. So it may be a tad of a risk, since most of these have faded into the gaming black hole, but I see a huge craze for this one as My son is already asking for another, so his sister can play with him too. Read the full review on my blog at entertainmechannel.com
My son loves this game and loves that he can customize and battle it out and has the starships. He wont even leave the PS4 lately since having the game.

Interesting concept, taking the toys to life idea from Skylanders and combining it with the exploration aspect of No Man's Sky and you end up with Starlink. Very neat idea, but I don't like any of the characters. Wish there were more ships. Do not buy at full price. Buy at 50% or more discount.

Some graphics (water), and draw distances are improved on PS4 versus the switch. Great gameplay with cool toys that open the future of this franchise to many fun and exclusive possibilities.

My son has been playing it and he said that It has a good story and he really likes that you can switch out the weapons, ships, and characters. It is an open-world space saga that features modular toy technology that let the players assemble and customize real-world physical starships, link the starships to their game controller, and launch into an epic adventure across the Atlas star system. The game has awesome graphics and many things to do with the game. With the real life pieces (weapons kit, pilot kit, space ship, etc) its fun to create your dream ship. If your kids have a Nintendo Switch, it has an exclusive feature. Star fox comes to Starlink: Battle for Atlas with a Fox McCloud pilot, Arwing ship, and an exclusive mission.

Features we love: Mix and match pilots, ships, wings, and weapons to fully customize your dream starship. This makes the possibilities almost endless for hours for unique play! Instantly see changes that you make to your physical ship get applied in-game- my son loves this! Build your own play style with unique pilot abilities and weapon configurations to overcome deadly challenges. The more weapon configurations, the more challenges, the more fun! The starter pack includes a controller mount, which allows you to connect your starship and pilot your controller. Mix and match weapons, pilots, and starships and watch the seamless transition happen in-game. You can purchase additional physical Starlink: Battle for Atlas starship, weapon, and pilot packs at participating retailers. This is a great game for kids of all ages! Its a safe game environment for kids but has challenges that teens will love

First of all, this game is a love letter to Shenmue fans that have been waiting for almost two decades, however those people have already purchased the game so my quick review wont be focused on them. I know this game has gotten interest from people that may not have played or known about this series until recently. I strongly advise those people to play Shenmue I & II first before jumping into this game, that collection is available on PS4, Xbox and PC for a very affordable price, also included in Xbox Game Pass. Shenmue is a game thats fairly hard to describe how unique and groundbreaking it was unless you were there to experience it back twenty years ago, when the gaming industry was smaller and still growing into the giant it is today. Just play those and experience it for yourself. Shenmue is one of my favorite games because of how charming and immersive the world is, however I understand completely if some people dont like this type of game. However, if you enjoy those first two games (which is great!), then I would suggest playing Shenmue III.

Here are the pros and cons that I felt after played it for over 20 hours: Pros: 1. The game gives the player(especially the series fan) a genuine Shenmue experience. 2. The world the game created is is full of details. If you are a patient player which accept a leisure style of playing, you might encounter many surprises during the exploration of the world. If you are an old gamer from the 1990s, you might even find yourself addicted to some of the mini-games in the world..... 3. Shenmue 3 is also a journey of improving one's body and soul, recommended for those players that are interested in KongFu or Asian culture. Cons: 1. The graphics of the game feels like in PS3 standard, which might prevent some players of the new console generation to pick it up. 2. The story of Shenmue 3 doesn't progress much. Since Suzuki has mentioned before that the Shenmue story has 11 chapters, I guess it would take at least two more games to finish the story while Suzuki is already 61..... To sum up, as a player, one definitely have the right to criticize Shenmue 3's outdated graphics and lack of some modern open-world game features(like in Assassin Creed, GTA V, etc), but do remember that this is NOT a AAA game and the funding for Shenmue 3 is limited. So here I rated the game from a kickstarter game perspective, and I think in this perspective, Shenmue 3 does live up to the expectations of most of the series fans by providing a genuine Shenmue experience. PS: Suppose one is asked to rate the three games which come out recently: Death Stranding(abbreviated as 'DS'), Pokemon Sword and Shield(as 'PokeSS) and Shenmue 3(as 'Sh3'). A hard core gamer might rate them as follows: DS: 9/10, PokeSS: 7/10, Sh3: 8/10. A serious game media might rate them as follows: DS: 6/10, PokeSS: 4/10, Sh3: 5/10. A 'generous' game media might rate them as follows: DS: 9/10, PokeSS: 10/10, Sh3: 9/10. I believe for a normal person or game media, the rating standard for games should be consistent. Guess how IGN's ratings for the three games are? It turns out to be as follows: DS: 6.8/10 PokeSS: 9.3/10 Sh3: 5.9/10 It's so inconsistent and almost felt like it was rated by a lunatic to me. How shameful!
Finally this game is out and it was worth the wait feels just like playing the originals on the sega dreamcast

I have been waiting for this sequel since 2002 when I first beat Shenmue II on the original Xbox. It is everything I wanted and then some. Thank you to everyone involved and on to #SaveShenmueIV! I'm a long time Shenmue fan. When the kickstarter was announced a while back it was one of the best moments in gaming for me. But those the game live up to all that hype? It's a yes and no kind of thing here. Long time shenmue fans will love this game because the core feel and atmosphere is there. But the story in this one leaves a lot to be desired. Feels like we get only a small bit of the story and they could have fleshed it out more. All in all, it's a decent game, doesn't outdo the previous games for me but I still very much enjoyed everything this game had to offer.

This game is trash, its all built around nostalgia with hopes of blinding your realistic expectations of what a modern game in 2019 should be. It plays like and looks like Shenmue 2 on the PS4, there are mobile games that look way better than this and probably didn't cost close to how much kickstarter funds this raised. I'm honestly questioning how all that funding was spent developing this. You would think being the third installment of a franchise and the amount of time in between there would be significant improvements, nope, its like they had this game made already 18 years ago, put a $5 suit on it and sent it out the door to prom. The voice acting is horrid, and if your argument is that's how the originals are, or that's how Shenmue games are suppose to be, you should really raise your expectations. I consider God of War to be a masterpiece and one of the best games I've ever played, and when it was $60 it was worth every penny of that price tag. Shenmue 3, isn't worth more than $9,99 in the bargain bin.
Such a beautiful narrative and smooth gameplay. Enough of the old school mechanics along with smoother movements. Can't wait to finish the story!

If you are a fan of Shenmue 1 & 2, then you have to get Shenmue 3! If you are new to the series, i suggest getting the remastered Shenmue 1 & 2 to understand the game. Shenmue 3 looks great! Great story and music! I am happy that Shenmue 3 finally came out!
I love the Shenmue franchise. I could not wait to play this edition and it did not disappoint.

Shenmue is an incredible series that set the tone for modern gaming. Shenmue 3 is a great continuation of the story we've been dying to see continue for almost 2 decades. Do yourself a favor and buy this game. Don't forget to pick up the originals in the Shenmue 1 & 2 collection so you can experience the entire series. You will not regret it. The steelbook is really nice too.
I'm very fond of Shenmue and Shenmue II. I haven't dived into this game very deep, but I can say the nostalgia has been turned up to 10.

This is the most faithful sequel we could have asked for 18 years later. It picks up where the second game left off, and feels like it never skipped a beat. The game is gorgeous, and shows that Suzuki-san is not afraid to slow it down and finish the series in the way he originally had in mind.
I'm so happy this game is finally out. I played the last 2 when they came out. I am excited to see how this game unfolds.

This is what most people did not like about borderlands the pre sequel. The graphics honestly are nothing to write home about. They look very cartoonish. I prefer the borderlands 2 graphics. Couch co-op is a pain to play because the quest only shows up on the player 1 screen and not on player 2 screen. All in all I have to say that I'm disappointed I spent $100 for this game.

They force you to use Bethesda Launcher, and I can't even play the game because despite my GPU meeting minimum requirements, my GPU isn't on their official supported GPU list (which btw is not public) so the game will automatically refuse to launch.

Solid collection package but the only thing missing from it was the season pass which is not included but for that price should of been.

SC6 still remains a fun, technical fighter, even with a few hiccups like the day 1 DLC controversy. The new Reversal Edge mechanic spices fights up with cinematic, rock-paper-scissors-like clashes, and the Create A Soul mode is fun, with plenty of options to customize your own fighter. Single player is okay, with RPG-like mechanics, but is definitely not the most interesting mode as most of the story is told through illustrated storyboards and mediocre voice acting. The Collector's edition came with a pretty sweet looking Sophitia statue and a talking Steelbook case (press a button on it for a few voice lines from the Narrator), but the CE does NOT come with the Season Pass, which is frankly infuriating. But if the physical goodies entice you, it's still a pretty good purchase. Just be sure to clear some shelf space for that figure.

Lots of content, single player and multiplayer, the character creation is deep, and the mechanics are as good as they've ever been. The Sophitia statue that comes with the Collectors Edition is very high quality. The steelbook looks great and plays audio clips from the game. The downside of that is that instead of it playing audio upon opening the case, there is a button on the front cover that plays whenever it's pressed, making it difficult to put on a shelf. The CE also does not come with the season pass which would have made this edition a better value. That is probably my biggest issue with the CE.
This was well worth the,money for the game, the very awesome figure, and the CD case talks!

Collecting Limited Run Games offers a more enjoyable experience than hunting down any other publisher for Nintendo. The inclusion of extra content in the case reminds me of retro games with registration cards and booklets.

Dark Souls has been a staple in my video game collection for years and the latest installment is another amazing dungeon romp. Graphics and controls have been improved, leading to a less frustrating experience than its predecessors. Add to this a supportive and active community to make PvP matching fast and exciting. Overall, the game seems more forgiving than DS1 and DS2 making for a more enjoyable experience to a wider audience. I highly recommend this game if you've wanted to get into the series but thought it was too difficult before.
Best game of the series so far,wonderful story, great sequel.
A wonderfully built world with such cool looking enemies that will ultimately kill you at almost any turn. If you can handle a challenge, go for it.
I managed to get ahold of this game early with my time machine. Fantastic game. I got gud. 10/10
too difficult to play and progress in game; not worth the effort

It's alright. It's fun. It's fine. What more do you want from me? A f#%*ing neck rub? If you're just wondering if it's worth getting; it is. If you want to know why it's good as well as Dark Souls in general, then read on. I like difficult games. I was able to finish Ninja Gaiden II for the Xbox 360 on Mentor difficulty. One of my best achievements. If you call achievements sitting on your butt playing video games instead of going out and curing cancer. Or something. Ninja Gaiden II is hard but more for the cheap tactics the enemies do to you, the player. I had avoided Dark Souls because I didn't want another time sink of games considered hard for the wrong reasons like Ninja Gaiden II. A year ago I popped in Bloodborne which I got from Christmas of 2015 (It's from the same developers do it's literally the games as Dark Souls). And I liked it. Soon I got the other Dark Souls games. This was the last on my list. Now to go to my point: IT'S NOT AS HARD AS PEOPLE SAY IT IS! These games still are tough as nails. They'll pile drive you into the ground time after time because you can keep coming back. But in reality, persistence is the key here. NOT SKILL. This game is more fair in its deaths than Ninja Gaiden II without a doubt. People on the internet say it's always fair... BULLSH*T! A fair game doesn't require you to use cheap tactics to win. Which you WILL have to do at one point or another. 'What do you know? You're just one player! Git gud! lol' If that's what you're thinking, why are you reading Best Buy reviews? Second, if you're saying this you probably already own this or watch other people play it. And third: I consider myself an expert on the subject of cheap game design. Ninja Gaiden II: -Unblockable explosive shuriken that stuns you when you're hit and the only way to not get badly hurt is to abuse invincibility frames -Enemies at the top of a tall ladder that can knock you back and kill you instantly -enemies that attack you when you're climbing across a rope with no way to attack or dodge -bosses with high damage outputs and fast wind-ups for strong attacks along with attacks that can easily break guards and have attack range further than you can dodge Dark Souls and Bloodborne -Game is not meant to take on multiple opponents at once because you get blindsided by an enemy you couldn't know was there. You have to usually get one's attention and repeat the process -boss attacks that one-shot you and require you to die over and over to understand their move set. -Nonlinear nature of the games can sometimes bring you to enemies that wipe the floor with you without possibly knowing prior -attacks that have further reach than you can dodge Both have many other instances of cheapness. Regardless, Dark Souls is a fun game series and worth your time. You will die a lot. Dying is the only way you can get some achievements/trophies! Perservere. I know you can do it.

I love the soul series and this one keeps with the challenging aspects commonly found in From Softwares titles. It's not extremely like the first Dark Souls, more so the second one. Enjoy dying time and time again!

I was new to the souls genre of games, so I had no idea what to expect. This game is different from what I normally play which is FPS games. It is different and going on the offensive you will just die. Oh yeah get used to DYING like a lot.
Son asked for this game, and was very happy when I gave it to him

I'm someone who was never interested in demon souls/ dark souls games after trying them as they were a bit too slow and clunky for me. I decided to try bloodborne which I thought was a masterpiece because it was unique, fluid and always left me wanted to play more. I decided to try dark souls 3 and it isn't a bad game to me but it just doesn't have the same appeal as bloodborne. Dark souls 3 was beautiful but doesn't have the atmosphere and interesting lore that bloodborne has and the gameplay mechanics isn't as good. Also, not to mention that the first 5 or so bosses I fought were extremely easy compared to bloodborne. I also thought the gun parrying and transforming weapons was amazing and the change that bloodborne brought to souls series inspired dark souls to change the flow of ds3. To me going from bloodborne to ds3 is like going from a 5 star hotel to a 3 star hotel. A 3 star hotel isn't bad but with a choice, i'd rather stick with the 5

This is my first Dark Souls game and I've got to say, I'm hooked! What an amazing game so far I can't wait to do some videos for it on my YouTube channel!!! Definetly a nice add to the collection!! Buying it on PC as well!

This is my second souls game after Bloodborne and I'm slightly underwhelmed. The camera angles seem to be even worse, if that's possible and the frame rate is awful in certain areas. There is input lag when rolling and you can die due to these issues when a fat enemy pins you into a corner and the camera goes bonkers. Target lock on is more trouble than it's worth. Weapons of the same type will generally have the same moveset as each other. Katanas are boring to use. Greatswords are too slow and cumbersome. Straight swords are the most effective but also boring. Sorcery is too weak. Pyromancy has a lot of useless and similar spells but is probably more viable than sorcery. The story is confusing and makes no sense. The combat in general is nowhere near Dragon's Dogma level. This would probably be a good game to co-op, and unless you like PVP or self-torture you would find more frustration than satisfaction when gaming alone.

I didn't like the controller layout of the way the character moved. I was hoping this game would be like god of war but i was wrong. Don't bash me for saying that. Ive never play a 'Dark Souls' game before so i wasn't sure what i was getting into but the trailer was COMPLETELY miss leading. the fighting style is very slow, and the combos don't seem like combos. your character is slow and its very hard to dodge. I would like to think I'm an expert gamer 'BO3' but this game made me feel like i had never played before. Took me forever to get passed the first boss and by that time i finally did.. i was over it. allllll dodging.. I would give this game a 1 star in my personal opinion. But i hated everything about it. except the character building was very in-depth. didn't mind that. but i gave it a 2 star just because its not a bad RPG game, its just not one for me.

I bought this game thinking it would be a challenge but also have a great story as well but come on, this game is only 20GB large because there is no data in the game. Its point is to take forever to complete a section and to cuss the screen until your face turns red. So basically the maps dont need to be large and there is no story its just a RPG locked on Extreme difficulty. It takes so long to progress you forget the story line and mechanics are a joke. The only defense that works is the roll away and that dos not even work I got 3 hours in this piece of garbage and I am only pass the first mission. I will never buy another Souls Game I will stick to Skyrim and other franchises where the developers understand there are people like me that work all day, come home and just want to relax play a good game with a story that dos not raze my blood pressure to the point this game does. Game disk makes for a good drink coaster though!
Didn't like style of game. Too much set up and creating character before gameplay

If you enjoy getting killed constantly and love feeling frustrated, then this game is perfect for you. If you want to devote hours and hours developing skills that will serve no useful purpose in your life, then this game is perfect for you. If you want spend months acquiring skills and then spend months going online and telling people to 'get gud', then this game is perfect for you. If you want a fun game that you can play for and hour or so a night and enjoy yourself in the process, then this game is not for you. If you enjoy playing PS4 games but aren't a hardcore 'gamer' who values PS4 ability over all other, then this game is not for you. Some people will enjoy the incredibly steep learning curve, I suspect that most will not. I certainly did not, but I'm not hardcore player.
This game presents an intense challenge that I in no way had patience for. Promptly traded it in at game stop. Only lost out on $10
This is such a horrible game worst game ever made.

This game may have been disappointing to many when it released on the last gen consoles. At $20 though you just can't beat the amount of content offered here. It may not have been anywhere close to the best RE game but Mercenary mode alone is worth the price of the game.

Game isn't as good as part 5, but for the price it's alright.

I was excited for this expansion but then my dreams were crushed. It's like the last one but instead of artifact lvling, we now lvl a heart. Ughh.
Started playing again after quitting after Pandaria. This expansion offers so much content and ways to play. Love it!

I played wow for the first 6 years it was out. I had to take a break due to really life things. Getting back into wow in this expac has been great. I'd recommend it for any old players who haven't been online in some time.

Full disclosure: it's my belief that BC and WotLK were the best times to be had in Wow. Nothing has proved me wrong yet, but I still keep going back for the nostalgia feels. This is super grindy. Like, WoW is expected to be grindy and this feels grindier than grindy. And the writing itself might be better, but the story.. Blizzard, c'mon, do something new. The ol' Batman trope of dying the hero or living long enough to become the villain has been done, again and again... It seems more and more like Blizzard doesn't care what their players think, as long as they continue to make money. Unfortunately they seem to be applying free-to-play elements to a game that is not only buy-to-play, but also has a subscription fee. I understand wanting to extend content so your players need more in-game time to finish things, but Blizzard likes to double dip. So I'm gonna go ahead and not recommend this one - yet. I think it's going to take several more months for them to bake out enough changes to make the community happy. Maybe then it'll deserve a look. Until then, I'm done with Warcraft.
Game got its hooks back into me. Some of the new mechanics are a bit of a grind, but the new content is amazing and well worth the time investment.

It's tough for me to say whether or not World of Warcraft is worthwhile for a new player, as I've been playing off and on since the game's release (heavily for the first 3 expansions, and then hardly after that). For someone like me, though, who enjoys games with lovingly-crafted environments which encourage exploration, the new Battle for Azeroth expansion is exactly what I'm looking for. There are so many fun details packed into every corner of the world, and I'm having a great time poking around and taking my time. If you remember World of Warcraft fondly and haven't played for a while, but are willing to look beyond the fact that it's likely not anywhere close to the same game that you remember (in terms of systems, community, and activities), then I'd recommend it.

World of Warcraft: Battle for Azeroth had a lot to live up to considering how well Legion was received. Although it was just recently released, it's already surpassed my expectations. The theme and feel of the expansion really takes you back by making it about the Horde vs the Alliance. The story hasn't gotten me this hooked since Warth of the Lich King. I'd definitely recommend this expansion.
I'm new to wow and it wasn't very hard to get into the lore of this game . Theres so much stuff to do on this game since u get all past expansions when you buy game time.

I've put so many hours into this expansion. The new zones are some of the best ever, and the most graphically intensive and unique. I came back 'For the Horde!' and I've enjoyed a ton of time both alone and with friends adventuring the new dungeons/raids/zones. Definitely, recommend if you're a fan of WoW. If you're a newcomer, I advise the free trial to level 20 and if you decide you're interested, this is a great expansion to jump on.

Some of the things I enjoy, but many of the things are just an extension of Legion's grind. Island Expedition is a pain and not worth the reward and most of the content is a grind again. Hopefully, some changes will be made in 8.1 as promised.

Ok, the 'bad' out of the way first. The box is cheaply made. If you're a collector, this may mean something to you. Otherwise, look below. Box contents: -no dvd (just a digital code) -a Blizzard notebook -an advert about free videogames in battle.net platform(starcraft2, heartstone, wow until level 20 and hots) -another code for discounts in the blizzard store (wearables) 7th expansion for WoW and this one is pretty fun. A lot of fans asked for more faction war, and this expac delivers on that in spades! You'll get a Level 110 character boost to get you started right away if you've never played/been awhile, also great for twinking a new character. New level cap of 120. Warfront, a new 20payer coop mode, is a pretty fun PvE experience as well.
Great Christmas gift! My teen has been playing this for a few days and says its really good.
Loving this PC. it is everything i wanted plus room to expand later if i choose too.

Battle for Azeorth brings Warcraft back to its root sof the Alliance versus the Horde. If you haven't played recent Warcraft expansions, this game recaps the events through cutscenes and interactive quest chains, allowing you to dive right back into the lore. The gameplay mechanics have been simplified from past expansions, which makes it more accessible to new players. Content is rolling out for the game as of this review, so there is even more to experience on the way. It can take a while for it to be released, leading to some lull in the action, but you can continue to play alts or complete daily quests for rewards. It's worth picking up now to get caught up and either start or return to your journey through Azeroth.

This expansion has a different feel to it than previous ones. The one thing I really like is leveling from 110 to 120 which was much better in terms as how long it takes. The scenery is great. They made the main story line in my opinion much more involving and engaging which is great because its gets you more involved into the game I think. I think this expansion is one you should really consider if you haven't played in awhile.

A remastered platformer from the Playstation 2 era. Its ok. a pass really but if you haven't played this before and have played all other platformers, this one is a great game to spend a couple of hours on. Just get ready for long load times in between the gameplay.

As i was looking for games on the switch i notice one game that caught my eyes on, and decided to give it a shot. at the time i was looking for something for my sister's birthday as i was on vacation during that time. When i got back home my sister wanted me to experience this and as result i did not know what to expect. I sat down, gave this game a chance with a completely open mind, and what i had experience throughout this game. little did i know this was not what i expected as a result, i felt very conflicted, but never in my life did i ever drop a controller, and walked away completely from this game. to top it off i had no idea this game existed in the first place until later on that i am not only shocked that this game blew my mind in the most conflicting way possible by this game, and that somehow has a fan base in another country. This remastered version that was base on the PS2 as well as it did get a Nintendo DS release, for a rating that is E10+ this game should not be for younger viewers, and should be more for adults as a M Ratting. As i was playing the game, this has racial stereotypes as the voice acting were trying so hard that in the most offensive ways possible to how bad the voice acting was throughout the game, the camera when moving around was so bad it gave me such a bad headache that i had no clue what was going on, the story made no sense what so ever, and everything else in this game just made me feel like i was dumb throughout my experience. for those who like this game all power to you, but for those who had an unexpected experience that made make others conflicted with mix emotions not knowing how to feel, i recommend skipping out.

ith most of the Mario titles in the past decade, I've always been disappointed to smash my way through them in under a week without having faced any real difficulty at any point in the game. Mario 3D Land turns this on its head at the last minute. Upon defeating Bowser at the end of your standard round of 8 worlds, the game unlocks a new character and a new set of 8 more worlds that are all exceptionally challenging. The second set of worlds gets *NINTENDO HARD* at some points, and even the most experienced player will find themselves burning through dozens of lives on the same stage. The main difference is that there's no real punishment for failure because extra lives are near-unlimited and ridiculously easy to come by. Despite that, at the end of the day the sudden uptick in difficulty is just one of the many ways that Mario 3D Land honors and makes references to its roots. It borrows powerups, stages, tropes, enemies, and music from all throughout the series and ultimately makes this into one that was meant to appeal to the most longtime of fans.

This Super Mario land 3D is like super Mario world 3D on the Wii U. It is simply now on the go in the new Nintendo 2DS and is a game thats best on the go! Whether your on the bus or outside is best to play this game outside. You get into it and you feel great. The game has worlds and so many power ups that it gets your day on to a good start. 2 ds plays all Mario 3ds games and this game simply excels on the new 2ds.
Not gonna lie this game was a little hard for me! I am an adult and it was maddening.
I enjoy playing the game. I purchased it for my 6 year old but its a little rough for her.

The sims is a phenomenal game when on mobile but once you get your hands on the console version its a blast! Absolutely brilliant replay ability. Good bye social life!!

I have been a Sims player since the beginning and this was the lonest wait I think we've had between console releases. It was worth the wait, creation mode is very detailed both for homes and characters, the only thing missing is pets.
Really fun game! Love building houses. There are lots of choices
Really in-depth game for people that are looking to be entertained for long periods of time.

A+ Game. Reminds me of the game as when I played it when I was very young. It is a very cool game. It actually even helps me be more social person and kind of excited to interact with people on the outside world in the same like fashion that I interact with people on this game. You will enjoy this game if you buy it. Its hours of fun guaranteed. The ability to create a Sam and nurture and nature of them through their lives and find them friends and buy them homes and get them jobs and socialize them every day is such an exciting adventure

I've always played Sims on my computer so this was the first time playing it on a console. The controls were a little tricky at first, but the more I play it the more I get used to it. It never lags for me or slows down and sometimes that would happen on my computer, so this is a bit of a step up for me.

The first time I loaded up the game, I wasn't even sure how to change my Sim's appearance. The game does give you tutorials, but it seems to be a bit buggy as to when it brings them up for you. I've also had small (non-game breaking) bugs while playing: Visiting Sims get locked into playing Chess and wont leave, pressing X sometimes don't bring up the action menu and I'm still not sure if my hired gardener is still hired after I turn off the game. Besides those little annoyances, the game is even more intricate than previous Sims games. I will definitely try to keep this basic and spoiler free! I have played the original Catherine on PS3 back in 2011 and absolutely LOVED it! Had no idea what I was getting myself into, but never would've thought 'a love horror story and puzzle game' hybrid would make for hours of fun! I'm just over halfway through my Full Body run and I can say: - Replayability should be decent as there are two ways to 'play' the puzzles: Remix and Classic. It basically just changes the shapes of the blocks you pull (reminds me of Tetris pieces) but it did make things a tad more tricky - It's been so long since I've played through this that I can't easily point out the 'change and additions' they made to the story (with the exception of adding Rin, obviously) - The graphics are about what you would've expected on the PS3 version - I did notice several cut scenes that I didn't at all remember from before - The puzzle sequences are solid, smooth, and challenging as ever - Can't remember if there was a online multiplayer mode on PS3 or not, but there is now - They added a bunch of endings to this version as well - I'm just as hooked as I was 8 years ago playing this! I will definitely be going through once choosing all the 'douchy' answers and again being the 'nice guy' lol The worst part of the game is having to talk to all the sheep in between puzzle 'stages' - however, I'm only doing it on my first play-through to see if anything changed, and also I believe there was a trophy for doing so. I'm not sure - I don't look up any trophies on a first run lol First timers should love this game - especially puzzle connoisseurs - and veterans should welcome the changes and addition. My favorite part is the Persona 5 soundtracks that show up in the jukebox at the bar!! If you don't like puzzle games, I think there is an option to either skip the puzzles all together or an 'easy' mode to blow through them and focus on the story. Don't hold me to that though! :)

Catherine is a game I meant to play when it was on the PS3, but this remake is outstanding. It's the story of Vincent and his relationship with a woman named Katherine, his longtime girlfriend, and Catherine, a woman he's cheating on her with. It's sexy, but it's really a mature story about a guy trying to decide on what's important to him. One half of the gameplay consists of you sitting in the Stray Sheep Bar talking with friends, answering messages on your phone, and generally moving the story forward. The other half is Vincent's nightly nightmare climb up a wall. You can move the blocks around to create a path up the wall, and it's generally clever. The puzzles become more dangerous as you progress, and it's never boring. The presentation is amazing. Even though it's a remake, the visuals are great, but this game's art is packed with style in every frame. It's probably the best of the year in the way it combines the music, visuals, and voices. It's really that good. If you waited to play it, Catherine: Full Body is ready for you to lose yourself in it's colorful story and world.
Wow. This expanded on the original in a way I didn't even think was possible, get this game!

Every aspect of this games is like :the enemies are stronger than you, your people disagree with every decision you make and if they don't they starve to death anyway. For example, the objectively 'right' choices are either burning your supplies to keep the enemies from getting them and losing morale for people who are going to starve to death anyway or losing one of your few in-battle protagonists. Sometimes every single choice you are given ends EXACTLY the same way no matter what because your enemy is literally the devil and he's smarter than everyone. To top this off the game takes place in norse mythology so Raganatok is still in play albeit jormagundr can't eat the world really quick because the dredge are complete jerks and didn't tell him christmas was canceled. Most of the good guys also have REALLY bad ideas 200% of the time and the ones with good ideas are again, already dead. That being said the struggle laid before you organically through this resource management srpg is really well done and the art design reflects the story's dire circumstances.
Although the game isn't what I expected, its still fun & the story is cool.

For a perfect score on Just Cause 3 it would need much more time before release (being a Grand Theft Auto world and all); developers' needed more tweaking of specific things; such as expanding the gameplay/sea-life/ structures/AI/ and simple glitches patches before release!! I also enjoyed the slight change to combat mechanics, which in other Lego games is simple and repetitive. The game's story follows the movie pretty closely, and clips from the movie are sprinkled in through the journey... although the voices (and some lines) felt like they'd been changed? Game looks amazing but that is where it ends the world feels empty and the flow of the game and combat is terrible and boring. I am extremely disappointed in this game I was looking forward to it. Also no English everything is in Japanese with subtitles.

It took me around 20 plus hour to beat the game so In terms of hour per dollar I guess its worth $60. However there are several issues with it that make me wish I waited for a sale. The issues I have with the game are with its combat, controls, enemies, open world, and main missions. The controls are not as responsive as I would like them to be which actually slows the combat and as for the combat it is too simple which makes it dull. There are only two types of enemies grunts and bosses, the boss fights being the only good part. However, due to the combat being dull the bosses are fought in the same way as the grunts which disappoints. Now we have the open wold well that sucks too, it is empty hardly any A.I. and the ones we do get lack variety which the grunt enemies also suffer from. Finally to the main missions, while I did like the story the way several missions were designed made the experience lackluster. There are several main missions that there sole purpose is to prolong the story, half of those 20 plus hours I mentioned I played are because of these time consuming missions. One mission literally asks you to do several side quest like missions in order to continue the story another has you defeat the same group of enemies 9 times. There are 2 mission that ask you to find something which becomes extremely time consuming because the area to search is almost the whole map, these two mission should have been side quests. Also there is no second gear mode and forth gear mode sucks I do more damage using red hawk instead. Okay now hopefully I convinced you to wait for a sell and not buy it for full price like I did. P.S. The score would be lower but I'm being generous because its One Piece(my #1 manga series).

one of the best, if not the best, anime/manga adapted games I've played. I love that they actually took a route other than just straight up fighting like Naruto, my hero, black clover, etc... (not that those are bad, just all similar bandwagon games). this game is an awesome fusion of legend of Zelda breath of the wild game play and graphics mixed with God of War power ups and enhancements combined with the amazing story that is One Piece. Jump Force was a hyped up game that pretty much overshadowed this game, but while jump Force didn't quite live up to the hype, this game far exceeded.

First off, lets take a minute to observe that the Metro series has, and most likely always will be, a series thats success is built primarily on the cult following of players whove always had a deep love for whats being offered with the franchise. But thats not to say that each new entry hasnt attempted to do something special that opens the door for new players. Not the gimmicky sort of special, but the kind that has charm and care in the details during creation - especially concerning the players immersion. 4A is by and large a AA developer, some could even consider them somewhat of an independent studio when it comes to their working conditions and team size. While this aspect definitely shows through at times in all of the Metro games, the series also operates on par with, and sometimes better than, big budget blowouts. Exodus is absolutely no different. Just like Last Light did previously, Exodus takes what came before and tries to refine the fat down, while also building upon the strengths of the series. And just like all other entries in the Metro series, Exodus releases to mixed reviews, and a somewhat bitter reception from all to the bugs that are all too familiar to a Metro release. For those new to the series: Metro is a narrative driven survival FPS, with an emphasis on SURVIVAL. While not Resident Evil, Dead Space, or The Last of us - Metro does embody elements from these sort of titles. But also brings to mind titles like Singularity, Fallout, and most importantly S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - post-apocalyptic, (mostly) stealth-driven shooters that are hellbent on immersing the player in the atmospheric wasteland, then challenging them to survive the world and its deadly inhabitants. Metro leans more towards the horror outings with its creature designs and dreadful tones. Previous Metro titles focused more on linear and claustrophobic levels, whereas Exodus allows the player to exit the confines of the Metro underground and explore semi-open world wastelands, each broken up by the four seasons, as well offering completely different environments. This isnt to say the linear and claustrophobic environments arent still preserved. In fact, Exodus does a good job funneling its levels down into some intense areas that operate just like previous titles. The open environments still leave the player open for encounters out in the wild, these tend to feel a little less intense, and sometimes frustrating depending on the enemy behaviors. Human enemies can be rather dumb. And the creatures tend to be viscous and overbearing. Though these issues arent all encompassing of the game, nor do they really break immersion. Gunplay has never been priority in Metro, as opposed to the overall feel of the experience, but they do their job in feeling pretty good to shoot. Especially some of the more creative weapon build outs. Those who have played Metro Redux know the gunplay can feel comfortable and good, though that wasnt always the case - and the same goes again with Exodus. The guns feel good and do their job, but the perfection of the aim falls apart at distances, and sometimes when playing stealthy. Some frustrations came from the lack of pulling off a headshot, even though you had the enemy lined up perfectly. This is an area Id personally like to see patched up, and soon, as the guns are great and would be even better with precision. Players looking for action, twitch type gunplay will find themselves disappointed with Metro, as the series is focused on more concentrated and paced out scenarios - survival scenarios. This by and large plays into movement too. Metro is not creamy or crunchy, but more janky, like...Fallout, though with a better emphasis on gun control and button mapping. Speaking of movement, the character is definitely more of a tank - despite the sound design saying different - thus even running will make you feel like gravity is hugging you in its entirety. This is to translate the reality of the character to the player, and it definitely works. Right up until you take your feet off the trail and into the sticks - this is when movement gets a little sticky and the character hangs up on literally everything. Again, I get the immersion factor here, but in this case its absolutely breaking the immersion - a mechanic that shouldve been streamlined for the sake of optimization. Among all of Metros immersion mechanics, this is really the only one I felt could go far away and never come back. The rest I found to be alright, and far from the complaints of other reviewers. Many of which seem to come from lack of holding the players hand - something that opposing reviewers have knocked the game for. But by and large, most complaints that I see against the game are features overlooked by the player. As mentioned, Metro is a game that likes immersion, therefore HUD elements are greatly reduced to be non-existent, and instead incorporated onto the character - much like Dead Space. Most of these features are put on the wrist of the character in the form of watches/bands. Most importantly is the compass, which will always point you towards your waypoint. This is not given immediately, but instead a little later on after the tutorial period. Right from the start you will have a radiation gauge on your wrist, so you can monitor areas where a gas mask is needed. The map seems to be a tricky thing for some players, but fear not THERE IS A MAP, and the map does tell you what your main mission is if you flip it over. Main objectives are marked with a big X on the map, while side missions will show up as smaller (!) marks on the map - the player is absolutely free to approach what they want, however they desire - with only 1 or 2 being a little confusing at first. Side Missions will provide you with game-changing gear in some circumstances, so theyre worth doing, not to mention theyre nothing exhausting. Crafting is another fantastic addition that can be easily overlooked by both old and new players. Your backpack and crafting tables should be taken advantage of, especially if youre a player thats finding themself short of supplies or bullets. You can craft everything needed at these 2 places - the backpack is great for building a lot of survival supplies on the fly: health, air filters, ball bearing ammo, arrows, and other similar items to keep you going. And the tables will permit the player to get into deeper customizations and crafting. But most importantly is guns. You can pick up and put down any gun you comes across, as well as dissemble them for parts and ammo. Players can carry 2 guns and 1 specialty gun (I.E. Air Pressure gun or Crossbow) and all guns can be altered with parts found, or just to your hearts content, straight out of the backpack. Overall, theres a lot of greatness to be experienced in Metro Exodus, especially if youre a fan of the series. A vast beautiful, and atmospheric game full of tense moments, as well as adventurous moments into the wild open environments to find crafting items and lore. The gameplay is great blend of survival and gunplay. It offers a stylistic blend of horror and post-apocalyptic sci-fi to immerse players in the story of Artyom and his family of merry misfits that have just emerged from the underground. Though its not to say the game comes without some shortcomings upon release. Hiccups and bugs are definitely present, though I personally havent experienced anything game breaking in my playthroughs...yet. Load times are a little too long, though as some have said - its mainly when booting the game up into the first gameplay of the day, or if you reset the game. The load times are a little shorter between deaths, though Ive had a few bouts of waiting that were near 2 minutes, and thats a little ridiculous in-between deaths. My biggest gripes are toward the lack of precision in gunplay/shooting, and getting hung up on the environment when exploring off the path. Those 2 really broke immersion for me and became frustrating at times - looking at you sticky environment. The gunplay issue can be compensated for once the player learns the guns, but its still something thatd really help if it were fixed. But knowing 4A Games is basically a AA developer with the skeleton framing of an independent studio, theyve really done a fantastic job building a AAA experience, and hopefully with a little time well see these minor issues with Exodus get tightened up properly for players in the fence waiting.
It took a while for this game to come out but it was worth the wait. Terrific graphics and animation.

First off the game itself isn't that bad, up to personal preference though definitely not as good as the first two metro games, especially last light. Anyway the reason it is terrible and nearly unplayable is the bugs. There are so many bugs it should have been called Metro the Try Not to Die For No Reason Simulator. My first playthrough managed to finish the game despite several bugs that were very annoying but not gamebreaking (ie, enemies can see knocked out enemies in dark rooms through walls and floors, bullets and throwing knives will randomly go through enemies with no effect other than alerting them to your pressence, when driving if I pulled up the map the camera would change so i couldn't see where I was going until i got out of the van and back in again literally half the time, etc, etc, etc.. Now the nearly unplayable comes in for my second and third attempted playthroughs to get the bad ending and finish on ranger hardcore and iron mode. On ranger hardcore I had several of the same issues I had on my first playthrough, which were very detrimental considering there are no auto saves and you are at the mercy of the games horrible auto save feature which somehow made me lose half of my inventory on one and considering you must spend time scavenging for supplies without any autosave, at least in my experience, until you made it to your objective or a question mark on the map usually meant 20 or so minutes of scavenging wasted each time I died. Combine that with the fact that a 3 foot drop will kill you and running or walking, yes walking, will somehow launch you forward off of the stairs to the ground below and possibly your death. After about 4 hours of that I decided to wait on ranger hardcore and try out iron mode, which only has saves at the start of each mission, on a lower difficulty to get another playthrough under my belt and further familiarize myself with the game. I made it to the volga and got out of the church, got attacked by the catfish, got to the shore, started talking to duke and suffocated in fresh air, with my fully intact gas mask on and over 14 minutes worth of filters. I tried to change filters and nothing happened, I took off my mask and put it back on and tried to change filters again but I just died. I tried again, having to start at the beginning of the level, and was in the process of clearing out the church when I walked into one of the closed rooms where someone was behind a desk with a little candle on it and to save ammo I hit them with a melee attack and was burst into flames as I was instakilled by a little candle. I have no problem or issue with difficult games but if developers are going to put them in their games, well, the games need to work. This is a game that has been out for over a year. I have version 1.07 so it has had 7 patches. The developers released 2 dlcs and patched in a new difficulty without fixing the issues that make the high difficulties nearly impossible. The game never should have been released in its current state now let alone over a year ago in as hard as it is to believe a worse state than it is now. I was looking forward to this game but I think I may be done with metro an 4A and I really cannot understand the praise that I see for this game everywhere so I wanted to pass along my experience to try to save others the extreme disappointment that is this game. In closing I would like to expand on my answer to the question would I recommend this to a friend? No, I wouldn't recommend this game to my biggest enemy.

Metro Exodus opens up a world held closed by its predecessors. This time, it's up to our well-known hero Artyom to explore the unexplored regions of Mother Russia, in all of its open-world glory. So sit back and enjoy the unique experience, visual wonders and darkest secrets of the beloved Metro universe.

This game isn't bad at all. But could use pointers to guide the player on the objective at hand like where to find certain items and what to do to progress the story. For instance on more than one occasion several to be exact I had to go on Youtube for help just to find out what to do to progress the story like find a generator to restore power to an elevator lift. Things like that and the unnecessarily long load times between maps make for a less than perfect score. The graphics and gameplay are solid though but sometimes the game is too confusing.
Metro Exodus is a fantastic game, with solid shooting mechanics, and beautiful graphics. I would highly recommend playing the first two games in the series before tackling this one.
Well this game just kicks butt. I honestly shouldn't have to say much more then that because if you have two thumbs and a ps4 this a must own.
Been wanting to play this game for awhile, then bought it for a great price.
graphics are amazing. game plays well and story is plenty long
It has an amazing story line and MANY decisions that affect the whole game
I didnt like the game cause it didnt have any good looking characters

This is a great game for anyone who likes exploring in a wasteland with a touch of nightmarish encounters The game is based on sci-fi book and is next in Metro series but can be played alone Ive actually read some of the Metro books and I think it adds to overall experience If you contemplating whether you should spend $60 on this game you may want to try the first two games in the series as theyre similar and you can get them for next to nothing

I really wanted to love this game. i've played both Metro titles on PS4 and thoroughly enjoyed both. Exodus looked terrific based on trailers and previews, and in a lot of aspects it is terrific. It looks absolutely incredible, so if you just want a game for some eye candy, you can't go wrong here. It's among the best looking games I've every played on console. However, there are some huge negatives here. And the big one for me is the framerate. I've played a lot of games at 30 FPS as a console gamer, and I don't despise it. I prefer 60 obviously, but I can live with 30. However Exodus struggles to stay at a consistent 30, and the gameplay/gunplay just feels awful. I'm not sure if that's a result of the framerate or what, but any type of movement is a total slog. It's a pain just to turn in this game. Aiming and shooting guns is comical. The best way for me to describe it is like they took a walking simulator (think about something with really slow awful movement like Everybody's Gone to the Rapture or something) and gave you a gun. The environments are gorgeous, but the way you interact with them is brutal. Let's not even get started on the voice acting, AI or character animations. All of which feel decidedly last gen. Which is all the more striking considering how next gen the game *looks*. So yeah, a game I wanted to love, but it just would not let me. Maybe it's better on the PC. I've heard as much. But as a PS4 game (i played on a Pro btw) there's just no way I can recommend it in its current state. Wait til they do another Redux and put it out on the PS5.
Long load times, in-game errors and glitches and crashes. Screens that dont load at all. Do NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!
Lots of glitches. Short gameplay. Very linear gameplay with limited open world. Not very satisfied especially for the price. The hype is fake.
By far a phenomenal game. Haven't played yet but this game's graphics and storyline looks BOMB!!! I've heard and saw nothing but greatness from this game it don't regret it
This game will literally make you lol at how terrible it is. I dont know how anyone could like this, it is TERRIBLE. I love to game but wow this is something else do NOT buy.

First of all I dont care about the fact metro went to epic. Good for them to make more money. I have my issues with the game on PS4. The first load from start up is too long. I played the first 2 metros and enjoyed the linear approach. It feels too often not enough Ammo in exodus and story doesnt interest me and level design uninteresting. I have the slow responsive knife and other item throwing. I cant even finish the game. I know the reviews are pretty good with metro but I just dont enjoy it. The wooden facial animations also dont create a believable world. The AI is inconsistent and not enjoyable to interact with.

I read reviews on this game and expected a Great Game as some reviews sad. instead, this was a big disappointment. the graphics were like cut out back ground play book for a three year old. the gameplay was stiff and not smooth like i have come to enjoy with the likes of Assassins Creed and Fallout or Doom. big waste of money.......will not recommend this game to anybody. threw my copy in the trash. only played this for about ten minutes. Just plain bad.

The game is fun too. Note: The sticker that appears on the package is actually made into the cover art. I was hoping it was a only stuck on the cellophane wrap, but nope.

This version has the season pass included on a dlc voucher. Its not on the cart. But the game is solid fun and worth having.
I collect switch games and buy any that are a good deal. This will stay Shrink wrapped for awhile.
Epic VR version of an already great golf game. Recommended
This game is sweet already then they make it for VR just take my money very fun take a little bit of time to get use to but overall its great!
Huge fan of the original everybody loves golf and now with the interactive VR version you just got even more immersed. Recommended for sure
I am sure it is a great game, but I did not realize it was a VR game, so I need to return it for a different game
This was the best when it first was released on ps2 but now it's better.

'Resident Evil with samurais' was probably the most common description for the Onimusha series. Like its sister series, Onimusha featured bygone gaming designs like fixed-camera angles, pre-rendered backgrounds, and tank controls. Capcom married these three elements into many of their games, creating fantastic and epic titles that still hold up today. While newer gamers may take some time getting used to these design choices, veteran players will feel very familiar with the setup and find their groove as they hack and slash the demonic hordes in this feudal era-inspired action-horror. Everything has been given a nice HD touch, though this does reveal some glaring graphical limitations, but the aim is to present the game in a perfected format rather than achieving the fidelity of modern-day titles. The biggest change however comes in the music, which has been remade from the ground up due to events concerning the original chief musician for the game. However, the new soundtrack remains largely faithful to the feel of the original, and the original sound effects are still present and accounted for. The Trophy/Honors the game now boast will surely challenge old and new players to put their skills to the test. Here's hoping Capcom brings the series back to life with a new installment.

For a game that originally came out 18 years ago this holds up surprisingly well. From cleaned up visuals to tighter controls (the old RE tank controls are gone.) this game is just as great now as when it first came out. Everything from soul collecting to power up your weapons to puzzles to boss fights are as fun as ever. And at the $19,99 price point this is a must buy. Hopefully it sells well so Capcom decides to make a new game in the series. And who knows maybe we'll see Dino Crisis get a remaster soon as well...

This game is pretty much a port of the PS2 version with improved (often simply upconverted) texture work, an HD presentation, and no other significant changes. The game seems to be bug free and plays as well as it did 10+ years ago. The original was a classic, though if you haven't played it before, this game will probably feel a bit stiff and dated in terms of controls and general game mechanics.

If you're a fan of the first 3 Resident Evil games you'll feel right at home with Onimusha. The game uses the same fixed camera angles, map layout and puzzles. The key difference is the more dynamic combat. You get different weapons and special abilities that keep the combat fresh.

Onimusha: Warlords was released nearly two decades ago on the PlayStation 2 in 2001 (and later the original Xbox in 2002.) This is a game that received little fan fare and press. This remaster is the same game that came out 20 years ago, which modern graphics and settings. If you missed this title back then, don't miss this title now. Onimusha: Warlords is worth every bit of your time. (I purchased both XBOX One and PS4 copies, and am reusing the review I wrote for the other platform on this.)

This was a classic game that would lead into the creation of games like devil may cry and other landmark titles. The tank controls might be tough for newer gamers to get the hang of. But this is a definitive version of this epic franchise. Worth picking up for under 30 bucks.

This is basically a samurai game with the visual style of the original resident evil games on PS1. it's not a very long game but the price is fair. Just don't go in expecting a full remake. It's the original game in high definition. That isn't a bad thing.
I played this game on the original Xbox! Im so happy they remastered this and brought my childhood back. I just played the first 4 hours like it was nothing! 10 out 10 stars!!! Its a must get!!

The same magic I felt when I first played this game I just experienced again. This game just sucks you in and keeps you coming for more. The graphics by todays standards are sub par but are fine by me. The music remains beautiful as it always was and the story draws your attention and keeps it. This is truely one of my favorite games and I hope Capcom brings out others in this underrated series.

I loved the original Onimushu Warlords game when it came out in the early 2000's for PS2. Very similar in style of play to Resident Evil, but set in feudal Japan. This PS4 re-issue is an exact duplicate of it, and that is probably what is disappointing is that it is an exact duplicate. The graphics have not been improved, overall gameplay is the same. If you want a fun bit of nostalgia, this is okay for the good price. If you want a true melee battle game that takes full advantage of the graphics and performance of the PS4, go buy the 2018 God of War game.

I am an old-school RPG gamer and purchased Prey recently after needing a break from replaying Skyrim, Fallout 4, and Assassin's Creed Odyssey for the umpteenth time. After reviewing some of the gaming websites feedback, I thought I'd risk the $15 on checking this out. I was not disappointed. It is almost like playing a new version of System Shock mixed in with some more horror-ish themes. It is not overly gory so just horror-ish with the types of enemies and some that utilize the element of surprise...I'm looking at you Mimics. I'm probably only halfway through the game but am thoroughly enjoying it. This is not a shootem-up killer game. Ammo is relatively precious but can be made once you figure out how to recycle just about anything thanks to the recycler charge. I do like that there are many ways to navigate obstacles. It's mostly a slow, methodical exploration game but there are some enemies that make you run as fast as you can to change locations if you can't fight. Highly recommended game for a very small investment if this is your style game.

This game is awesome BUT it is not for casuals! If you're a fan of the old PC games, System Shock and System Shock 2, or want to play a game that's like a more challenging Bioshock, this is for you. Especially in the beginning of the game you are very squishy (you can only take a few hits before dying) compared to most modern games, so if you're looking for a game to mindlessly enjoy you might want to look somewhere else. But if you want a challenging game that makes you strategize, plan, and play methodically, then this is right up your alley.

If you're like me, and you've been waiting for word of Half 2 Chapter 3 (or Half Life 3, or really Half Life ANYTHING), you've probably given up hope. While we may never see another installment in the series from Valve, Bethesda has done the next best thing by delivering Prey. That is not to say that this is a clone of Half Life - far from. But it delivers much the same atmosphere, and admittedly a similar premise. Something goes wrong during a scientific experiment, and all heck (really Best Buy, I have to say 'heck'?) breaks loose. The game-play can, at times, be nerve wracking (in a good way) much like Half Life could be. DO NOT try to treat this like a COD-style shooter - you will die. A lot. But if you liked Half Life you will enjoy Prey.
Very tense game with a great story weaved into the exploration of the Talos I space station

I'm very new to Arkane Studios games, having only played the first Dishonored briefly and not giving the sequel a chance. Not for any real reason, I just had other games to play. But when Prey was announced, and I saw the things you were capable of doing in this game, I was hooked. I had to have it. This is an incredible game for anyone looking for a change of pace from your average FPS games or for anyone needing something to play until Shadow of War comes out! Highly recommend!

I love scrounging for good cheap games. @ eight bucks I thought Prey was worth the risk after reading a couple of reviews. Ive already gotten my moneys worth. This is a first person shooter /survival game. It reminds me of Half-Life, a really good game that is probably older than many of you out there. Prey is a science fiction game with a pretty good story involving dangerous aliens, family betrayal, and time manipulation. It is a slower paced game with many clues and keys to track down in order to unravel the mystery of what happened to your characters memory and figure out why almost everyone on the Talos 1 space station is dead. It seems like a long game, as Ive played over 20 hours and I dont feel like I am even close to the end. The graphics & sound are well done. The controls and inventory management are a bit cumbersome, but do not detract from the overall experience. A good game.

My Best Buy only had one of these games left and at first they could not find it..but lo and behold they were finally able to locate it. Great atmosphere, challenging puzzles and interesting physics. This game is to be added to your collection.
Its just like the original game from the ps3 and 360 I loved the old game this one theyve improved the mechanics and the graphics look good I payed $10 for it so it was a win for me
Not sure why this game didnt do better maybe the company didnt promote it enough or something but its Actually a really good game

Prey is a fun a well made sci-fi shooter. Would recommend to any fps fan. You can't go wrong with your purchase, at it's current price point. If you're thinking of checking this game out, it is worth it.
Haven't had a whole lot of time on this one since I bought three games at once. Looks interesting though
A fun game with a good story and gameplay. Graphics are good too.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. Ever. There is no multiplayer which honestly is a good thing because they put all their focus into the campaign and as a result produced one of the best and most enjoyable games I have ever played. The only con is that the game is a bit difficult, I am playing it on easy as I dont play games as much as I used to and now look more for a good story rather than a challenge, and I still sometimes find myself with no healthkits and not enough materials to make any more. Overall though I give this game 5/5.
It's Bioshock with a twist! Truly an amazing beautiful game. Don't listen to gamespot or ign on the reviews. Great story and a lot of fun.
Excellently done. Lots of freedom. Keeps you on edge, but not scared at all. Tons of fun, already playing a second playthrough in just over a week.
The atmosphere is great. With a subtle soundtrack that complements the eerie plot twists, you'll be on your toes. Unique weapons and encouraging exploration. Play how you want.
Bought this game had hrs of entertainment easy to play

Arkane Studios is one of the game dev's that everyone should trust. They make great games with internal interrelated systems - physics/powers/abilities that are all upgradeable through the game. The atmosphere is based on an alternate timeline where JFK survived and partnered with Russia to advance the space race. The enemies, are very well designed from the mimics which can transform to any object in the environment, requiring you to be cautious whenever entering a new room/area. This is a great game, like the Dishonored series, which Arkane also created. Go play it! :)
My son has been playing this game regularly since he got it
