These are among my favorite games of all time, in fact Shenme II is number one on my list. I've played both games so much that I broke three Dreamcast GD-ROM drives. Needless to say, I am overjoyed that they received a re-release on modern console and PC systems. The design and aesthetics hold up well, even nearly 20 years after their initial releases. Anyone who has not played this franchise should know going in that the pacing is very slow. This is intentional. Yu Suzuki, the creator, wants the player to get immersed in the world, and few games have pulled this off so well. You truly feel like you are exploring real-life locations in the time period in which these games take place. This said, I have to be somewhat critical of this re-master. Despite a day-one patch, there are still many significant bugs. I've experienced glitched cutscenes where you cannot see the characters interacting. One of the QTE (quick time event) mini-games you can play refuses to register up on the directional pad, screwing me out of getting high scores. There is noticeable input lag when navigating some of the in-game menus. Some in-game sounds flat out refuse to play. I have my fingers crossed the developers will address these issues. One thing that cannot be fixed, however, is the quality of the audio. It sounds as low fidelity as it did on the Dreamcast. Unfortunately, the tracks could not be remastered without re-recording everything, so it's understandable. Just be prepared when you go in. Overall, the mere existence of this collection is a very positive thing. I just wish it had a little more 'time in the oven' so players would have a more polished experience.

Shenmue and Shenmue II are two of the greatest games of all time. Playing through the Shenmue series was and still is an absolutely incredible experience. Almost 20 years later, there is still nothing else quite like it. Therefore, it truly pains me to have to give this collection anything less than five stars. Unfortunately, this collection contains extremely shoddy and subpar ports of these two seminal classics. They are riddled with bugs and have extremely poor audio playback, with inconsistent volume levels, speech samples that are even lower quality than they were on the Dreamcast, randomly missing sound effects, and inaccurate music. The fantastic music in the Shenmue series is an integral part of the experience and it is a crime that Sega managed to mess it up so badly in this HD collection. Ultimately, I would still recommend this if it is your only way to play these games. However, I would highly advise playing the original Dreamcast/Xbox versions if at all possible. While Sega is actively patching this game, there is so much wrong with it that I doubt it will ever be on par with the original games that it is attempting to recreate. After waiting so many years for these two masterpieces to be released on modern platforms, it is a true shame that Sega was unwilling to give them the care that they deserve and do proper justice to Yu Suzuki's original work.

Shenmue is easily my favorite game of all time. I never grew up in the time when this game first came out in America in 2000 but first played it as a 15 year old back in 2009. Even at that young age emmeresed with games that are technically better looking, this old game on a system I never grew up with gripped me like no game has ever had and still never had to this day. Both of these games have stood the test of time with their deep level of immersion that I have not even felt with any game and with the care and craft that went into making the envoironments you explore. Shenmue 1 is easliy my favorite game of all time and 2 would easliy be in my top 10 and am definetly looking forward to 3 on August 27th 2019. Highly recommended if your tired of the same generic Sandbox games or Fortnight/PUBG clones that are the popular games out today.

I always herd this game was one of the greatest games on the Dreamcast and you just HAD to play it. So when they announced 1 and 2 would be coming to the PS4 I decided to give it a spin. What can I say about Shenmue it's a story of a boy who witnesses his father getting killed and tries to go about getting his revenge. It starts off well enough but is quickly halted by cheesy voice acting wonky camera a few glitches that were not in the Dreamcast version. I have only played the first game so far. But I can tell you if you are a gamer who started playing games in the last few generations and are used to the modern conenicens of video games like a mini map or a way point telling you where to go or being able to skip cutscenes then you may be put off by this. But if you are a Yakuza fan and want to see how that series got started then I'd recommend you play this as Shenmue is the father to the Yakuza series. This game was a technical marvel at the time it achieved many things that games were not doing back then. Like day and night cycles weather effect fully voice acted story intelligent AI that went about there day being able to go in almost every building and interacting with items. Mini games inside a video game. If you want to experience a piece of gaming culture give this a go but if you are impatient easily frustrated by not knowing what to do or where to go if you are used to having your hand held then this is not for you.

It's great revisiting the Shenmue franchise. I would argue that it was well ahead of it's time and still arguably one of the best RPG/Fighter games of all time. The graphics have been cleaned up since the games original launch though not much needed to be done whereas Shenmue was a very beautiful game compared to other games that launched in it's day. I am disappointed though many details that made the game a great time waster was removed or made linear where it was previously non-linear. Checking dressers, cabinets, collecting cassettes, learning and the practice needed to master moves, and other elements. This takes from some of the replayability of the game and much of what made Shenmue so revolutionary. Considering the space available in the Blu-ray format and the technology available now, I can not understand why the game was scaled down. If you want to sell it as multiple disks to release it in its full glory, please do that. I enjoy the game despite the noticable differences from the original.

First, I am a Dreamcast and Shenmue fan. I still own the originals of both. Here's the good and bad of the this updated compilation: THE GOOD: Classic tale of revenge. Wastes no time getting you roped into the story. The characters and environments are memorable. The story is engaging and it's easy to get sucked in for hours. The pacing is slow, but I find it as a comforting zen-like experience. I love that I can remote play on my Vita and enjoy it handheld throughout the house. The games don't seem to take too much HD space on my PS4 either, which is nice. THE BAD: In regards to the core game itself, the game and flow feels dated. Especially if you grew up on anything newer than PS2 era systems. These are basically just ports of a game engine that was released almost 20 years ago. Keep that in mind when it comes to graphics and textures. The controls pre-date the dual analog stick standard. So expect tank controls with minimal right analog support. The audio samples of the voice overs are not very good and you'll definitely notice it when you first play. The combat is based on old Virtua Fighter mechanics which are not great, but it gets the job done. There's not much combat anyway. In regards to the re-release efforts, I hit multiple cutscene glitches. During realtime cutscenes, the camera would change to some random static shot while the music and voiceovers play. Sometimes it's a static shot of a lamp or a static shot inches from a blank wall. I hit these bugs in less than an hour of play. I really hope they patch this soon. The main draw of the game is its ability to pull you in. But these cutscene glitches are immersion breaking. It's unfortunate because the original releases felt so polished. I think there's audio problems when running through the streets that was not present in the original. The sound of the foot steps randomly cuts out. I'm surprised they couldn't improve the NPC pop up. The popup may be worse than the original.

When this title was initially released on the Dreamcast I thought it was the greatest game of all time. Playing through it now I see how far games have come since then. It is a very slow day. In between tasks you frequently need to waste time wandering around, playing arcade games, drinking a soda, listen to the same few people say the same few things, etc. The combat is terrible! As are the controls. I barely remember not having 2 joysticks to use. The 3 stars comes from the nostalgia and terrible voice acting known from Japanese titles at this time. If you never played this you will hate it. If you played it before and remember it, you will likely enjoy some reminiscing.

DBZ games have been flops the past few years...the last great one I remember was probably Raging Blast 2, for its excellent gameplay. This one, with its extensive customization, great gameplay, and unique new story, makes it a must have for all DBZ fans, and one that fans of fighters should definitely consider.
Awesome game which gives new life to the series everyone should play !

I bought this because I had the strange urge to relive my Budokai for PS2 days. The combat is SWEET. You create your own Z fighter from all different races you'll recognize. The introduction is RIDICULOUS, as some of the first things you do to learn the controls is go Toe-to-toe as a new super saiyan Goku on Namek delivering a good spanking to Frieza. The game was developed to be... like an MMO of some sort I think? I don't know, I don't do anything with other players-- never see any anyways. This is a non-cannon excuse to make your own Z character, 'apprentice' under a famous character, learn all their moves, and legitimately play out your childhood fantasies of ascending through your race's power levels to save the galaxy. Only bad thing is the weird 'menu'/'lobby' between fights... you walk around in a non-combat, mmo-like 'town' with vendors and stuff. Just ends up being a little inconvenient in the end.
for long time fans of the series and for people that are willing to put a lot of time into the game, this is a very good game.
So much fun and a lot of customizable features. The story is so cool and well thought out.

This game is seriously addictive. The leveling system and reward systems are solid and fun to play around with. The storyline takes what I love about DBZ and gives it a whole new perspective. If I had one negative thing to say about it, it would have to be that they should have made the game more open in terms of free roaming. It would be nice to be able to explore the world a bit more and find new tasks outside of the small map they give you to roam around in. Otherwise an excellent game.

Pros: Really entertaining to play with friends Went over the majority of the Sagas Multiple Races Multiple Skills Good amount of characters Cons: I didn't like that the transformation and charge up ability had to take up a skill slot, I feel as if it should of been a passive ability. I also feel you should of been able to cycle or choose any of the Saiyan levels, not just one while in combat. I also feel that you should of been able to use a fusion ability, and become like vegito without having to choose the vegito character to play as.

it is a really good game best dragon ball game in a while but they are lacking characters for some reason it is ok to have 15 versions of Goku but no cell first or second form and I hate having to walk around the entire map it gets really annoying and also the drop rates for moves are ridiculous you can sit there and play the mission 25 times and still not get the move you are looking for. Also you can play as the main villain you have to buy the dlc and the third villain is not playable. maybe for the next dragon ball game they can leave the last gen consoles behind so we can use the full power of the Xbox One, PS4 and Pc. Hopefully with the next Dragon ball game they can add ALL of the characters and not a lot of versions of just some and make ALL of the villains playable without buying the dlc. What I like about the game is what they did with the story and parallel quest along with the character customization.

As a DBZ fan I knew this title was a must have, I was not disappointed. Though there are some questionable design choices, then Hub world feels like a throwback to Phantasy Star Online, the actual gameplay is quite fun. Where this game really shines is the use of your custom created character, you participate in all of the biggest battles of the DBZ timeline. The story really integrates your character, its more than just retreading the same battles as you know them. Aside from the main story there are 60 or so side battles that can be played solo or online coop. On thing of note, I highly recommend you be a fan, if not I cannot imagine you will fully appreciate the game!
It is a step up from the last game. Enjoyed everything about it.

I've not played a Dragonball Z game in a long time. I am a long time fan of the franchise. If you are too, and a video game player, then you should get it too! Awesome new concept on the universe seems like Days of Future past and more stories and battles to play on and Off-Line

Dragonball Xenoverse is pretty good, if you're a fan. The game takes cues from the previous Dragon Ball games and amps up the action, allowing for 3 vs 3 fights in full 3-Dimentional space. You're tasked with creating a new character at the start of the game, and you can choose between Saiyan, Earthling, Namekian, Buu's, and Frieza's race. The story is done cleverly enough by introducing two new characters who change pivotal moments in time throughout the Dragonball Z series. It's your job to stop these two and fix the timeline. Unfortunately for the game, much of the online features depend on the servers, which are down quite often. But, when things are going well, the main hub where quests and battle options are found, are packed with up to 200 players, making it feel reminiscent of an MMO. Overall, the grindy leveling system and server quality limit this game from being great. And though The game has a lot of customization, it still feels lacking.
Wish it goes straight to two player mode. You have to work your way through a lot to earn new character
The controls are lacking nothing like Budokai 3. Not usually too worried about graphics but they're terrible for next gen.

It's a fantastic, visually stunning game, with a lot of bonus content besides the main story line to keep you busy. The achievements are average difficulty, noting too hard or weird to unlock. The game is great but could be better. The camera during some battles can be shaky and some of the villains are tough, but if you are a fan of DBZ, it won't matter as much since this is probably the best console game attached to the Dragon Ball franchise.
The game itself is decent, but it is easy to lose interest in it.

I picked this game up because I'm a big DBZ fan and I was hoping it would expand on the fun and game play of Battle of Z. However this is more of an RPG fighter than Battle of Z's jump right in and play style. This game has some cool aspects to it like reliving some great DBZ moments, however the grinding and training aspects of the game are tedious and do not make for much fun. I think this game is for the most hardcore of DBZ fan because of all the grinding you must do to progress.

After playing Ultimate Tenkaichi and Battle of Z, as well as avoiding Kinect, I can say this is the best DBZ game as of recently. That's not to say that there aren't other DBZ games better than it, since that's not true. DBZ Budokai 3 and the Raging Blast games are certainly better. The gameplay takes a lot getting used to in this game, and there is a bit of grinding involved but once you do good it's a decently fun game. Also the character creator is pretty nice.
My son in into Dragonball but I bought him this game and he never plays it. I'm guessing its not as cool as other games.

Rally car driving and physics are fantastic using a good force feedback wheel. I did have to change the wheel settings to correct the very loose steering the game had by default but once I got that dialed in I was good to go. Can't speak for using a controller but I've heard that works okay as well. Career modes are okay and more real world tracks would have been nice but the core driving experience is what makes this game great. Racing is very challenging even on the default medium difficulty setting but if you have the patience to learn every corner and nuance of a track, get your car setup right, adjust your driving to suit what type of car you are in (FWD/RWD/4WD), you will start leading the pack. Head-to-head 6 car racing in the officially licensed FIA World Rallycross Championship series is also great fun.

Admittedly I'm not the biggest Gears fan. I owned the first one back in the 360 days, but barely played it. Same goes for the digital copies that came with Gears of War 4 Ultimate Edition. Onto Gears 5...this game is awesome. I'd say I'm about halfway through at this point. Graphics, sound (new home theater *drool*), and the Jack commands are great and add another layer to combat. I like the story and especially the random banter. It all comes together well.

The only issue I had was when I went to pick up the game & a label made sticker with name & preorder number was stuck to the side of the game slipcover. Removing the sticker destroyed the whole side of the slipcover. Doesn't affect the disc or anything but as a collector I don't want any labels of stickers slapped all over my product. Other than that, Gears 5 is possibly the best Gears to date
Absolutely love the changes they implemented in 5. The 'Open World' is great to explore, but still keeps you moving in the right direction

I buy for the multiplayer even though I'm horrible(its still fun) but but.... the continuation of the COG/Swarm corruption continues in the mindblowing solo(can play online with friends) campaign. New to this game is a little freedom to explore certain area and not just a push through like previous gears game.

Taking places right after Gears 4 its great to return to the franchise and see where it continues to go. Only a few chapters in, the story is emotionally driven with the intensity of tried and true gameplay. There are more modes to play to give this game the longevity it needs after you complete the story. Worth every penny given how polished this entry is.

I've followed Gears of War since the beginning. The story line is what hooked me in but the multi-player games keep me playing. The story line continues to amaze. I'm not a very good at PVP but I still love trying the different PVP games. Horde is where I excel as I'm a team oriented player. Horde concept in Gears 5 is basically the same as Gears 2,3,4 but adds character special skills and makes players themselves collect power, which used to be mainly the job of the scout. If you're into the Gears of War franchise, this is another great pick-up and if you haven't you're missing out.

I enjoyed playing the Gears of War franchise since its start on the Xbox 360. However, like many franchises, the gameplay became repetitive and the story, especially in Gears of War: Judgment, lacked heart and emotion. Upon hearing about Gears 5, I grew curious about returning to play in this franchises once more. Spoiler-free, the story is amazing and hints a continuation. In short, it is a roller coaster of heart and emotion that I have grown to expect from the Gears franchise. Multiplayer returns, and it is a fun time to play. It is very forgiving to new players of the franchise and old veterans alike. There is a perk system in place that rewards players to access different type of weapons for the specific class of character you are playing as in multiplayer, which is great. Progression is documented through a leveling up system. There is no season pass this year, and The Coalition, game publisher, promises to add different types of levels, modes, especial events, and characters that can be earned through playing the game. There are micro transactions hidden in Gears 5 and are used to buy basic skins for weapons and characters that can be earned by playing the game. Overall, I am very content with my purchase of Gears 5 and feel that it is a must for any fan of the franchise and Xbox owner.

Gears 5 is a great addition to the universe. The graphics are u believable, audio is great, controls are on point, although I wish I could map functions to buttons as I see fit. Other than that, the game is incredible and the story is well laid out. Multiplayer is fun as ever. This is a must have for the collection.

Exactly why I wanted to play it. Well worth getting.

The reason 360 has 'downloadable content' is the entire reason the game was delayed and truly one of the reasons blu-ray won the format war. Everyone knows that Blu-ray discs can hold massive amounts of data while hd-dvd's are very limited in the amount of data that they could hold. 360 owners think they are getting something that others arent getting, but in reality, all they are really downloading is the remainder of the game that the developers couldn't fit on the hd-dvd. The real reason the game was delayed had NOTHING to do with development, both versions were completed almost a year ago, the delay was with how to fit it on the hd-dvd's limited space. So, in order to get the game top us, they had to compromise, they gave 360 owners what they could on the disk, then released the remainder as 'downloadable content'. PS3 is the FUTURE! trade up now you 360 fanboys while you still can...

this game is very exciting and amazing. this game has the best graphics ive seen in a game and what is most appealing is the reality, you get to control a person that can kill, punch, throw, drive, fly aircraft, steal cars etc. it also has real life features such as subways, different cars etc. its a game that is closest to reality. one last thing, multiplayer in gta 4 is very interactive, you can do many things even drive your frineds in a car or helicopter! it is just like reality.

I was never a fan of the GTA series but this one caught my eye with the online play as I always thought that was the one thing that could get me interested in the series but even that in the end wasn't enough. This game has so many issues including the lack of customization, even with the brightness game option turned all the way up I still can't read the display on the in-game cell phone unless I turn my tv brightness up as well, lack of vehicles (the series has been going for some time now so you would think the vehicles would be spectacular although the helicopter is a nice addition) and perhaps my biggest issue with this abomination is that the game isn't formatted to fit all screens and doesn't have a display option to change it. Overall I would still recommend it to a friend becuase a lot of people love this series but I would likely advise them to hold off for Saints Row 2.

From GTA3 this has certainly improved in every single aspect of the game. Once you start you cant stop, you will really enjoy the missions and story since the main character has a more interesting story in this chapter of GTA4. The game also allows you to be more involved in your social life to make it more real and at the same time this also will help you achieve more in your adventure since you might meet some well conected people along the way. All this and I haven't even played the multiplayer. This game has previously had a decent replay value just for running around the city creating chaos but now you also have the social life, kind of like the Sims, as well as different types of multiplayer games. It has a value of more than $60 if you compare what you usually get for $60 with other games. if you are already thinking about it, just go and get it, trust me you will love the game and continue to enjoy it for a long time. Hope it helps.

I own both the 360 and PS3 versions of the game. I have had Zero problems with the 360 version but with the PS3 version it freezes for 2 or 3 seconds about once every 30 mins or so. It also crashed once when I was doing something with the phone. The PS3 version seems to look slightly better than the 360 version, fewer jagged lines, but the constant freezing is annoying. And to top it off you can't play online! Whenever you try it says you can't find the server. Lame, very lame. I've had no problems with the 360 version getting online. So, if you own both a 360 and a PS3, get the 360 version. If you only own a PS3 go ahead an get the game, it's worth it even if it's still beta.

While It is true that the Xbox 360 version does have Downloadable Content on the way next year the game itself is what you need to grab no matter what system. The pros of the 360 version is the downloadable content but thats about it depending on your taste. The Playstation 3 version has softer colors making it seem more realistic while the 360 version has brighter colors making it seem a little like previous GTA's with the comic book look. in addition the Playstations version of Liberty City where the game is set is more alive than the 360's it has more people, cars and more lifelike reflections than it's 360's counter part. This comes from the Playstation 3's outstanding core processor being able to do all these things at the same time without slowing how the game looks. It all depends on your taste and how you want your GTA IV to feel.

While the 360 version is the definitive version of GTA IV, the PS3 version is the inferior version. The PS3 caused this game's delay from 2007 into 2008, and is still weeks behind in development compared to the 360 version. It has many graphical glitches and framerate issues that are nonexistant in the 360 version, which is already complete. It has been stated in previews that the 360 version has more vibrant graphics and better lighting, while the PS3 version looks bland and washed out. Also, the 360 version will be getting an exclusive expansion pack that will add 20 hours of new gameplay. The PS3 version will not be getting this. The 360 version is by far the superior version of GTA IV.

Everybody should agree that Grand Theft Auto IV is going to be a waste of time, no, a waste of life. This game is going to be just like the PS2 version. The Xbox 360 offers the most advantages to buyers because of Xbox live, but it won't be that great. Most of you that are reading this have a PS3 and can play PS2 games, so why dont you just get Grand Theft Auto: Vice City for PS2 (It is going to be the same!). The only difference from the PS2 versions are GRAPHICS. So go ahead and pay $60 for graphics money wasters. If you have a PS2, buy that version. If you disagree with me, fine. I'm not mean, I'm just trying to save you some money.

Overall I think GTA4 is mostly a good game the only reason I give it a 5 star rating is for the story mode. Other than that the graphics are a 'been there done that' kinda feel to them. They don't really ever push the PS3 to it's limits like COD4 or GT5 prologue does. The dualshock 3 makes this game that much more interesting. DS3 adds something missing from most games depth and a sense of being there. I love the minimal load screens (you can goto any building thats interactive and just walk into or out of it) The mission load screens are unadvoidable. Just a little side note: this game takes a HUGE chunk of HDD space (5 gigs) so have little to nothing on the HDD before installing gta4. The helicopter flying leaves something to be desired such as a joystick accessory for the ps3 (you know just like a pc one) It is really hard to fly one of those things. The sixaxis controls are goofy and might as well be turned off. I was mostly let down with the graphics more than anything.

Little Dragon's Caf is a casual sim/exploration game which is simply overflowing with charm. It's easy to get drawn in by the game's forgiving gameplay, great music, heartwarming stories, and dramatic day-night changes, and hard to put down, given all there is to do post-game. While its sim mechanics aren't especially deep, LDC provides a delightful way to escape the woes of the real world alongside your own, adorable pet dragon.

The one flaw that ruins this game is that if you die, you have to start the entire game all over again (Much like Rogue Stormers). I am not sure why developers think it is fun playing the same level over and over, but if I don't feel like I am making progress in a game, I am not having fun. As far as the character movements and combat. Everything is fluid and responsive. It has the retro feel of the old castlevania games. The graphics, unfortunately, aren't great but for this type of game they are passable. I believe there is around 12 levels of this game. And if you die on say level 10, you have to start again at level 1. You are allowed to keep some things like gold, but who cares. You just lost all your progress by dying. And yes, I know some players love a challenge. Well, have different difficulty levels then. The hardcore gamers can brag when they beat the game on a higher difficulty, but why punish the casual gamer that just wants to have some fun exploring these levels and fighting things? And this is coming from someone that has finished all the Dark Souls games. At least in those games, when you died, you didn't lose progress on every area you explored or things you unlocked. Either way, if you think you will like replaying the same levels over and over again, then enjoy! For me, I rather be having a root canal.

This game is full of glitches. I cant believe this made it past quality control at Ubisoft, because this is completely unacceptable for a $40 game. Music and sounds are missing, the rules of the game dont function correctlyits a total mess. Here's a list of all of the issues: Missing sounds: Bankrupt whistle when you land on Bankrupt 1/2 Car Horn when you land on 1/2 Car Tag Solved puzzle music cue The iconic 'ding' when letters light up blue on the puzzle board The speed-up music during round 4 The bell sound that should be heard when the final spin graphic is being displayed Bugs: The game breaks randomly and the million dollar wedge, prize wedges, 1/2 car tags, and gift tags just stop coming off the wheel after a round or 2--including during the final spin where ALL extras on the wheel should be removed The wild card and gift tags will re-generate on the wheel not just visually; they can be claimed again and again. This is NOT how the game is played--once these are off the wheel, they are off for the entire rest of that game, with the exception of the 1/2 car tags which should replenish. Update 1.0.1 that was released, BROKE the flippers. Depending on where the wheel lands, the flipper will register the adjacent wedge, that WAS NOT LANDED ON. The background lights that flash when you solve a puzzle, at some point just get stuck flashing, even when normal play resumes the next round (it happens in the bonus round as well) The debounce when hitting buttons is poor or non-existent. There have been many times when you push a button to solve the puzzle, it shows you the screen to start inputting text, but then immediately jumps to the next player to spin, as if you forfeit your solve. After playing a round, if you want to go into the options to change the prize wedge or the gift tags, the wheel doesn't spin to the correct places, so you cannot see the changes you are making. The game has been out for weeks with these reported bugs and not a peep or update from Ubisoft.

So I'm 36 years old, my crazy bar days are behind me, but I still love video games. This is (obviously) not a gamers game, but if you're looking to have a fun night of shouting at the TV with your significant other, or a bunch of friends, this game is a great choice. My fiance and I love it, and when our friends come over, we've turned it into a drinking game because why not? In all seriousness though, it's a fun game and a great way to kill an otherwise uneventful evening. If you like word games/trivia, I highly recommend this game

It has crashed or frozen in the middle of games for me several times, with no way to save or resume progress. Online play is a nice addition to play against others around the world in real time, but often nobody is available to play and youre up against very slow computer players that make the games way too easy. Also, the clues on Jeopardy begin to repeat after only a few full games. Not sure its worth the price for how quickly it repeats game play.

Ohhhh so much better than shouting at the tv show when it broadcasts! We love competing against one another and learning new facts (especially in the Jeopardy game). Great categories! My 6 yr old tried his best to compete (Harry Potter and other kids related topics), he isnt there just yet, but Im sure hell be giving us a run for our money pretty soon.

If you like Dishonored 2, then Death of the Outsider is a great sequel. While going from Dishonored 1 and 2 can be a bit jarring and disorienting (different mechanics, abilities, scenery, and graphics), going from 2 to Death of the Outsider is super easy. Death of the Outsider is set in Karnaca, and so far I've visited at least 2 places that are familiar to me from Dishonored 2. Billie has different abilities from Emily (or Corvo, or even Daud for that matter), but that doesn't make this game any less enjoyable. If anything it makes it more interesting as a lot of Billie's abilities are unlike that which we've seen before. For example, Billie's Foresight is completely different from Dark Vision, in the aspect that she astral projects while time is frozen, giving you a chance to look over your surroundings. Even when being attacked by guards. There's been a couple of times where I've thought 'Man, if I had any of the other's powers, this would be a breeze' and I think that's why Billie's abilities are so different. This is a fantastic game, 10/10, would recommend.

I love and enjoy the Plants vs. Zombies franchise. Yeah, PvZ2 is not the greatest sequel you could ask for, but Garden Warfare is a hilarious take on modern first and third person shooters. The game is just great overall fun. Playing as the Plants or Zombies provides hours of entertainment and lots of unlockables. Yes, this a multiplayer only game, but I feel it is better for that and maybe that was the point? Multiplayer is great, community is great and everyone just has a good time. Not a lot of skill is required to play the game, but if you are able to master one of the classes, you can dominate a match. Another great feature is splitscreen co-op. My wife and I use this all the time and have a great time together playing. She loves Plants vs Zombies, but does not play shooters at all. She was able to pick this game up right away. Online is required, so take that into consideration before purchasing.
This is one of my go to online multiplayer games. Solid controls, great presentation, addictive rewards, this game is great. *online is required to play this game.

If you have totally avoided the Battlefield 4, Call of Duty: Ghosts or other similar hardcore multiplayer shooter experiences and/or have been looking for a fun, accessible and less violent alternative, Plants vs. Zombies: Garden Warfare is definitely worth a look.

Kids cannot play this game without access to a PSN master account. Doesn't matter how old they are, but once you create a PSN sub-account, you can't upgraded it to a master account until the account reaches 18 yrs old. Downside of them having a master account is there are no parental controls. Security architecture wasn't thought through for this game.

I had no idea what I was buying before I purchased this game. I assummed it would be similar to the tablet p vs z, and I was wrong. However, I would say this is a good game overall. Several game modes, competitive and non. A third-person-shooter perspective, with a silly plants vs zombies twist. Upgradable abilities, cards that you acquire to boost certain areas on the playing maps, and several customization unlocks. Not a bad game for the amount of fun versus the cost of the game itself. Would be great for younger kids, as well as those looking for something different to do if you enjoy shooter games.
My kids and I have played the Plants vs Zombies games on our PCs and iPhones. This is a great new take on the series, Everyone loves unlocking new costumes and attacks for their characters.

This is yet another team based shooter but with some fun, unique twists. There is a good variety of game modes, maps are varied in art design, verticality and confinement, and it's a great balance with accessibility for those that are poor at shooters or children, whilst offering depth and 'room to show off' if you're more advanced. I wish local split screen offered more than one mode, and although coins are gained pretty rapidly, the in-game purchases does mean some players can advace their characters much quicker if they are willing to pay. A great game and different enough to stand out.

This edition comes in a Sega Genesis style clamshell. The dimensions are the same as the original clamshell cases, although maybe a little thinner of a spine, and the quaility seems pretty close as well. Instead of a Sega game cartridge, however, there is a foam insert with the Switch cartridge nested inside. It also comes with a fold out poster and one full color manual containing Aladdin in one half - and if you flip the manual 180 degrees and flip it over - you have the Lion King Manual. The manual is of similar paper quality as a Genesis game manual. The case even comes with the hanger on the top. This does NOT come with a Nintendo Switch case inside, so it will not match the rest of your Switch collection - if that is of concern to you. There is also a Super Nintendo variation of this retro edition, in which the cart comes in a recessed cardboard inlay much like the original SNES carts did - no Nintendo Switch case in that variation either. Both games are on one cart, and if you want a review of the actual game/port/emulation/etc; there are plenty of reviews on the listing for the standard version of this game. Overall, I recommend this edition to people who loved these games when they were kids (who played on Genesis), and to people who enjoy physical media and like getting manuals with their games. If you can, buy this in person as the clear plastic outer film that holds the cover sheet can become damaged fairly easily. If you want to see it unboxed, I have a video on YouTube - as may other people, and check it out that way.
I grew up playing these games as a kid and I'm so glad they're back on the Nintendo Switch!

I love these games. This is such a cool collection. A must own from the 16bit era of gaming. My only grip is that there is no traditional case in this collection. I know it doesn't advertise one, but it would have been nice. Also my case doesn't hold a genesis game cart. It has a cut out (filled with foam to hold the switch cart) like it should hold one but it doesn't.

I've tested this on both the Xbox 360 and the PlayStation 3. While it's not as impressive with the PS3 version, the game in general is an absolute blast. After quite a streak of unimpressive and repetitive story lines, Sonic Unleashed finally breaks away from tradition. New characters and a whole new circumstance with the same old die hard attitude make the game fast paced, full of action, and fun for people of all ages. The music, as usual, does not disappoint in the least. The only disappointment to the true fans of this game would be side characters are in short supply, and unlike usual, play a very minuscule role in the plot development and progress. With that in mind, the newly introduced character for this story fills that void quite well. There have been some complaints that this game is too easy and boring. Please realize that most of the people writing reviews like this give the game less than an hour to play, and as per usual, this game gives a tutorial for the first short bit on how to play like many others so that you can get used to the new controls. One stage in this game took me an hour and 10 minutes to complete racing through it and I still earned a C ranking. Anyone who had played fully through this game in comparison to the older Sonic games will be glad to tell you that by the end the difficulty has really stepped up a notch. I'd give this game 5 out of 5 stars. Sega finally took their time with development on a game, and this is a great end result to their work.

A great RPG by one of the industry's best (Atlus). It's very nice that the Launch Edition comes with extras (art book and decals in a dvd sized box) while costing the same as the average 3DS game. The decals are of decent size. The art book isn't hard covered, instead it's that type where if the cover is opened too far it'll stay open. The illustrations are wonderful. The book details the characters and settings and is 38 pages long.

I wanted this long before it's release. I love this edition so much that I bought 2! The art book and decals are awesome. If you love Atlus as much as I do then do yourself the favor of buying this. It has a new character named Nemesia, added gameplay, added story content, redesigned character art, new character voice overs and music from the original composer Yoko Shimomura. It features 2 modes perfect and append. With append you are able to play the original game before starting a new game with all the AWESOME added content. With perfect mode you begin the game with the added content from the beginning. Anyone that has any interest in jrpg's needs this in their collection. If you're new to jrpg's I definitely recommend starting with this because your first experience with jrpg's should be memorable, beautiful, fun and authentic.

Ive only played a few hours into the game but the fact that it deals with time travel and having the option to change it reminds me of Chrono Trigger. It puts me in a state of nastolgia. The voice acting is great and the pixel art is even better. The combat is turned based and allows you to perform combos for higher damage and xp. Did I mention this version came with an art book and stickers!

As many already know, this is a remake of a DS game released about 7 years ago. For newcomers that love RPG games, I would totally recommend this new version over the original DS since it's improved in many ways (it has voice acting, more save slots, the graphics look better, and there's new content/sidequests/a new character). For those that already played the original, there's still fun to be had in this remake; mainly the extra content/sidequest/new character; and it's in my opinion, a good reason to revisit this game! I'm 10 hours into it and loving it (even more than the first time I played it). Also, I would like to note that the original localization effort done by Atlus when the DS game was released was great; but this time it was taken one step further with the voice acting; which is pretty good and compliments well the work done earlier. Additionally, keep in mind that the launch copies come with a nice cardboard box, an artbook, and decal artwork that includes the characters of the game. So I would recommend getting your copy while supplies last if you want to get those. If you haven't tried the game before and you're hesitant if this game will be your cup of tea, there's a free demo in the Nintendo eShop; and you can transfer your progress to the real game if you decide to buy it (which I did).

I just bought this game on 2/19/2018!! Will have to give kudos to Atlus for picking up this game and remaking it for the newer system. Game comes along with new additional contents, DLC, art and more! For those who are purchasing the limited 'launch' edition, an artbook and sticker sheet are included which are package inside the box. Friendly mode makes it easy for new players to enjoy game which helps focus more on the story vs normal and hard mode. For those who have played this game before, you're welcome to play the append mode which have additional stories or re-visit the original story line with updated graphics and voicing! Def. a must have JRPG game! Advice: if you're not sure if the game is right for you, you may dl the demo on the DS shop! The demo version allows you to save your progress onto your SD card which you may transfer /load the file onto the full version (when purchase) and OH! in demo they give some freebie in game healing items too.. so even if you plan on buying the full game, PLAY DEMO ANYWAY! :)))))

Don't get me wrong, this game is amazing, the 3 star review comes from the poor handling of digital codes on Best Buys account when it comes to the time it takes to get it. The site clearly says you will get an email within one hour. Well two hours later I finally got one saying 'Hey thanks for your purchase, you'll be getting another email with instructions on how to install shortly.' Or something to that regard. It was 3 am at this point so I decided to call it a night and download it in the morning. Well, 1230 rolled around and I still didn't get a code, had to call in and have them expedite it. Finally got the code about 10 minutes after the phone call, but even the woman on the phone said it takes up to 24hrs to get codes. I could have walked into a store, purchased the card from a gaming section and come back faster then waiting all this time. Just know that if you buy digital content from DotCom it will take extra time, if you are in a hurry to play, swing into a brick and mortar.

While the RTS genre has largely been replaced in popularity by the MOBA genre, I'm glad to see Microsoft release this title against the dying popularity of its genre. The game is a solid RTS, though it lacks the trifecta (per se) of the StarCraft series, lending more to a focus on Leader Powers (powers you can use from your camera perspective that target anywhere you want that aren't tied to a unit's action) than playing to your 'race's' strengths. Since there are only two sides, and both share a large portion of their unit strategies with only a handful of real differentiation, large-scale (and ultimately longer match) battles get to be a bit on the boring side. This is remedied by several modes, opting for quick matches of sheer strategy and all-out chaos, but I do only recommend fans of the RTS genre to give this game a chance. If you're not into this sort of game, this one won't change your mind!

I'd rate Halo Wars 2 as a buy after the first price drop. It's got a great mix of content for RTS veterans and RTS newcomers alike. Storywise, Halo Wars 2 seems a bit too brief of a campaign, but the missions are extremely varied in a way that rivals Starcraft, and the cutscenes are some best looking cutscenes I've ever seen in gaming. Multiplayerwise, Halo Wars 2 really shines as you have a great mix of Online Co-Op, verses, and Firefight modes, coupled with offline Skirmish modes against AI. Blitz is a fun game mode for quick games, but the pay to win microtransactions in that mode are going to really prevent a lot of people from playing on an even footing. (I'd stick to blitz firefight in that regard, as it cuts the pay to win element out entirely) If you love Halo and RTS, defintely buy it at launch. If you aren't quite sold, wait until you can get the ultimate edition at a better price. 343 has a good track record of post-launch support off of Halo 5, (Free maps, tendency to listen to the community for post-launch features and updates) and as good as this game is at the moment, it will be a great addition to your game collection in 6 months when the post-launch DLC campaign, maps, and leaders arrive.

My very first RTS ( Real Time Strategy ) game was Halo Wars. I went into that game not knowing anything about it, and not even knowing if I would like it at all, but as it turns out I absolutely LOVED it. So Halo Wars 2 was a no brainer to me, it was a day one buy. If you know what an RTS is and have experience in this genre of games then you know what to expect here. Base building, troop development, land and air, vehicle & armor , weapon development etc etc etc............ then of course moving troops and etc from one place to the other to complete the objectives of the game . Sounds simple and boring? LOL, it is not, you will have multiple things happening at once, not all the time but it will happen, you may have troops engaging a target and more somewhere else engaging some enemy somewhere else and then your base comes under attack and you have to mange what is happening there as well.. Don't think this will be to much to handle for you, the game is set up in a way that you can quickly move from one engagement to the other very very quickly and seamlessly. Most RTS games will be found on PC, and few have been developed for Console, but the way the game has been tailored for controller control instead of mouse and keyboard it is absolutely outstanding. the controls are simple and easy to remember and understand, allowing quick response for what ever situation you find yourself in during the game. Story - The Game begins as the crew from The Spirit of Fire awaken from cryo sleep due to a distress signal from an instillation called the ARK. Upon deploying a Spartan team to the Ark to investigate the signal, the team encounters the Atriox, a Brute that has risen through the trials of war to become the most brutal and fierce leader of a rebel covenant faction. It is now up to you to stop this terrible threat and save the galaxy and the human race.. This game will also impact the Halo 6 story line, which is very interesting because the original Halo Wars had no impact at all on the games that came after it. I love this idea and upon playing the upcoming Halo 6 title I will remember and be able to reflect on what happened during Halo Wars 2, and why the things happening in Halo 6 are happening . Halo Wars was a game that was set in the Halo universe but had nothing to do with the main line Halo titles and the Master Chief, and that is not the case with this game and the upcoming Halo 6 main line installment.. What a great idea, I absolutely love it and absolutely cannot wait for the inevitable Halo 6 release in 2018. Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous, detail everywhere, you know you are playing a Halo game, there is no doubt. The cut scenes are absolutely AMAZING, and the original Halo Wars was no slouch in this department either, but DANG they are beautiful in this title, and just help immerse you into this game and the Halo universe. Voice Acting - The cast in this game are top notch as you would expect from a AAA game release. There are a few characters throughout the campaign that are better than others, but that is to be expected just like any other game or movie, but over all the voice acting is exceptional to further your game immersion. Sound - If you have played past main line Halo titles you will be right at home here, from the sounds of gunfire to the pop of plasma grenades, it's all here. The Scorpion tanks, Warthogs and all Covenant vehicles sound absolutely great and just like they should and are definitely what you remember. Also just like all Halo titles this entry has an excellent orchestral sound track that's just puts you into the Halo universe and keeps you there, simply amazing.. Conclusion - This is an AMAZING title for everyone not just the Halo fan base, there is just so much fun to be had here. In my opinion this game is well worth the purchase price, and I urge everyone to pick it up. Solid 5 out of 5

Being a long time fan of BioWare's Dragon Age series, this game does not disappoint the roleplay gamer. There are a few bugs here and there, mostly in making sure you're not moving around too much when the game is trying to save as it runs the risk of crashing. But as far as game-play, story, character development, and overall badassery, this game is beyond perfect. The score is brilliantly produced to get the dragon-slaying blood pumping, the dialogue is full of wit and heart and information, and the combat techniques are incredibly easy to pick up on. Whether you're a master tactician or an in-the-moment fighter, Dragon Age: Inquisition is both challenging and rewarding. There are just enough moments of humor to ease the harder decisions. and plenty of hard choices to discover who among your allies is the most morally conscious. The world of Thedas is vast, truly encompassing the enormity of Origins and DA2 without losing the charm and appeal that we were first introduced in the predecessors. The companions are bright, eloquently designed, and regardless of their personal and moral standings, you can't help but love them regardless. I would definitely consider this to be one of the absolute best games of 2014, if not of the last ten years all together (but, perhaps, I am biased). 100/10, I definitely see this game becoming a major fan favorite, as well as having replay-value for years to come.
DRAGON AGE is visually captivating game. Reminds me of Skyrim. It's an open world. I like the update of the dialog system because it allows the characters to express their emotions.

This game truly shows how far the Batman Arkham franchise has come. The visual effects of this game are stunning, it is set in Christmas in Gotham two years after Zero Year and the snow is a wonderful backdrop, the characters all have their breath visible, everything you would expect to see if you were watching an actual movie with real live actors. From the very first boss battle, I was hooked, it took me back to all the challenging boss battles I remember from the Nintendo/N64/Sony PS1 days where you cursed because it was actually a CHALLENGE to beat the boss. All the normal Arkham things are found here, Batarang, Detective Mode, Batwing, etc. Because it is set so early, Commissioner Gordon is Detective Gordon still (which I liked that little detail they stuck to, they could have screwed that one up). The cast of characters is phenomenal. So why did I give it 4 stars instead of 5 stars. Here is my opinion why it did not earn that last star from me. Roger Craig Smith voices Batman, and he just doesn't do it as well as Kevin Conroy has done Batman for so long. Mark Rolston as Deathstroke just doesn't pull it off, they should have recast Ron Perlman to reprise the role from The Flashpoint Paradox or Fred Tatasciore from Young Justice. I will say one casting that was well done, Nolan North as the Penguin was fantastic. The other reason I gave it 4 stars, they screwed up Copperhead and totally changed that character. This truly was a departure from DC cannon and it bothered me. Do not let those issues though dissuade you from buying what is possibly thus far the best game in the Batman Arkham franchise.

If you like the other two arkham titles you will like this one too. You cant tell they had a new game developer develop this one. You can hardly tell the difference of the new voice actors. Some of the boss fights are great and some are disappointing. There is more detective crime scene stuff which is good because Batman is suppose to be the 'worlds greatest detective.' This adds a new multiplayer game thats entertaining enough.

Arkham Asylum and Arkham City are my top 2 favorite games... ever. City is my #1 and Asylum is #2. If you are new to these games, here is what you need to know... The Arkham series is the BEST superhero game series ever made to this day. These are openworld games and the main gameplay is divided into two categories. 1) brawling with groups of thugs and 2) predator challenges. The brawling is amazing... the combat system starts out very simple but as you progress through the game you learn new moves and you quickly discover that the combat system is very very deep and can be as complicated as you want it to be. The predator csequences are stealth based gameplay where you are confronted with between 5 and 10 armed thugs who roam about a large room who batman takes down one by one. Again, this system is very deep and there are countless ways to approach each situation. However... Arkham origins is the 3rd game in the series and this was made by a different video game developer than the first two games. Arkham Origins tries to improve on the first two games in several ways, some which work and some which dont. While I didnt find Arkham Origins as enjoyable as the first two games... I still did find it enjoyable. So in summary... if you have not played Asylum or City then go out and play those NOW. If you really enjoyed Asylum and City then go ahead and pick up Origins and Im sure you will be glad you did. But if you played Arkham cCity and did not like it too much then I'm sure that this title is not worth your time.

The multiplayer has been unsuccessful for me so far. I spent 20-30 minutes trying to get into a game without success and after getting into a few lobbies only to be kicked out, i gave up. Thanks to this and a few other extremely difficult trophies, I will not be attempting a platinum on this one. Get it for the single player and for your love of the Batman.

I haven't had as much time to play Origins as I did when I played the other two in the series, but when I do get to sit down to play it's nostalgic and refreshing. The game is full of action and the pacing seems to be solid throughout. Opportunities for exploration beyond the primary storyline are as abundant as they were in Arkham City (if not more so) and things work almost exactly like the other two, although the interface seems to be a bit less easy to get used to. I haven't finished the game yet, but I can already tell where things are headed just by the easter eggs--the creators of these games have really done a great job appealing to the hard core fans with those sorts of drops. Arkham Origins is a winner--I already feel as though I've gotten my money's worth, and I'm sure I'll replay it at least once.

I've been playing the Just Cause series since the first game was released. LOVED JC2, and enjoyed JC3, even though it had some issues. Just Cause 4 is a MESS. There is SO much wrong with this game, I wouldnt be able to get to it all here. (Google problems, and you'll find them). My biggest issues with this game arent visual, its the gameplay. JC2/3 worked because it was fun running around and blowing things up. JC4 isnt a whole lot of fun doing that. Its the most fun in the game, but its not as fun as 2/3. The world is large, and there is a LOT of land area. But that isnt necessarily a good thing. The world seems lifeless and dead. JC2/3 both had an 'alive' feeling, and beauty to the world(s), which JC4 just doesnt have. There are insane restrictions on ammunition, a weapon drop, drops with only 2 magazines. So youre constantly swapping out weapons from enemies or calling in nee drops. Gets old VERY fast. The 'busy work' they have you do in this game is boring, easy, and tedious. The developers took away liberating settlements!! That was the best part of JC2/3! Now there are settlements to blow stuff up in, but theydont count towards anything but Chaos points. You cant blow up bridges, or trains (easily). Enemy AI isnt the best, theyre quite stupid (flying/driving into random stuff duringnon-fighting times), but when you're fighting them, they are on their game, and there are TONS of them. It can make things quite difficult at first. But you learn to play in a style that works. If you must buy this game, wait until its $20 or under. And even then, i wouldnt say its worth it. Fins a used copy of JC2 or 3 and play those. JC2 is the best of the series, but JC3 was tons of fun for me to play, especially with the rocket boosted wingsuit (which JC4 also doesnt have). Save your money. PS - makes me sad to post such a poor review of a game I've been eagerly awaiting. :(

I enjoyed JC 3 and had high hopes for this version. It's fun to play, but it's not holding my interest as much as the previous version did, and the game play gets quite boring after a while. For some reason the graphics don't seem as good as the prior version either with several noticeable glitches and jittery performance. And this is while being played on an XB1X.

Rage 2 is bombastic fun with little considerstion for story, having any semblance of deep character relationships or a memorable open world. It's still serious fun until about 8 hours in, when the game make you grind tedious and repetitive side missions just to progress the main story. Up until that point though, the combat feels like if Doom (2016) was a cover shooter, and that was amazing to play and learn how to combo actions and skills together for massive carnage. Rage 2 is a good pickup when on sale or if you really have $60 to burn and no other games under consideration.

My review is based on about 4-5 hours of play and from what I've seen so far the game is better than I expected. It's a little slow at first but gets better as you acquire more powerful weapons, abilities and powers. It does require a bit of searching to find all the good stuff but is worth it making the game more enjoyable. The graphics and sound are excellent but the characters look a little cartoony when seen up-close. The weapons are varied and have a nice feel while the driving is more than adequate for it's intended purpose. All in all, a good shooter to hold me over until Doom Eternal arrives.

The shooting in Rage 2 is like a slightly wacky version of any one of the more recent Id Software titles, so it's exceptional. The driving is a bit slow, but also feels fun throughout the game. Graphically, the game is impressive on an Xbox One X, but only runs at 30fps on the S or original (as opposed to 60fps/1080p on the X). Its gameplay loop is most like a Far Cry, but I'm not sure the structure is as polishedbut who cares? The shooting is what you're here for, and I'd compare it to Doom or Wolfenstein II in terms of overall quality and fun factor.

Rage 2 has really impressed me. I've heard mixed things about but overall I've heard it's a lot of fun. I totally agree after spending some time with it. The shooting is some of the best I've ever played. The weapons feel powerful and unforgiving to your foes.

Art direction they chose for the environment is great, the wide variety of colors from the swamps to rain forest like and desert areas looks great. This game is very light on story, so if you're looking for a story driven shooter, you'll probably be disappointed. If you're looking for a game with great shooting mechanics, and powers (such as a Hulk smash, quick dash, double jumps, hovering in air while shooting, blasting an enemy to pieces with an 'iron man' type hand blast) than you will enjoy this game.

Game looks like something from 360 era with pop-in throughout, generic quests in a world map populated with the same cookie cutter things you've done in every other game in the past 10 years, but somehow even worse. Horrible character models and voice acting, had about 6 hard crashes while trying to slog through the campaign, character abilities and guns that bring NOTHING new to the genre. I could go on and on. One big problem I have is that the marketing makes the game out to be a wild and wacky spaz fest of nonstop gunplay and explosions. So far it feels more like a snooze fest much of the time. You drive around in barren wasteland to get to the next area where anything is happening. The game is also full of glitches. It isnt a good time to have NPC audio cut out and then be prompted to answer a question that was never asked. Maybe that kind of thing could be patched out at least. Now the controls: I played and played with the aim sensitivity and couldnt find anything that felt good. Why is it so hard when most console shooters these days get it right?

Pros: Fast paced shooting (like Doom) Great wasteland setting Music Cons: Blurry graphics (1080p, even on X1X) Weak story and cheesy characters Repetitive and generic I loved the first Rage, this one is just ok. Feels generic compared to many other current shooters this generation and many of which are better games. This one is good, not great. Wait for it to be $20.

I'm not really a UFC fan, but I do enjoys sports and fighting games, and since WWE 2K16 is still somehow still missing key wrestlers, I picked this up through my Gamer's Club discount and gift cards. This game is a lot of fun. The graphics are great, they really capture the big fight atmosphere. The roster is enormous - you can pick pretty much any fighter that's fought in UFC and isn't under contract to another company (no Brock Lesnar then, unfortunately). It's a pretty easy game to pick up and play - the striking is a ton of fun, and I enjoy the animations for big hits and takedowns. My two complaints: -For a MMA game, tapping out someone is almost impossible. Submissions are six-step process that can be pretty easily blocked at multiple points. This really needs to be simplified for future games because it breaks immersion (so many submissions happen in a flash). -I know EA Sports for 'realism,' but future games should allow openweight fights. I would have loved for my heavyweight created fighter to be able to go against Conor McGregor, for example.

If ur a UFC fan then this may be a must buy. If not then rent first and try it before u buy it. The submissions definitely take some getting used to and maybe even some retooling on EAs part to allow it to be a bit easier. But i had it for a few days and i like it.

I've been a fan of the Dead or Alive series since the Dreamcast version of DOA2 in 2000. Since then, I have seen the series have its ups and downs. I was a little hesitant when DOA6 was revealed because I wasn't a fan of part 5 in the series. I am happy to say that DOA6 is a return to the foundations that made this fighting series great, to begin with! As expected, the visuals are simply stunning for a DOA game. What I appreciate is that they added visual damage to the characters. The damage doesn't have any effect on the gameplay, it's just a nice touch. The mechanics of this fighter are tight and are welcoming to newcomers while veterans will feel right at home with the quick reflex blocking and throwing counters. I could write an entire chapter on the interworkings of the fighting mechanics but it's fun for the player to discover this for themselves. Learning to master these characters is streamlined in the training features. Don't understand how to perform a move? Simply have the game give you a tutorial, learn it and then easily return to where you left off in the previous mode. If I had any complaints, it would be with the stage designs. While some are gorgeous and are multitiered, there are others that fall flat. DOA2 and DOA4 had some of the best stage interactions in my opinion. But this complaint isn't a deal breaker by any means. The online component is good and so far, I haven't encountered lag or disadvantages. But for me, DOA6 is a couch fighter that I play with friends and guests that come over. There's a lot of excitement when played this way. At the end of the day, I think you will enjoy DOA6 for a long time to come. With a slew of fighter games being released, I think you will enjoy having this in your collection.

Hey Everyone, I wanted to finish the game before giving a review so now that I have finished it, here goes: The game is a lot of fun for the powers and combat. I like how the game gives you choices throughout the storyline. The missions are interesting at some points but I started to feel like all the battles were just fillers. I went the evil path and it was VERY easy to defeat all the bosses with the powers I leveled up. Some people online have said it is harder for the final boss if you are majorly leveled up but I found that wasnt the case. I found it was relatively easy and never even used the health/stamina/blood syringes that you can create for a boost. I was really surprised. Maybe it will be harder for a good play through? Anyways, the critics are correct that there are glitches at some points during the game and the loading screens can be ridiculous in length and bountiful. Other than that, it wasnt bad. I dont have an internet connection so I didnt download the updates/patches so my game probably was one of the few lucky vanilla versions to escape the bad glitches of freezing frames and game crashes. The conversations can get a little bit tedious as you are playing but it was interesting to hear about the characters stories. Maybe wait a little bit to buy until they fix all of the glitches the game has. Unless you get lucky like me, install the game and play offline the whole time making sure you dont connect your console to the internet until you are done playing the game.

I am enjoying progressing the story to see what unfolds in Dr. Reid's unlife. The game is a combination of dialogue driven interactions, finding collectables, and basic combat. You can opt out of some or skip to rush through most if you'd prefer. There are ways to make the game easier or harder by feeding or not, waiting longer to level up, and upgrading powers and weapons. There is one (autosave) game per playthrough, but dying means regeneration to try again (but at cost of supplies). Ultimately this seems to be a game of reasonable length that I will be playing again to try for different outcomes. I read online about 15 hour storyline but 20-30 to really explore; with replay value I think it's worth the cost.

One of the more interesting games out there in today's market. An RPG based in London about a vampire, whom, ironically is a blood specialist surgeon. The game has amazing visuals in a gritty, dark London. The game play is a little tricky to master but is loads of fun when you know the controls. Get it while you wait for other amazing releases.
The way the world changes by your actions is very interesting
An excellent vampire game that allows players to choose their paths and decide how the world around them will shape up. Each choice has a visible consequence in this game, so choose wisely.

Vampyr is a dark dramatic story of a doctor turned vampire in turn of the century London, where the player gets to choose how the story unfolds for our character. Will you keep the Hippocratic oath and try to save as many lost souls as you can or will you give in to your newfound powers and feed on the citizens of the city. The story and the characters are both well executed and unique the only flaws I see with the game are; combat is a little simplified for a game of this play-style and you are unable to fast-travel across the relatively large map. All in all good game, and anyone looking for a more story driven game where your choices carry weight and stay with you throughout the game I recommend trying this game out.

Vampyr is a tremendous achievement considering the budget developers, DONTNOD Entertainment, had to work with. The graphics I would say are a solid 7.5 with faces being more around 8.5/9. It's London and the environment portrayed in Vampyr that makes the game shine visually. The story is engaging and forces the player to make meaningful decisions that hold consequences. The dialogue with citizens within the game can begin to be too much at times, but the information and knowledge gained on them is interesting and intriguing enough that I went through full interactions with them to get the most information I could. Overall, it is a great single player story based experience that one should not pass on.
