The trailers for this game looked fantastic. The sales pitch of open world game play from beyond the grave, investigating your own murder, and seeing some spooky sites in Salem, MA. Well, here it is. The game has decent graphics, but not what you would expect from the nexgen consoles. The world is extremely small and you are blocked at nearly every turn from getting outside of the main paths. The game plays more like a story rather than an actual game. Run here, run there, press this button sequence and then watch the cut scenes. Even the 'combat' left much to be desired. No action, sneak up on a demon and press a button sequence and voila! There is absolutely no replay value to this game because it will be the same every time you play it. Same story, same sequence of events, same roaming patterns of demons, and the same lackluster finale.

I was worried when I first picked up this game because of awful reviews given on gaming websites. However, I'm a fan of ghost stories AND detective games, so I had to give it a shot when I was able to pick it up for around $30. The first thing that struck me was the atmosphere. The art style is very well designed and portrays two separate worlds, the real world and the ghost world, very well on one screen at the same time. The voice acting for the main characters is incredibly well done, although some of the random characters walking around are average. The sound in this game is surprisingly important, as often times you'll hear enemies shriek long before you ever realize they're there. The collectables are a lot of fun to hunt down and find, with many of them providing extra Ghost stories that are narrated over a still picture. They are wonderfully done, and add a lot to the world of the game. The investigations are fun, if not terribly deep, and you never really fail an investigation so you don't have to worry about starting over. The 'combat' is... a little wonky, and really is best viewed if you try it more as a puzzle than an action game. It's designed to try and sneak up on your enemies, since there's no way to directly confront them. The story is everything I hoped I'd get from a good ghost story, and is why I have enjoyed playing this game so much. The main character is #surprisingly# incredibly likable, finding information about the killer is intriguing, and the side ghost stories can be especially fun. However, a fair warning: If you're considering buying this for your young teen or child, please consider that this game is rated M for Mature for a good reason. There are acts that are described in the game or shown in cutscenes that, while not gory, can be downright disturbing, and sometimes involve children. The game isn't perfect though, and suffers from a few technical faults. The game hiccups at weird, random locations sometimes, and can make it feel a little sluggish. Other times, you'll get spotted when you think you're clearly behind a wall, only to find out you had a tiny spot of you sticking through but didn't notice because of the camera angle. Minor details for a story game, but makes it seem not as polished as it could of been. Overall, if you like games for the story, or you like a good ghost story. If you're unsure, I would highly recommend this game once it drops in price a little bit or goes on sale. Definitely have enjoyed ever minute of the game. I paid 30 and don't regret it at all.

This is my first souls game... In fact I recently just got back into gaming altogether. I was trying to get some fun games to play as a returning gamer. This one looked intriguing. So I picked up a copy and have barely touched the other half dozen or so games I bought. The other games, all great titles, and honestly lots of fun, spend most of their time gathering dust while I attempt to grind through this beast. I want to play other games, I just can't put this down. It is freaking me out. The game is beautiful and captivating from the get-go. It is designed incredibly. The level of detail and thought put into the world and systems is impressive. The combat mechanics are amazing. The music is beautiful. But wow, it can definitely be difficult, at least for me as a new player. I was not prepared for the 'prepare to die' tagline to be such an understatement. But it is totally worth playing, and it IS fair, even though sometimes it does not feel that way. At this point, I almost always know exactly why I died, what I did wrong (which can sometimes be one misstep), and what I need to try to get through the next time. I will say that the feeling of accomplishment you get when taking down a boss, or successfully getting through a tough area, is incredible. The developers and the game itself do no hand-holding. Online message boards and videos have been necessary for me at many parts, not just with difficult spots or bosses, but with the lore and character development. There is a whole 'souls' world out there, and the community is really great for the most part. Dark Souls will haunt you. It requires so much from you... patience, strategy, critical thinking, creativity, your constant attention... but the payoffs are huge. If you want a challenge, and a game that is as much a blast as it is beautiful and deadly, pick a copy up. If your new like me, just be prepared to be humbled.

So I read the reviews everywhere for this game and saw that it was challenging and it almost put me off the game completely. I'm glad I took a chance to try it myself. It is a bit challenging, but it's not too bad. Do the training missions before starting your solo play and you'll have the basics down for getting around, which is pretty much all you need when you start. If you avoid combat like the plague to begin with, you should survive long enough to make some money. The game does lack a narrative or story fir the most part, but if you're a choose-your-own-adventure type, you won't really miss it. You have the freedom to do what you want, and when you want. Lastly, the scenery and exploration are top notch. If you love space, that should be enough to sell you. Give it a chance and play something different from your typical linear FPS. I don't think you'll regret it.

First. If you are a fan of space sims where you farm tasks nearly 100% of the time then this is your game. And, this is my game! Oh my goodness this game is right up my alley. Why did I wait so long to purchase it. I have spent so many countless hours playing that I'm being to lose touch with reality! LOL. Not really, but this game has a step learning curve. Expect close to 4-5 hours of becoming basically acquainted with it before truly taking off. And make sure you do the majority of the training missions before just jumping in the game. After doing that and knowing that this genre is your cup of tea, you won't be disappointed. Elite Dangerous is an absolute gem if you're looking for a space sim game. I highly recommend it.

If you kept up with Army Of Two news after 40th day you probably found out you wouldn't be playing as Salem and Rios. To many people this was probably a turn off, me included. What is Army Of Two without Salem and Rios? You probably asked yourself. The two new characters, Alpha and Bravo, don't disappoint. They each have their own personality. They don't try to be Salem and Rios. I didn't want them to. Gameplay and tactics are essentially the same. Which is a good thing. If it ain't broke don't fix it. This installment fixed a few problems in the past two games. The actions for shoulder switching and melee have their own buttons now. When you reload you actually take out the mag and put in a fresh one. The weapon upgrade system has a new level aspect to it, plus a lot more gun color skins.So if enjoyed playing the past AoT games you'll enjoy this one.

I am back to gaming after a 10+ year absence now that my 9 year old got an Xbox for Christmas. In terms of game play, the Madden game is very similar to the Madden game from a decade ago although the internet has created some problems. We bought the disk rather than download the game but when installing the disk, it still took 6+ hours to download the game. Every time we open the game, it asks to download updated rosters. We honestly don't need real time roster updates throughout the season. There are zero instructions with the game and if there are tutorials within the game, we haven't found them yet. We haven't even downloaded the FIFA soccer game yet. The best way to do that is to start the download before going to bed because the download takes all night. I'm just used to putting in the disk and playing right away. We haven't tried any online head to head games yet. Again, no instructions or guidance on how to do that either although I've figured out that we needed to buy an Xbox gold subscription, which I did, but I still don't know what to do with it. Overall, the game is good and consistent for the past 15 years, but the platform and the instructions are wanting.

I've played through the first dead island (I'd reccomend that to anyone who wants to play this game) which I actually enjoyed. The game picks up where the first one left off where you left the island of Banoi with the same characters that escaped on the helicopter. One of the main differences with this game is the ability to do a diving attack on an emeny that is standing below you (very useful skill), also doing missions for the other surviving members from the first game is also an option. In the event if you don't feel the need to max out your stats (or what you can) on the skill tree you can work on things like shooting, two handed combat and I believe the third was defensive skills/survival. The game does have it's issues, for example when the characters talk, their lips don't quite match up as well as some of the close up cutscenes seem block like or a game that was made in the early stages of the ps3. Other than that it's a very solid game to follow up the first one, and the ending clearly leads up to a third dead island. I'm not a big fan of the star system, but 4/5 stars seems like a good rating (7/10).

I didn't get the chance to play the first game so I won't be able to compare the two or say about the improvements since the first. The story was mediocre and some of the NPCs were kinda annoying and have no personality, so there was no reason to care for them at all. The loots were great and kept me coming back to look for more but it was very frustrating when your items disappear from time to time. I didn't like the checkpoint save system cause it's an RPG you should be able to save whenever you want and whenever you quit then come back to play again you'll be respawned at the place where you took the main quest, very annoying. I liked the coop system, it was smooth and fun playing with friends and strangers. The game was kinda easy with no real challenge at all and every time you die you'll respawn at a near location and the only penalty is cash, and the exploits in the continuous quests made the game really easy also since you can buy it. Bosses were too easy in Dead Zones you can just throw molotovs/grenade or shoot them at a distance and they won't attack you. The AIs were useless during defending points and you'll have to do all the heavy lifting 90% at a time. The main point of this game is killing zombies and they achieved it. I enjoyed the game but there was some bugs and some glitches along the way that hinders the experience but overall it was a great game. 7.8/10
I purchased this game for my son for hi 12th birthday and he loved it!

A lot of people seem to either love the DI series or hate it. You either enjoy certain aspects of it like trying to remain undetected and modifying your weapons, or you are upset that its not a game where you go around lobbing an unlimited supply of bombs to take out 100 zombies every 3 seconds. I am in the former category. I will say that DI has had its share of glitches can be infuriating, but DI:R seemed to address them pretty well.

I bought this for my son for Christmas, it's the one he asked for! He Loves it! I would not recommend for a young child. There is language, gore and 'adult conversations/actions'. He's happy, so I'm happy.
Got the game for my son and it freezes. Too late 2 return

If you've already played the first Dead Island, you'll find nothing new here, save for a few creatures, boats, and some woman who won't shut up about canned food. ('Canned food is all we have here!') Everything else about this sequel is exactly - I do mean EXACTLY - like the first one. Even the setting is essentially the same - well, it feels the same. Still, I bought this game because I enjoyed the first one so much that I didn't think I'd mind playing it again. What I hadn't counted on is that all of the first game's weaknesses make this one just plain tedious. The writing - especially in the cutscenes and at the beginning of missions - serves no purpose other than to set up the missions, which half the time is moving stuff around. You'll give it a try, and then stop caring. Play this if you're working your way through the survival genre so you can scratch it off your list. Otherwise, put this title down and reach for The Last of Us - it's everything this game isn't. P.S. Don't let the trailers fool you! Most of the scenes are from cutscenes, not actual gameplay.

Overall this sequel is a great one to the original Dead Island. Get to play as one of four characters each with a different ending. Graphics are good. Obviously lots of blood and gore, but it is typically for this type of game. The game is very 'fetch quest' heavy which I don't mind.
This game is better than the first which was amazing. The storyline is awesome. Its a must have if you played the first one.
May not be as good as the original but there is plenty going on to make this game interesting and entertaining .
Good co-op game. Nothing wrong with killing zombies, pretty good graphics, need a better tutorial

Overall the game is fun especially with others.. tory is average and so is the graphics, tho the gameplay makes up for it with weapon upgrades and hard co-op zombie bashing fun..

The PS3 version of this awesome game is stripped down to the bones from its next gen version. Just look up any video comparing footage from this version to the PS4 version and you'll see it immediately. The rough dirt trail looks like paper and the stone walls look like cardboard walls. Pausing is seamless going back in the game of the PS4 version but you have to wait forever in this version. Would I recommend this game? Yes. But only on PS4.

This game is fantastic. Just great gameplay, especially the combat, super addictive. The Uruk Hierarchy system is really neat as well, getting to know each orc that you hunt adds a lot of satisfaction to the slaying of them, especially when that orc has been labeled your 'Nemesis' as a result of multiple stand-offs. The story is somewhat interesting, but you'll find your self ignoring it much of the time. The game is really short if you just play through the story, and the ending is so abrupt that it's painful, and there really isn't a final boss at all, just the hammering of a single button for ten seconds, then a cutscene, then the game is over. Ka-pow. The game is great though despite those things, and I highly recommend it, BUT I do NOT recommend you play this game on PS3 or Xbox 360. If you do, just know in advance that the game will be glitchy, glitchy, glitchy. Not all the time, mind you, but certainly glitchy enough to get in the way of your having fun. It might take 20 seconds to load the pause screen at times, the cutscenes before 'Uruk Duels' look like your old VeggieTales VHSs on fast-forward and sometimes the game will just run painfully slow and the sound will cut in and out, as if you were trying to play Titanfall on Windows 98. They just didn't put much work into the 'Last-Gen' ports at all, it seems. Maybe it'll get patched, I don't know (Really, I have no idea if patches could fix it or not. Not a techy at all.), but if I were you I wouldn't bother getting it on PS3 or Xbox 360, if you're planning to upgrade soon.

If you plan on buying the game, get either the ps4 or x box one edition. Lagy graphics and lots of loading time. I have played the x box one edition and the transition from menu screen to game play only takes seconds, the graphics take forever to load and they look like paper mach.

I was excited for this title, considering how unique the concept was: dungeon crawling, looting, dictating a market around the loot you found and selling said loot. However, I found both systems - the combat and the shop - to be shallow and repetitive. I wasn't expecting anything particularly deep in either category, but dungeoneering is barebones and simplistic, with repeating enemies and weak bosses. Selling your loot, the standout feature of the game, becomes a tedious chore as there is no outstanding punishment for pricing your goods too high or low. You simply adjust the prices until you find a sweet spot, rinse wash repeat. Again, I wasn't expecting overly complex systems, but the shallowness was too grindy and mundane to keep me interested.
GREAT GAME TO ADD TO MY COLLECTION OF SEALED GAMES

I bought this on a whim, looking for a new roguelike I could play in short bursts. It has a distinctly Zelda vibe in visuals, plays like Binding of Isaac, and has some fun Rune Factory-esque life simulation segments. You alternate diving through dungeons by night to stock your shop and by day openinging your doors and gauging customer reaction to maximize profit. Along the way you invest in your town, bringing in new merchants from a smith, enchanter, and a few others to improve your chances at progressing the dungeons. This is a great game for any fan of action/roguelikes/life sims and a very welcome addition to the Switch library.

Can't beat the price.

The Good: Deus Ex Mankind Divided is a very good game that has excellent storytelling and characters. The gameplay is relatively smooth, except for the occasional drop in framerates when running around the multiple locations. I feel the levels are well designed and give the player a multitude of options when completing objectives. I found myself constantly exploring and more often than not being rewarded for that curiosity. The Catch: The story ends very abruptly. It feels as if the story was intentionally left open to later be addressed in DLCs. My advice to game companies would be to release complete stories in the core game and introduce 'NEW' stories in DLC. I hate being left on the hook with plot-lines on TV Shows and movies and I hate it even more in $60 video games.

Deus Ex: Mankind Divided represents what I feel is sometimes a lost art in games today: A compelling story, an immersive world, and a sense of ownership over who you play as. DX:MD stays true to the franchise. If you like the semi-open world, multiple path approach to the previous DX titles, you won't be disappointed. The game has something for everyone whether you prefer combat and weapons upgrades, or stealth and world exploration. That said, like other similar titles, you need to be willing to invest into the game. If you don't have a ton of patience, or just want a pick-up-and play experience (while the game does offer an arcade mode for this), you might find this title is not for you. It certainly is a game for the hardcore gamer. The only knock against it is that some of the animations and voice acting can be rough around the edges at times, but is easily forgivable as you get to explore what is quite a thought-provoking story and believeable environment.

Deus Ex: Mankind Divided is the fourth main installment ('main' meaning I'm not including the mobile spinoffs) in the Deus Ex video game series. Your enjoyment of this game will probably depend largely on your enjoyment of the prior games in the series, specifically Deus Ex: Human Revolution from 2011, given that DXMD is a direct sequel to DXHR, taking place a mere two years after the events of DXHR. Much like its predecessor, DXMD has you in the role of Adam Jensen, a human who has, without his consent, been upgraded with experimental mechanical augmentations. Following the fallout of DXHR, mechanically augmented humans are being cast out of society and discriminated against by natural humans. Adam's goal is to expose the conspiracy of the Illuminati, who have orchestrated the events of DXHR and DXMD from the shadows. To accomplish this, Adam has access to a wide variety of augmentations that allow you to modify your play style. You can choose to upgrade your weapon proficiency and defensive capabilities if you're looking to play the game as a first person shooter and go head on with enemy combatants. You can choose to upgrade your hacking abilities to change the environments in your favor and against the enemies. You can choose to upgrade your stealth capabilities to completely disappear from sight and never engage your enemies at all. You can also mix and match any of the above to discover your own preferred play-style. The keyword there was obviously 'choice.' That's what the DX games have always been, or at least tried to be, about. DXMD is a worthy follow-up to DXHR and would easily recommend it to a fan of the DX series. Non-fans may want to watch some videos of various playstyles to get a feel for whether or not they'll enjoy it.
I bought the last 1 and couldnt put it down beat it 10x and find something new each time wish this 1 was like that. i sold it but was such a fan i bought again smh couldnt stay away

This game was one that I had heard many good things about so I decided to give it a try. One thing that I am not a fan of is first person shooter games. This game is a pseudo-hybrid as it has elements of first-person and also third-person views. I mention this because I might have stayed away if I knew it was going to be first-person shooter-ish. That being said, the game is very good. The graphics are good, the game play is challenging and there are a variety of ways to complete many of the missions. The power ups for weapons are pretty decent too. The game reminds me of a cross between Metal Gear and Bioshock. The negatives are few but must be mentioned. The voice acting is ok for the most part but the lead character is very bland and since he has so much to say it can get annoying listening to him speak. I also noticed some issues with the sound track cutting out during some scenes with dialog. Also the sound track was pretty uninteresting so don't look for anything special here. Many have said the story wasn't as good as the previous game was. I think the story is good as far as stories go for video games. There are branching paths as well so your experience may vary from someone else. Since I haven't played the last game I can't offer a comparison but I can say that this story has some meat to it. All in all this is a great game with some replay value as you may want to try playing through a different way for a different outcome. I think the game will take roughly 15-20 hours to complete depending on you level of experience with these types of games.

I was very excited for this game to come out after playing the first one in the series, Human Revolution, a few years back on PS3. This one did not disappoint with the feeling of being able to go through the game however I felt like it (stealth, action, dialogue) in order to complete each part of the game. My only real complaint is that the story of the game. It felt rushed with many holes that I do not feel are answered as you complete the game. The side missions are great, and are very in depth for being so few of them. Also the only real boss fight you can encounter is the final piece of the game, and when it gets to that high, the game ends, which was a bummer, but the ride there was amazing,

Never played the first Dead Island but I've had this one on preorder since last year when the steelbook cases were in stores. Always been a fan of the zombie genre and I figured this was a great place to start with the games. Anyone picking up this game and not the first will feel a little lost at the beginning but the story is good enough to stick on its own and not leave you scratching your head. Some of the quests can be a little repetitive at times, but once you get to the point where you have guns; everything is right in the world. Nothing quite beats that feeling when you put a sniper into the face of a boss mob and blow it's head off in a single earth-shattering blast. It's even better when a single shot takes out a group of zombies. Grenades are great as long as you don't blow yourself up, too. Riptide looks amazing as well. I felt the graphics were on par with Halo 4 and other titles. Didn't mind standing on the top of a building or tree house and just looking at everything around. Slightly long loading times were a tad annoying. And my only complaint is the multiplayer system. Both players should have to confirm that they want to join together rather than one person just deciding to join someone at random. Would find myself in a party without even knowing it. Also, when someone joins a party, almost all of the zombies in the area respawn which can nearly get you nuked if they're right on top of you. I spent 42 hours on the first playthrough and only got 71% completion. Going to have to go back as the other characters and try for the rest. So many sidequests and stuff to do!

If you liked the original Dead Island, you will like Riptide. Just like the original, it is not perfect. Even though it seems smoother than its predecessor, It suffers occasional lag and is not as refined graphically, or control wise as Borderlands, Bioshock, and other AAA releases. The missions can be a bit repetitive, and the side missions are mostly what the magazines refer to as 'fetch quests.' In spite of its obvious flaws though, Riptide is a B-Movie, zombie slaying blast. Creating weapons, upgrading them, leveling your character and choosing which skills to level up is incredibly addicting. The fact that its $10 less then a typical new release is just bonus. BB giving the $20 RZ certificate with preorder is an even bigger bonus! Fun game. If you liked the original, continue the fun with Riptide!

This game has its moments, but in the end I enjoyed the first much more. But killing zombies always makes for a fun time. My main gripe with this game is you do fetch quests after fetch quests all the time. It would have been nice if they could have done more creative missions.

I loved Dead Island. I have played it 5 times front to back. I per-ordered the game, and even with the special BBQ weapon, I have lost it with two different player just because I hit the wrong button and dropped it, and was unable to recover it. You do not have a choice at what level you want to play the game, so you better know what you are doing. The plus side of it you get to go up to level 70 where it was level 60 in Dead Island. You can also import your player from Dead Island and start out at level 60.

this game is getting a lot of hate online from contra fans. i been playing contra since the original so i like to think i'm more than qualified to judge contra games. first lets get one thing out of the way, the graphics. this has been the main point of contention among fans of contra. yes, the graphics kinda suck. this game looks like an early ps2 game. Neo Contra looks a lot better than this game. if you're going to pass on this game based on poor graphics alone, you're doing yourself and this franchise a disservice. if you can get pass the 'bad' graphics, which imo isn't THAT bad, the game is very fun to play. after all, contra is all about the gameplay, not how pretty it looks. i been playing this game for hours and i have been enjoying it so far. the only thing i don't like is that your weapons will overheat so you need to be careful not to overuse your weapons. there are upgrades you can buy to reduce the cool down time. imo, contra is a game about Run and Gun and i don't know why your weapons need to overheat. besides this, the gameplay is very fun. it's good for people who want a quick pick up and game type game. it won't waste your time and you will get right into the action, which i prefer. story is weak but c'mon, this is contra, in contra games, story takes a backseat to the gameplay. this game plays very similar to Neo Contra. you control your character w/the left stick and aim with the right stick. this type of game is commoning called 'twin stick shooters,' similar to games like Smash TV or Robotron. another thing i like to mention is the awesome case art. i love the cover art for this game. not too bad for Konami. on the reverse side of the cover is another great art work. most other switch games would be blank but konami decided to put great art work on every inch of real estate. cool stuff. great for collecting. is this the best contra game? no. imo if you want great contra games go play the original contra games on the NES, play Alien Wars on the SNES, then go play Shattered Soldier and Neo Contra on the ps2. is this game worth $40, imo yes. my shoes that i'm wearing right now that i bought from payless shoes cost more than this game. $40 isn't much. go buy this game! it's fun, nevermind the ps2 graphics, the gameplay is fun. if you want konami to make more contra games then buy this game.

As a Contra fan, I was excited about playing it in Nintendo Switch. Game is great if you focus only on shooting, improving your character, and reviving your childhood memories. However, graphics are not that good as expected for a 2019 video game technology. If you don't care about graphics quality, game is awesome.

Yes this game does have inferior graphics regardless of what platform and somewhat resembles a mobil game. And no it is not a side scrolling run and gun like we all know and love of the Contra franchise. But all of that aside, the cut scenes and story is unique with continuity to Alien Wars, the characters are interesting and the gameplay is actually fun. I will admit the platforming in the game is a little problematic at times but not broken. If you see and play the game for what it is without preconceived visions of what this Contra game SHOULD be in your minds and keep an open mind I think this is a great video game. Give it a try if it goes on sale below the retail price of $39,99 Or better yet download the demo on your respective platforms and try it out first like I did. I think you may enjoy it.
Not as bad as people are saying. Has been patched. Much better now..

The Contra games have been among my very favorites since the 1987 original. I knew that Rogue Corps looked very different from most of the previous games in the series, but being Contra, I still crossed my fingers and hoped for an enjoyable experience. Unfortunately, even after playing for a couple of hours, it's hard to get past 1) how slow the action seems to be, and 2) how frankly ugly the whole affair looks. The graphics don't even look HD. They're like something out of the PS2 era. The game starts promisingly with a comic book-style opening cinematic that looks great and is entertainingly presented, but it all goes downhill from there. The biggest hinderance to the gameplay is that your weapons have cooldowns, which is an entirely new and equally unwelcome addition to the series. Contra is about fast and ferocious running and gunning, and you shouldn't have to pause so your gun can cool down while you're being swarmed by enemies, especially when your secondary weapon overheats just as quickly. There are a number of character and weapon mods that can be purchased which will presumably lessen the pain of this misguided creative decision, but the modding system is almost impenetrably incomprehensible. At its very core, Rogue Corps can offer some brief bursts of action enjoyment. But it doesn't take long before you find yourself just wanting to play something else. A disappointing misstep for an iconic action series. At least it wasn't released for the standard full MSRP of most new games.

First off the frame rate seems to be off, when there is heavy action onscreen there appears to be slow down and clipping on the characters. Second the upgrade system is a bit confusing, although I've just gotten to where I can expand on some skills, but there's so many options it's easy to get lost. Other than that I love the gameplay, simple run and gun that can be played couch coop or online. Can't speak to the online portion as I've yet to try. Shaq-Fu: A Legend Reborn review (2018, T) I had heard of this game, and I was intrigued, but not enough to pony-up the cash for it. I was familiar with the infamous reputation of its 16-bit predecessor, but I had never personally had the displeasure. When this sale-dropped to $5, I figured it was worth at least that much. Honestly, I found the game to be rather ok, but maybe thats because my expectations and monetary investment were so low. The game is not a fighter like the original, but a mediocre arcade-style beat-em-up. Shaq just beats on the dozens of cookie-cutter enemies that flood the screen. Strategy or technique are not necessary; its pure button-mashing simplicity, and I can oddly respect that. Its as monotonous as one would expect, but not to the point where I was annoyed at it, but it did get close at times. There are health and energy orbs aplenty, as well as power-ups that make you and even bigger curb-stomper than before, so there really isnt a reason to ever die or even get close to death. Its not even that long; a 100% playthrough with all achievements plus the DLC should take less than a few hours. The graphics and art style are simple and cel-shaded, nothing special or memorable. The story, setting, and characters is where this games meager enjoyment get the most mileage, at least for me. I can understand why lots of people would find this games humor sophomoric and even stereotypically offensive, but I am an immature man-child so it worked for me. As you should expect from Shaq, the product placement is belligerent and numerous. I chuckled at the absurdity and shamelessness of the actual real-world products being used and referenced. The extras text and game dialogue did have a lot of funny, tongue-in-cheek moments that I felt worked for what they were trying to do. The plot is practically non-existent, but funny enough. An orphaned Shaq grows up as any normal Chinese master of kung-fu would, and now he must save the world from evil demons disguised as thinly-veiled parodied celebrities. So if you ever wanted to deck the lights out of expies of the likes of Justin Bieber or Donald Trump, youll at least get a kick out of that. The physical disc-only DLC swaps Shaq out for (no joke) Barack Dirty Barry Obama, who takes up the quest to finish off Kanye West. Its like a mad-lib found inside a fortune cookie. All in all, its by no means a great or even a good game. Its barely passable, and certainly not a notch in the belt of crowdfunded games. But what I can say is this: I paid only $5 for it, and I felt I at least got my moneys worth out of it. Any more than that, and this is just another miss like all those free-throws.
Shaq Fu is a fun beat em up style game. I think this game gets a bad rap because of its older counterpart. Had a lot of fun and great for a budget title.

The skating is probably worse than ever, and online play is all but dead a month in. For a hockey fanatic, it's likely going to be the standard regardless, but EA again proves its need for competition. Online play is further away from realistic looking hockey than ever (pokechecks extremely overpowered, lack in variety of scoring), and the same bugs (loops, glitches) and annoyances (slow menus, lack of attention to fine details) that have plagued the series for a decade return in force. Threes is an enjoyable edition, and franchise mode took a slight step forward, but the NHL series still remains well behind all other sports games on the market in quality.

You can also play HUT with a friend online too which is a fantastic addition.

I am an avid gamer, so I'm used to a few bugs here and there, but the PS4 version of this game is astoundingly awful. I am not even 1/3 of the way through the game and I can no longer progress - it tells me to do things that I've already done and have in my inventory. It tells me to talk to people and then the game won't allow an interaction. It says to put on certain clothes, I do, and the game doesn't recognize the new clothing and won't let me move on. I didn't read enough about this game when I ordered it. All I saw was 500 games and I thought it had 500 games on it. It doesn't and when I actually read the cover, I exchanged it for a different game....it just wasn't what I was looking for.

The Crew 2 is fun but not like the first. In Crew 1 the story allowed the adventure to travel across the USA. Where as crew2 focuses on racing. There is no need to explore the USA because all races are accessible in menu. This is a little disappointing. The races are hard but fun. Frustrating when you can be 6 seconds ahead of the pack at one check point and get passed at the next check point. The mechanic of changing from car to plane or boat is cool and graphics are better, but crew2 uses the same map as crew1. This full price game is merely a DLC.
I like the story better on this that on the first one. The boats, planes, etc is an awesome added touch and the game plays really well.

This is the type of game that puts development studios out of business. I could not find one ounce of fun in this game so I uninstalled it. I regret purchasing it. I really enjoyed the first Crew game so maybe my expectations were too high. This game fails on every level. In regards to game play, the physics are a disaster. I don't care about graphics if the game is fun. This game is far from fun and the graphics are not on par with modern games. Although the graphics are better than the first Crew game, at least that game was fun. Everything about The Crew 2 is lifeless. I can find something positive in almost all games I play but there is nothing positive I can say about The Crew 2. I don't recommend this game to anyone who enjoys racing games.
I understand its a arcade racing game but the car physics and handling is trash. You will grip around one turn then zero on the next.
Love this game, still trying to figure out all the moves!! This is so fun!

This is a great addition to the Street Fighter collection. What's nice about it is it stays true to Street Fighter roots while adding some pretty interesting additions. I like that SF has stayed along the classic 2D style of gameplay, it's always been preferred for me over 3D fighting games. However, they did add some 3D elements that are mostly animations that add some cool visual effect to the game. The directional pad can be frustrating to use until you adapt to it, depending on your experience with the Xbox 360 controller and fighting games. Using characters that require charging back or down for 2 seconds for special moves can prove difficult depending on your skill level. The new focus special moves and super special moves (can't remember what they're called) are cool editions, but if you're playing someone who is well accustomed to using them and you aren't, you're done for. If you like to play against the computer, and you play on the hardest level be prepared to be dominated by combinations of super attacks and focus attacks. It is labeled 'Hardest' for a reason though, so no complaints here. The only problem I have with the game is the Xbox Live portion, which was actually the portion I was most excited about. Finding a match against someone with a good connection can be a pain, and sometimes the lag is so bad it will take a full second for the game to render a command. Also, when you search for potential opponents, the game brings up three choices, and all three of those people might be in a game already. Why format the search this way? There should have been a search filter that searched for the optimal connection speeds and only displayed those hosts that weren't already engaged in a game with someone else. I've spent up to five minutes just searching for someone to play with on Xbox Live...very frustrating. If you have a friend who also owns the game, it is relatively easy to connect to that friend via an Invite to Game request. Despite the multiplayer downfalls, the game is extremely fun if you're a fan of the series. I think some of the new characters are kind of dumb, and I'll never play as them, but they're still fun to play against. If you're a fan of Street Fighter, you'll be a fan of SFIV.

This is an amazing game. I picked it up for $30 at bestbuy and could barely put it down. The difficulty settings can be switched around so you can make it as hard as you want, the controls are just as simple as they have always been and they didn't make the mistake that other fighting games like Mortal Kombat have done by making the environment 3-D. This is a game that you can play over and over with friends and the best part about it is that you don't need a fistful of quarters to play it anymore.

Street Fighter 4 marks the 20th anniversary of the franchise and does it in a big way. The game includes the traditional Arcade mode where you fight your way through 7-8 stages unlocking the story for each character. Difficulty ranges from Easiest which is ideal for players new to the franchise or fighting games to Hardest for veteran players who need a challenge. A big part of Street Fighter 4 is the Versus mode which includes local if you have friends over and Online if you feel like challenging someone around the world either for fun or a ranked match. Challenge mode makes an appearance offering three different modes time attack, survival, and trial. Trial is unique because it will show new players how to play the game by making you perform all the moves of a character of your choice in order to proceed. Later levels of trial will teach you how to string combos together. Gameplay consists of three different punches (L,M,H) and three different kicks (L,M,H). By imputing different directs and pressing the correct punch or kick you can perform special moves as well as finishers. Moves execute flawlessly without any lag. All 25 of the characters available are evenly balanced so you never feel like you are at a disadvantage if you choose one character over another. The only problem with the gameplay is the Xbox 360 controller itself. The D-pad is very unresponsive when doing some moves so using the analog stick will be something you may have to get used to. Street Fighter 4 is a very easy game to pick up. However, if you are just starting to play you should stay away from the online until you have a general understanding of the moves and can perform them when needed. That doesn't mean that if you are new to the game that you should never play online. Street Fighter 4 takes a minute to pick up but a long time to master. Collectibles are what will keep you wanting to play more and more. There hundreds of Icons and titles to unlock by playing vs mode as well as different colors for each character, personal taunts for each character, concept art and anime movies from each characters story. Overall, I was very satisfied with my purchase. I had never played a Street Fighter in my life but this game makes it possible for someone new to be able to compete with the veteran players because of how simple the fighting system is to pick up yet it holds so much depth. Both 'casual' and 'hardcore' gamers can enjoy this game. If you are looking for a good fighting game; look no further. If you are looking for a good game to play with friends; look no further. If you are looking for a game that will entertain you for a long time; look no further. Street Fighter 4 is THE best fighter out this generation of gaming.
My 7 year old son loves this game. I've been looking for a fighting game he could play. This holds his interest longer than most of the other games

Ignore the first review, its useless and not accurate at 'ALL'. Sorry but thats my opinion. This game is NOOB friendly on controls and most moves come out smoother than most of the previous SF incarnations. The cartoon graphics are cool IMO and I love the revenge & focus features. My only complaint about this game is no tournament mode. I hope they add it as DLC later or in the sequel. Also I think they should find a way to incorporate spectator mode with tournament ala Gears of War when you're watching a team-mate play once you've died/eliminated from tourney. Just a suggestion.

One of these reviews is obviously a troll. This game was not made to coicide with the movie. The movie was made to concide with the game. This gameplay brings back the concepts from Street Fighter 2 with a dash of Street Fighter 3. The moves have not changed for the iconic characters. The game is gorgeous and fluid. It runs at 60FPS. This game will probaley bring back the fighters for a new age of online competetion. Jump into the fighting circuit if your new or if your an old timer come in and start to learn a new system.

I was born on street fighter, played it on my super nintendo when it first came out. It was the thing me and my brother always played because it was challenging and just plain fun. When I heard this new version was coming up, I was ecstatic and having been waiting so long for it to finally arive. My hopes were high for a good reason, because Capcom delivers. Go buy it now!!!!

Everything is amazing and fun to play no matter what, and I love beating scrubs online. To those scrubs who think the game's terrible and reviewed it down, good job, just because the game's too hard or you're too much of crybabies to play a real game, then don't review it and call it trash. Go back to your call of noobie and your WoW because this game is def not for you.

I can't say that i have played it yet but for what i have seen its a must buy. the character models look funny but im not complaining; it grew on me. unlike other games they made the characters pretty even in power witch i love. if anyone has played Soul Calibur 4 at all they know who im talking about (Kilik). the only problem i saw was a tournament video on gamspot where everyone used Zangief and spammed the Pile driver over and over. i guessed not much has changed sense SF2. oh well though, its still looks like a great buy for all people who love the fighting genre.

I'm grew up with the arcade street fighters and looked forward to this as a present. Out the box the game was fun UNTIL i reached Seth. On the normal setting dude is rediculously cheap, constantly grabbing and teleporting, this does not change when you lower the difficulty setting to EASIEST. The final boss is needlessly difficult. That's a turn off about this game. I probably would not recommend this game to anyone and I'm trading it in for Modern Warefare 2, atleast with that game teh difficulty is realistic!!!

I got the privelidge to play street fighter 4 at comic con this year and it has to be the most antisipated game this year. Although i had to wait in line for2 hours to play it, it was well worth it. Didnt get a chance to play with any of the new characters but from what i saw while i was waiting in line, they are all pretty sweet. I can't believe how much hype the new Street Fighter IV has been getting. After getting my thrills from Soulcalibur IV, MK vs DC, and Virtua Fighter, playing the new Street Fighter IV was like going BACKWARDS in video game evolution! My little cousins who I tried to get to play with me were wondering if I pulled out the old Super Nintendo to play this game and I had to convince them that this was a 'brand new game for the Xbox 360'. The combo and ultra systems are very confusing. Even using old favorites such as Ken and Ryu was just disappointing. For a 2D game, it's okay overall. But this is the 21st century and video game fighters have evolved a LOT since the 90s. Even Mortal Kombat has stepped it up a notch (even though their main lure was the gore which was incredibly toned down with their latest release). I wanted to return my SFIV game after trying to tolerate learning it for a few days. I've had it. This game made my Mortal Kombat vs DC game look like the game of the year. If you're a die hard Street Fighter fan, this game is for you. But a game that hangs on to mainly combos and counters? No finishers? Annoying announcer voice? A one word description of all this is: DISAPPOINTING.
Game is to fake and way to hard. Opponents use crazy combos even while getting hit. GAME SUCKS and graphics are awful.

I don't know what the big deal is. It's a SF game. It was out a long time ago and they're bringing it back. It's a personal opinion, of course, but I don't see what everyone is getting all excited about. I plan to save my $65 and spend it on a much better and def more anticipated game than this joke.

Ace Combat 7 is an excellent entry into the series. It is a massive improvement over the last entry, Assault Horizon. I like how there is more to unlocking aircraft and upgrades through the Aircraft Tree. The weather effects and terrain features are so realistic that you feel like your actually flying in the plane. It's a little more stripped down so far, after 3 missions, it looks like they took out the command feature, which didn't really work well, and having multiple operations which you had to choose 2 or 3 to complete the mission. Like previous Ace Combat games is more of an arcade game and it is not realistic in the number of weapons your plane carries. It's more of an arcade flight game. Overall I would recommend this game to fans of previous Ace Combat games or anyone looking for a great arcade flight combat game.
I love combat air games and this one an enjoyable one if you have a ps4 try the vr version, a nice experience.

I purchased the game due to the preorder bonus of Ace Combat 6: Fires of Liberation. I never got to play it since it was an Xbox exclusive. I remember playing the Ace Combat series on my PS2 back in the day. It's partly simulation and arcade like gameplay. It's not complicated in the controls and gameplay. If you've played any of the Ace Combat games in the series and enjoyed it, then you will probably enjoy this as well. The game looks great on the Xbox One X. For the most part, the game feels and runs smoothly. I don't really play the game for the story, but mostly for the feel of flying a jet aircraft in combat. There were some issues with the pre-order bonuses when the game first released, but it was solved the following days after posting on the Best Buy forums.

I've been a fan of combat flight simulators since Chuck Yeager's Air Combat in the early 1990s, and Ace Combat 7 definitely thrilled me like a kid again. The graphics are some of the most stunning I've seen on an XBox One, and the sound design is incredible - I love the pilot chatter and effects. Gameplay is great too - each plane has a unique feel.

Good story line that continues with the series. Easy to learn controls, fun to play. Rated teen for a little language and mild violence but I allow my 10 year old to play and he likes the challenge and is able to complete missions. He is currently outranking my fianc.

It you liked WD1 you will like this game as well. They mad a lot of improvements to the single player game but completely failed on the seamless multiplayer. A lot of the same abilities from the last game with a bunch of new one. You are able to control an RC car and fly a drone to assist you in missions, profile from the air and solve puzzles. Hacking puzzles are now open world instead of on terminal server. The game relies to much on the drone to complete missions. If you try to go in anywhere guns blazing you will die. Multiplayer is / was broken they are patching the game (2 patches have released so far). Hard to connect to multiplayer games...must restart system / load another game to dump the memory to connect online (could be fixed by now). High memory usage, lags out the system. Cortana is unresponsive (only when this game is running). Connecting to a party chat will kick people and force a new party to be started. T-Bone should have been the main character :)
Story is great, but the combat and gameplay is where the game shines. Collect different FF monsters and then use them in battle similar to Pokmon.
My daughter Loved it. All of my kids have enjoyed Kingdom Hearts and while in the store this caught my eye for my almost 10 year olds new XBox S.

This game has all things Deadpool. It was the funniest game experience I have ever had. It was an action game of epic proportions. If your looking for a thought provoking RPG look elsewhere. This is the return of truly entertaining hack and slash, run and gun, awesomeness. You can upgrade everything from stats to weapons and the challenge modes leave you something to do after the 6-7 hour campaign. If you beat it in 4 hours you played on easy and skipped all the Easter eggs. This game was made for true fans of The Merc With The Mouth!!!!

This game cannot be compared to games like 'The Last of Us' or 'Batman: Arkham City' as it is not as technical or in-depth as games like that BUT if you are a fan of Deadpool then this game is a must have. This is the funniest game I have ever played. No game before this one has ever had me actually laughing to the point of tears. The action can be a bit repetitive at times but that does not mean the game is not fun. There are some wonderful animations that go with his combos and when you perform his momentum moves. Silent kills can be performed in certain areas and each weapon has 2 different silent kill animations. Each weapon also has numerous upgrades available. The writer of the game, Daniel Way, also a writer for the Deadpool comics, totally nails the character again for this game. Combined with the voice genius of Nolan North, Deadpool is never at a loss of words when fighting a group of villains or making anatomy size jokes while standing at a urinal. This game is meant to just pick up the controller, mash some buttons, and decapitate and maim endless waves of enemies. I believe it was Activision and High Moon Studios' goal to create a simplistic but extremely fun game that is not taken too serious due to that is not in the character's nature and for that I believe they have succeeded. Deadpool is the Three Stooges of the Marvel Universe and this game does a perfect job of capturing him and all his crazy 4th wall breaking hijinks. 4 out of 5 stars easy!

I was really excited for this game to come out on Xbox 360. However, after playing it, I'm a lil disappointed. While Deadpool's inner and outer dialogue with his multiple personalities as well as other characters in the game is nothing short of comedic genius, the storyline, or lack thereof, is slightly disheartening. Also, from level to level, it starts to feel fairly repetitive. The graphics, audio and gameplay is pretty good for the most part. The witty banter, the use of other characters from the Marvel Universe and the leveling up system are enough to keep you playing...BUT...I do find myself (often) wishing for better and more diverse levels. They're far too linear to call 'Deadpool' a 'great' game. Another aspect I find bothersome are the enemies. It feels like they go straight from being a normal, fair difficulty to being far too difficult fit where you are, and what you have to use in the game. All in all, of you're a Comic fan or a Deadpool fan specifically, you can find a decent amount of entertainment in the game, but don't expect anything epic. I would recommend either renting it first or waiting for a price drop.
THIS GAME IS HILARIOUS TO PLAY... LOADS OF FUNNY COMMENTS... GREAT GAME PLAY!!!
Deadpool - Xbox 360 great love it crazy fun must have
Awesome game alot of action good price not expensive

The game is as rude as it is funny as you would expect from one of the rudest yet comical marvel characters. If the crude potty mouth humor is not your gig, Deadpool may win you over because he is hilarious. Coupled with sick action and decent story you have a pretty solid game but definitely not for children as the rating indicates. Kids are sponges people...

I thought this was the best game I've ever purchased, Not only was it because it was a marvel game but also because it was deadpool and there was so much comedy in it unlike any marvel game. I would highly recommend it to any marvel fans.

I love the character of Deadpool. He's fascinating, insane, and funny, and the developers found a really great balance for his persona, and it actually translates really well to the video game. Gameplay is kind of clunky at first, but it's easy to get the hang of it once you get going. For any fan of Marvel characters, this game is for you.

I love the game. It's funnier than all heck and Nolan North is a scream throughout the whole game. The developers really captured Deadpool's insanity and then some. The game has me howling with laughter and my favorite part ever in the game is the part after Deadpool flies the jet, crashes it, and tries to wake up Wolverine by slapping him across the face over and over and over and over again. What I don't like about the game, however, are the graphics and a lack of good battle dialogue. But I'll gladly see past that to play the game itself. I love the game and if I would rate the game a lot more than 5 stars if I could.
I know its deadpool and thats his thing but he is over the top obnoxious in this game. I got this for Christmas, played for about 2 hours and havent put it back in since.

This is a great game for a focus on Deadpool. It's funny and there are upgradeable options however it at times can become very repetitive. It's a great quick play through but I wouldn't pay fully price for it that's for sure.

Any fans of Deadpool would do themselves a great disservice by not purchasing and playing this game. I'm a Deadpool novice and still had a blast playing through the entire single player campaign. Previous history or familiarity with Deadpool is thankfully NOT required. The dialogue can get pretty blue and juvenile at times, but Nolan North's delivery had me laughing throughout the game. Controls are tight and responsive and the upgrade system based on DP (Deadpool Points) is rewarding and adds multiple layers of gameplay. My only complaints are in regards to the camera breaking when boxed into a corner. Lack of enemy variety and a severe difficulty spike on the last level where everything is thrown at you - including the kitchen sink. That being said, I still had loads of fun with Deapool.
It's a sold game. One of the best comic based games I've played. It does well to represent how he is in the comics. But is definitely meant for adults.

Bought this game after watching a video of someone getting some of the Achievements for it. At first I was a little hesitant about getting it because I knew barely anything about Deadpool. Thankfully you don't have to in order to enjoy the game. As the title suggests, the game is about Deadpool a mutate mercenary for higher from the Marvel Comics universe and a character that is constantly breaking the 4th Wall. The game starts off with Deadpool taking on a contract and then the story takes off from there. Depending on your skill level, the difficulty you play on and whether or not you want to get all the achievements, gameplay can last from 6-35hrs. The game uses its character's affinity for absurd dialog and actions quite well. High Moon leaned on this heavily and there's barely a scene where Deadpool doesn't do something to make you laugh. High Moon also made sure to include a lot of 4th Wall breaking goodness. Taking heavy amounts damage will have Deadpool telling you to give someone else the controller, pets included, and deaths will earn you a quick rant. There are a few instances in the game where Deadpool will go so far as call up the Development team to complain about what is happening in game. Story wise, the game is sort of straight forward. Sort of as in, you are playing Deadpool's game and there is other stuff going on, but it is not important to Deadpool. There is a general 'stop the bad guy, save the world' theme, but the exact nature of this is thrown out by Deadpool himself and you never actually learn what the bad guy is trying to do. The game is pretty much linear and doesn't offer a branching storyline of some sort. Comedy plays a heavy hand in everything, but this unfortunately makes replay value drop quickly. One can only hear the same joke so many times before it gets old. Gameplay wise, it's 'use various weapons to kill a bunch of a bad guys'. There isn't that much variety in the enemies in the game. You will see same guys throughout the game with the only difference being what grouping they appear in. There are a total of 4 boss battles in the game and the latter 2 felt somewhat lazy. Case and point, the final battle is that you have to progressively battle 20-30 of the same guy, with only a slight variation in each wave. Navigation is quite easy with a pretty linear path and very few puzzles to deal with. Unfortunately the linearity of things made backtracking impossible. There were a few instance where after you jumped on a ledge, the game would set the death line immediately below the ledge so jumping backing down to get your loot from an enemy, that you may have knocked of the edge, was impossible. One of my biggest qualms with the game was checkpoints. There are several points where the game will screw you over with checkpoints. Depending on where a checkpoint is set to go off, you may end up fighting guys you have killed before triggering it. In the last level, you have to kill 2 melee enemies and a flying enemy. After killing them and triggering the checkpoint you would expect to never see them again, well that is not what happens. When you return to the checkpoint all 3 will be waiting for you and you have to fight them again with the same ammo you had when you triggered the checkpoint. This made it extremely annoying when you have to use only 2 specific weapons to get an Achievement. Another major flaw is the spacing of the checkpoints. There were a couple of occasions where you have to battle some seriously annoying enemies and then battle some more in the next area with no checkpoint inbetween. If you died, then you have to repeat both battles again. Achievement wise, they are all pretty easy with only the 300 hit combo and the 5 medals in challenge mode providing any difficulty. Aside from the checkpoints and lack of variety in the enemies, the game was quite fun. Depending on your skill level, the comedic dialog might keep you playing the game if you start with the games hardest difficulty. In terms of pricing, the game would be better priced at 39.99, but is fine at 49.99. If you are looking for a game to make you laugh, then this is your game. I have never laughed as hard at a videogame before. Here's hoping for either a sequel or maybe some good DLC. Note: I started the game on the hardest difficulty #Ultra-Violent# and used the other difficulties to get the Achievements I missed. In total it took me 32-35 hours to beat the game and get all the Achievements.

I got this game because I'm a fan of the character. That part the game got right. The character is fun and funny, just like in the comics. However each level is very repetitive and the game play is very similar level to level. I'm not an avid gamer, but even I'm a little disapointed by this game.

I went and picked up this game 4 hours ago. Guess what? I beat it. Now I'm here in a fit of rage that I just paid $50 dollars for this. DO NOT BUY IT! IT IS AN ACTIVISION CASH IN! It's funny I admit that they at least kept that in but, everything else was just awful. Stay clear of this.

The short version. Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 is a fantastic game, especially if you happen to be a fan of Dragon Ball. Xenoverse 2 fixes a lot of issues that the first game had but it created some new problems along the way and sadly ripped a lot of its content from the first game. All that said, here is what it comes down to. If you played the first game, wait for a price drop. If you didn't play the first game. This one is THE Dragon Ball experience bar none. The long version Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 is fun, it is. But most of the story and the side quests are lifted right from the original. And if you happen to transfer your character from the first game you see them maybe 5 times over the course of the game and then never again. You can't even pick them as a playable character in side quests or Expert Missions which I found to be a little disappointing. All that said, there are some redeeming values here. The hub is huge and once your character gets their flying license its really immersive to fly around Conton City looking for side quests and training with your favorite Dragon Ball heroes. Getting new attacks, and clothing options is much easier, and the game is much more balanced. (Though not perfect) The biggest new feature is the new Expert Missions which can be played with 6 people. These are fun if you can get 6 people together and they do provide a nice challenge. However this creates the biggest problem, when doing Expert missions or any mission for that matter. At the time of this writing, only the party leader gets credit for completing them. You can still get new attacks, items, clothing, EXP and Money but the game does not recognize YOU completed it. In other words if you and your 5 friends want to complete all the expert missions will need to play each expert mission 6 times for you all to get individual credit for completing it. Overall the game has a lot of content, and as I said if you didn't play the original you will get the most out of it. If you did, I would suggest waiting for a sale or price drop.

I bought this game for $25 on Black Friday (Normally $50). I haven't played it yet as it's a Christmas gift for my son. Hopefully it's better than '1-2 Switch' game that seemed very rushed to get out to the stores. 2K games usually does a good job. Hopefully it's fun.

From the very first cutscene to the last, the translation of the Harry Potter movies over to a Lego games was done without flaw and with much attention to detail. The voiceless acting and added humor makes the game so much more approachable for any level of Harry Potter fan. The gameplay is much like other Lego games, but throws in a magical twist. With the ability to learn new spells throughout the game, the interaction with the world evolves and is already a very lively aspect of the hub world. The music is flawlessly scored and makes the experience absolutely authentic. The graphics are smooth and very well made to feel like Harry Potter while hanging on tight to the Lego-esque vibe of the playing field. Boss fights flow like you'd imagine they did in the movie, and by knowing the movies and its occurrences your knowledge of how to conquer the game is already partly in place; as far as battles and puzzles go. New characters are unlocked through going back and using all of your and current character arsenal making the lifetime of the gameplay double. Great game for Harry Potter fans.

I bought this for my 5yo son but my 13 yo daughter loved it too. Graphics are wonderful, animation is very cute. They did a great job with the story line. Very impressed. My only complaint is its too easy to accidentally overwrite a saved game and you cannot save progress on different save slots. Daughter has gotten to the end of year 1 two times and my son has accidentally overwritten it both times with a blank game save...BIG OOPS. Needs to be better protected. Be nice if you could keep different save points.

I bought this game for my 7 and 11 year old. They are not big gamers so it is a little difficult for them to play. They are also girls so they do not spend much time trying to figure out how things work.

I just bought this game and it was fun to play until we were on two player at the giant spider then the game froze. I had to turn the xbox off, and when I turned it back on all the game data was gone. I haven't tried the single player hopefully it isn't a waste of time like the freeze on the 2 player. Great looking game. Just DO NOT play two player (which was the one reason I bought this game.)

Good game, when it works. Read up on the internet and you'll see, there's TONS of glitches and bugs in this game. We're talking fatal game ending glitches. Especially if you're playing 2 player. We found out the hard way about the poly juice 2 player glitch. We spent hours playing through the entire game, and wondered why we couldn't use the poly juice potion. Found out it was a glitch and how to fix it. Didn't know that when you fixed it (By watching a movie in the in game theater), that it would cause a fatal glitch in the game where you couldn't go any further. You're basically locked in a room, and the only way to fix it is to start all over again and play through 1 player. That's the first glitch. There's a TON more. There's the red brick 12 glitch that's a fatal glitch to the game resulting in having to start over. And then the game likes to freeze, A LOT! Go online, look it up, it's a super glitchy game. We actually contacted lego directly and they said that there's no way to fix the glitch(es), and then sent us a 10 dollar gift certificate for a lego product. (That is after spending 60 bucks on a glitchy game). It's a long game, with tons to do, so it's a grind to have to play through everything again. If it wasn't so full of bugs I'd definitely say this is a great game.
So I ordered this game for my nephew. Typed in Harry Potter wii game and bought the only thing that was populated by the search... when it arrived I realized it was for Xbox 360... ugh
I give this 5 stars to counter this stupid troll's review below.

Ok, let's start with graphics. They aren't pretty. It's clear the character design is meant to promote movie versions of characters here, which is dumb because people buying this game would rather see the comic representation and 2D hand drawn beauty that made this series famous. Menus are bland garbage as well, if you are the type that cares about presentation (I do). But after that, it's all good. The controls are fantastic and the mechanics are sound. The 2v2 change from 3v3 is fine and the ability to tag in and out during combos adds a new layer to the strategy. The infinity stones can be an added boost affecting different areas of your preference. Overall, still a lot of fun despite the more bland look compared to previous entries. That being said, if you are an offline fighter, Ultimate Marvel vs Capcom 3 remastered for XBO or PS4 is the better game.

Disclaimer: This is no MvC2. Or MvC3. The art style is weird (everyone looks like they ate a truck of steroids prior to coming to work). The story is quite cheesy and laughable. And the combat will push some veterans away (your attacks need to be more precise this time; no more button mashing!). No difficulty selection either. That being said, it is still a fun game and stays semi-true to the shell of the series.

Huge MvC fan- MvC2 set the standard. The gameplay in this one is great but its pretty bare bones. Capcom shouldve took some tips from Injustice 2- if MvC: Infinite had the customization of that game than itd be close to perfect. Good game but a huge missed opportunity and couldve been so so much more.

They changed the controls to more of a Street Fighter setup than the previous Marvel vs Capcom. Also, two character teams instead of 3. No Akuma as of now which is a terrible idea for a game bought by predominantly Street Fighter fans.

...this game looks to be terrible. The DEMO game play is terrible and so boring. I played it for an hour to give it a full chance, but nothing in it could make this game fun. I am a big fan of the MvC series (especially MvC2) but this game looks rushed and looking to make $$$ of fan boys. This is just my opinion.

Starts off in traditional JRPG games where you are a young man in a 2D world clicking through text bubbles. Teaches you how to play step by step as you advance. Reminds me of the old Sega Genesis games. I love the fact that it is portable and can be resumed whenever you have some time to spare.

First I am so glad limited run games is now getting some of their games stocked by Best Buy! I wont be able to rate the game much because I haven't played this much. It is a very fun game and very innovative for it to be a golf RPG. This comes with a cool booklet and it's awesome to have a game that would normally only be digital have a physical copy!

As a retro gamer, I always enjoy when games come out using older styles. Here you have a game that uses 16 bit type graphics for a golfing rpg. That sounds incredible odd, but it works and it works great! The actual golfing is alot of fun. The gameplay is engaging when you golf. The RPG elements of talking to characters and progressing through the story is also fun. I never thought i would ever enjoy a golfing RPG. The writing is clever. Also this game being released physically is awesome. LRG and Best Buy teamed up to get this in stores (LRG also sold it but it's gone now) and from what I hear the quantities of these are EXTREMELY limited. Just a heads up if you were thinking of picking this up.
This is a fun and interesting twist to golf genre that's entertaining in physical form

Then Best Buy out of the kindness of their hearts gave me a 2nd chance at owning this game. It's pretty fun, like the best golf game on the Switch fun and that's just the ten minutes I actually played it before I went back to Smash and Pokemon Let's Go To The Polls.
This is a retro 'old school' game format and I did not find it fun at all, not worth owning or manufacturing for that matter.
I bought it only reading the synopsis and looking at the cartridge cover. I thought it would have more 3D graphics but it look like the original pokemon games.

It's a brainless superhero fighting game...at least, I thought that was the extent of the game. I was way wrong. The story mode plot is intelligently-designed and multi-faceted, and it can go in more than one direction. The characters and highly-customizable (even alternate versions for characters, e.g., Power Girl, Black Lightning, Grid, etc., and the alternates have their very own Super Moves). The pre-fight interactions between the characters was also unexpected, and the interactivity WITH the arenas was a great touch (you can throw objects, jump off objects, and hit your opponent into a totally different part of the arena). I was leery about paying extra for the Legendary version, but it's definitely worth it, in my opinion. Nods to Mortal Kombat, Killer Croc and TMNT were very well done. If you have pre-teen kids, be aware of some teenage verbiage, especially in the story mode ('suck', 'a--', 'd---', 'h---', and maybe even a 's---' or two). Great game, overall, and I'd definitely recommend it.
I loved the original Injustice and this sequel is even better than the original. Great new characters and old favorites! Lots of ways to play this game. You will not be disappointed!

My 14 year old son has been wanting this and recently bought this game. Normally I can't get into what he buys as they are just too complex (I don't have that kinda time) or they involve too many buttons and too much 3D movement (yes, i'm old). However he was describing this to me and my husband, and we turned to each other and said 'it sounds like streetfighter.' We headed to his room, and took over. So much fun! I'm not sure that the three kids like having to share with their parents as much as they thought they would, but it's nice that we all get to finally have a game we can all play together. For those who think this might imply the game has limited complexity, I don't think that's the case. I think that is just how those of us unversed in modern gaming play it. My son takes it to a whole other level when he plays and how he upgrades his characters, etc. I just like that I can keep it simple and just play and still have time to connect with my kids in this way.
I'm glad, I bought this Injustice 2 again. Basically bought the Legendary edition because of 4 characters, 'The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.' The best super heroes game ever on XBOX One.

The DC universe continues to succeed at adapting their properties into the gaming world. With the sequel to Injustice, however - it feels like this take has overstayed its welcome. The plot was a struggle to stay with as it veered into the ridiculous and just expected us to go along with the plot. Sticking with Superman as a continually untrustworthy villain grows old with the argument of the world is evil and only we can make it right... by any means necessary. The AI mechanics are also frustrating as you have to get superiorly skilled at combos to even stand a chance. The AI also tends to defy the rules of its own game at times as it becomes increasingly frustrating to maintain a pleasurable gameplay.
It's nice since it has all the downloadable content but some dont make sense like the MK guys or the ninja turtles and hBoy.

This is a tough one because the game is 10 out of 5 stars BUT it's hard to justify spending an extra $40 on this edition due to the fact that you really just don't get anything impressive for it. If you are a big fan of aesthetics (AKA making you're video game character look cool) then there ARE some nice skins with which to do so. If you're not..well..in this gamers humble opinion; save the $100 punch in the wallet and instead 'settle' for a slightly less hard $60 punch in the wallet.
The reason why but his version is because the game gives your horse an extra guns. These guns and horse carry over to the online of the game which give you a huge advantage over other players.
This game is just amazing. Make sure you have at least 100 GB of space on your console! It is BIG!!!! But that is part of what makes it amazing!
