I'd honestly like to see more reviewers here compare & cotrast it with Skyrim, which I'm considering buying, but am hesitant, because since I have this one, I'm wondering why should I bother with Skyrim?

I have been playing the game for 4 days now, I dont really pay attention to the storyline, I just like to do the main quests and the side quests. I am looking forward to beating every quest in the game. Its a very addictive game. I like the fact that you can roam around and break stuff. I dont like the fact that for some of the side quests you have to steal things, and when you steal things you either have to pay a fine, resist arrest, or go to jail. When you resist arrest it makes your fine go up, and you cant go back to that town until you have enough money to pay the fine, and if you go to jail they take everything that was in your invintory, including the weapons you need to continue.

This game is so much fun! It sucked me in during the demo. After I unlocked all of the 'exclusive' weapons and armor from playing the demo I immediately pre-ordered it at my local bby! The graphics are very rich. The story line is intriguing, and I have played about 18hrs and am still finding new areas. My only complaint is the time it takes to navigate the menu system while in combat. This is a little frustrating because it takes awhile, but doesn't affect the combat, which is paused while accessing the menu. It would've been nicer to have a radial or some other kind of quick-select menu for weapons (there is one for potions while in combat) instead of opening menu, opening inventory, opening weapons, opening primary (or secondary), scrolling through everything I'm carrying to find the weapon I need and then hitting b repeatedly to back out. But the way I look at it is, if that is all that I'm complaining about this far into my game, then there are no real complaints! I love it. If you enjoy games like fable, you will love this game!

This isn't a perfect game. It's a light role player with very limited options and the ability to control the actions of only a single character. Your party only walks in a straight line, with only occasional paths for you to pick. Weapons and equipment are not so much purchased as upgraded, as you have to buy each version to unlock the next, and the upgrades don't make any sense. The 3-D is present, but very weak. So, why the five stars? It's all about the Miis. Creating an avatar of yourself and choosing three companions, who could be anyone you can imagine. You can go with people you know, characters from popular culture, celebrities, historical figures, or people you invent yourself. The list is limitless. Not in the creating mood? There's always Mii Central, an online database where people post their own Miis for you to use at your pleasure. It also supplies the Miis which populate the towns and other minor characters (which you can change, should any prove not to your liking). Once you've chosen your team and cast the major roles (including the main bad guy), your set out on an adventure unlike any other. Where else can you watch your sister fall in love with Albert Einstein, see Han Solo and Doctor Who get jealous of each other, or the sight of Jesus Christ prancing around in a cat suit? If you weren't a fan of Tomodachi Life, you probably won't get much out of this, but for people like me who thoroughly enjoyed Tomodachi, this is the long-awaited (and probably only) follow up. Not sure if it's for you? Download and play through the demo. It's impressively long, and if, when you reach the end, you're itching for more, then this is for you.
Purchased for teenager who had asked for it as a birthday gift. Has her stamp of approval

Miitopia is a pretty fun RPG even though it's quite basic. Battles are turn-based and falls more inline with older RPG games. Meaning, you can control what your main character does, but not what your pals do. What your friends can do depends on the classes you choose for them and the personality you chose. Their personality traits show themselves in battle through quirks, both good and bad. Like Tomodachi Life, you're able to use your own Miis to stand in as the rest of the characters. This includes other Miis people have made and are shared online. This is possibly the most fun you're going to have with Miitopia. You can always change the roles as well, so don't feel like you're stuck with who you've chosen. Another part of this game is eating food. This seems to be taken from Tomodachi Life as well. At the end of every stage, your Miis rest at an inn where you can feed them. What they like and dislike is random. For example, you may find yourself bummed out that your mage doesn't like food that increases the Magic stat. Yet another feature that seems to be taken from Tomodachi Life is the friendship feature. As you and your pals spend time together during the evenings, as well as helping each other out in battle, your friendship level increases. This will unlock nifty bonuses that help a lot in battle. It might as well have been easier to say this is Tomodachi RPG. It's fun if you're not expecting much and don't need much out of an RPG to be entertained. However, if you're looking for something more complex (like me), you might be disappointed in your purchase. I still had fun with Miitopia, but I'm hard-pressed to finish the game because I feel I've seen everything it has to offer. The story isn't engaging enough (I've spoiled myself silly to write this review in good conscious) and the amount of battles between each story segment is long and repetitive with no real way to evade battles you don't want to fight. Miitopia is very 'hands off'... like Tomodachi Life. I can't see myself recommending this to others. They might get bored faster than I did.

Out of all the things EA could have done to improve on UFC 2, they redesigned the striking system that was perfectly fine. Terrible grappling and clinch controls? Great! Let's revamp the one solid aspect of the previous game. Ground controls remained untouched and are still confusing and unresponsive. The striking system makes this more akin to fighting games like MK or SF with the combo inputs. If you dig that kind of thing then you'll probably like this. But it felt like a step back from a very solid striking experience 2 years ago. Career mode is terrible with absolutely zero depth. All the added bells and whistles get old after about 2 hours of gameplay and you realize you're slogging through the same old garbage as usual. Nothing exciting here.

Gal Metal is wild, weird and cool. If you can embrace the vivid and wacky art style of the comic panel segments and strive for percussive nirvana, there is a refreshing, deceptively deep and gratifying experience here. What stops it from being truly great are the minor inconsistencies of the motion controls, the completely bonkers alien invasion plot and the slow, text-heavy teen melodrama stories. Even so, the game mostly succeeds by subverting many stale genre tropes. It will take time to master your set list and the absence of more contemporary music is initially jarring, but this is a title that is rewarding as well as just really fun. For those who are about to rock, we salute you.
This game is kind of quirky its a music game but with story and other elements. You have jobs and stuff you do while you are not playing with your band. Very fun

This game is so much fun, and it fits the nintendo switch the best. The game its a mix of Parapa the Rapper, Taiko no Tatsujin and Elite agents. The premise is just as crazy, involving an alien invasion and saving the planet with the power of music. Really cute art style, kind of looks like manga panels. definitely recommended.
Wow! Such a surprise! Gal Metal is a quirky and charming. I found the motion controls to work quite well and the story is hilarious. If you enjoy odd games give this a shot!

A interesting free-form music rhythm game with lots of charm. Gal Metal encourages the player to practice and learn drum patterns. And in turn put those skills to use during stages where you freely drum to score points to clear stages. The timing for executing these drum patterns will take some getting used to for most players. The story is charming and told in a very cute manga style. Plus the games packaging is superb featuring a shiny foil cover, full color manual and stickers.

This is easily one of the best PS3 games available. First, the storytelling is quite stellar and you really do not know what is coming next in almost comic book fashion. After reading reviews and raving recommendations from friends I took the leap and picked up AA:GOTY, and I'm thrilled that I did. The storyline feels like it could have been ripped right from the pages of the comics, a real treat for those familiar with the Dark Knight. The graphics are top notch, with fast paced action you can almost feel Batman thrashing the goons and villains, or the slow and careful sneaking and detective work you need to navigate your way around Arkham Asylum.. The added bonus of this version being in 3D wasn't much of a sell point to me, and since it didn't come with glasses I can't really rate how good/bad that feature was. But to me what really steals the show on this game is the voice acting talent, they really bring all of the characters to life in ways you could only hope for in a big budget movie. I also really enjoyed the addition for the PS3 version of getting to play as the Joker on the challenge maps, definitely a fun change of pace. As an avid gamer, this game goes way above and beyond what I'd hoped for and finally delivers a thrilling Batman experience on consoles. As a parent with young kids who are also gamers, while the atmosphere and some story elements were darker, it wasn't over the top and there is not massive amounts of gore or bad language to worry about. The kids enjoy the game just as much as I did, and the plus for me is that even my wife enjoyed watching me play it. Now I look forward to diving into Arkham City...

How does the idea of a DIablo 3 clone without the charm, gameplay, graphics, music, writing, or fun of Diablo 3 sound? It sounds like... Warhammer Chaosbane! Let's look, shall we? Weapons and armor that, when equipped, barely change how your characters look. Almost none of the loot in this looting RPG, therefore, matters much. Everything is the same. The storyline, such as it is, is told exclusively through text boxes voiced by a very small handful of voice actors straining to make their roles sound different. While cheap and obnoxious, it was kind of amusing to hear one voice actor talk to himself in a Russian and British accent, both terrible, via two different characters. So bad. Each character gets a couple dozen skills and abilities, a tiny percentage of which are actually useful. This leads to repetition and boredom within hours of starting. The UI is a near identical clone of Diablo 3, a game I adore, but it's... tiny. So tiny. Everything is tiny. My eyes literally began to water and hurt as I played through this game, barely able to see the dwarf on my screen fighting his way through troves of baddies who all look alike. And fight alike. Even the weakest mob trash on easy mode takes multiple hits to defeat, rendering every single fight in the game tedious and boring. Sense a trend? Here's another trend: Vermintide 2, Inquisitor, and now Chaosbane, all failures, duds, and overall terrible games. Let's not keep this trend going, shall we? Avoid this title at all costs.

Like many of the other reviewers, I was won over by the games character design, music, and overall charm. Its a cute game, but I do feel there are some areas that aren't quite perfect yet. Maybe in the sequel the game will feel fully realized. 1. Having a three party team seems a little small. I feel like if I could have four people I wouldn't constantly have to go back to the oasis to get a different member to solve a puzzle. 2. When you meet a seedling in the wild, they will most likely want to join your team to complete a rather easy puzzle. Problem is, you will need to send one of you current members back to the oasis. I found that annoying as you have to go back again to get them in your party once the puzzle was completed. 3. There are lots of areas and boundaries you think you can squeeze passed or get around, but the game really likes using invisible walls to keep you where it wants. If I can't fit between the wall and that boulder, don't leave enough space to make it look like I can 4. I feel like the game is missing out with not having a jump button. Granted that would probably break a lot puzzle, but that could be reworked. Also, would also like a proper dash button as well. I know you can run a little faster when you sheath your weapon. but it would be swell to dash with B or something. 5. Some requests by the villagers can be a little obtuse. They will want a specific item from a monster drop. You figure, 'thats simple, the map tells me where to go' So you head to the spot and start killing the mobs there but none of them are dropping what you want. Turns out you have been killing the wrong monsters, because the right ones don't spawn until night time. But you wouldn't know that. Other times they will want an item from an area you have never been to and you have no idea how to even get there. So you have no choice but to watch them depart and hope they come back soon. Overall the game is pretty fun. I would recommend it if you are a fan of animal crossing, fantasy life, or zelda. There are elements of all those games present that should appeal to most fans.

I have not tried any multiplayer or soccer in Mario Sports Superstars yet as of this writing nor have I really used amiibo cards, so this is more like general impressions of the game. I, however, have played nearly all past installments of the various sports subseries, including Golf's Toadstool Tour (GameCube) and Advance Tour (Game Boy Advance), Mario Super Sluggers (baseball on Wii) and Mario Sports Mix (Wii). So I have much experience with these kinds of games and can speak with an expert opinion. I also think the amiibo functionality is a rip-off. The game's biggest selling point is also its biggest flaw. There are 5 sports, so there is variety. Unfortunately, none of them are really fleshed out. A good comparison to make for side-by-side value might be Wii Sports though there's more to MSS in terms of content. Those looking for the variety in modes per sport will only get some generic challenges and limited stadium or course variety. Only 36 holes in golf from 4 different courses, plus 4 extremely similar and dull themes for 12 horse racing tracks, none of which feel at home in terms of the Mario Universe. No special items like shells or fire flower either. And the unlockable characters, OH GOD! You won't bring back Neil and Ella from Advance Tour or have some random inclusions like Petey Pirahna, King Boo, or anyone from WarioWare, Nintendo? But you will include Metal Mario and PINK GOLD PEACH!?! So, why isn't this game awful and just average to me? Well, that's just it. It's not Super Mario standard, but the gameplay is solid. I especially like the pitching mechanics in baseball and taking care of horses in your stable. If anything, I think horse racing would make a great standalone title if they had interactions between Mario characters and the horse and expanded on everything else in the mode, including item variety, track themes, and customization. It just feels like Mario Sports Superstars should have been the start of a new franchise or even just a new subseries in the Mario universe with either forgotten or entirely brand new characters and just some Mario classics like Luigi, Daisy, Waluigi, etc. being unlockable bonuses. At least then, despite still being of average quality, it could than be looked at in an standalone context and then improved upon for an Nintendo Switch sequel. Instead, because of the Mario Sports stigma attached to it and lack of creativity to help back it, it ends up alongside more recent Mario and Sonic Olympic titles and general Nintendo spinoffs as a fun diversion for fans and newcomers. But one that will probably be forgotten and forsaken by said players who will probably replay older, much larger standout Mario sports titles instead.

If you own a 3DS you must add Metroid:Samus Returns to your game library. It's arguably the best game on 3DS. A+

Metroid 2: Return of Samus is a frustrating timesink that can feel hardly worth the effort you put in. Now Metroid: Samus Returns is a fantastic game that sets the standard for 'remastered' games. The first breath of fresh air Samus Returns introduces is the counter-attack mechanic, which lets you manage fights and your speed. Then the first Aeion ability you're given is Scan Pulse, which reveals most secrets within a certain distance, removing the need for guessing which blocks are destructable. Just as with the original, how you go about exploring is mostly up to you. The map helps tremendously with this, as well as the hints from the Chozo seals. You'll *almost* never feel lost. Only once did I really feel lost, and it was during a specific boss fight (which I feel could've been designed better). Now, the downsides. While the counter-attack mechanic is nice, it also gets fairly stale, fast. Although, this is mostly due to the lack of variety in enemies and having to backtrack through them. The controls a great, but they're locked in. That means no adjusting your key configs for the physical buttons or the touchscreen controls. The touchscreen buttons would've been great to rearrange because some of them are in such awkward positions. Whether you have big, small, or the perfect hands for the 3DS, unless you're fine taking your time to select things, you'll find yourself thinking the same thing. Overall, Samus Returns is a great addition to the Metroid series, with very minor issues. The perfect thing to sit on while you wait for Prime 4.

I am a long-time fan of Nintendo Games, and of Metroid in particular. Metroid has always been a series I've regarded with a great fondness. Super Metroid was one of the first games I was truly enamored with, even before Mario and Zelda. This title is a remake of the second entry in the series, Metroid II: Return of Samus, which appeared on the original Gameboy. I have only played a little of the original myself, and therefore cannot go in-depth into the updates in the Remake, aside from improvements that have become standard since the time of the original release. The gameplay shares the style of side-scrolling Metroid titles like Super Metroid and Fusion. Abilities such as the Spider-ball make their re-debut, and abilities like Wall-jump and Edge grab are present as well. Four new abilities, called Aeion abilites, reveal a portion of the map, offer damage protection, rapid-fire, and slow-down time. They are powered by an Aeion meter, and are unlocked a certain points in the game. The premise of the story, which I'll get to, is that Samus is hunting-down and exterminating the Metroid population. As such there is a certain amount of repetition. The development team did a good job of making the level design varied, and the gradual progression into more challenging Metroids satisfying. Still, most Metroid fights aren't all that unique. Also many of the standard enemies in later levels are upgraded versions of those present in earlier levels. Even so, I personally found there to be enough variety to avoid making the game a slog to the end. Difficulty-wise, this game isn't punishing, but it isn't easy either. Newer players will likely struggle, even with helpful abilities enabled. When the next level of Metroid is introduced, fighting it can be a pretty decent challenge. By the time you're pretty used to that kind of Metroid, a more powerful one is introduced. The Omega Metroid was epic to fight, and a joy to defeat. There are also a few boss fights that are pleasing, if occasionally frustrating, challenges. I also greatly enjoyed the final boss, and found it to be quite difficult. A gaming savant might find it easy or moderately challenging. An unskilled gamer would likely find it impossible. Overall, I found the challenge to be slightly more than what I would find in most other games. Story-wise, there isn't much there explicitly. Lore exists outside the game, such as the origin of Metroids, or the Chozo, but it isn't delved into. Veterans of the series will definitely notice nods to other titles, and easily see where this game falls between the original Metroid, and Super Metroid. Newcomers may be lost entirely to the narrative, or the significance of certain events or enemies. What this game accomplishes is a sense of solitude. A lone huntress charging in headfirst into a danger-filled world. The story, in that sense, is more experienced than told. Much can be, and has been, extrapolated from the series as a whole, for those who are interested. For average gamers, I encourage you to simply play the game, and enjoy it for what it is upfront. Overall, I think this game appeals more to experienced gamers than newcomers. While the difficulty curve isn't extreme for newcomers, this wouldn't be the first game I'd give them to play. As a game, it is mechanically solid, and is a blast to play. It is more centered around an experience than a narrative, which may be a turn-off for some. However, I think most gamers will enjoy it, and especially fans of the Metroid series.

Finally we get a real Metroid game! Metroid Samus Returns is a remake of Metroid 2 which only appeared on the game boy. The remake is awesome and plays fantastic. The remake expands and makes the game better in alot of ways by adding more to explore and making it less linear than the original game. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the new melee attack. Enemies will often flash signaling that they are going to rush you and you can counter them with a melee. Usually if successful you will kill the enemy (if its not a boss) with one shot of your beam after a counter. I feel this really changes how the game is played and I didn't like it as much. Some of you might like the melee counter alot, but for me it didn't click. However, it isn't enough to bring the game down since the game is still fun.

Everything is on full aggro so you have to stop and use the counter mechanic every half second... It lost all its charm cause you used it too often. Exploration is disappointing in that there's too much boring dead space and monotonous ball maze detour puzzles. There's also unnecessary segmented abilities that takes you out of your control comfort that get scattered usage but ultimately feels very lame and uninspired. The only redeeming thing about this game is that it allowed you to free aim, which adds a neat layer, but it never gets utilization on puzzling. Overall mediocre experience, the design and setting is pretty disappointing. Reused tracks for lava area was also a dumb lazy move.
Samus does indeed return in this iteration of this great series. Awesome graphics, gameplay, and story!
This game looks amazing, looking foward to that metroid fusion suit....

Just beat the last world in the Mario challenge to unlock all the items! Overall I think this is a great game. However, not all of the perks are there like the Wii U version. Pros: *You have to play through levels to unlock items. *Levels have added challenges for extra difficulty but are not required. However completing challenges unlocks more worlds. *You can download and play levels created from the Wii U version Cons: *You can't use amiibos *You can't upload your own levels via internet, instead you have to use street pass or download with friends who have the game. Overall it gives you endless mario levels to explore and create. Glad Nintendo made this for the 3DS

This game really should exist. You can't upload your own created levels, and you can't search specific levels to play. The one thing that this game has on the Wii U version is there are 100 premade levels to play through, and with two challenges per level, there's a lot to play through. As a Mario Maker game, it fails, but since it's a Select title which makes it cheaper, it's not a bad value to get it just for the levels. But I'd still rather have a Wii U original, or better yet, wait for the Switch sequel.

If you have the Wii U version, this might not be worth it. The online sharing options are very limited compared to it. However, it adds 100 new Nintendo-developed levels, that are worth playing if you're a platformer fan.

Fun game to play as one is reminiscing about one's childhood and all the fun that was had playing the Mario games on a Super Nintendo. One complaint that I have with this game is that it was very short. Game needs more levels to get that full nostalgia.

I had blast playing and creating Mario level on the Wii u version that sooner or later I was going to pick this up for my 2ds. It maybe on a smaller screen but still same amount of fun and imagination of so many creative levels from other players around the world. Only think I wish they can change is the internet section. But I totally recommend this to Mario fans and creative fans of all ages.

We picked this up on a whim for my son to play on a long road trip since he loves the Wii U version of the game. It did the trick, though it lacks in some features that are in Wiiu such as being able to share your levels online. The graphics definitely don't look as good on the 3DS screen but most young kids won't notice. My son didn't mind at least. It's annoying to have to re-unlock everything, but if you're looking for the ability to play around with level design on the go then this game will do the trick.

I got this for my 5 year old and 6 year old son. At first, it seemed hard to figure out for me, but my son taught me and it's a fight to get them to put it down. Every now and then I sneak to play it! It really let's the kids be creative. I usually don't like games that aren't educational, but I realized this definitely is!

I was intrigued by the idea of this game on the Wii U, if only just to play some of the crazy levels people come up with. Seriously, check them out on YouTube. I never got around to buying a Wii, and now the Switch is out with a few of the games I was interested in... So why not wait? I picked this game up on MAR 10 day on sale, it's been fun so far. I've heard it's missing some of the elements of it's older brother on the Wii U, but that was to be expected. Don't dismiss the 3DS version!

My son loves this game the most; he was asking for Super Mario Maker since mid or late Oct 2016 now that he got it for Christmas gift and the help i got from my local Best buy to make my son very HAPPY thanks

It's basically the same as the Mario Maker on Wii U but lacks the ability to upload levels online or search for specific levels online which is a huge downside. Still fun, otherwise.

I purchased this game during the Black Friday in July sale which had a glitch that discounted games by half instead of only 1 by half. Not going to play it. Purchased it with the sole intention of flipping it on eBay.

The super Mario maker 3ds edition is a good port from the one on the Wii u but dose lack Internet course function it has a real fun 100 custom nintedo course challenge that's fun and interesting. Fun for all Mario fans that love the Mario series.

glad this finally came to the 3ds..the wii u version was great
My son has always been a fan of Nintendo games. The graphics in this game are awesome.
Our are getting it for Christmas and are going to be so surprised and excited!

I honestly didn't have high expectations with this game. However after putting several hours into it, I am quite surprised. The story is the strong point of this game. The writing and voice acting of the characters are both believable and relatable. Although the story draws you in, the actual gameplay becomes tedious and boring after a while. The mechanics of the game are nothing new and a bit old school. The player has to continuously pick up ammo. This might not sound like a big deal, but after hours of playing it is quite tedious. Lastly, I would say that the game takes around 10-12 hours to beat. There is no multilayer for this game so one really needs to assert if the game is worth buying $60. In the end, I enjoyed this game, although I wished I rented it instead of purchasing it.

This game in my opinion is absolutely phenomenal I was skeptical at first because of all the hype but the graphics are great the gameplay is great its truly amazing. I'm not to sure why these people are complaining about gameplay as well as physics of the game I do however agree the 'DOOM' beta trial is a load of well cant say on here but you catch my drift. Maybe the ones that complained about this game play should go back to playing camp of duty and battlefield 'three/four' <==. Which just saying neither of them ever changes Wolfenstein: the new order on the other hand did change for better where as the older Wolfenstein games lacked in physics of in game play although the stories were ok and the online was just pure terror in the older Wolfenstein games this game has a great story it is somewhat of a bummer there is no online but the story makes up for it if you don't like playing campaigns this isn't for you the graphics are amazing unlike call of duty's... which has no grit war games are supposed to be brutal guns blazing not sit in a corner camp wait for enemy's to come to you this game has it all I recommend to anyone who truly likes these types of games.

This game is, by its definition, a standard shooter. The mechanics are all similar to other FPS games, so if you are used to this type of game, them you will feel right at home. This, however, helps you focus less on the mechanics themselves and allows you to pay attention to the plot, which is actually interesting (after the intro, that is). You have to get through an over-the-top set piece before you see what I am talking about story wise. It is believable within context and you can relate to the characters feelings and emotions. At least, that's how I would feel if things panned out like they do in the game. Buy this game for the story and nothing else. If your looking for a fun shooter, there is one to be had here, but there is no multiplayer. However, an interesting decision early on in the game encourages to do two playthroughs, but I won't spoil the fun. Dual wielding the gun is fun at first, but then it becomes cumbersome with too many enemies on screen, since it is less accurate and more clunky. I, instead, found it more satisfying to go for stealth kills. I do like having both options at hand. Minor issues with AI not recognizing you on rare occasion, but in those cases, it usually works to your advantage. Overall, I would rate the game a 7 out of ten, which is not a bad rating. Buy it, play it, and then, take advantage of the Best Buy return program so that you can invest in another game. You will have fun with this one.

I thought this game was going to be another lame, boring shooter. Boy was I wrong! I have recommended this game to few close gaming buddies of mine. I love the graphics and how well the cpu reacts to your actions. Give it a try, you will not be disappointed!

Wolfenstein: The New Order is the first game developed by MachineGames, a new game development studio comprised of industry veterans who worked on such titles as The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay and The Darkness. After leaving Starbreeze, these talents started MachineGames to continue their passion of making great games, and if Wolfenstein: The New Order is any indication, this studio has a bright future ahead of them. First and foremost, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a single player game. Is that a negative? Not one bit. There are enough multiplayer games out there if that's what you're into, and only a few of them actually succeed, so it's best to leave multiplayer to the games that have people who want that and not waste resources on it when they could be better spent making a meatier and more satisfying single player game, and that's exactly what MachineGames did with Wolfenstein: The New Order. Depending on your style of play, you can get 20 hours out of this game on one playthrough, which is very long for a first-person shooter. In addition, both running & gunning and stealth are viable options since the level design allows for exploration and planning which is important if you're play stealthily. This also adds replay since here are two different ways you can play the game. As for the shooting, it's so buttery smooth and packs a punch. I haven't played a shooter in a very long time that felt this good. As for stealth, it's pretty basic but satisfying. It's fun throwing knives at the enemy or using a silenced pistol. :) Onto the graphics, this game is available on Xbox One, PS4, PC, Xbox 360 and PS3, so it's a cross-generational release, which means it won't be the most graphically impressive game you've ever seen. Sometimes it looks outstanding, sometimes it looks okay, and other times you'll notice that some textures aren't as detailed as they could be. With that said, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a rarity on consoles like Xbox One and PS4 since it outputs native 1080p resolution and 60 frames-per-second on both. Now the big surprise for me is the story. Wolfenstein was never known for story, but The New Order changes that. Likable protagonists, despised antagonists, all wonderfully voiced and acted. In addition, the soundtrack is tops. Wolfenstein: The New Order surprised me by how good it is. Probably my favorite FPS since Half-Life 2.
Maybe I'm just getting old. Makes the early ones look like, well, the older ones. Awesome graphics. Spooky feel. Definitely playable. Need my old reflexes.
All around good game. Just a little short on longevity. Wouldn't recommend paying more than $30.
This was a surprise hit for me last year. Great story and gameplay.
Best Wolfenstein to date. Good story and challenge plus hidden bonuses
An old school pc game, remade. Awesome game. A bit tough, but worth the struggle.
Game was fast paced, excellent! Had me in total excitement from beginning to end.

SPOILERS I'm a fan of anything Wolfenstein/DOOM/Quake. So I was excited about this release, especially on Xbox One. I have to say I was a little disappointed. The game is not bad, just not as good as it could've been. For starters, this is an FPS - from one of the franchises that pioneered the FPS. So you expect firefights, gun battles and the like. Sadly, this game promotes, sometimes forces, you to sneak around with a knife. It also forces you to rely heavily on a laser cutter. Not the kind of FPS experience that I was hoping for. There's also no multiplayer or coop. In all fairness, the laser cutter doubles as a very cool laser shooter - though with limited capacity. All of the weapons are a lot of fun to shoot, when you do get to use them. I wish there was a 'BFG' somewhere. I really miss having a weapon that will lay waste to everything with one shot. The variety of weapons is nice, as is the dual wielding for some. There are some rare opportunities to fire larger artillery weapons, but it's done sparingly which was a little disappointing #one sequence takes you to a cutscene when you pull the trigger, kinda lame#. The story is nothing spectacular. The 'bad germans' won WWII and are the ruling class of Europe. You join forces with a group of resistance fighters in Berlin and lead the charge to take down Deathshead. The dialog is a little cheesy and there are a few too many cutscenes for my taste - some that you can't skip. The ending is very predictable. There are actually two slightly different storylines, depending on how you play the game. The enemy AIs make for fun, challenging targets. The bosses are also pretty cool, but the actual battles were a little boring. There's a VERY cool throwback to old school Wolfenstein within the game #hint: take a nap on the top floor bed when you get to the safehouse#. The graphics on Xb1 are very clean/clear with no frame rate issues that I could see. The unlockables aren't all that great #I thought unlockable concept art died out in first gen console games??#. I did enjoy this game, though it fell short in a few aspects. I plan to keep it and play through a couple more times.

I was pleasantly surprised by Wolfenstein: New Order. The Alternate Reality/History angle with the German's winning WWII was truly unique and made for a fantastic backdrop for an otherwise modern shooter. Gameplay was fast and fluid with little to complain about. The option to go in guns blazing OR stealthy varied the campaign considerably. There is no multi-player for those asking/looking. I did not miss it, as I was looking for a meaty single player campaign and Wolfenstein: New Order delivers it in spades.

Wolfenstein was the (first) First Person Shooter I ever played (like many others) way back in 1993 when I was just 9 Years old and I will never forget that. I played the Ravensoft release in 2009 and found that to be quite a sleeper hit and very enjoyable. This latest game was made by MachineGames in Sweden and does not disappoint. Solid controls, great weapons and excellent memorable character designs. It's just long enough, not too short and not drawn out. If you want a new FPS on Xbox One definitely give this a go, you will not regret it. It's a game that was definitely made for the fans but did not alienate any will be new players at the same time. Highly recommended.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a fantastic game overall and I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good shooter with a great story. The AI can be mindless at times but it doesn't really take away from the action or story.

This game is really fun and engaging with lots of puzzles as well as good FPS action but sometimes it's frustrating trying to figure out how to get past some boss fights with little to no hints so you die a lot and try again, die and try again, die and try again... Get the point? But, this is not always bad as sometimes you discover things you missed after the first or second death. But like all ALL FPS's I've played, there is no real replacement for peripheral vision and this game fails at this but it's in a big club. Also, there are some surround sound issues, so don't rely on shots coming at you they may be behind you but the sound is coming from everywhere. Also, this is NOT for Children! There are Adult scenes (Rated=R)! And blood so parents, pay attention to the 'M' rating. Multiplayer would have been a great addition! Too bad it's missing.

I am a big fan of the old Wolfenstein 3d from the early 90's and always wished for a reboot that would do the title justice. The attempts over the years have fallen far short. With this newest installment it has come very close to restoring the name. This game has a lot of action and has great story telling. I enjoyed that it modified history to bring a fresh spin on how the world could have ended up. The gameplay is very good but sometimes the difficulty seems to range too much throughout the game. I played it through on the second to last difficulty so some spots were decently difficult (just right) but then it would get too easy in certain areas then become absolutely unforgiving in others. Overall, even though the game is a bit short for a game with no multiplayer offering (about 10 - 12 hours) I would recommend this game as it is worth at least one play through.

A smooth shooter with great graphics and cool weapons to tear apart your enemies with. Too bad that so far there's no plans to release a multiplayer or co-op mode add-on for this game. Still worth playing though.

With the lack of great next gen games, I picked up Wolfenstein with the great Best Buy Gamers Unlocked deal. Regardless, the game was mindless fun. It was a solid First Person Shooter with an OK story. However, the game lacks any multiplayer, so once you finish it I don't see myself playing it again. There are lots of unlockables and things to find if you are into that stuff. There are also two story lines, so you can play twice if you care about both stories. Overall, it was decent. For the price I paid I recommend it. MSRP, not so much.

i was not sure to buy this game because it didn't have any online multiplayer but after watching some youtube let's plays i decided i couldn't resist. I am glad i bought it. The story is very long and you will need to play it more than once to get all the collectibles and save different people. The action is great in this game. I couldn't really stop playing it till i beat it. Graphics are good and sound quality is good. You can also choose to do stealthy kills or go in guns blazing. It's up to your preference how you play it. Also you get rewarded by a perk system for doing things like stealth kills, throwing knife kills, dual wield kills etc. Overall i would give an 8 out of 10. only because of no multiplayer.
Love the game, the alternate universe versions of weapons are interesting, and the combat A.I can be fierce.
Overall one of the best Wolfenstein's I've personally played in years. Great story line for the SP part. Probably about the only disappointing side is the no multiplayer... still its worth the money!

The latest Wolfenstein title continues the experience of taking down evil German soldiers & does not disappoint like some previous titles. This game is single player only & with that the publishers chose to focus on a long (20 hour) engrossing campaign that has you fighting for the resistance against evil German control. It starts off during the final days of World War 2 & then jumps to 1960s. The Germans have won World War 2 & have taken over the world. It is your job to take it back from them. Reviews gave it a 8 on Gamespot.com, a 8 on Gameinformer.com & a 7.8 on IGN.com.

this game is awesome, it is pretty hard, I am passing it on medium and am already struggling on the first couple of levels. the AI reactions need some work but since its the first installment I wont pick at it this game is great!

I haven't been doing a good job of looking at games to see if they are online only or have no online before I buy. I just really wanted the old school Wolfenstein back in this game. The single player is definitely fun and keeps getting better. Nothing spectacular but still a fun shooter.
Wolfenstein: The New Order is a fun and mindless shooter that scratches that itch. It's like a popcorn movie, and that's not a bad thing. :)

Having only just started playing this game, I haven't seen very much, but the stuff I have seen I am enjoying. The city is oppressive and gloomy, painting a portrait of a city being destroyed by plague and corruption. With all the twists and turns and various paths it's easy to get lost in feeling of this game. The negative is that the real challenge is to get through the levels without touching any NPC. No killing, no knockouts, no suspicions raised. As with most stealth heavy games, guards patrol a set pattern, always turning the same direction and pausing for the same amount of time. This is my biggest frustration with these games. With these new systems, AI should be more random, more lifelike. Give me consequences to taking out the guards. If you were a guard talking to your buddy, and all of a sudden he disappears when you turn your back, would you be concerned? At any rate, this game is a great play and makes me excited to see what the future holds for the new consoles.

I got this initially thinking it would be something similar to the Assassins Creed series, which it started out as. After getting farther into the game, it moved to stealth only in which you must think out side of the box to finish the mission objectives with 100%. I would recommend having a good surround sound system/headset when playing to get everything you can from the awesome sounds.

I loved the older Thief Games that being said this one was just...alright. It was hard to get used to the controls and the voice acting was sub par. I am so used to other first person games the controls took me forever to get used to. I also couldn't marathon this game like I normally can others. The story just didn't grab me. It was a good start to reinventing the franchise and I cant wait to see where they go from here, but this game was just kind of...lacking to me.

A great new take on a FPS. Instead of shooting everything in sight, you must try to be as stealthy as possible to avoid detection, only fighting when necessary.
