I was able to play this game at E3 2015. I'm sure the final version will have minor differences but I will share my experience with the game. For Honor is very much a cooperative effort with your four teammates. You will have a tough time if you try to go '5150' on your team members and take down the enemy on your own. During my match I played on the defenders as the second defender. There were three bases A, B and C that we were trying to take a hold of. The goal was to get to 1,000 points to make your enemy army feel defeated and give them the finale blow before winning the battle. From my experience, you earn points the more bases you take over. My defender teammates would call out bases they intended to take over or defend. You and your teammates can team up on an opponent, but it will leave you vulnerable. If no one is there to defend your base, another team can run to it and claim it. Similar to capture the flag type games. There are also perks you earn as you kill off your enemies. You can head over to your fellow soldiers and inspire them as a perk, heal yourself or kill a bunch of your enemies by using a catapult. You do have the option to customize your character. There were different armor options and you can choose between playing as a male or female. There is no statistical benefit from playing as a male versus a female. They are equal matches. I choose to play as a male. I didnt have much time to look through the armor options, but there were at least four I was able to choose from. The main concerning aspect is whether the gameplay will get repetitive. While the excitement of battle stayed strong throughout the 25 minutes I played, Im having a difficult time seeing the replay value in the game. The game could get boring once you settle into the game and the controls become second nature. Check out the trailer online for an example of graphics quality. I did find the graphics to be crisp and well polished.

For honor is a fantasy based fighting game that pins the samurai, knight, and Viking factions against each other. In terms of skill based game play the mechanics include parrying (controlled with timing) , blocking (directional input) , dodging (directional input as well as coinciding button press), attacking (controlled with directional input), and chain attacks ( heavy and light paired with directional input) While the game is fun, certain scenarios will make you angry, facing a team that gangs up on you will lead to your immediate death. In a game that stresses Honor (it is in the title after all) you may very well be faced with opponents who have zero of it what so ever. The customization of the characters is in depth and relies on a small part of RNG. Gear pieces can be awarded at the end of games or 'scavenged' in boxes or bought by using in game currency(that can be earned in game/bought) called steel. The leveling process to get the different tiers of weapon and armor qualities lead to a grind, but at times can feel rewarding. Downside to this game is the ability to boost by buying different armor sets to have permanently and/or status boosts (increase in xp, steel, more item drops) at the end of a game session. This model of microtransactions is common in Free to Play game models, but in a game that costs $60, it has no place in it unless it's purely based on cosmetic items. Overall fantastic game concept but executed rather poorly in a sense of server management as well as built around microtransactions.

Great concept and a beautiful game. The Fighting engine is great. Unfortunately, the released the game before it was complete and never really focused on the core issues. Instead of getting dedicated servers they used p2p which means getting connected and staying connected to an online match was near impossible. Everyone in the party had to have open NAT type just to have a chance. I believe they have servers now but much too late. instead of correcting connection issues they tinkered with the warriors. Killing great warriors and making other much too strong. I understand balancing, but taking a player that you have put a ton of hours into and making him unplayable is frustrating to say the least. Also the micro transactions are insane. My friend bought the $100 version of the game and didnt even get his perks. couldve been a GOY candidate

I bought For Honor caught up in all the hype and it was worth it at first. Exploring the game was exciting and collecting gear while leveling up heros was great. Then the issues began. The game uses players xbox 1 systems as the servers for the game. Anyone with a bad connection who is the server or who leaves mid game freezes game play until another 'server' can be found. If a server is not found in enough time the game drops and all experiance and items you may have gathered are lost no matter how long the match has gone (matches can last 20 minutes). After one attempt at a game session of 3 hours i only completed 3 matches. At that point I gave up playing at all and havnt touched the game since. It would be fun but honestly its not worth the annoyance.
Had a great time playing with my suns,had a fungame.

For Honor is the best swords and Shields multi-player game I've ever experienced. You can play as either a Samurai, Vikings or Knights as different factions at war with each other and each one has multiple different classes to choose from and they all look and play differently. It's also not for children. Some of the execution finishing moves are brutal and could be in Mortal Kombat. They do look good though. Also a very polished looking game visually. Unique combat system with depth. And there are multi-player modes that u can play against the a team of computer controlled characters if u don't enjoy playing with other real players just for fun or to get better until your ready for other players. It also has a single player story mode for people that don't like playing with others at all. Very complete, good game and if your into the medieval time period even a little it's worth a purchase.
played the beta and fell in love with it. it's something new and interesting to play especially with friends.

This game wasnt on my radar until I tried it in Beta. It was fun enough to make me go out and pre-order. Although some may see it as repetitive at times, it is still highly addictive. I can say, no two battles were ever the same... I'm hoping once the full game is released, that the faction rewards system gives an extra sense of accomplishment.
Its like a dynasty warriors fan dream come true! So much action. So much chaos. Its awesome!

Tried out the Beta. This game looks cool, and is kinda fun. That said, there is nothing that actually wants to keep making you play it. Everything was very bland. 4v4 was just pitiful on the Xbox One. I'd maybe try this if it was in the $10 range. All this talk of 'big battles' isn't there. At least not from my experience.
The kids and holiday time. The days of basketballs footballs has gone into electronics, a new era.

This game is a must buy for fighting game fans or for fans of medieval warfare and combat in general. I have never experienced something so close to actual medieval combat. Every matchup is like a game of chess between you and your opponent with parries, blocking, and shuffling back and forth trying to gain better positioning than your opponent. 16 classes with more to come as well makes every matchup unique. Highly recommended!
Literally the best game ever. EVERYONE TRY IT OUT!!
Can be fun but at times can be boring as you just fight the same over and over.
Game is decent but the always online requirement is annoying.
I like the theme but it's just titanfall minus the robots and jetpacks
this game is a cool game, but not the type of game I typically play and wasn't really what I expected. the quality of the game is great.
The game is literally a medevil version of dynasty warriors its not as great as they made it look. graphics are ok.
This is a great game to play. This game is realistic and fun.
This game is better than the Beta had revealed....

The Gameplay itself was fun, but the storyline and interaction level in the map was limited. I was hoping to have more of an Assasins Creed or FarCry level of story. I thought Ubisoft would have done a better job.
I hard a lot of good things about this game and was really eager to play it. It is great so far!
I played the open beta and it was fun, I like that the game/characters was a little true to history.

Great game , very skeptical of another attempted swordplay multiplayer. Classes have a lot of distinction between face rollers and in depth advanced classes. 4v4's , 1v1's 2v2 duels , eliminations , dominations etc. Characters progress to lvl 20 and prestige. You level up your gear ,(chest,helm, arms,legs and weapon's blade, guard,grip) and collect gear for accomplishments. Very promising

I couldn't get enough of just a weekend playing the beta. It was fun and exciting and it got really competitive playing 4v4 PVP. I can only imagine how great it will be when they work all the kinks out. I also hear there will be campaigns for those that don't like pvp.

I'm a big fan of Dragon Ball, I had great expectations of this game, but after playing 1 week it gets really boring. Especially for people without online access. History mode is that make boring the entire game, just a female Majin buu trying to eat everyone. I had to fight clones in order to fight more clones, those clones look like the already known Dragon Ball characters: Goku, Vegeta, Piccolo, Gohan, Freezer, Cell, etc., but had different and awful colors. It's always the same thing, I just watch the cutscenes for the prettiness of female Majin buu. The good thing about the game is the graphics and that's it.

Well in all honesty all the Dragonball z games been great, But after year after year it's all been the same and finally this great Anime gets a new and original game for both Fans of Anime and games in one.

Game was hyped up so much, I believed it would be very different from any other DBZ game before it. I expected so much more from the company responsible for Blazblue and my favorite, Guilty Gear. This one is nothing like those games, its just a button masher dressed up as DBZ with beautifull animation. Fighting game fans should stick with the classics (Tekken, Street Fighter, Guilty Gear, etc). This game is for kids.

I know the original game came out 6 months previous and got great reviews, but I recently decided it was time to pick it up and this version was coming out with all the DLC in one total package. This is an absolutely fantastic game, the best 'licensed' game made to date, and generally a thrilling game that is like playing through a long timeline of gritty Batman comics. I am typically a Marvel guy, but to-date noone has put out a comic hero based game this well written and acted. The game features a huge map, spot on gameplay, and a huge variety of challenges. Do yourself a favor - Buy this Game!

I am sure one of the oldest gamers out there so when I say this is one of my favorite games I have played thousands. My love of Batman goes all the way back to the early 70s. The fighting engine is amazing. Love the Joker!

First thing's first, if you haven't played Batman: Arkham Asylum then I recommend doing so. It hints back to what happened there often. If you haven't played it then you'll be sitting there looking pretty confused when you see Joker, Sharpe, and probably other things/people that I can't think of off the top of my head. Now look man, this game is a game of the year edition for a reason, all those 10 of 10's and 5 out've 5's you're seeing on the cover aren't make believe, this game is the real deal. Whether you're the world's largest batman fan or you've never even heard of him(which is unlikely) is irrelevant, this game is one of if not the best RPG games I've ever played. The gadget's you can use are awesome(there is quite a bit of them), the fighting is just flat out ridiculous, it put's in just the right amount of stealth to where you still get the thrill of stealth take downs but without over doing it to the point that it gets boring, tons of side-missions(optional), unfortunately no killer croc or scarecrow(atleast not that I know of), but there are still a good number of villains. The ending to the riddler's challenge in Arkham Asylum was just nonsense to me, they gave him a larger and better role in Arkham City. The thing that separates the regular B:A.C. from the game of the year edition to me was the fact that it brought in Robin and Nightwing. Unfortunately they aren't playable in the campaign mode, but you can use them in Riddler's Revenge(the challenge mode). I think Catwoman comes with the regular B:A.C. but you might want to double check that. Another thing as far as the challenge mode goes is you can use countless other costumes for Batman, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing( You can't use the other batman costumes in story mode until the main story is complete). The ending left me with a confused look on my face, but Harley Quinn's revenge made up for it. On challenging gameplay, I rated it a 4, but if I could I would give it a 4.5. Don't misunderstand me, it is a challenging game, it WILL make you think. The hand-2-hand could be a little bit more challenging in the campaign mode, but it get's pretty tough in Riddler's Challenge's. So if you just want to test yourself against a mosh pit of opponents then you can, just not so much in the story mode.
The game is excellent, especially with the bonus content on the game of the year edition.
Got this for my 15 yr old, I could not pry him off, 8 hours a day for 4 days at first, now an hour or two at a time. Best $20 I ever spent on a video game. Thanks Best Buy.

I have been playing video games for over 30 years. This is 1 of the best games I have ever played. It is challenging but not impossible. It looks great. And it has tremendous replay value. I would recommend this game to anyone. It is worth owning this system for.

Dont even want to start saying all the positive because we would be here for a while, Amazing start... Consistent action packed middle, Shocking end. Mix of villains was perfect and loved the new gameplay. Catwomen side story was perfect for the game to not get boring. i dont normally say a game is perfect but this game is so darn close. 4.9 of 5 because im stubborn.... go buy this game especially at this price.
Love the story line, can't wait to play as Catwoman and Robin.

I got this game after playing through 'Batman, Arkham Asylum'. This game has a great storyline - it's almost like watching a movie and you are inside controlling Batman. The game is full of all of the familiar DC Comics characters and challenging bosses. This is one of the few games that I only had to take a cursory glance at the controller function buttons, and go to town without having to go online to 'cheat' my way through certain puzzles or scenes. It is intuitive and can offer hints #an option in the setup# if you are killed. The game is able to render 3D, but I can't comment on it as I don't have the special glasses needed. BTW, if you WANT to get the 3D glasses, don't expect the cheap ones used in movies to work. There are plenty of thugs to battle and tons of upgrades. Batman has a ton of gadgets to help him throughout the game. I'm 57 years old and addicted to this series - WB and Rocksteady have done a great job at bringing a decades old character to life in a game that will give you hours of amazing play. As a retired teacher, I would say that I would NOT recommend it for young children as there is some mature material throughout the game, but for teens on up, I think it's OK. I like the fact that when Batman has fights with the criminals, he never kills them - only knocks them out. Therefore, I rated it as 'family friendly' with this caveat.
this game is amazing! great plot, and excellent sequel to the first part.
This game lets you move, think and respond like the Bat.
The overall gameplay in general is amazing! I love how you can try the Riddler's challenges!
Game has great graphics and storyline. Reminds a little of AC, but if you're a big fan of Batman this would be the game, and be sure to get the Game of the Year addition to get the add-ons.

The GOTY Edition has it all, great graphics and gameplay, an engaging story line and all the DLC, at an absolute bargain of a price. If you are a fan of Arkham Asylum, don't hesitate to pick Arkham City.
The game has great characters from the Batman universe, creating unique experiences for fans and beginners alike.
This game has an excellent story line with challenging missions. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a Batman fan.
great for the 12 and under set. But not compeling enough for using up valuable game playing time.
kept me entertained for much longer than most games
Walking Dead on A Video Game. Who Doesnt Want To Kill Zombies ? This is the Game just for that.
Who Doesnt Want To Kill Zombies...... Its amazing how much time you can Kill by Killing the Zombies. I Give it a 20 On a 1-10 Scale.
Game is ok. Did not live up to the promotion videos
Needs to be more adrenaline edge of your seat type of game
It's slow it looks terrible and it's just bad. Not worth even renting
It's creative for sure and there was a world of potential but I've already stopped playing it.

I'm thoroughly enjoying the game so far but it's definitely not going to appeal to everyone. If you've played the first game then there's quite a few things done differently. To start off, the familiars are gone. Whether you are happy or not for this will depend on how you felt about that system. It is replaced with very standard Action RPG combat you can find in games like the Tales of Series and Kingdom Hearts. Characters can equip multiple weapons, learn skills (not the same as learning spells) and equip a sub weapon. What if you didn't play the first game? Well NNK2 stands on its own and doesn't really have much of a connection with the exception of a bit of location lore. Gameplay wise, the game is fast, fluid and beautiful but it's pretty easy. There's no difficulty settings to select so you're not going to struggle much if you've played a few JRPGs. Storywise, NNK2 isn't the strongest. The game focuses more on you assisting with King Evan quest to build his kingdom than resolving any conflicts or hunting down a primary villian. Cutscenes are short and voiced acted scenes are few and far between. You'll do more battling than you will reading/listening. For the story that the game does have, it's a pretty standard story of a young boy wanting to bring people together and live happily ever after (literally). One of the biggest parts of NNK2 is kingdom building. This is where things can drastically shift based on the player. Kingdom building is where you recruit your citizens, build different shops you can profit off and do some sidequests. This is a huge part of the game and partially optional. Do you need to fully max it out? No but there is a certain point you have to hit with your kingdom to continue the main story. So if you don't like the city management aspect of this game then that might be a bit of a problem. All in all, it's an enjoyable JRPG if you want a somewhat relaxing time. The biggest complaint I have is that the text while running around is incredibly tiny and autoscrolls far too fast for most people to be able to read. And I do wish some more of the game was voice acted as I feel that some of the scenes lost their impact due to their silence.

If you ever played the first or even if you haven't, this game was a blast to play. So many different styles of game play you can explore. While it can be difficult at times, if you take your time & enjoy the game, you'll eventually get the hang of it. The art style & music is top notch as well. If you're a casual RPG fan, you'll love this as well. Highly recommended.

This game feels like its unfinished. Which is ridiculous because it was announced years ago. Most of the characters are one dimensional and contribute little to nothing, the plot is extremely boring, the pacing is way off, and the game is TOO easy. Theres a hard mode now but early adopters like me didnt have that option because it wasnt patched in yet. The battle system is decent as far as action RPGs go, but nothing that special, especially when a lot of us who wanted to play this when it first came out did not have a harder difficulty available. Even then, its not that great. Skirmish and kingdom building are way too arbitrary, clearly thrown into the mix to make you feel like you have a complete game, but its not hard to realize Ni No Kuni 2 was not really finished when they decided it was time to cease development and ship. Even the graphics are inconsistent. Some places are gorgeous, others fall short. This game was clearly not faring well in development and never got on the right track. Extremely disappointing, since the first game on PS3 was one of the best titles for that console.
This is a really good game. It has a bunch of different game mechanics and systems and manages to merge them together with a good result.
The game feels like a true sequel to the first game, with an amazing world and soundtrack to engross you. The gameplay has changed quite a bit but I think for the better.

While so far there are only a few very small hints at ties to the first Ni No Kuni, this game definitely stands on its own. The kingdom-building aspect has been what I've sunk the most time into thus far, but the new locations and characters have been great as well. Combat isn't quite the hassle mechanically that it was in the first game (Familiars have been replaced by support creatures called 'Higgledies'), but the new engine does force some of the forested environments to be more open and less vegetated. The animated cutscenes have also taken a big step back, with far fewer vocalized sections instead replaced by text alone in most cases; the charm and quirkiness of the first game is lacking a bit because of this. But overall a solid RPG and highly recommended.
I loved the first Ni No Kuni. With that said, this is by far becoming my new favorite of the 2 part series due to its revamped combat system. Color pops on a 4k HDR TV with a PS4 Pro.
This game is fun to play. I am not a huge JRPG fan but took a risk on purchasing this game. I am loving it!

This is first off the finest sequel so far to any RPG I seen so far for the PS4. Only level 5 and Namco return in making this titles but hints of Studio Ghibli is in the game. The battle system is so much better then the first tile that was released on the PS3. This game has multi fighting styles. in here like simulator and so on. The animation is so awesome too. the story is great too for any age that loves anime. The music is once again outstanding. There will be tear shedding scenes in the game too.
Easy to learn combat with fluid controls. A must play for the story alone.
It is a little different form the first one but I like the action RPG style a little more. The story is great. My only complaint is that it is a little to easy.

I picked up this game expecting a lot because of the reviews. The game was nice and fun although seemed very childish. The fighting mechanics are fun. However, when I mobilized my army to go to war with a large bandit base for a library card and to get the librarians lipstick it kind of struck a nerve. Seems very kiddy. I couldn't hear the protagonist say 'live happily ever after' without wanting to backhand him. Since then I put it down. Its still a good game and I'll most likely continue but it seems very 'kiddy'. I prefer the Tales games a lot more. If you're ok with it the game is still fairly interesting with a lot of fun game mechanics and gameplay. All in all a good game but not for me.
I bought this game on sale and strictly for my game collection. But I've read good things for you JRPG fans,

I have never been much of a JRPG and though this game does suffer from the usual cliches of JRPG's like long and unnecessary dialogue it innovates in so many other ways. New gameplay mechanics were still being introduced many hours into my journey and it always felt well instituted and not hard to understand. Combat is real time as opposed to turn based and the art direction is superb. A must buy for any fan of RPG's
It took me over an hour to unwrap the packaging once delivered to my home.

I loved how rich, beautiful, detailed and special the first ni no kuni felt, and ni no kuni 2 is no different. For example, items can be saved for assorted quests, spent to level weapons, armor or even higgledies (cute elementals that help you in battle). Many of the people you meet along the way will join your kingdom and help build your town, or even your armies. The more you do, the more you get, and I'm loving it. The one downside is that every so often the game slightly stutters (maybe once every couple hours, and it's simply an animation glitch that doesn't affect much. Overall a great game and I would highly recommend it

I am a huge fan of the first Ni No Kuni and was really looking forward to the sequel. As it turns out, it's better in some ways and worse in others. The story has suffered a lot; it's just overwhelmingly bland. The decision to do a little bit of voice work but mostly text is irritating and I end up turning the volume down and just playing my own music instead. The variety of enemies is also shockingly low with so... many... pallette swaps! But the combat itself is fun, the graphics are mostly great, the new gameplay ('skirmishes' and kingdom building) are good... so overall, it's still a recommend. It could've been better! But it's still good.

While the overall story isn't as good as the first in my opinion, neither being particularly rich in story line, this game continues the charm of the first and introduces new mechanics that make the game feel more involved. Overall if you enjoyed the first, this will be more of the same and I'd highly recommend to anyone who hasn't played the first to try this out anyway. It's easily accessible and charming to boot.
Ni No Kuni 2 is def a fun game with some cool mechanics but it falls short in some areas. It's not very difficult and the overall story is lacking.
I loved the original, but Ni No Kuni II has a more simplistic story and mind-numbingly easy combat.

Ive waited for a sequel to the original Ni No Kuni since it was released on PS3 in 2011. Ni No Kuni 2 delivers on brining the series onto the PS4 and updating many things that made the original a success. It has a very compelling story, the graphics although look cartoony - play very well, and I really enjoy the real time battle system. My only negatives are that it should have more voice acting and even though I enjoy the battles - the game is a little on the easy side. Ni no kuni games have never been ones that required you to grind for levels and it really shows when you are taking down enemies that are five levels higher than you. Another nice piece for the series is the kingdom builder - it adds an extra element that will both side you in your travels as well as bump up the number of hours logged in the game. I was able to beat Ni No Kuni 2 in about 40 hours and that does not include any of the additional content coming with the Season Pass. Overall, well worth the $48 paid to get an immersive RPG to fill your time until God of War comes out in a few weeks! :)

Some people will actually like this game, I thought multi player wouldn't be a big deal - the other players don't actually bother me much at all. The issue for me was it feels like its geared to leveling up go here go there fast fast. Fallout for me was for the exploration, taking your time to look around. The map is great but I feel like you cant really explore it, enemies spawn all the time - clear an area and they re spawn so quickly. Not being able to pause and when dying having to go get your stuff back are online games I get that, I just don't like it. I have only played for 2 days but have gone back to red dead so take my view with that in mind - 2 days to decide I didn't like the game. I was looking for fallout, the small things you see like vault tec make you smile but overall the game play has changed enough for me not to like it.

Despite being mutliplayer it felt as if very few (if any) players online wanted to interact. The notification message text was very small and didn't realize i recieved team requests until they sent it to me 4 times. The free in game items were nice but didnt benifit much other than grabbing the attention of online players for a few seconds. In game events felt boring, due to if you are in the vicinity of the event taken place it doesnt matter if you actively are participating, you would recieve the event prizes and xp without doing much of anything. There were many lag spots especially in areas where enemies would spawn making it hard to defend oneself during battle. At times i would recieve server errors and would be unable to play despite having perfect internet connection. I highly suggest not getting this game until bugs are fixed or if mmos arent your cup of tea.

Let it be known that I loved Fallout 4. It was my introduction to the Fallout franchise. While I did go back and play bits of Fallout 1, 2, New Vegas, and 3, I played through Fallout 4 three separate times, eventually getting the platinum, 100% completion trophy on the PS4. Even when the story ended, I loved wandering around the Commonwealth and the DLC zones, finding all the cool little visual vignettes the designers had hidden in each broken down shack and ruined campsite. Each time I'd wander out -- alone -- I'd come back with bits of junk that would help me reinforce my settlement, personalizing my own little corner of post-apocalyptic Massachusetts. And in my survival playthrough, I'd have to think very carefully about just how much food, water, and ammo I had with me. That's what Fallout 76 is like, but in West Virginia, and with this constant feeling that some jerk is going to step out of the woods and end you for your inventory full of junk. It's light on story (yet heavy on lore, if you like reading terminals and listening to holotapes) and all about exploration and survival. Life is about food, water, radiation, ammo, and the deterioration of your weapons and armor. Now, I've been playing since the beta, and that hasn't happened to me, yet (knock on wood scraps). The limited number of players on each server and the humongous open world map make it really easy to not see another human-controlled character for an entire gaming session. When you combine that with the absence of any human NPCs, however, that can make Fallout 76 a very lonely experience. There has been a lot of controversy connected to the launch of this game. It is buggy. I have been disconnected a few times. There are choices that the developers made to make this work as a multiplayer game that futz up the solo Fallout experience I enjoyed in Fallout 4 (e.g., bobbleheads are a single-use perk, almost like a super chem), and others that are just weird (e.g., you can pack your power armor up and carry it around with you). I'm hoping Bethesda will do what Hello Games did with No Man's Sky and spend the next few months carefully addressing the issues their gamers are raising, while at the same time adding new and cool aspects to a 2.0 version of the game. If they do, I would come back and boost my review to 5 stars. If they don't, I could easily imagine this game fading to a 3- or even 2-star experience.

The NPC-less world is a bit stale, but doable between the story delivered via terminals and holotapes, but you very rarely run into other online players, whether you want the company or are just don't want the trouble of higher level characters bothering you. But personally, the technical problems like server disconnects, not saving quest progress for certain quests whether signing off or server disconnected, and spontaneously not being able to respawn anywhere among other things make this more of a hassle than fun to play. This is probably up there with destiny for buyer's remorse.

This game was released way too soon. It lacks any engaging story elements, is online only, suffers from performance issues, and is overall fairly boring due to lack engaging content within the game. Bethesda should have sat on this one for another year or more to finish fleshing it out instead of going for a cash grab. I would not recommend purchasing this game until it has been further patched an improved.

I've been a huge fan of the fallout series for a while now and I really started with Fallout 3 on the Xbox 360. I never completed 4, but will be going back to it soon. Especially now that I've shelved Fallout 76. I follow the two Fallout (Fallout and FO76) subreddits and while I appreciate what Bethesda has done for communication, it has really tarnished my feelings for the developer and in the future, I will be hesitant to purchase another one of their games until we see how it turns out. The lore is great. The exploration is fantastic! Unfortunately, this is about all the game has going for it. It's a huge bug-ridden mess, there are so many issues. Combat is clunky and don't even get me started on V.A.T.S. I play on an LG C7 OLED TV and while there is HDR, there are NO video options for brightness or anything of the nature. My TV is calibrated perfectly, yet this game is so bright - even in dark scenes. It all just looks washed out. The lack of including even the simplest things really drags this game down. The building feature of Fallout 4 was pretty much an 'experimentation' leading up to this game. There are just far too many issues and the game feels so lonely without the NPC's and dialog trees to go through, which are all highlights of any grand Bethesda game of this scale. Save yourself the money. Get something else instead. Wait 6, 9 or even 12 months and see if this game shows any improvement over that time span. Hopefully, Bethesda doesn't abandon this game. The ONLY reason I give this game 2 stars is because some parts of it are very enjoyable (the lore and exploration)...WHEN it works. This game does have promise and if handled properly, could be a fantastic addition to the franchise. Maybe they will 'rework' this like what happened to Final Fantasy XIV, when they turned it into 'A Realm Reborn'.

As an avid Fallout fan, I was of course excited about the new fallout being released. I was very willing to put up with more settlement building and online play (even though neither are things particularly well liked in the fallout community). What I have enjoyed about the last 3 fallouts in particular is the depth of the stories and NPCS/companions that you encounter that add to the gaming experience. What I can only assume is an attempt to cut cost and coding, there are no NPCs in this new Fallout. No companions. Only other wandering online players that may or may not kill you as much as ally with you. It really does feel like you are wandering through an empty wasteland. This will be the last game I pre-order; it does nothing but perpetuate bad habits of the industry. Save your money and go back an play New Vegas...

this game has so much potential but its just horrible. am still playing this game and i do want o finish it. but if i didn't get this game for so cheap. i wouldn't of bought it. so if you decide to buy and play this game then. just try to enjoy it. but try to get this game for as cheap as possible.
Bought this for my bf as he is a huge FO fan. He likes the game but his favs are new Vegas and FO4.
You need to subscribe to PlayStation to play. Its a multiplayer game though, like Fortnite. Also, cant install mods.
I was so excited for this game but it is just disappointing. Would not buy again.
wish I had saved my money. Broken missions have killed all playability for me. Previous game gets more play time than this. Very disappointed. Had high hopes.
Game needs work, havent tried after launch, waiting for patches. Love fallout 4 so hopefully I can enjoy this one day.

This game is extremely glitchy and just online play really doesnt not help.

This game is still very broken, Absolutely no thought has been put into game balance. The stupid junk death mechanic will waste hours and hours of collection time and then steal everything you collected due to lag/crashes/clipping bugs with ZERO COMPENSATION for your effort. It doesn't even register Playstation accomplishments when it crashes but will still remember to steal your crafting materials, even when it made it impossible to have a chance to retrieve them. Extremely dull and grindy, there is no sense of progression after level 50-60. After you've found the major locations there is absolutely nothing. Crafting is 98% GARBAGE and very few useful plans(>1%) ever drop. Ridiculous amount of armor recipes, 100% of which are not ever worth crafting, it is all just for show. Perk card system stops progressing meaningfully after about level 70 and gets VERY annoying with all the card swapping. Zero effort was put into any quality of life touches regarding the perk system Inventory management is a never ending nightmare, there is no way to preset any armor combinations and food is constantly rotting with no easy way to manage it effectively. It is obvious that other than cut and pasting code from other Bethesda games and creating very little new art that this game had 4 months of rushed development, not 3 years. This game should have been released Free to Play there is ZERO replay value after about 50 exceedingly grindy hours, especially after all the crafting material losses due to bugs. The game gets WORSE the longer you play, it is nothing but a quick money grab.

This game has to be one of the best let down I have had since I have played all of the fallouts. The one thing that I have always loved about fallout is the great in depth story line that it runs with but with this game it is pure garbage. I think That due to its a one course way with no options how to get to the end. The lack of npcs I this game made it worse than vanilla games and just very bland. I do like the idea of playing with other players but it would be nice to be able to go through a nice story mode instead of an open world mode and basically a new version of fort ore/pubg which not everyone likes those trash games. I just wish the next fallout has some sort of hope for the actual rpg that we all love and now miss very much
This cannot remain an online only game. It just doesn't work. Can't pause, no human npc's so makes the game quite lonely.

One of the worst games I've ever played. This is not a real fallout game. Just a cheap cash grap. The only thing that works in this game are the overpriced microtransactions. No real RPG elements. Safe your cash.

I've played every Fallout game since the original on the PC and while this is very different from previous entrys in the series it still has it's own merits. This game is a sandbox-type game with light survival elements. It is not a traditional Fallout RPG. There are not any human NPCs but there are robots to talk to and other mechanisms in the game to help push the story and quest lines forward. I would reccomend this game to anyone who has previously enjoyed the exploration aspects of Fallout games and does not mind it being light on the story aspect or the fact that it has a multiplayer/survival component. I would NOT reccomend this game to someone who is wanting it to be Fallout 5 or is expecting it to be a single-player RPG. It's not a cash grab as other reviewers are calling it. However, this game would have been better off being a ~$30 DLC/expansion to Fallout 4 vs it's own game at the $60-80 price point.

This is the first attempt from Bethesda to take the Fallout world online. There are not a lot of real changes from Fallout 4 when it comes to the graphics and overall game play. The lack of NPC's is a disappointment, but it is fun to play with friends. I have had the most fun by gathering up the 3 TV's in the house and having a few friends over with their PS4's and playing that way. Like the LAN parties back in the day. We tried 4 players, but the home internet connection could not handle it. Anyhoot, I think Fallout 76 is a good gaming experience overall. I feel that it is a good way to tide one over, until the next single player Fallout game comes out. Probably some time in the real 2076.
When I booted this up, I expected the usual Bethesda bugs, what I didnt expect were the improved graphics as I just expected this to be purely a Fallout 4 port.

I watched many reviews that bashed the beta but I did not want to base my opinion on early beta game bashers I wanted to have my own opinion so I bit the bullet and here are my impressions/review. After playing for a few hours of trial and error I bumped into a few players that added me to their group and that's when the game picked up for me. I have a few memorable things happen to me in the game,I was in a abandoned building with another player online and he said he would be back he was grabbing a snack so I decided to roam around outside while he came back but all of the sudden a level 20 scorcher elite came out of nowhere with his goons trying to kill me and I was just like lv 7 at that time and I had to run back into the building my friend was in and hide and you could hear the monster saying 'you will have to come out some day' I was like what?? lol so then my friend finally came back on and we ended killing the orcs and that was really fun. I like the perc card feat the leveling in the game etc. I am not too fond of the survival gimmick but its not a deal breaker because at times it makes me feel immersed. ok now the bad: Game lags like crazy and sometimes when you teleport to someone it will teleport you in the middle of zombies! smh.. another thing that is cringe worthy is how sometimes you have to do a mission were dracula in dragon form spawns out of nowhere flying in the sky spitting some green fire.ohh and he is level 50! it becomes such a pain to get to where you need to go. over all the game is fun with some frustrations that I am hoping they will fix and I think that at this rate it is too early to fully bash on the game since its so early and games like the division and battlefront had bumpy rides also so we will have to wait and see.

As a fallout fan and player of all previous versions this game is pretty cool. I like the new mmo feel and there is so much to do and the maps are gigantic. Ive put in well over 24 hours of game time and havent even scratched the surface.
I am never let down by the Fallout series. Theyve done it again!

As a physical media fan, I did my best to research this before release and had been lead to believe it was ALL physical. Didn't find out until I picked up my preorder. The 'in' thing now is producing homemade crafts. You visit those sites where crafty people sell stuff they hand painted, hand crafted and hand knit stuff. That's what makes Yoshi's Wooly World so current. The whimsical visuals are a treat. And there's no baby Mario to take care of!

This, obviously, doesn't look quite as nice as the Wii U version, but it still holds up quite well and you can play it on the go! It plays just as well and has some extra content via Poochy-only levels (these are quick Mario Run-type levels). It also has 30 video shorts that star Poochy and Yoshi amiibo in cute stop-motion. The game times these unlocking, so you get one per day. I bought this game despite already having the Wii U version because it is a GREAT 2D platformer with tight controls and tons of secrets. There isn't a ton of challenge if you just breeze through it, but it you want to collect everything, the game can get pretty difficult and challenging if that is what you want. Can't recommend this game enough! BUY IT!!!

The art is great. An pinball exploration game that is surprisingly great and charming with its crazy bug characters. If you are looking for an interesting game, this is one to get.

This game is unique! It's a great concept and it works great. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a change of pace. It's good for young players because it's a simple concept but also good for more experienced players or those who like a challenge in collecting items.

Yuki's Island Express is worth you money and your time! One of the better and more creative platformers in years, you play as a beetle making his way as a postmaster... Through a world of pinball! That's right, this is a platforming pinball adventure game and it's amazing!

This metroidvania-style re-imagination of pinball is exactly the type of game you didn't know you wanted to play. The open world is fun to explore, with great sound FX and music. A great game, albeit short - particularly fun when played on-the-go on the Nintendo Switch.

This game really took me by surprise. I read about it and was intrigued by the pinball aspect of the game. And man is this game a real hidden gem. Not only is the pinball aspect cool... but it's just a fun adventure game with cool characters, unique locations and additive gameplay. Would love to see a sequel!

This game reminds me a lot of Sonic Spinball from the Genesis. Its a fun game but a little overpriced at $40, thats why I waited until it went on sale. But its a great game regardless and a nice addition to my collection.

I actually bought this game for my fianc, because I'm trying to get her into gaming...well...into more games than just Donkey Kong Country. She loves platforms with a little dash of puzzles, and really doesn't like to fight baddies. This game combines all of those things into a super cute, upbeat look as you literally pinball yourself around the large world map. You explore all of kind of different areas from jungles to snowy peaks, and collect fruit to unlock more bumpers to knock you around to other areas. I highly recommend this if you're looking for something different. It can be frustrating at times, and it's annoying that there isn't any fast traveling, but I think the creative pinball/platforming mechanics make up it on their own.

A beautiful platforming adventure with a twist on how you control your character. You are Yoku, a mailman beetle, you will explore a big and gorgeous world without the ability to even jump. How can this be done? Pinball mechanics. Can it possibly be done well? Somehow the developers made controlling Yoku by launching him around with pinball flippers work perfectly. I was skeptical it could be done well, but the controls are seamless. Fantastic game, highly recommended.

I was not sure if I was going to buy this game at first, but I decided to get it due to high reviews. I really like 2D platformers and on top of that I really love pinball so I decided to give the game a chance. I am really glad that I did because this game is beautiful and so fun to play. The art style reminds me of Ori and the Blind Forest and the game play and characters are really charming! You never run out of things to do due to all of the quests that you pick up along the way to help you further your exploration and story. Overall if you like 2D platformers and/ or pinball please give this game a chance!

It also can hang on saving causing you to lose your progress and you wont know if its happening or not until you realize the save icon wont go away and the world doesnt load when you move away from where you clicked save. I even left my Xbox on for 3 hours to see if it would eventually save and let me keep saving and it never did. If I could do it again I would get it for PC not console because the beefier hardware can handle the game better.

Subnautica is a fantastic exploring and survival game that I find my son playing every chance he can get. He cannot wait to dive deeper into, there is always something new to explore. Gorgeous graphics and very unique sea creatures and wrecks make this very entertaining - my daughter pulls up her lovesac just to watch my son play this game

If you like open world something similar to minecraft or no man sky this is your game I love the traffics and the controls of the game but i just wish the game was little more simplified from the beginning with little more guides in the game but in general it a good game I enjoy and do recommend to play.

I was hesitant to get this game for Xbox due to some comments about issues with it. I am glad I decided to take the plunge (pun intended) and get the game as there are hardly any issues. With the statements that follow, keep in mind I've sunk over 24 hours of gameplay in already. So far I've noticed a few times where the ground does not render in quick enough but this is infrequent and usually only if moving quickly, just wait for a second to let it load in. There was some choppiness in very high activity zones but that smoothed out after all the elements rendered in (takes a few seconds). One time a save was lost, lost about an hour of game time (frustrating but not too bad). Overall, this is an incredible game that I intend to continue sinking hours and hours into because it is so rich and interesting. The map and environments are beautiful and terrifying at the same time. I highly recommend it on the Xbox as I believe the devs have fixed most of the issues and it is highly playable, but be prepared to occasionally have an issue once in a while - just be sure to save often.

The framerate is buggy which can be annoying at times and I've come across some glitches so there is still some work in progress needed. But this is a really really fun game. Scary once you try to go deep and if you have a fear of water be prepared because big things swim deep.

So far this game has been super fun. You explore underwater to find resources to craft items that allow you to explore deeper in the ocean. Graphically the game is pleasing. If you enjoy exploration games, this is highly recommended.

Lego Harry Potter's gameplay is similar to that of most previous Lego video games, with an emphasis on collecting, exploring, and solving puzzles. Casting spells is an integral part of the gameplay, with a wide range of spells available for unlocking as the player progresses. As there are many spells available in the game, the player can use the spell wheel to select the spell. Potion-making is another integral feature; potions can help the player complete levels or, if created incorrectly, have adverse side effects
Great for the avid Marvel fan but confusing for those who just watch the movies. Some challenges might be too tough for young kids

Battlefield one is the excellent counter to call of duty's infinite warfare, and a perfect answer to the longing of many gamers (myself included) to play a shooter that doesn't cast them as a barely human cyborg, powered by cybernetic implants. It is the difficulty of BF1 that makes it so compelling. It is incredibly inconvenient every time you reload your weapon, and your character takes 30 seconds or so to do it, but at the same time, a little grin creeps on to my face each time it happens. Health is hard to regain, unless you have a medkit, and it is not uncommon to be unable to ADS because of the gasmask on your face, protecting you from a deadly cloud of mustard gas. It's these little details, that make this came so compelling. The story is incredibly powerful as well. From the opening sequence where you play as about 5 different characters, all of whom inevitably perish, the game powerfully conveys the hopelessness of a war where battlefield tactics had yet to catch up to the death dealing technologies of the period. The Short anthology type stories do a great job of highlighting specific aspects of the war. These stories are extremely moving, as they manage to connect you to the characters and create meaningful development over the course of only three or four levels. BF1 also features an immensely fun multiplayer. The most enjoyable aspect of which is the new operations feature; a bit of a cross between domination, and rush, with the large scale chaos of conquest. One match will take about 3 rounds, and sometimes moves to a different map. Usually at least once in a course of a match, one side is reinforced by a zeppelin, train, or dreadnought battleship. The scope of the matches is monstrous. Each time you spawn in, the camera zooms into a spot on the map, speaking to how small, helpless, and inconsequential each soldier must have felt; especially when there are things like Zeppelins looming in the sky, raining death on all who dare to venture underneath. Whether you are a hardcore fps gamer, or someone who is interested in history, and compelling heroism, Bf1 is a mightily entertaining experience.

If you have gotten any battlefield title before then THIS ONE WILL NOT DISAPPOINT YOU! Amazing story mode and graphics not to mention best war sounds EVER! You will get sucked in the game, and you will love the multiplayer! huge maps, if you wanna run, then RUN, if you wanna 'camp' then CAMP! maps soooo large that you can do whatever you want and no-one gets mad at you or 'trash talks' LOVE IT!

Every year I purchase the latest Battlefield and Call of Duty titles. I have a difficult time choosing between them, so I wind up just picking up both. I have to say that with both franchises going back to basics, it has made it a great year for fans of both of these series. That being said, when it comes to realism and keen attention to detail, I have to give this year's award to Battlefield 1. There are so many little things that are captured in this game that really help immerse you in the action. Sure, it's still a first person, fast paced shooter, but everything from the destructible environment to the way the weapons respond are just done so well here. If you have a chance to pick this version up, do it. So much added content and multiplayer maps give this game very high replay value. It is also very refreshing to not have enemies running up walls and jet-packing over you to take you out from out of nowhere. This is what first person shooters should be like. It brings the genre back to basics and you can tell there was a ton of work put into this game, Very impressive and a must buy!!
Used to playing the Call of Duty series, but this one keeps up and gives a great change of pace. Very realistic and challenging!

This game is incredible! If you're reading this review, there's a 9/10 chance you've already bought the game and are just reading reviews for humor. If you don't own the game and are considering buying it, do it! The single player feels like an interactive movie but in the best way possible. The multiplayer is truly outstanding. Again, if you don't own this and like shooters, get it, NOW!
