As a young woman, Lara Croft is in search of adventure and herself. She embarks on an exploratory quest when her hunt for adventure comes looking for her. Now, stranded away from civilization and equipped with only her instincts and the ability to push herself beyond the threshold of human endurance, Lara must look inside and find what she needs to fight for her survival.Re-experience the origin story of Lara Croft in this Definitive Edition of the critically acclaimed action-adventure on your Xbox One. Re-built to take advantage of your next-generation console's power, this Definitive Edition lets you experience the raw ferocity, brutal environments and unforgiving terrain as an all-new Lara Croft. Utilizing TRESS FX technology, Lara now features realistic hair that allows each strand to move on its own and blow in the wind plus, you can see every bead of sweat and clothing stitch

Tomb Raider wears its influences on its sleeve. If I was explaining how Tomb Raider plays to someone that hasnt been following the game, Id say its the beautiful love child of Uncharted and the Batman Arkham titles. It takes the smooth platforming and gunplay of Naughty Dogs series and mixes it with the quasi open-world exploration and equipment upgrade elements from Rocksteadys titles. But to say Tomb Raider is just a by-the-numbers amalgam of those two popular franchises is doing the game a huge disservice. Tomb Raider manages to take the best elements from those brands and mix them together so well that the resulting concoction feels like something wholly fresh and original. Read more at linklink

The campaign is very lackluster though, and the fighting system is not very deep at all. Combos are EXTREMELY limited and can make for some pretty boring matches even at high tier matchups. I dont think the game is worth the full 60 dollar price tag, but that doesnt mean you cant enjoy it. Loving the anime will help you have more fun with this game, like myself.

I've put about 10 hours into this game so far, great customizations throughout. Boss battles are pretty cool and provide a challenge, which is always welcome. Overall really enjoying myself with this title.

The game is a lot of fun. There are some really nice customizations for characters; in fact you can have multiple characters to play through as. The game adds some new characters to the SAO Universe to join you on your unique journey. There are also tons of familiar faces that can join you on quests and boss fights anytime in the game. There are squad controls as well to help you control how your squad reacts in battle. The story is very unique. It is separate from the SAO canon (Anime) But it is a lot of fun and the story is really good so far. The game's dungeons are fairly challenging as well. Which makes it more fun. The game is Subbed into English but there is no English dubbed version. That is very important to most. As far as I know they will always speak Japanese in the game and the subtitles are English which isn't a huge deal and you get used too it. If you watch anime you probably are used to it. The AI Characters are a little off at times but they do definitely help you clear enemies and bosses. What's extra cool is each companion is different; So you can mix it up when fighting different bosses cause each one differs in skills and weapons. There is also a fairly decent size of weapon selections as well. Also Online Boss fighting mode and PVP Boss fights. Its pretty cool. Overall I really enjoy the game as I am a SAO fan already. Hands down though its a very fun game to play; existing fan or not.

Got this for my 4 year old- its a simplistic platformer with no enemies/combat but thats great because its highly age appropriate. He is leaning how to control the game and there arent any real ways to die or get stuck in the game. There is no platinum trophy which is a bit odd for a full priced retail game. I figured Id at least get an east platinum out of it. The only other thing that struck me as odd about the game is that Ryder is the only voice in the game: the pups dont talk. Also they dont seem to use the licensed music from the show, some kind of Muzak appropriation soundtrack. Otherwise its a great first game for my 4 year old.

There's a decent amount to like, but even in its current patched state, there's still more than a fair amount of glitches in it. Hard to enjoy something when you have to reset your game because the mission you're supposed to go on doesn't activate.

I am enjoying this game. I did not play much of the Wonder Boy series, but this game is awesome. The anime intro and the music is awesome. This game will be overlooked but it should not. It is a platformer and you can transform into different animals. If you are hesitant give it a chance. I highly recommend it.

This game is one of the funnest games I have played in some time. The platforming, controls, and puzzles are all very well done. It has absolutely beautiful graphics. The music is mesmerizing, with every song having a unique feel and fitting perfectly with each area that you explore. Boss fights are exciting and memorable. I really loved being able to change into different forms, each with their own set of special abilities. The equipment and shop system are great as well. There are secrets hidden everywhere and many areas you can't access right away when you first come across them. This aspect feels very similar to the Metroid games (a huge plus). Also worth noting is the inclusion of an actual instruction manual and cool stickers with the game itself. I'm glad that there are still companies that put effort into their physical releases. If you are ready for something both new and old, you definitely can't go wrong with Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom!

This game is hard but totally worth the learning curve. You control a girl who uses a fishing rod to get around. Think the Legend of Zelda hookshot, but bouncier. It's a platformer that's physics based, you need to let out slack on your fishing rod to bounce and get the momentum to propel yourself higher. Then release to launch yourself higher in the stage. The graphics are the only drawback. The game itself doesn't look like the cover, it's mostly cartoony pixelated environments. This game is hard and challenging so be prepared. Once you get the mechanics down this game will worm it's way into your heart and you will become a fan of the series for life.

This particular game is a great platformer that can also be challenging as you progress further in the game and also there can be challenging bosses to battle within the game. You play as Kawase as you go and do some deliveries or item searching in various parts of the town. You have to use your trusty fishing equipment to reach new areas and master how to swing to places and also the angle in which you throw your lure. It is a fun game but can be a bit hard to master unless you get the hang of it.

played NH2 for roughly 4 hours and have thoroughly enjoyed it so far. I have experimented with virtually all the various game modes and each one has left me coming back for more. Visually the game leaves a lot to be desired with dated graphics and decent damage model. Game play is fun, fluid and challenging with the aggressive AI. My BIGGEST complaint so far is the lack of a mini-map...how can a racing game in 2017 NOT include this? If you liked the first Kingdom Hearts, I would highly recommend picking up this collection. Kingdom Hearts II and Kingdom Hearts Birth By Sleep are great action JRPGs with a fun blend of Final Fantasy and Disney characters. The Final Mix versions add more to the games than were previously released in North America, which makes this collection even better.

These last few years have seen the re-release of the fan-favorite Kingdom Hearts series. Possibly as small recompense that the series proper hasnt been given another true installment in over a decade and thus skipped over this entire last generation of major home console, these games are bundled Remastered versions of PS2/PSP classics. The graphical enhancements are notable, but are they worth the full purchase? Are these not the same games weve already played? For us Americans, yes and no. You see, these are the Final Mix versions of these games, which until these releases, have never seen the light of day on Western shores, having previously been Japan exclusives. So then, there are some elements of these games that are certain to have never been experienced by most American games. So what do these changes add? What do they take away? Do they warrant the new purchase price and time investment? Since most of us have already played the original version of this game, Ill focus on the new version for this review. Kingdom Hearts 2 Final Fix does a lot of what Kingdom Hearts Final Mix did. Nearly all basic Heartless get a palate swap, some more visually appealing or sensible than others, but still essentially the same. There are additional cutscenes, fully voiced in English, which explore more of the goings-on with the games antagonists, Organization XIII, and fill-in a few more gaps between this sequel and the first installment. They fill time mostly well, although some drag out longer than they are welcome. Another minor addition is a new puzzle sidequest. Simple in its execution, there are several crown-shaped piece scattered around the worlds. They are not hard to find, but somewhat difficult to acquire, with most requiring Sora to max out his Drive Abilities. Its a nice distractive additional quest for the collector types. Sora also gets an additional Drive Form, Limit Form. His clothes resemble the color scheme he had in the last game, and he can preform the special Limit abilities he could last game. Because they take the place of Magic Commands and can be difficult to time right and be blocked, they are not very useful outside of being the experience needed to level up this Form. Still, the sheer power of this Forms combo finishing moves make this Form very valuable in combat, especially since Sora can trigger it alone without any allies. There are new synthesis materials that are quite powerful, but difficult to obtain. Most come from a new section of the game, the Cavern of Remembrance, in Hollow Bastion/Radiant Garden. In it, there are new Heartless, palate swaps of other Heartless that are much stronger than their counterparts. They drop the new synthesis type materials, Remembrance, and some strong weapons for Donald and Goofy. They are not earned lightly, but they do provide a good challenge and excellent means of grinding high levels. There is also another group of additional special Heartless, called Mushroom XIII. As you could guess, they resemble the members of Organization XIII. They are scattered throughout the Worlds, and their powers faintly resemble their Organization counterparts. They are the only source for another synthesis material needed for unique items, Tranquility, and they drop extra staves and shields for Donald and Goofy, but they are mostly too weak to be effective. And sadly, these new enemies are where the game loses some of its traction: the difficulty. Each of these encounters plays like a mini-game, and the challenges you are expected to complete range from doable if you know how to downright nigh-impossible. Trying over and over again, with no apparent progress can suck some of the fun out of the game and replace it with frustration. This trend continues to an even greater extent with the final addition the Final Mix makes: extra boss fights. And theres a LOT of them. There are fights against Absent Silhouettes, rematches against the Organization XIII members defeated during the mid-quel Chain of Memories, with reworked mechanics to include KH2s battle system. These can be very challenging, particularly at lower levels. There is also an additional fight with Roxas toward the end of game, replacing what was just a cutscene before. At the end of the Cavern of Remembrance is the Garden of Remembrance, where Sora can fight Data Rematches against the greatly power-up members of Organization XIII. These fights are mostly identical to their previous encounters, but their stats are maxed out and some condition mechanics are made much harder. And to top it all off, there is after-game fight with a foe called Lingering Will, to set the stage for Birth By Sleep. His combos are unbreakable, his Strength, Defense, and HP enormous, and he can lock Commands. These fights can be downright insane, impossible to beat at lower levels, and possibly even difficulties. They are extremely trying on even the lowest game difficulty setting, to say nothing of Normal or Proud Mode. This kind of difficultly greatly harms the game in my opinion, require ridiculous amounts of practice, grinding, and farming to be able to complete for 100% game completion. Victory seems to come more from luck than perseverance, and thats not a good point in my book. In sum, Kingdom Hearts 2 Final Mix is still a phenomenally good game, in terms of story, gameplay, battle mechanics, and character. While the new edition adds much to this release, it can suffer a bit from much higher difficulty. Sure, its all optional in theory, but not for us completionists. A new purchase is easily warranted for the die-hard fans of the series, but for those who might want to try it out, it may be better to wait for a price drop. Final score: 8.5/10.

I have always been a fan of the Kingdom Hearts series. I've played each and everyone of them. I slept countless hours on Kingdom Hearts 2 when it was released on PS2, and ever since a final mix version was created from it, I've been wishing it to be translated in English. Birth By Sleep on the PSP was one of my most favorite Kingdom Hearts. It was a day one purchase for me. I had beaten multiple times. Now, let's talk about the 2.5 Remix. KINGDOM HEARTS 2 FINAL MIX: THE GOOD: At the base this is still the Kingdom Hearts 2 we grew up with on Ps2, but there has been a lot of new editions since this is the final mix version. Tons of new bosses, new abilities, new weapons, items, and Sora even receives a handy new drive form that pays homage to the first Kingdom Hearts. This being a HD remastered, Square Enix really outdid themselves in some area. The music tracks for Kingdom Hearts 2 Final Mix have all have been completely re-orchestrated to one of the most dynamic soundtracks I have ever heard. The upgrade in SOME textures really are great. The BAD: Some texture weren't really changed. (building and some armor and other details in textures) With everything else looking so nice and top notch, it is hard not to notice the textures that weren't changed at all. Something else, (not a big deal) the loading times for drive forms are a bit..timely sometimes. Not a big deal. KINGDOM HEARTS BIRTH BY SLEEP FINAL MIX: This HD version of Birth By Sleep is a great Upgrade from it's psp original. I'm not going to be as hard on it about the textures as I was with 2, because Square came a long way with Birth By Sleep HD Remastered compared to the Psp's original textures. As for the Final Mix version, a ton of new bosses, mirage arena events, new commands, new weapons, items, and even a 'Secret' story episode has been added. The BAD: Now, you noticed I didn't talk much about the Remastered upgrades? Because outside of the textures, there really aren't much. They kept the original music tracks with the exception of 'Dismiss' and 'Keyblade Graveyard'. I wished they would've redone them as well. I came to my attention when I was listening to the 2.5 soundtracks, and the only tracks it contained from Birth By Sleep were to two I mentioned earlier. The reason is: Those were the only two tracks they redid. Not a big deal, but I noticed it. The only reason it's worth mentioning: They did it for Kingdom hearts 2 why not keep the quality consistent and do the same for Kingdom Hearts Birth By Sleep? As for the camera, it helped me when I set the Left/Right Camera to inverted. This sets the L3 to L=L and R=R direction whereas the original settings were L=R and R=L. BottomLine: Other than those minor issues this is well worth for the forty bucks I paid for it. If you played 1.5 Remix and loved it, than you will love this one even more. If you hated it, the upgrades and changes in Kingdom Hearts 2 will make you love it. If you're reading this review now and are curious about buying this game, DO IT. And if you haven't played the 1.5 remix, there's a collector edition that includes both the 2.5 and 1.5 Remixes and the soundtracks and art of them both. If you really don't want to shell out 90 bucks then you can always just purchase the standard edition of them which totals to about 60 bucks. 2.5 = 39.99 1.5 = 19.99 I hope this helped your decision.

Review for Kingdom Hearts 2 Pros: Expanded levels- KH2 expands the areas of worlds that were in the previous KH. There are also new worlds to choose from. The music- The music is KH2 is amazing. Many of the songs are taken from their respective movie, such as This Is Halloween, and are blended in with the game to deliver a fun atmosphere. Gameplay-The gameplay can be seen as very simple or very complex. To someone who just wants to play he/she can play through by simply mashing buttons, however the game offers a variety of tools that can make the game more suitable for the more advanced player. There are spells, summons, special attacks, tram attacks, etc. The best thing about is that they are not difficult to perform. It all depends on the playing style of the gamer. Visuals- The graphics in this game were nicely retouched, complimenting the Disney/Final Fantasy theme. Cons: Cutscenes-The cutscenes in this game seemed a little excessive, especially in the beginning. Telling a story is not a problem but the game would not allow the player to immerse his/herself in the fame without interrupting them with a cutscene. They were nice to look at but should have been a little less. Gameplay- As stated before the game can be played through by button mashing. The problem with with this is that players run the risk of playing a game that extremely repetitive. Without using the extra tools the game will seem bland and boring. Story-The KH story is a very complex one to understand. The die hard KH fan will be more willing to explore and try and understand what the true purpose of the story was. For the casual player, however, the story would just seem complicated and end up not making sense. It does retell some parts of the previous games but it is still recommended to play the other games first, if you are interested in the story. Overall Kingdom Hearts II is a fun and complex game that will appeal to both hardcore and casual gamers. There are obviously more pros and cons to this game but I felt these were my biggest concerns. I believe people should try this game as it is very well put together.

MK11 boasts great and deep fighting mechanics which take the best from previous MK installments and borrow some from other popular fighting franchises. Audio and visuals are top notch with sharp play controls. There are lots of single player and multiplayer options. The gear system is a bit broken, with high (border line) unfair AI in the Towers of Time and steeply prices krypt items which require ample grinding to unlock. However the developer is said to be patching this.

Mortal Kombat 11's variation system is rather extensive and each character has hundreds of combinations of gear pieces that can be equipped (masks, weapons, costumes/skins, etc.). However, all of these items (even the basic variation icons) are locked away either inside the Krypt or the Towers of Time. This is where the issues begin to get out of hand. The Krypt is just a large lootbox mode disguised as a third-person adventure game. The boxes inside the Krypt are randomly generated for each user and all cost such a high amount of coins to unlock/open, in contrast to the very small amount of coins that are earned from playing the game itself. This means it will take hundreds of hours to unlock all the gear for your favorite character and will take thousands of hours to get them for the entire roster. To make things even worse, rewards cannot be earned if the game is being played offline, and it requires internet in order to validate your rewards. So, if you were looking to play the game 100% offline, that is not a possibility. I would recommend passing on the game and picking up MK XL instead, as that game can be found for relatively cheap on either the Xbox One or PlayStation 4 and it includes all of the characters (on disc) along with all of the other DLC without any need to grind it hurts Ive already paid 100$ for this and they still want more never again.

I waited for this game to drop down to 25$ to pick it up, and honestly It was far more than worth it. I loved the first metro when I got it on PC and never got last light until this redux'd version. Last light met my expectations of a metro game and introduced more mechanics and elements expanding on the original. But we are here to talk about the redux, not just last light. For those who played the original metro, this redux'd version plays very similar to it, but with a few notable changes. these changes are minor cosmetic changes such as picking up all the supplies in a stash instead of each piece individually. The most disappointing change was the removal of the armor system from 2033 in the redux. this isn't a big deal, but I was hoping more for a game updated visually without touching the game's mechanics. Because there is no stealth suit or heavy armor the stealth plays more closely to last light and the health i can not tell for sure, but I know you can not have the same protection as heavy armor. For those who have never played the metro series, this game is not for everyone. Focusing on the combat, you have the choice of a stealth approach or all out firefights. supplies can be little and far in between depending on what difficulty you play on. The shooting is solid and satisfying as is the bits of chatter you will hear between soldiers as you are sneaking around them. Overall I love this game and is an instant favorite for those into stealthy FPS games that limit your resources.
A strong repackaging of Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light for next generation consoles.

This game was a lot of fun to play. I spent a good 25 hours playing it, beating both Metro 2033 and Metro Last Light. The disc actually contains both games which take about 10 hours each to complete. The stories are great, and so is the gameplay. There were a couple glitches with the game, but nothing major. The biggest con in my opinion was the AI intelligence. It was very basic.

The Metro series is a great franchise. Both, Metro 2033 and Metro: Last Light, are highly acclaimed games, and while both have appeared on the Xbox 360, only a powerful PC can do them justice. Console gamers, especially PS4 owners, have never played Metro the way the developers intended due to technical limitations. Thankfully, after remastering both games from the ground up. So now you get awesome versions of both Metro games with all the DLC included, running at a locked 60FPS, for only $50. It's one of the couple of remasters that are actually justified.

Let me start off by saying that this is a Sim Racing game. It is by no means easy, but with that being said Project Cars 2 is insanely realistic, addicting and fun. I dabbled a bit into the career mode, but mostly been spending my time online. You race against a lot of respectable fellow racers who race clean. The tracks are a lot of fun, the cars have a lot of liveries to pick from. My one main grip is the sound issue, it seems to me the sound overall is too low of a volume.

I'm in the minority I guess but I actually really like the handling on gamepad. I can correct from over steer, unroll the wheel properly coming out of a turn, and brake and throttle with comfort. I've always liked the project cars career, and in project cars 2 it's been fun so far. Unfortunately the AI still leaves a lot to be desired, and I've typically been faced with poor connections in multiplayer settings (despite having fast internet). I think it could've been a perfect game that is unfortunately hindered by some frame rate issues, inconsistent AI and at the moment spotty multiplayer connections. I still thoroughly enjoy it though, hopefully it gets better with time.

I was initially excited for this game bases on reviews and YouTube clips. For me, now looking forward to Gran Turismo Sport

Visually, this game will be beat by Forza 7, GT Sport, and is beaten by Dirt 4. Wait for the console exclusive racers because this game should have been delayed.

To be fair, I really do like the concept of this game. Take an alien suit, and become a super soldier roaming around with a compound bow. Including the following perks: stealth, super strength, super armor, etc. However, the game has been glitchy, and the campaign is pretty short. As for the online aspect, I've enjoyed it greatly. Yet, there are just too few of people online playing it on the Xbox 360. $60 is a bit steep for this game. I recommend picking it up when it gets down to the $30 range. I know most people will enjoy this game, but they'll enjoy it more for less dough.
This is a great game and the perfect follow up to Crysis 2.

Overall, the game is good and if you only game on a console, I would suggest picking it up and playing it through. If you have the option to game on the PC, I recommend picking this up for the computer. The graphics on the PC (with the right video card) are nothing short of Amazing! Perhaps my review is not the same as others as I have had the opportunity to see this game on a solid built gaming PC. After seeing it on the computer and going back to the console version, it's like watching something in HD and going back to SD. The game makers put a ton of time into the details and graphics which unfortunately are lost on the console version.

I'm not a fan of the mainline Dragon Quest series, but I wanted to try out a game with this style of combat. I really liked how colorful this game is and the great variety of enemies. This game is actually a lot of fun. In addition to fighting hordes of monsters in the main story, there are a lot of interesting side quests. The main story itself is very generic, but still interesting enough, most of the playable characters are cameos from the main Dragon Quest Series (there are 4 original ones, so far), but they are all interesting and quirky. The characters have a lot of variety of weapons and move sets, and the two main characters can change their vocations to give them access to new weapons. The only main issue with this game is that it can become repetitive quickly. Personally I can only play it in short bursts. However, the game counters this by giving you new characters with new weapons and combos, and also by adding new areas and enemies. All in all a very fun experience, when you are in the mood for fast pace action that is light on the story.

This game is not as stiff and rigid as it looked like during Tokyo Game Show. That was a huge turn off for a lot of people and they definitely smoothed things out. I have to say that first in case people still have that in their heads. +You. Can. Pet. The. Dog. Whenever you want. Plus you get an achievement for doing it so many times. :D +Really interesting story plot where you go between Purgatory and Real life. Sadly the IRL segment is limited to choosing where to go next and healing yourself. +Beautiful art. From characters to scenery, they went all out with this aesthetic and it Works. +Crafting is there to power up your equipment using what you find. +Costumes to unlock. The Day One version gives you 2 from the start as a bonus start. +Fascinating mechanic of carrying the regrets of monsters you kill. If you let too many thoughts build up you start to suffer so staying clean is key. Cleaning yourself also gives you crafting items so it's a win win. +Endless Dashing. I didn't see a limit--or didn't notice one--while playing. Mostly dashed through dungeons in record times since walking/running is far slower. Honestly I felt like a speedrunner mapping out the best dash routes. +/- Voice acting. I'm really on the fence on this one. Some of the characters are really well done and felt Triple A quality. Nailing the small nuances of their character and bringing life. Then there's some that are good but don't quite reach that level. And there's some here and there that are not impressive at all. It's honestly a mixed bag. You can hear them giving it their best, but they don't quite resonate. -RNG drops. Crafting needs drops from enemies more than anything else. A dungeon run could get you anywhere from 12 of what you need to only 3. It's all luck. -Enemy designs. For the most part, bosses and rare enemies definitely stand out and have that high level of polish. But for the majority of enemies, they're quite simple. They do fit the game world without question, they're just very same-y. Would I suggest this? I would simply from the art direction alone. It's genuinely really pretty to look at. Architecture, colors, fashion, it's all lovely. The RNG and mixed voice actors are the main reason for going 4 stars instead of 5.
